abstract: This paper determines methods to develop a novel technique for predicting a nation in view of the Olympic awards owned by 2012. It is the combination of three methods are Pearson correlation coefficient, Spearman correlation coefficient and along with linear regression. The main idea of the paper is to compare the value of Spearman and Pearson correlation coefficient as there in the same set of data. The example concerns the comparison of the total medals and the GDP (gross domestic product) that has been obtained by each country. The results from using these methods do the heuristics prediction of Olympic medals using machine learning.

title: Retraction Notice: Comparative based beneficial analysis of smart grid technology developments with the conventionally available power grid
authors: D. Ravi Kishore, T. J. Prasnnamba
publish: 2017 2nd International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: In recent decades, the power scenario in India is drastically ever developing due to industrialization and rapid urbanization. This situation compels the urgent incorporation of information technology into the power system, resulting in smart power gird technology. The practical implementation of smart gird concept throws some challenging issues onto the conventional technology such as control and operation of energy resources, both renewable and conventional type, demand side management in real time mode, embedded generation, etc. The smart gird technology differs conventional existing technology in terms of extensive use of advanced sensors, inherent quality of outage recovery and healing capacity, communication in two ways, etc. In parallel to progression in smart gird technology, there is also rapid development standalone renewable energy resources operation where accessibility to main gird is the main concern. The next generation power systems are synthesized by intensive use of Information and Communication Technologies together with traditionally usable technology. In this paper endeavors have been taken to detail about new smart gird based technology and its part, advantages of this latest technology which is not quite the same as in house technology.

title: Adaptive super-twisting control for visual leader-follower formation tracking applications
authors: SriKrishna Tkvss, Jishnu Keshavan
abstract: Most existing approaches that deploy the super-twisting control (STC) policy for regulating a first-order sliding mode (FOSM) rely on assuming the perturbation and its derivative are bounded by a known constant, and/or achieve exact finite-time convergence in the constraint-free case. In contrast, this brief considers the development of a novel adaptive STC policy that guarantees exact finite-time convergence of the FOSM subjected to a state-dependent uncertainty arising from the presence of a time-varying, asymmetric output constraint. This is achieved by first initiating a smooth invertible nonlinear transformation that explicitly accounts for the output constraint, which is followed by the design of a novel adaptive STC policy that guarantees exact finite-time convergence by explicitly accounting for the state-dependent structure of the perturbation term of the resulting unconstrained error system. Formation tracking experiments under visibility constraints, including performance comparisons with leading alternative designs, are used to verify the efficacy and demonstrate the advantages of the proposed scheme.

title: AI-Powered Decision Support System for Sepsis Management in ICU Nursing
authors: Mangesh Jabade, Husain Nadaf, Jasneet Kaur, Sheela Upendra, Ranjit Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Sepsis still a common cause of morbidity and mortality in Intensive Care Units (ICUs). Early sepsis identification is essential for improving outcomes for patients with sepsis. Therefore, the aim of this study was to assess the efficacy and feasibility of an artificial intelligence (AI)-powered Decision Support System (DSS) implementing sepsis management in the setting of ICU nursing. As a Decision Support System, the DSS was designed to ingest real-time patient data, employing machine learning algorithms, and analytics to improve early identification of sepsis and support clinical decision making. A multi-center randomized controlled trial (RCT) was conducted in three hospitals with 200 ICU nurses and 400 ICU patients. Participants were assigned either to the intervention group, using the AI system, or to the control group, who followed the standard sepsis detection protocol. Outcome measures were time to sepsis detection, response time by nurses, length of stay in the ICU, and 30-day mortality. Data collection was via electronic health records (EHRs), system logs, and hospital records. The use of the AI-driven decision support system yielded better clinical outcomes. The intervention group identified sepsis 3.4 hours' sooner (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.001$</tex>), had 5 fewer minutes in nurse response time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.01$</tex>), had an ICU length of stay that was 1.8 days shorter (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.05$</tex>), and had an overall 30day mortality rate that was 9 % lower <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(p<0.05)$</tex> compared to the control group. Nurses reported the system had a high usability rating and a System Usability Scale (SUS) score that averaged 86.5/100 and perceived the AI system was clinically relevant to the team (mean Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) perceived usefulness 4.4/5). This research confirms that an AI-enabled Decision Support System can lead to earlier sepsis detection, quicker response times, and improved patient outcomes in ICUs. Nurses reported that they found the system intuitive and beneficial, illustrating that AI can effectively enable nursing practice. Overall, this study demonstrated one approach to leverage AI within an ICU workflow with the potential to improve the quality of care provided to patients, as well as enhance the efficiency of sepsis management. Next steps in this area of research would include multi-site and multi-center trials, researching the longer-term impacts of the system and finding further improvements.

title: SmartFare: Dynamic Pricing System
authors: Revelle Akshara, Vydyula Venkata Sai Dutt, Tadepally Sudheekhsha, Madduri N. V. Gayathri Sri, Madugula Ganesh Mahesh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Increased growth of e-commerce, ride-hailing, and delivery services has generated the need for dynamic pricing strategies that can adjust to actual time variables including demand, time, and location. This article proposes a dynamic pricing prediction model utilizing Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) combined within a simple-to-use Tkinter-based GUI. The system predicts past ride prices from attributes such as time, location, weather, traffic, and categorical attributes like city or type of car. ANN is capable of mapping non-linear complex relationships, and RNN considers temporal dependencies. Data preprocessing one-hot encodes and normalizes the data to prepare it for training, and the performance of the model is gauged by the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> score. Users can input ride data manually or via CSV uploads, switch between ANN and RNN models, and show predictions and SHAP-based feature importance for interpretability. Results show that ANN performs slightly better than RNN, though RNN is promising for more sequential data. The software is designed for real-world deployment in sectors like transport, logistics, and e-commerce. The modular nature allows for easy integration of future upgraded models or cloud APIs. Ultimately, the system covers deep learning and user interaction, promoting transparency, accessibility, and usability in real-world dynamic pricing prediction.

title: SHAFI: Securing Hash-Based Post-Quantum Cryptography from Hardware Fault Injection Attacks
authors: Yanze Wu, Qian Wang, Md Tanvir Arafin
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: SPHINCS+ has emerged as a hash-based scheme to win the National Institute of Standards and Technology’s (NIST) post-quantum cryptography (PQC) standardization competition. Unfortunately, recent research has demonstrated that fault injection (FI) attacks on SPHINCS+ can significantly compromise the security of the signing process. This paper introduces SHAFI, a countermeasure to FI attacks on SPHINCS+, that protects the signature generation and verification process via address masking. Experiments on a standard fault injection platform, ChipWhisperer, demonstrate that the proposed method renders faulty signatures unanalyzable by an attacker, eliminating the possibility of universal forgery attempts. This proposed technique is simple, memory and computation budget efficient, and applicable to virtually any SPHINCS+-derived hash-based signing technique. The code and experiment artifacts for the fault injection experiment and the countermeasure are published at https://github.com/SPIRE-GMU/SPHINCS-Chipwhisperer

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Medication Named Entity Recognition and Text Expansion in Multilingual Clinical Data
authors: Kiran Preet Bedi, Prabjot Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Medication prescriptions found in hospital discharge summaries are often presented in free-text form, which lacks consistency and structure. These texts frequently contain a mixture of local languages, non-standard abbreviations, and brand-specific drug names, making them difficult to interpret accurately. The unstructured nature of these statements poses significant challenges for both healthcare professionals and automated systems, particularly when it comes to ensuring patient safety and facilitating effective clinical decision-making. With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence, large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT3.5 have demonstrated impressive capabilities in understanding and generating human-like text across a variety of domains. These models offer a promising approach to addressing the complexities of medical text by enabling automatic extraction and clarification of critical information. In this study, we leverage the capabilities of ChatGPT-3.5 to process and refine medication statements from discharge summaries. Our goal is to automatically identify key medical entities and expand these statements into more structured and interpretable formats. By doing so, we aim to enhance the readability and usability of medication information for both humans and machines, ultimately contributing to improved healthcare data management and patient care.

title: Improved Round-by-round Soundness IOPs via Reed-Muller Codes
authors: Dor Minzer, Kai Zhe Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We give an IOPP (interactive oracle proof of proximity) for trivariate Reed-Muller codes that achieves the best known query complexity in some range of security parameters. Specifically, for degree d and security parameter $\lambda \leq \frac{\log ^{2} d}{\log \log d}$, our IOPP has $2^{-\lambda}$ round-byround soundness, $O(\lambda)$ queries, $O(\log \log d)$ rounds and $O(d)$ length. This improves upon the FRI [Ben-Sasson, Bentov, Horesh, Riabzev, ICALP 2018] and the STIR [Arnon, Chiesa, Fenzi, Yogev, Crypto 2024] IOPPs for Reed-Solomon codes, that have larger query and round complexity standing at $O(\lambda \log d)$ and $O(\log d+\lambda \log \log d)$ respectively. We use our IOPP to give an IOP for the NPcomplete language R1CS with the same parameters. Our construction is based on the line versus point test in the low-soundness regime. Compared to the axis parallel test (which is used in all prior works), the general affine lines test has improved soundness, which is the main source of our improved soundness. Using this test involves several complications, most significantly that projection to affine lines does not preserve individual degrees, and we show how to overcome these difficulties. En route, we extend some existing machinery to more general settings. Specifically, we give proximity generators for Reed-Muller codes, show a more systematic way of handling “side conditions” in IOP constructions, and generalize the compiling procedure of [Arnon, Chiesa, Fenzi, Yogev, Crypto 2024] to general codes.

title: Radial Isotropic Position via an Implicit Newton’s Method
authors: Arun Jambulapati, Jonathan Li, Kevin Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Placing a dataset A = {a<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>}<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i∈[n]</inf> ⊂ ℝ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</sup> in radial isotropic position, i.e., finding an invertible R ∈ ℝ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d×d</sup> such that the unit vectors ${\left\{ {\left( {{\text{R}}{{\text{a}}_i}} \right)\left\| {{\text{R}}{{\text{a}}_i}} \right\|_2^{ - 1}} \right\}_{i \in [n]}}$ are in isotropic position, is a powerful tool with applications in functional analysis, communication complexity, coding theory, and the design of learning algorithms. When the transformed dataset has a second moment matrix within a exp(±ϵ) factor of a multiple of I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>, we call R an ϵ-approximate Forster transform.We give a faster algorithm for computing approximate Forster transforms, based on optimizing an objective defined by Barthe [1]. When the transform has a polynomially-bounded aspect ratio, our algorithm uses $O\left( {n{d^{\omega - 1}}{{\left( {\frac{n}{\varepsilon }} \right)}^{o(1)}}} \right)$ time to output an ϵ-approximate Forster transform with high probability, when one exists. This is almost the natural limit of this approach, as even evaluating Barthe’s objective takes O(nd<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ω−1</sup>) time. Previously, the state-of-the-art runtime in this regime was based on cutting-plane methods, and scaled at least as ≈ n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> +n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>d<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ω−1</sup>. We also provide explicit estimates on the aspect ratio in the smoothed analysis setting, and show that our algorithm similarly improves upon those in the literature.To obtain our results, we develop a subroutine of potential broader interest: a reduction from almost-linear time sparsification of graph Laplacians to the ability to support almost-linear time matrix-vector products. We combine this tool with new stability bounds on Barthe’s objective to implicitly implement a box-constrained Newton’s method [2], [3].

title: Cryptography Meets Worst-case Complexity: Optimal Security and More From iO and Worst-case Assumptions
authors: Rahul Ilango, Alex Lombardi
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We study several problems in the intersection of cryptography and complexity theory based on the following highlevel thesis.1)Obfuscation can serve as a general-purpose worst-case to average-case reduction, reducing the existence of various forms of cryptography to corresponding worst-case assumptions.2)We can therefore hope to overcome barriers in cryptography and average-case complexity by (i) making worstcase hardness assumptions beyond $P \neq N P$, and (ii) leveraging worst-case hardness reductions, either proved by traditional complexity-theoretic methods or facilitated further by cryptography.Concretely, our results include:•Optimal Hardness. Assuming sub-exponential indistinguishability obfuscation, we give fine-grained worst-case to average case reductions for circuit-SAT. In particular, if finding an NP-witness requires nearly brute-force time in the worst case, then the same is true for some efficiently sampleable distribution. In fact, we show that under these assumptions, there exist families of one-way functions with optimal time-probability security tradeoffs. Under an additional, stronger assumption - the optimal non-deterministic hardness of refuting circuit-SAT - we construct additional cryptographic primitives such as PRGs and public-key encryption that have such optimal timeadvantage security tradeoffs.•Direct Product Hardness. Again assuming iO and optimal non-deterministic hardness of SAT refutation, we show that the “(search) k-fold SAT problem” - the computational task of finding satisfying assignments to k circuit-SAT instances simultaneously - has (optimal) hardness roughly $\left(T / 2^{n}\right)^{k}$ for time T algorithms. In fact, we build “optimally secure one-way product functions” (Holmgren-Lombardi, FOCS ‘18), demonstrating that optimal direct product theorems hold for some choice of one-way function family.•Single-Input Correlation Intractability. Assuming either iO or LWE, we show a worst-case to average-case reduction for strong forms of single-input correlation intractability. That is, powerful forms of correlation-intractable hash functions exist provided that a collection of worst-case “correlationfinding” problems are hard.•Non-interactive Proof of Quantumness. Assuming subexponential iO and OWFs, we give a non-interactive proof of quantumness based on the worst-case hardness of the whitebox Simon problem. In particular, this proof of quantumness result does not explicitly assume quantum advantage for an average-case task.To help prove our first two results, we show along the way how to improve the Goldwasser-Sipser “set lower bound” protocol to have communication complexity quadratically smaller in the multiplicative approximation error $\varepsilon$.

title: Deterministic factorization of constant-depth algebraic circuits in subexponential time
authors: Somnath Bhattacharjee, Mrinal Kumar, Varun Ramanathan, Ramprasad Saptharishi, Shubhangi Saraf
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: While efficient randomized algorithms for factorization of polynomials given by algebraic circuits have been known for decades, obtaining an even slightly non-trivial deterministic algorithm for this problem has remained an open question of great interest. This is true even when the input algebraic circuit has additional structure, for instance, when it is a constant-depth circuit. Indeed, no efficient deterministic algorithms are known even for the seemingly easier problem of factoring sparse polynomials or even the problem of testing the irreducibility of sparse polynomials.In this work, we make progress on these questions: we design a deterministic algorithm that runs in subexponential time, and when given as input a constant-depth algebraic circuit C over the field of rational numbers, it outputs algebraic circuits (of potentially unbounded depth) for all the irreducible factors of C, together with their multiplicities. In particular, we give the first subexponential time deterministic algorithm for factoring sparse polynomials.For our proofs, we rely on a finer understanding of the structure of power series roots of constant-depth circuits and the analysis of the Kabanets-Impagliazzo generator. In particular, we show that the Kabanets-Impagliazzo generator constructed using low-degree hard polynomials (explicitly constructed in the work of Limaye, Srinivasan & Tavenas) preserves not only the non-zeroness of small constant-depth circuits (as shown by Chou, Kumar & Solomon), but also their irreducibility and the irreducibility of their factors.

title: Visual Surveillance Methods for Fishery School Search by UAVs
authors: Filipp Belchenko, Ivan Ermolov, Georgij Nagajcev, Pavel Ostrikov, Artem Sukhanov
abstract: The article suggests an approach to using unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to monitor fish schools. The existing techniques of fish schools exploration are classified. The problems of using manned aircraft for such tasks are also being considered. The characteristics for identifying fishing facilities in underwater environment have been determined. Image processing algorithms are proposed to improve the efficiency of fish search. The main focus was aimed on working with color, histogram normalization, adaptive histogram normalization, and the Navier-Stokes based algorithm was implemented to eliminate glares and flashes. Promising techniques for determining the accumulation of fish schools based on a photogrammetric approach are proposed. The paper describes in detail the features of visual identification of pre-spawning and spawning aggregations of these fish. The article contains a classification of features that correlates with the Yudovich classification [1]: spots, fountains, color shades. There is additional information on chum salmon, beluga whales, underwater rocks and debris covered with seaweed. In this work adaptive histogram normalization was applied to local areas of the obtained image.

title: A Source-Load Synergy-based Multi-Time Scale Optimal Scheduling Strategy for Multi-Source Flexible Resources
authors: Liangsong Guo, Jianguang Zhao, Hailong Fu, Xiaoming Chen, Yanxiang Lei, Zhou Ji, Feng Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address the spatio-temporal mismatch between PV (PV) generation and EH loads, this study proposes a synergistic scheduling strategy for PV systems, electric vehicles (EVs), and EH. A multi-time-scale matching model is constructed, incorporating weather characteristics and user behavior patterns. Furthermore, a Time-of-Use (TOU) pricing mechanism is designed to incentivize daytime charging and nighttime discharging of EVs, which automatically adjusts the operational modes of charging infrastructure. The proposed strategy effectively enhances the local consumption efficiency of PV generation while significantly mitigating the peak of the EH load, thereby achieving synergistic optimization of both source and load. Simulation results demonstrate that this multi-time-scale optimization method can effectively flatten the load curve and reduce grid fluctuations.

title: Pinning-Based Distributed Voltage Convergence Control for Islanded Microgrid
authors: Xing Gao, Wei Liu, Lijuan Song
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Most secondary control strategies for stand-alone microgrids today are centralized, which leads to all important issues, including complex communication network requirements, single-point failures, and other issues related to topological changes in the system. This study proposes a Pinning-based Distributed Voltage Convergence Control (PDVCC) strategy for isolated microgrids. The proposed PDVCC incorporates a pinning consensus algorithm that enables synchronous operation of all participating agents with minimal energy overhead and guarantees fast convergence in dynamic operating conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the PDVCC can enhance the overall dynamic voltage cooperation of islanded microgrids, while only requiring a small number of controllers and simple communication exchanges.

title: Control and Instrumentation Strategies for Hydrogen-Ammonia Microturbine Systems: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Shubham Das, Luciano Bueno, Ailton Gonçalves, Marcelo Rosário, André Fonseca, Edgar Fernandes, Guilherme Gaspar
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Retrofitting microturbines for alternative fuels such as hydrogen and ammonia represents a critical pathway for decarbonizing distributed power systems. This paper presents a comprehensive review of instrumentation and control strategies specifically designed for microturbine (MGT) retrofitting applications, covering power ranges from 10 kW to several hundred kW. The study examines control methodologies, sensor integration requirements, and operational challenges when transitioning from conventional fuels (diesel, natural gas) to hydrogen and ammonia. Detailed energy and mass balance analyses are presented for representative microturbine models including Capstone C30/C65, Bladon MTG12, and select Ansaldo systems. The paper addresses critical aspects including combustion dynamics adaptation, safety system integration, emissions control, and grid interface requirements. Control strategies ranging from adaptive Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) to Model Predictive Control (MPC) are evaluated for their effectiveness in managing the unique characteristics of hydrogen's high reactivity and ammonia's ignition challenges. The research contributes with practical guidelines for retrofitting existing microturbine installations while maintaining operational reliability and grid service quality.

title: Data-Driven Conflict Resolution Method for Topology Update in Low-Voltage Distribution Station Area
authors: Wei Wei, Chen Hu, Cheng Zhang, Meng Yu, Yuxuan Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address conflicts between old and new topologies that may arise during topology updates in low-voltage distribution station area (LVDSA), a data-driven conflict resolution method is proposed. A rolling window scheme performs online updates of meter data sequences. Topology-Update conflicts are detected by the count of near-zero singular values of the power data matrix. When a conflict is flagged, it is handled via weighted similarity analysis on voltage data and the LVDSA topology is updated according to the inferred cause. If no conflict is detected, principal component analysis (PCA) is used to perform routine topology identification. Leveraging the complementary characteristics of voltage and power data, the method promptly senses conflicts and accurately updates the topology. Simulation case studies verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Depth-Aware RGB and IR Image Alignment Using ToF-Based Homography Interpolation
authors: Roberts Treize
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This paper presents a depth-aware method for pixelwise registration of RGB and infrared (IR) images using Time-of-Flight (ToF) sensing. Unlike fixed homography models that fail under varying scene depths, our approach dynamically adapts the transformation matrix based on per-pixel depth information. We perform a two-depth calibration using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 7$</tex> checkerboard target, obtaining homographies between the ToF and both RGB and IR image planes. These matrices are linearly interpolated to generate a continuous, depth-dependent transformation model. Each pixel's depth is retrieved from the ToF camera and used to evaluate a tailored homography, which maps coordinates between modalities. To handle missing or uncertain depth data, we apply percentile-based outlier removal and edge-aware interpolation. Final alignment is performed via bilinear resampling. The method is scalable to high-resolution input, and achieves precise multimodal overlay even under non-uniform depth conditions.

title: Flexible Supercapacitor Made by ZIF-graphene Composite Materials AND Iron-based Carbon Nanofiber Composite Material
authors: Chi Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address limitations of traditional supercapacitors, we synthesized FeP-CNF and GNPC composites, fabricated asymmetric supercapacitors, and conducted electrochemical tests. The device showed enhanced energy/power density and long cycle life, highlighting its potential as a sustainable energy storage technology.

title: Image-Based Localization and Navigation Using Deep Learning for an Omnidirectional Human Assistive Robot
authors: Genci Capi, Shin-Ichiro Kaneko
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: In recent years, nursing care has faced severe labor shortages, highlighting the need for robots capable of autonomous navigation and assistance. Accurate self-localization is crucial for autonomous movement; however, existing indoor navigation methods often rely on expensive equipment and suffer from delays caused by intensive processing demands. This paper proposes an autonomous navigation system utilizing a deep learning model that requires only visual input. The proposed method has been implemented on a newly developed omnidirectional mobile assistive robot and its performance has been validated through experimental testing. The results show that the robot could follow its designated path with minimal deviation while providing standing assistance. This approach offers a cost-effective and versatile alternative to conventional indoor navigation systems.

title: A Hybrid Approach for Driver Drowsiness Detection Using IoT
authors: Abhishek Khonde, Mustaqeem Sayyed, Dinesh Barode, Seema Kawathekar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Driver fatigue is a critical factor contributing to road accidents, particularly for long-haul and heavy vehicle drivers. Extended driving hours on highways can lead to reduced attention, slower reaction times, and microsleep, increasing accident risks. Traditional physiological monitoring methods such as EEG and ECG, while accurate, are expensive and intrusive. Vehicle-based systems like lane departure detection do not directly monitor the driver and are dependent on external conditions. Existing image-based solutions, though promising, often struggle in low-light conditions or require high-end hardware. This study proposes a real-time driver safety system that integrates Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR), Mouth Aspect Ratio (MAR), and Head Posture Analysis to detect drowsiness and fatigue more effectively. The system, implemented on a Raspberry Pi, utilizes a Pi Camera to monitor the driver's eye closure frequency, yawning patterns, and head movements. EAR analysis identifies prolonged eye closure, MAR detects excessive yawning, and head posture analysis determines if the driver's head tilts beyond a safe range, indicating drowsiness or inattentiveness. When fatigue signs exceed predefined thresholds, an alarm is triggered to alert the driver. The system leverages OpenCV, Dlib, and Python for efficient image processing and incorporates IoT functionality for remote monitoring, making it a cost-effective and scalable solution for enhancing road safety.

title: Blood Cell Classification for Cancer Detection Using EfficientNetB3
authors: Prabhjot Kaur, Amandeep Singh Kalra, Abhishek Bhattacherjee, Khushboo, Richa Brar, Pratham Kaushik
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The research employs EfficientNetB3 as a deep learning model to detect and classify blood cells as Basophil, Erythroblast, Monocyte, Myeloblast, and Seg_Neutrophil based on a pool of 5,000 high-resolution images. Preprocessing included resizing, normalization, and splitting of the data to enhance model performance. The model was trained for 30 epochs with the Adam optimizer and categorical cross-entropy loss. The classification accuracy yielded a total accuracy of 95%, with precision, recall, and F1-scores of more than 0.92 for each class. The confusion matrix revealed minimal cases of misclassification, largely due to morphological similarity between certain types of cells. These outcomes validate that deep learning has the potential to enhance automated classification of blood cells and reduce reliance on human analysis. Future studies can explore ensemble models, large-scale data, and realtime integration in clinical practice to enhance classification accuracy and reliability in cancer diagnosis.

title: Study of a Multiple Mediation model of Strategic Foresight influencing Innovation Ambidexterity
authors: Abdelati Hakmaoui, Wafaa Harandou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This paper aims to study the impact of Strategic Foresight (SF) on Innovation Ambidexterity (IA) and investigates the effects of Knowledge Management (KM), Dynamic Capabilities (DC) and Perceived Organizational Support (POS) in influencing this relationship. While existing literature highlights connections among SF, IA, KM, DC and POS, there are – to the best of our knowledge - no empirical studies that analyze the dynamic interplay among these constructs and particularly how the joint effects of KM, DC and POS can interact together to leverage the SF-IA relationship. To empirically test the hypothesized effects, we draw on a survey data collected from 76 foresight practitioners. The findings show that SF has no direct impact on Innovation ambidexterity, while KM, DC and POS are mediating variables that jointly account for this relationship. Theoretical contributions and managerial implications along with future research directions are also discussed in this paper.

title: Development of a Coordinated Control Algorithm For a Carrier Ship and an AUV Considering the Characteristics of the Underwater Acoustic Communication System
authors: Alexander Yurmanov, Alexander Konoplin, Denis Kopylov
abstract: The paper considers the problem of improving the quality of acoustic communication between a supply vessel and an autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) by ensuring their coordinated movement. An algorithm for controlling the movement of a vessel based on the model-predictive control (MPC) method is proposed. The algorithm generates the trajectory of the vessel, taking into account the predicted movement of the AUV, the dynamic limitations of the vessel and the parameters of the acoustic channel. Unlike approaches aimed only at minimizing the distance, the objective function of the algorithm directly maximizes the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). This allows for comprehensive optimization of key parameters: transmission loss (TL), vessel noise level (NL), and antenna orientation. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed control algorithm, comparative modeling of three strategies was carried out: the developed algorithm; movement behind the AUV; movement along the center of the tacks. The results of numerical modeling demonstrate that the proposed approach provides a higher and more stable quality of communication compared to traditional strategies, minimizing the risks of its interruption during AUV maneuvers.

title: Optimizing Web Scraping for Enhancing Efficiency with NLP and Machine Learning
authors: Shahid Metkari, Atharv Gaikwad, Yash More, Jayesh Sarwade, Sakshi Devi, Umakant Tupe
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Web scraping is a powerful tool for collecting large - scale data in online sources, especially cyber security. Nevertheless, traditional scratches often fight non - efficiency such as slow extraction speed, high resource consumption and detection using similar mechanisms. This article explores a modern approach that increases the scaling efficiency of the Internet, which focuses on integrating natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML). It emphasizes an effective strategy that analyzes existing studies to automate data extraction, improve classification, and optimize cybersecurity analysis. It will also take into account the actual applications, potential problems and future achievements that can expand, accurate, and restrict web data extraction. Our goal is to present a comprehensive overview of modern methods. At the same time, we are suggesting ideas for the development of smarter and more effective frameworks for cyber security.

title: Fault diagnosis of a class of nonlinear switching systems based on adaptive observer
authors: Xin Dai, Xingxing Hua
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The inverter is an important part of wireless power transmission system. The safety and health of the running track are the primary premise to ensure the stable operation of the inverter. In this paper, an adaptive fault diagnosis observer method to tracking the running state of inverter is proposed. Firstly, the push-pull current source inverter as a new nonlinear system and this kind of structure is studied in this article; secondly, generalized state-space average(GSSA) method is applied on the push-pull current source inverter; at the same time, the fault vector is considered into the nonlinear system; then, an adaptive fault diagnosis observer is designed for this inverter and the stability of the observer has been discussed in this paper; finally, the adaptive fault diagnosis observer proposed in this paper is verified by the simulation results.

title: Carbon-Aware Adaptive Routing Protocol with Real-Time Traffic Information for Cyber-Physical Internet Networks
authors: Infix Li, Chenglin Yu, Yuchen Wang, Hang Wu, Ming Li, Hongxia Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel Carbon-Aware Adaptive Routing Protocol with Real-Time Traffic Information for CyberPhysical Internet networks. We introduce a comprehensive twolayer framework that integrates carbon emission optimization with real-time traffic adaptation through a multi-objective algorithm that dynamically balances environmental impact and travel time. Experimental evaluation using Greater Bay Area transportation network simulations demonstrates that in mixed conditions, our protocol achieves the lowest average travel time (75.2 minutes) while maintaining carbon awareness, showing no statistically significant difference from purely traffic-adaptive approaches (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}=0.3872$</tex>). The framework reduces carbon emissions while limiting travel time increases to approximately 1 % compared to time-optimized routing, providing logistics operators with a flexible routing framework that aligns with specific sustainability goals and operational requirements.

title: mAPO: A Modified Artificial Protozoa Optimizer for Solving Global Optimization
authors: Abdelazim G. Hussien, Adrian Pop
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Artificial Protozoa Optimizer (APO) is a novel algorithm that simulatess the behaviors of protozoa in dormancy, foraging, and reproduction. Although, APO has a good performance in solving different optimization problems, it might has unbalanced between exploration and exploitation and may be falling into local optimal especially for complex and high-dimensional problems. In this paper, we present a novel algorithm to overcome these challenges by integrating binomial-based cross-evolution strategy with the original APO. To prove the superiority of mAPO, we compare it with the original APO, and three recently-published algorithms namely: Harris Hawks Optimization (HHO), Grey wolf optimizer (GWO), and Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm (AOA). The results prove the superiority of mAPO in solving different optimization problems.

title: An Early Termination Strategy for the Distributed Biased Min-Consensus Protocol Under Disturbances
authors: Zicheng Huang, Wangzhi Zhou, Yuanqiu Mo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: The distributed biased min-consensus (DBMC) protocol is an iterative scheme that solves the shortest path problem asymptotically, requiring only local information exchange between neighboring nodes. By appropriately designing the gain function, prior work [1] proposed a DBMC-based system that ensures convergence within a pre-specified time interval. However, this guarantee assumes the absence of disturbances. In this paper, we study the DBMC-based system under disturbances affecting the edge weights. We first establish rigorous error bounds on the resulting state estimates. Building on this analysis, we then propose a practical early termination strategy to prevent potential singularities, specifically, unbounded gain, that may arise in the presence of disturbances, while still ensuring that the shortest paths are correctly identified. Simulations are performed to validate and illustrate the theoretical results.

title: DeepONet-Assisted Inverse Kinematics and Branch-Aware Redundancy Resolution for a Five-Bar Spherical Parallel Manipulator
authors: Yau-Zen Chang, Anh-Son Tran, Chieh-Tsai Wu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: We present a network-augmented inverse-kinematics and control framework for a two-actuated, five-bar spherical parallel manipulator. Using spherical geometry, we derive compact forward and inverse kinematic relations and show that the mechanism admits four discrete IK branches for any target orientation. A Deep Operator Network (DeepONet) is trained to regress branch-independent primitives across the workspace and combined with a branch-aware selection policy that enforces continuity, respects joint limits, and avoids singular neighborhoods. Deployed in closed-loop control, the learned model generates joint trajectories from orientation commands. Simulation results demonstrate accurate joint prediction (mean/max 0.0002/0.0007 rad) and precise spherical tracking (mean/max 0.0708/0.2994 mm), while maintaining stable branch behavior.

title: Reliability-Oriented Short-Term Planning of Energy Hub-Enabled Microgrids with Peer-to-Peer Trading under Uncertainty
authors: Amin Aboutalebi Najafabadi, Nabiollah Tayebi, Shahriar Kamailinia, Seyed Hossein Hosseinian
abstract: This paper presents a robust short-term planning framework for microgrids integrated with energy hubs (EHs) and peer-to-peer (P2P) trading. A mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model is formulated to minimize operational cost while incorporating distributed generation (DG), demand response (DR), and prosumer participation. To improve practicality, a linearized MILP approximation is also implemented for benchmarking computational efficiency. Beyond deterministic optimization, extensive Monte Carlo simulations are conducted to capture uncertainties in upstream prices, DG output, and load demand. Reliability and resilience metrics, including Energy Not Supplied (ENS) and Loss of Load Probability (LOLP), are evaluated to quantify system robustness. Results on the IEEE 33-bus test system show that P2P trading reduces operating costs by 11–16% on average and improves reliability by nearly 45% compared to the baseline. Importantly, the proposed framework not only enhances economic efficiency but also contributes to environmental sustainability by reducing reliance on fossil-fuel-based upstream grids and increasing renewable utilization. These findings confirm practical value of combining EHs with P2P trading for future smart microgrids under uncertainty.

title: Language-Guided Predictive Control: Synthesizing Semantic Safety Constraints for Adaptive Navigation
authors: Shruti Pandey, Arpita Sinha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: To become effective collaborators, autonomous robots must bridge the semantic gap between a human’s qualitative instructions and the quantitative world of a motion controller, particularly for safety warnings like "avoid the spill" which traditional systems struggle to ground in physical reality. This paper introduces a hierarchical control architecture featuring a Large Language Model (LLM) based planner that autonomously synthesizes geometric safety constraints (exclusion zones) from abstract warnings and uses a "semantic centroid" method to translate nuanced motion modifiers into a continuous parameterization of a downstream Model Predictive Controller (MPC). The resulting plan guides a dynamic path planner that reconstructs its navigation graph on-demand to generate consistently safe trajectories for complex multi-robot tasks, including cooperative transport. We validated our framework in a high-fidelity simulator, demonstrating that the system successfully generates paths that maneuver around language-defined hazards, representing a significant step towards creating more intuitive, adaptable, and trustworthy robotic collaborators for human-centric environments.

title: Pilot Resource Management for Channel Estimation Error Reduction in Digital Twin-Assisted User-centric Cell-free Massive MIMO Networks
authors: Manobendu Sarker, Md. Zoheb Hassan, Georges Kaddoum, Abraham O. Fapojuwo
abstract: This paper addresses channel estimation error (CEE) mitigation in user-centric cell-free (CF) massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) systems under pilot contamination (PC). To suppress the PC, we formulate an optimization problem to minimize the normalized CEE through the joint treatment of the pilot power allocation and the pilot assignment. However, the NP-hard nature of the problem makes finding a global optimal solution computationally infeasible. To tackle this challenge, we decompose the problem into two sub-problems: the fractional programming (FP) technique is employed for pilot power allocation, and a multi-agent reinforcement learning (RL) approach is applied for pilot assignment. The RL-based scheme, however, involves iterative action generation and reward computation, leading to significant overhead from repeated information exchanges. To mitigate this issue, we leverage a digital twin (DT) of the CF mMIMO system, utilizing its virtual environment and contextual awareness to optimize CEE reduction with minimal overhead. By employing closed-form expressions, the proposed schemes achieve computational efficiency without reliance on complex numerical solvers. Finally, we solve the original NP-hard problem via the block-coordinate descent and sequential optimization methods. Numerical evaluations demonstrate that the proposed FP-based pilot power allocation scheme improves the 95%-likely spectral efficiency (SE) by up to 15% and reduces the average pilot transmission power by up to 83% compared to existing methods. Furthermore, the pilot assignment scheme enhances the average SE performance by up to 7.4% over state-of-the-art pilot assignment approaches. These results validate the effectiveness of our proposed framework in reducing CEE, leading to enhanced improvement in system performance in the presence of PC.
