title: Automatic scoring system for digitized handwritten answers
authors: Tomo Asakura, Hung T. Nguyen, Thanh-Nghia Truong, Yoichi Tsuchida, Takahiro Yamamoto, Hiroshi Miyazawa, Nam T. Ly, Masato Nemoto, Masamitsu Ito, Toshihiko Horie, Keiichi Kaneko, Masaki Nakagawa
abstract: We propose a system for automatic and semiautomatic scoring of handwritten answers in Japanese, English, and mathematics, assuming the use of an electronic pen and paper. When quick scoring is prioritized, the system directly returns automatically scored results to answerers without requiring the scorers’ verification. When reliable scoring is required, the system shows the results to scorers for confirmation and correction before being disclosed to the answerers. The system comprises handwriting recognizers using deep neural networks and text-based scorers to determine whether an answer is correct, incorrect, or rejected. Question-specific scoring methods and rules (rubrics) (defined by the scorers) are used to score the answers consistently. To evaluate the system, handwritten answers in the three subjects were collected from at least 50 students for all grades of elementary and junior high schools. Scoring experiments showed that the average human scoring rate (percentage of answers rejected plus those falsely negatively scored and claimed) was under 30%, indicating that approximately 70% of the scorers’ workload could be reduced. The average risk scoring rate (ratio of false positives that may not be reported) was <2%, except for second-grade Japanese, which requires precise character writing. Finally, we conducted feasibility experiments on the entire system, including question distribution, answer capture, automatic scoring, score correction, and score return, with participants expressing satisfaction. This study lays the groundwork for a cycle of collecting handwritten answers and improving automatic scoring in educational contexts.

title: A CNN-Transformer Hybrid Framework for Mapping Annual Wheat Fractional Cover from 2001-2023 using MODIS Satellite Data over Asia_supp1-3660045.pdf
authors: Shunlin Liang
abstract: Wheat is a staple crop in over 40 countries, with Asia accounting for more than 40% of global cultivation. Long-term mapping of wheat cover is critical for agricultural management and food security. However, existing wheat mapping products face a key limitation in spatiotemporal coverage: they either offer broad spatial coverage for a single or few years, or provide long time series that are confined to specific regions. To address this gap, we propose DeepMapping, a hybrid deep learning framework designed to generate a consistent annual fractional wheat cover product at 250 m resolution from 2001 to 2023 over Asia. Our framework integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Transformer models to extract complementary spatial and temporal features. It processes multi-resolution data, including 250 m and 500 m MODIS reflectance, alongside GLASS Leaf Area Index and Fractional Vegetation Cover products. The model is trained with fractions derived from the 10 m resolution WorldCereal 2021 map and refined with ancillary information such as coarse-resolution crop products, land cover data, and agricultural statistics to enhance reliability. By learning the relationship between short-term, high-resolution labels and long-term, coarse-resolution MODIS observations, DeepMapping is efficiently used to generates annual wheat fractional cover product over Asia at 250 m from 2001–2023. Wheat is a staple crop in over 40 countries, with Asia contributing more than 40% of global wheat cultivation. Long-term wheat cover is critical for agricultural management and food security, but existing products face a trade-off: they either provide high spatial resolution with short temporal coverage or offer long time series with limited spatial coverage. We propose DeepMapping, a hybrid deep learning framework, to estimate long-term annual wheat fractional cover at 250 m from MODIS data. DeepMapping integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Transformer models to extract spatial and temporal features from MODIS data at 250 m and 500 m resolutions and Global LAnd Surface Satellite (GLASS) Leaf Area Index and Fractional Vegetation Coverage products. The DeepMapping is trained using WorldCereal 2021 at 10 m and refined with other ancillary information, such as coarse-resolution crop products, land cover data, and statistics to ensure reliability. By learning the relationship between high-resolution labels and long-term coarse-resolution MODIS observations, DeepMapping is efficiently used to generates annual wheat fractional cover product over Asia at 250 m from 2001–2023. Validation with 2,556 samples demonstrates overall accuracy of 84.1%, producer's accuracy of 87.8%, and user's accuracy of 70.07%. Comparison with national statistical data confirms high consistency (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula>: 0.880–0.943). DeepMapping offers a scalable solution for long-term, reliable agricultural mapping. This product is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://glass.hku.hk/casual/Asia_Wheat/</uri>.

title: No HDL, No Problem: HLS-Generated Power Wasters for Fault Injection in Cloud FPGAs
authors: Zeynep Gülbeyaz Demirdag, Hassan Nassar, Lars Bauer, Jörg Henkel
abstract: Power wasters are a critical threat to cloud FPGAs. They induce voltage drops that lead to timing faults or complete denial of service. Previous methods for generating power wasters rely on low-level RTL modifications, including primitive-level structures and constraint manipulation. However, newer FPGA platforms such as Xilinx Versal restrict access to such low-level features, preventing traditional attack methods. In this work, we are the first to show that power wasters can still be created using only High-Level Synthesis (HLS), which is a standard development flow for cloud FPGAs. We demonstrate HLS-generated power wasters that can inject faults or crash the FPGA by applying overclocking and selected input patterns.

title: Generative Data Augmentation for Transaction Fraud Detection Via Temporal Behavioral Sequences
authors: Yu Xie, Songwei Feng, Jiamin Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Transaction fraud detection (TFD) remains a persistent challenge due to extreme class imbalance and the intricate temporal dynamics of user behavior. Conventional data augmentation techniques typically generate isolated samples, failing to preserve the sequential and temporal dependencies essential for modeling fraudulent transaction patterns. To bridge this gap, we introduce BSCGAN, a Behavioral Sequence-aware Conditional Generative Adversarial Network, designed to synthesize realistic and temporally coherent fraudulent transaction sequences under specific class conditions. At the core of BSCGAN is a novel discriminator architecture based on Behavioral Sequence-aware LSTM (BSLSTM), which explicitly models inter-transaction time intervals and employs a dual-memory stream to disentangle long-term behavioral tendencies from short-term anomalies. This enriched temporal representation guides the generator to produce more plausible and context-aware sequences. By conditioning the generative process on class labels, BSCGAN facilitates targeted oversampling of fraudulent behaviors, thereby alleviating class imbalance during model training. Extensive experiments on realworld transaction datasets demonstrate that TFD models trained on BSCGAN-augmented data achieve significant improvements in F1-score and G-mean, validating the effectiveness of the proposed framework. Overall, this work offers an efficient solution for enhancing training data in TFD tasks by synthesizing behaviorally consistent and temporally structured fraudulent sequences.

title: Calculating Method of the Parameters of Marching Propulsions and the Battery of the Command AUV for the Complex of the Noise Field Operational Monitoring
authors: Jurii Matvienko, Vladimir Kostenko, Anna Bykanova, Andrey Medvedev
abstract: The article presents a methodology for determining the main parameters of the marching propulsions of the command autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) of the operational noise field control complex. The technique is based on the results of virtual purging of a 3D model of the vehicle with angles of attack that compensate for residual buoyancy at cruising speed. A hydrodynamic calculation of its propeller was carried out, taking into account the results of load tests of the selected electric thruster drive in accordance with the required thrust of the main propellers. An assessment of the required energy consumption of its battery is given, which ensures the necessary autonomy of using the device for its intended purpose. The dependence of the range of the device on the speed of moving has been revealed, and the presence of an extreme of this dependence has been determined.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning of the κ-η Regression Method by Training Data Sampling
authors: Kevin Baboolal, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The κ-η regression method presents a significant computational challenge for hyperparameter optimization due to its inherent quadratic time complexity for training, rendering grid search on large datasets prohibitive. This paper investigates sampling strategies as a means to mitigate this complexity. We evaluate the efficacy of performing hyperparameter tuning on a subset (25%) of training data using two distinct methods: uniform random sampling and Locality-Sensitive Hashing (LSH). Our empirical analysis, conducted across eight UCI regression datasets, demonstrates that both sampling techniques yield substantial reductions in computation time, ranging from 22% to 82%, compared to a full grid search. LSH-based sampling shows consistent performance in estimating the hyperparameters of the algorithm. LSH’s effectiveness stems from its capacity to create a subsample that accurately preserves the data’s local geometry, a crucial feature for distance-based κ-η regression. These results establish LSH-based sampling as a highly efficient and reliable approach for enhancing the κ-η algorithm, providing an attractive trade-off between prediction quality and processing speed.

title: Design Proposal for a Closed-loop Automatic Control to Improve the Pumping System of 110kw Submersible Pumps, use in the Mining Sector
authors: Luis Esau Mendoza Osorio, Gabriel Osiris Cairampoma Rodriguez
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The objective of this research was to make a design proposal for an automatic closed-loop control to improve the pumping system of 110kw submersible pumps applied to the mining sector. With the results obtained with the simulation of the LabVIEW software, in figure "4" it can be seen that the energy consumption of the submersible pump "1" is reduced by 33.4% and the energy consumption of the submersible pump "2" by 30%. In the same way, in figure "5" it shows us that there is a reduction in operating time in submersible pump "1" of 60 hours per month and in submersible pump "2" of 90 hours per month, all this is due to the fact that in figure "6" it shows us an increase in flow flow from 149 m3/h to 215m3/h in submersible pump "1", from 150m3h to 220m3h in the submersible pump "2". Concluding that by carrying out the design of the automatic closed-loop control of submersible pumps, there is greater reliability for the operation of the mining unit and performing real-time monitoring of electrical parameters remotely, thus increasing the useful life of the mechanical and electrical components.

title: Hybrid Compensation Topology for Suppressing Power Fluctuation of EV- DWPT System
authors: Quan Liu, Jing Xiao, Xiaorui Wu, Yuhong Mo, Jianxin Wang, Rui Ding
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The dynamic wireless power transmission (EV-DWPT) system for electric vehicles experiences power fluctuations in the transition zone due to mutual inductance drop, which affects charging efficiency and stability. To address this issue, this paper proposes an input series output series (ISOS) hybrid compensation topology based on LCC-LCC+SS, which suppresses power fluctuations through complementary characteristics. Theoretical analysis shows that this topology can achieve constant current output under resonance conditions, and the output power is independent of the load. The simulation results show that during the movement of the receiving end, the output power fluctuation rate of the system is only 4.3%, which meets the design requirement of ± 5%, verifying the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Channel Selection using Machine Learning Algorithms for Wireless Access Points
authors: Arnold Chau, Harry Chan, Corinne Geraghty
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The primary contribution of this paper lies in evaluating the potential benefits of using machine learning algorithms for channel selection for wireless communication systems on the 5GHz spectrum. In this paper we explore classification algorithms such as Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF) and Neural Network (NN) with multiple outcomes by considering multiple decision factors. This paper demonstrates, though simulation scenarios, the effectiveness of classification algorithms, and the results show that this approach can provide extra stability for the wireless communication network with the scenarios considered.

title: Learning Deep Wavelet Features for Infrared Image Destriping
authors: Bowen Qi, Yaozong Zhang, Chaojun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Signal Processing (ICGSP)
abstract: The inherent non-uniformity of the photoelectric response in infrared imaging systems generates stripe noise of varying intensity, significantly degrading the image quality in practical applications. The stripe patterns caused by this nonuniformity are sometimes subtle, leading to unavoidable blurring of scene details and structures when using existing image destriping methods to remove stripe noise. This paper proposes a deep network for stripe noise removal in infrared images, incorporating a multi-scale feature extraction mechanism to address the challenge of selectively removing strong and weak stripe patterns. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches on publicly available datasets. It achieves better preservation of image textures and edge details while achieving the same level of stripe noise removal, thereby significantly enhancing image quality.

title: Implementation Strategy of Soft-switching through DC Bias Variable Capacitance Based on Asymmetrical Voltage-Cancellation Control
authors: Wenbo Shi, Hongsheng Hu, Jing Chen, Shuai Qin, Zhankun Feng, Yijing Cheng
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This paper presents a variable capacitance adjustment approach based on direct current (DC) bias voltage control, aiming to achieve the regulation of the phase difference between voltage and current. This methodology employs Asymmetrical Voltage-Cancellation Control (AVC) to adjust the phase relationship of the system while simultaneously modulating its output power. Through Fourier analysis, AVC is decomposed into DC bias voltage and fundamental voltage components. The AVC is directly utilized at the inverter terminal to generate DC bias variations. By employing high-permittivity type-II ceramic capacitors, real-time alteration of capacitance values during system operation becomes feasible. Compared to conventional variable capacitance methods, this approach eliminates the need for additional devices, thereby mitigating power losses that may arise from extra power components. Simulation results demonstrate that this method can effectively adjust the phase difference in the system under conditions where coil parameter variations render the system distinctly capacitive, enabling it to operate in Zero Voltage Switching (ZVS) mode.

title: Optimized VMD-based fuzzy control of hybrid battery storage-assisted primary frequency regulation of thermal power units
authors: Jiangfeng Zhang, Shuhao Liu, Xinsheng Zhang, Quan Li, Wei Jiang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address frequency instability caused by renewable energy volatility, this study proposes a hybrid battery energy storage system(BESS)-assisted primary frequency regulation(FPR) strategy for thermal power units.A whale optimization algorithm-optimized variational mode decomposition (WOA-VMD) method enables two-stage adaptive power allocation: initially separating components for thermal units and hybrid energy storage system(HESS), then further decomposing HESS power between power-type and energy-type storage. A fuzzy logic controller prevents overcharging/discharging by dynamically adjusting output based on real-time state of charge. Simulations using1000MW plant data demonstrate the strategy's superiority over conventional methods in suppressing frequency deviations and optimizing energy storage management.

title: Powered Descent Trajectory Optimization of Chandrayaan-3 using Radau Collocation and Controllable Sets
authors: Suraj Kumar, Aditya Rallapalli, Ashok Kumar Kakula, Bharat Kumar GVP
abstract: India achieved a significant milestone on August 23<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rd</sup> 2023, becoming the fourth country to accomplish a soft landing on the Moon. This paper presents the powered descent trajectory design for the Chandrayaan-3 mission. The optimization framework is based on pseudospectral Radau collocation, and controllability-based waypoint refinement is employed to further enhance the robustness of the trajectory against state and control perturbations. Furthermore, the trade-off between fuel consumption and robustness is explicitly quantified, providing insights into the practical considerations of mission planning.

title: Active Target–Attacker–Defender differential game framework for analyzing multiple differential drive robot interactions
authors: Harish Bhamitipadi Magesh, Ritabrata Mandal, Moon Chetry, Shyni Thomas, Bharath Bhikkaji, Puduru Viswanadha Reddy
abstract: In this paper, we present a dynamic game-theoretic framework for analyzing multi-agent interactions in military and defense applications. Specifically, we study a variation of the active target-attacker-defender differential game involving a target, an attacker, and multiple defenders. The framework enables defenders to autonomously switch operational modes—from rescuers (rendezvousing with the target) to interceptors (intercepting the attacker), and vice versa. Using the Games of a Degree approach, we model the interaction within each mode as a linear-quadratic differential game and derive feedback Nash equilibrium strategies. We then adopt a receding horizon approach to enable mode switching and compute the agents’ switching strategies. The framework also accommodates scenarios in which the number of agents changes over the course of the game. We illustrate our results using agents modeled as differential-drive mobile robots.

title: Blockchain and Digital Signature Convergence in Academic Research
authors: Aicha El Abidi, Hamid El Ghazi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Traditional digital signatures depend on centralized authorities to build confidence, while blockchain mitigates this issue by distributing trust across a network. Consequently, the integration of digital signatures within blockchain systems becomes very interesting. The purpose of this review is to examine blockchain and digital signature convergence within academic studies. This work is based on the PRISMA framework to assemble studies stored in academic database, linking blockchain to digital signatures. Through this study, the number of publications associating blockchain with digital signatures has increased, reflecting a greater focus on the research scope. The study emphasizes the contributing countries and organizations, the most prolific authors, the relevant journals and publications, and the main research keywords and subject areas, recognizing their importance and the multidisciplinary nature of this research field. This paper proposes an additional research agenda to enhance the security and authentication of data, to develop strategies for the implementation of blockchain and digital signatures, and to enlarge the body of knowledge.

title: A Method for Synthesizing a System for Adaptive Forming a Program Signal of the AUV Pitch Angle when It is Moved in a Vertical Plane
authors: Dmitry Yukhimets
abstract: Currently, autonomous underwater vehicles (AUV) perform various missions in difficult conditions, moving along the bottom with difficult terrain. At the same time, the safety of the AUV and the efficiency of its on-board equipment depend on the accuracy of the AUV movement in the vertical plane. The paper presents a method for synthesizing an adaptive system for generating a program signal for the pitch angle of AUV. This method allows you to form the desired value of the pitch angle to ensure such an angular velocity of the AUV along the pitch angle so that the thruster system can compensate for the negative torque of mutual influence between the AUV degrees of freedom. To do this, based on the equations of AUV motion in the vertical plane and the model of kinematics of the thruster system, the coefficient of conversion of the depth error into the desired pitch angle is calculated. This allows for precise control of the AUV depth during its movement at various speeds. The simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: The Features of the Design and Development of the Navigation System for the Manned Submersible Vehicle “Jason”
authors: Ekaterina Gavrilina, Anna Kurashina, Marat Agapov, Nikita Vintonyak, Aleksey Bogdanov, Nikolai Stasenko
abstract: To date, the National Research Centre "Kurchatov Institute" has completed the development and is finalizing construction and conducting dockside trials for the Project 03660 "Jason", a manned submersible vehicle (MSV) designed for operating at depths of up to 2,250 meters. The navigation system of this MSV should ensure not only high-quality of underwater work, but also ensure the safety of the crew. Therefore, it has increased requirements for accuracy and reliability. The core of the MSV's onboard navigation system is an inertial navigation system (INS) with an integrated doppler velocity log (DVL) and custom backup navigation algorithms which reserve coordinate estimation algorithms in case of INS fails. This paper presents the results of field trials of the navigation system conducted in Lake Ladoga at depths of up to 100 meters. The accuracy of both the INS and the backup navigation algorithms was evaluated in various configurations. The obtained navigation error was less than 0.2% of the distance traveled when the DVL was operating in bottom-tracking mode and less than 6.6% when the DVL was operating stably in water-mass layer mode. Emergency failures in the INS operation were identified. These failures, not described in the known literature or operation manuals of the commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) units, confirmed the necessity of developing a backup navigation system.

title: AI-Powered Project Control System: A Conceptual Framework for Continuous Assessment and Mitigation throughout Project Lifecycle
authors: Elham Zafarghandi, Kaveh Safaei, Omid Fatahi Valilai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The rapid evolution of project complexity in today's business environment demands more elaborate control mechanisms than traditional project management can provide. This paper proposes a framework for using artificial intelligence to transform project monitoring and control from start to finish. Recognizing that conventional approaches rely on periodic reports and analytics, the proposed system integrates machine learning algorithms, natural language processing, and predictive analytics to produce a dynamic and responsive project control environment. Through a review of the existing literature and practical observations from real-world implementations, this paper develops a five-module framework that addresses critical gaps in current project management practices. This proposed model performs monitoring and learning, predicting, and adapting in a way that provides project managers with unprecedented visibility into potential issues before they become problems. We recognize that this task faces inherent challenges in implementing AI in complex organizational structures, and considering this, the paper provides a practical roadmap for organizations seeking to modernize their project control capabilities.

title: Face Recognition Based Attendance System Using Machine Learning and Euclidean Distance
authors: Soham Garud, Abhilash Jadhav, Sachin Jadhav, Omkar Doiphode, Mitrakshi Patil
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Traditional attendance management systems relied heavily on manual methods such as roll calls, sign-in sheets, or ID card swiping. These conventional approaches were prone to human errors, time-consuming processes, and the risk of proxy attendance, where one individual marks attendance on behalf of another. Additionally, biometric methods like fingerprint scanners, though more secure, faced hygiene concerns, especially during public health crises, and suffered from device wear and tear. This paper presents an intelligent and automated Face Recognition-Based Attendance System leveraging machine learning techniques and Euclidean distance matching for accurate identity verification. In this product the niche feature is QR code scanning. All the registered students will have their name called upon scanning the QR code, followed by their live face verification. Only after both IN and OUT verification the student attendance is recorded by the APP. The system is also developed using a combination of VB.NET, C\#, Python, and MySQL for back-end integration, with XAMPP used for local server handling and database connectivity. This allows the flexibility to deploy the project as either a web application or mobile application. This, in turn, makes the product economical. Hence, it can be deployed in any sector of society. The integration of multiple platforms along with the machine learning model has led to the accuracy of 92 %. As the model is trained, the accuracy is expected to achieve 100 %. With the existing system having specifications of Intel Core i3 processor, 8GB RAM, and Windows 10 OS, the time required for attendance is 1.42 sec approx. This system aims to eliminate proxy attendance, reduce manual work, and enhance reliability in academic and professional environments.

title: FPGA-Accelerated SPHINCS+: An Area-Optimized and High-Throughput Design
authors: Yanfeng Bai, Bei Wang, Jiansheng Chen, Chenghua Wang, Yijun Cui, Weiqiang Liu
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Hardware implementations of SLH-DSA-compliant digital signatures encounter significant challenges related to computational latency and area due to the algorithm’s reliance on extensive hash computations. To address these issues, this paper introduces a novel signature architecture that leverages layer-aware parallel scheduling (LAS). This approach accelerates signing speeds while only minimally increasing resource usage in lightweight standard implementations. Additionally, we optimize the hardware implementation for six cryptographic hash functions to enhance signature generation speed. Subtree optimization further facilitates a more compact signature generation process, reducing resource requirements. Experimental results on the AMD Artix-7 FPGA demonstrate that the proposed design achieves signing speed that is $\mathbf{2. 3 3} \times$ faster, with $\mathbf{6 5 \%}$ improvement in area efficiency, and verification speed that is $2.97 \times$ faster, accompanied by 111% increase in area efficiency compared to the latest standard-compliant implementation.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based Dual Adaptive Model Predictive Control for Improved Path Tracking
authors: Joshua D’Souza, Keith J. Burnham, Luis J. Manso, James E. Pickering
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a fuzzy logic–based dual adaptive model predictive control (AMPC) framework for robust autonomous vehicle (AV) path tracking under varying road conditions. The framework integrates two AMPCs: one for lateral–yaw control and another for longitudinal control. The lateral controller regulates AV position and yaw, while the longitudinal controller manages the vehicle speed. A fuzzy inference system dynamically adjusts the lateral controller weights, and the reference longitudinal velocity based on specific road condition inputs, including road friction and path curvature. The controllers were designed and implemented in MATLAB and Simulink and evaluated using a standard double-lane-change manoeuvre. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in achieving integrated trajectory tracking and stability control for AVs.

title: SAM-based Unrectified Binocular Disparity Estimation
authors: Pan Zhou, Liangping Tu, Xu Wang, Guowen Kuang, Panpan Yuan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Stereo vision is a cornerstone of depth perception and environmental awareness for autonomous systems and robotics. However, prevailing methods are often limited by their reliance on pre-rectified images and pixel-level matching. Drawing inspiration from human vision, this paper introduces a novel disparity estimation method that operates directly on unrectified images by performing object-level matching. We leverage the Segment Anything Model (SAM), redesigning and fine-tuning its decoder to generate object-centric heatmaps. These heatmaps enable robust correspondence matching between objects across the two views. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed method achieves robust and accurate performance, even on challenging unrectified stereo pairs.

title: A Coupled Two-Stage PINN Driven by Physical and Data Factors for Combined Electromigration and Thermomigration Stress Prediction
authors: Shuhan Zhang, Zheyu Luo, Yumao Wu, Kaihui Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: The reliability of on-chip interconnects in modern integrated circuits is critically challenged by escalating current densities and Joule heating-induced temperature gradients, which intensify coupled electromigration (EM) and thermomigration (TM) effects, leading to complex stress evolution and potential premature failure. Traditional finite element method (FEM) simulations, though accurate, are computationally prohibitive for large-scale interconnects in Very Large Scale Integration Circuit (VLSI) designs. To address this, we propose a novel two-stage Physics-Informed Neural Network (PINN) framework for rapid and accurate prediction of coupled EM-TM-induced stress. The first stage uses a data-driven model to predict stress in individual wire segments, while the second stage employs a PINN to ensure atomic flux conservation and stress continuity at junctions of multisegment interconnects. By embedding governing partial differential equations into training, the framework learns the coupling between electrical, thermal, and mechanical phenomena. Experimental results on multisegment interconnects show excellent agreement with COMSOL simulations, with a mean relative error as low as 0.52 % and over 21.8x computational speedup, offering a scalable methodology for reliability analysis in advanced ICs.

title: Machine-Learning based Steer-by-Wire Road Feedback Generation for Real-Time Application
authors: Franz Forster, Matthias Schölzel, Steffen Müller
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: A key challenge in implementing Steer-by-Wire systems, which omit the mechanical link between steering wheel and front axle, is the dynamic reproduction of road excitation as steering torque feedback for the driver. This research focuses on generating feedback torque using data-based approaches building on measured driving dynamics data from a testing vehicle, as well as simulated data from a multibody simulation. Feedforward and recurrent neural networks are parameterized and trained using previously identified signals, with the resulting rack force and steering torque being compared to reference signals from a conventional steering system. The study utilizes feature generation methods to improve estimation accuracy, and the discussed machine learning estimators are implemented on testing hardware with their computational load being examined for real-time feasibility. The results demonstrate accurate feedback torque estimation of road excitation for both measurement-and simulation-trained neural networks.

title: CopyR-3DGS: Protecting the Copyright of 3D Gaussian Splatting Models
authors: Jia Liu, Lifeng Chen, Jinfeng Li, Yan Ke
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) technology has achieved remarkable results in the field of 3D reconstruction. Compared with Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF), it offers faster training speed and higher rendering quality. However, training 3DGS models—especially those for large-scale 3D scenes—consumes substantial training resources, and these models are at risk of theft. Therefore, protecting the copyright of 3DGS models should be a priority. This paper proposes CopyR-3DGS, a method for embedding watermarks in 3DGS rendering. Specifically, we design an optimization algorithm to embed watermark information into the 3DGS model through two-stage training, followed by extracting the watermark using a dedicated extractor. Experiments were conducted on multiple 3D scenes to evaluate the proposed method. The results demonstrate that our algorithm can accurately extract watermark information from images rendered by 3DGS models while maintaining high rendering quality.

title: A High-Efficiency DC-DC Boost Circuit with High Voltage Gain for Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Reyhaneh Nazarzadeh, Seyed Hossein Hosseini, Ebrahim Babaei, Mehran Sabahi
abstract: This study introduces a novel non-isolated high gain DC-DC conversion designed for renewable power applications. The presented circuit architecture attains significant voltage amplification through the use of coupled inductors, ensuring effective energy transfer without relying on extremely high duty cycles or large winding ratios. Owing to reduced voltage stress across semiconductor devices and passive components, low-voltage MOSFETs with small RDS (on) can be employed, minimizing conduction losses and improving overall efficiency. Furthermore, the design alleviates diode reverse-recovery issues and recovers leakage inductance energy, thereby enhancing operational performance. The converter is supplied by a single DC input source, and its operating principle, mathematical formulation, and simulation parameters are discussed comprehensively. A performance comparison with other existing high-gain architectures highlights improvements in efficiency and voltage boosting capability. Simulation results demonstrating conversion from 20 V to 180 V in PSCAD/EMTDC, along with experimental verification using a 200 W prototype, confirm the accuracy of analytical predictions and validate the practicality of the proposed converter.

title: Thermal3D-GS: Physics-induced 3D Gaussians for Thermal Infrared Novel-view Synthesis with a Large-Scale Dataset
authors: Qian Chen, Shihao Shu, Heng Sun, Junzhang Chen, Xiangzhi Bai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Thermal infrared imaging has attracted widespread attention in many fields due to the advantages of all-weather imaging and strong penetration. However, existing methods for thermal infrared novel-view synthesis often produce results with coarse details and floating artifacts, primarily caused by physical factors such as atmospheric transmission effects and thermal conduction. These challenges hinder accurate reconstruction of intricate structures and temperature distributions in thermal scenes, limiting the practical utility of previous approaches. To address these limitations, this paper introduces a physics-induced 3D Gaussian splatting method named Thermal3D-GS, the first novel-view synthesis method that relies exclusively on thermal infrared image. Thermal3D-GS begins by modeling atmospheric transmission effects and thermal conduction in three-dimensional media using neural networks. Additionally, considering the sparse features of infrared images, sparse feature priors are designed to improve the reconstruction accuracy of thermal infrared images. Furthermore, to validate the effectiveness of our method, the first large-scale benchmark dataset named Thermal Infrared Novel-view Synthesis Dataset (TI-NSD) is created. This dataset comprises 50 authentic thermal infrared video scenes, covering indoor, outdoor, traffic and UAV(Unmanned Aerial Vehicle) scenarios, with a total of 15,213 frames of thermal infrared image data. In addition, an expanded validation thermal infrared dataset, which includes three high-resolution scenes and five special scenes under varying atmospheric conditions and complex propagation media is constructed to assess generalization performance of the proposed method. Based on this dataset, this paper experimentally verifies the effectiveness of Thermal3D-GS. The results indicate that our method outperforms the baseline method with a 3.19 dB improvement in PSNR and significantly addresses the issues of floaters and indistinct edge features present in the baseline method. The dataset and our code are both publicly available in <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/mzzcdf/Thermal3DGS</uri>.

title: Sliding mode based optimal trajectory tracking control of 3-wheeled omnidirectional mobile robots*
authors: Ankur Deka, Basireddy Sandeep Reddy
abstract: This paper presents a controlled-time tracking approach for omnidirectional mobile robots using sliding mode control. Conventional sliding mode control is known for it’s advantageous order-reduction property and the coefficients of the sliding functions are usually chosen from the reduced-order system established on the sliding manifold. However, recent literature reveals that even the full-order system can be used for choosing sliding coefficients even when order-reduction is established. This has been done for planar holonomic systems like marine vehicles, which provides a motivating source for applying similar approaches to control omnidirectional mobile robots given their holonomic kinematics. A sliding mode controller is developed based on an optimal choice of the sliding coefficient using full-order lyapunov matrices. The control design parameters ensure decay of uncertain terms, while ensuring that the error trajectories reach the sliding manifold quickly and maintain smoothness when entering the manifold. The robustness of the closed-loop system is proved via Lyapunov theory. Numerical results support the proposed approach.

title: Retraction Notice: Sparse based Dimensionality Reduction for Big Data Management: SDN Perspective
authors: Rajnandani Pawar, Vinod Jadhav
publish: 2019 International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: Brainy Grid (BG) is a coordination of conventional power network with advanced data and communication framework for bidirectional vitality stream among grid together with end clients. An enormous measure of data is being created by different smart gadgets sent in BG frameworks. Such a gigantic information generation from different smart gadgets in BG frameworks may prompt different difficulties for the systems administration foundation conveyed among end clients and network. Consequently, an effective information transmission system is required for giving wanted QoS to clients in this condition. The high dimensions of information may influence the execution of majority of the designed solutions in this condition. Maximum of the current plans announced to have complex operation for the information dimensionality decrease issue which may decrement the execution of any actualized answer for this issue. To address these troubles, in this paper, Sparse-based dimensionality decrease for huge information is intended for dimensionality reduction issue of colossal data made from various smart Gadgets. First the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) is applied to high-order tensors (utilized for information portrayal) to limit the remaking mistake of the decreased tensors. Then VLCP (Software-defined networks(SDN) Controller) is used to broadcast the compressed data. The adequacy of the proposed plan has been assessed utilizing simulations completed on the information follows using Python and various libraries. The outcomes got portray the viability of the proposed plan concerning the parameters, for example, dimensionality reduction ratio and approximation accuracy.

title: Intelligent Output Voltage Regulation of DC-DC Boost Converter Via Optimal Extended State Observer
authors: Tahereh Taleshian, Jalil Sadati, Abolfazl Ranjbar Noiey, Milad Malekzadeh
abstract: In the present study, the output voltage of a DC-DC boost converter is tuned to a desired value by implementing a PI controller with two loops. To achieve this, the output voltage of the converter together with the inductor current must be available for the controller. Since direct measurement of these variables may not always be possible, an improved intelligent observer based on the PI-type extremum seeking control method is applied. This is to provide the estimation values of the inductor current and the input voltage of the converter. The observer operates online, requires minimum system information, and can reliably estimate these variables using only the measured output voltage. The estimated values are then provided into a double-loop controller which keeps the value of the output voltage at the pre-set value in the presence of input voltage variations. Furthermore, a comparison is made between the results achieved by the applied observer and those achieved by classic extended state observer and a sliding mode observer to demonstrate its superior estimation accuracy and robustness. The simulations are done in MATLAB™ and the results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method during accurately estimating system states under gradual input voltage changes.

title: Energy Optimization in HVAC Systems Based on Model Predictive Control Using Linearized Thermal Dynamic Model
authors: Ali Karimian, Nasser Masoumi
abstract: This paper presents the design of a Model Predictive Control (MPC) framework for the intelligent management of HVAC systems. The proposed framework simultaneously optimizes two conflicting objectives: minimizing energy consumption while maintaining thermal comfort. The controller leverages a dynamic building model to forecast future conditions and disturbances, formulating and solving a quadratic optimization problem to compute an optimal sequence of control signals. To validate its performance, the MPC controller was benchmarked against a conventional hysteresis controller. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves a 13.68% reduction in energy consumption while successfully maintaining the thermal comfort index within the desired range. This is achieved through its high adaptability to dynamic environmental changes, highlighting the potential of predictive control for enhancing energy efficiency and sustainability in modern buildings.

title: Variational Methods in Analytic Number Theory: A Unified Framework Inspired by Ramanujan’s Work
authors: Sunidhi Pandey, Akansha Vishwakarma, Shyam Kamal, R. K. Saket
abstract: This paper presents a rigorous unification of minimal energy control theory and variational methods in analytic number theory, drawing inspiration from Srinivasa Ramanujan’s seminal work. We develop detailed formulations with complete derivations for (1) optimal control of prime distributions, (2) variational extremization of arithmetic functions, and (3) theta function-based lattice energy minimization. Each problem is treated with full mathematical rigor while maintaining accessibility through step-by-step explanations of all calculations and motivations. The paper establishes novel connections between these disparate areas while providing concrete, implementable results.

title: RRT* Based Optimal Trajectory Generation with Linear Temporal Logic Specifications under Kinodynamic Constraints
authors: Saksham Gautam, Ratnangshu Das, Pushpak Jagtap
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel RRT*-based strategy for generating kinodynamically feasible paths that satisfy temporal logic specifications. Our approach integrates a robustness metric for Linear Temporal Logics (LTL) with the system’s motion constraints, ensuring that the resulting trajectories are both optimal and executable. We introduce a cost function that recursively computes the robustness of temporal logic specifications while penalizing time and control effort, striking a balance between path feasibility and logical correctness. We validate our approach with simulations and real-world experiments in complex environments, demonstrating its effectiveness in producing robust and practical motion plans. This work represents a significant step towards expanding the applicability of motion planning algorithms to more complex, real-world scenarios.

title: IoT-Based Dehydrator System for Fruits and Vegetables
authors: Norvin Aragones, Kenneth Roi Balilihan, Christian Paul Flaminiano, Maribelle Dequilla-Nicerio
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper explores the research and development involved in creating a mobile software application and integrating microcontrollers and sensors to build an Internet of Things (IoT)based fruits-and-vegetables dehydrator. The evolution of IoT and microcontrollers has opened promising avenues for developing sustainable solutions to societal problems, such as food waste. The development and implementation of smart IoT devices, such as the Smart IoT Fruits and Vegetables Dehydrator System, allow users to prolong the shelf life of their produce through dehydration. To assess the performance of the Dehydrator System, a pliability test was used to evaluate the quality of dehydrated fruits and vegetables. Descriptive statistics were employed to interpret the data, and hypothesis testing was conducted to determine whether the calculated critical value rejects or fails to reject the null hypothesis. With a sample size (n) of 50, a significance level of 0.05, and a one-tailed hypothesis, it was found that most of the passed samples had a critical value of 1.645, which is significantly higher than the null hypothesis value of 0.5. Therefore, the number of passed samples is greater than the failed samples, validating the heating capability of the dehydrator and its ability to produce high-quality dehydrated produce.

title: Reliability-oriented Optimal Scheduling of Interconnected Hydrogen -integrated Energy Hubs
authors: Mahdi Nozarian, Mohammad Namazizadeh
abstract: Today, concerns about the significant increase in energy demand, as well as global warming caused by fossil fuels, highlight the role of hydrogen in realizing future sustainable energy systems. In this context, integrating the capabilities of hydrogen with the energy hub (EH), as an efficient framework for optimal operation of multi-carrier infrastructures, can pave the way toward sustainability and energy efficiency. Accordingly, this paper employs a hydrogen-integrated energy hub (HIEH) framework, which combines the advantages of EHs in achieving energy efficiency with hydrogen's unique ability to store electrical energy, leading to synergies in efficiency, as well as improved redundancy and reliability. This research proposes a reliability-oriented framework that aims at optimal scheduling and efficient energy management for interconnected HIEHs. Numerical result from the simulation of the proposed model within the IEEE 33-bus test system in the distribution level, including 33 HIEHs, denote the efficiency of the proposed model. Key findings from the simulations of the proposed framework demonstrate significant improvements in reliability, renewable energy curtailment, operational costs, and exported energy to the upstream grid.

title: Optimizing Human-Exoskeleton Physical Interaction Through Spatial Trajectory Adaptation
authors: Mohammad Shushtari, Livia Murray, Atusa Ghorbani Siavashani, Arash Arami
abstract: This study presents and experimentally validates an adaptive control method for human-exoskeleton interaction through online adaptation of desired joint trajectories. Leveraging gait phase and human-exoskeleton interaction torque estimators, our approach enables seamless assistance adaptation to varying walking patterns and speeds. Specifically, a pre-trained neural network approximates the exoskeleton's dynamics, enabling real-time interaction torque estimation from kinematic measurements and commanded motor torques alone. These estimates drive a gradient-descent update of the joint reference trajectories, minimizing a cost function that penalizes both interaction torques and trajectory modification, ensuring bounded convergence and stability without user-specific parameter tuning. We compared our adaptive controller with a fixed-trajectory gait-phase-based controller during overground and treadmill walking at three self-selected speeds ranging from 0.4 to 0.8 m/s. In 16 participants, the adaptive controller significantly reduced the hip and knee interaction torques by 51.2%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>11.1 and 63.9%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>29.7, respectively, during overground walking. Muscular effort significantly decreased in Bicep Femoris (21.0%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>34.5) and Rectus Femoris (28.1%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>34.6), while remaining unchanged in other muscles. Cadence and gait speed increased by 7.6%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>5.2 and 10.7%<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>8.3, respectively, indicating that participants could walk faster with less effort due to trajectory adaptation. Post-adaptation trajectories more closely resembled those of walking without the exoskeleton, and exoskeleton-torques aligned more closely with human biological torques. Our proposed adaptive controller, which requires only exoskeleton kinematics, also maintained performance during treadmill walking across speeds, demonstrating speed-invariant behaviour compared to the non-adaptive controller.

title: Self-Modified Dynamic Domain Adaptation for Industrial Soft Sensing
authors: Zeyu Yang, Wenqing Gao, Gecheng Chen, Jiaxin Yu, Bocun He, Lingjian Ye
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Data-driven soft sensors have been widely applied to estimating important yet difficult-to-measure quality-relevant variables in industrial processes. The complex industrial data exhibits nonlinearity and dynamics due to changes in operating conditions. Soft sensors developed based on the assumption of identical and independent distributions often struggle to adapt to target domain data with significant distribution discrepancy, which poses a great challenge to traditional soft sensor approaches. Additionally, the dynamic features embedded in the practical industrial processes are of great importance for an accurate soft sensor. Existing soft sensor approaches pay little attention to the combined challenge of distribution discrepancy and dynamic feature transfer, referred to as the dynamic domain adaptation challenge. In this work, we propose a Self-modified Dynamic Domain Adaptation (SDDA) soft sensor approach to solve this problem. We develop a novel sequential optimization framework for dynamic domain adaptation, where the target samples are progressively incorporated and pseudo-labels are iteratively refined to preserve the underlying temporal dependency and enable efficient dynamic feature transfer. Also, we propose a feature alignment with the transfer component analysis (TCA) to avoid potential significant distribution discrepancy and guarantee a stable prediction. We demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method via two real-world industrial cases.

title: MSFFRN: Multimodal Spatial-Frequency Fusion and Refinement Network for Hyperspectral and LiDAR Data Classification
authors: Ke Wan, Dongyang Liu, Yunqiao Xi, Junping Zhang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The fusion of hyperspectral image (HSI) and light detection and ranging (LiDAR) data leverages complementary spectral and elevation information to improve land cover classification, yet its effectiveness is hindered by heterogeneous data distributions and a common oversight of frequency-domain information. To address this, we propose a novel multimodal spatial-frequency fusion and refinement network (MSFFRN). The framework is designed to holistically capture and fuse multimodal features. It employs a dual-branch architecture that integrates wavelet-based frequency decomposition with CNN-based spatial encoding for complementary feature extraction. Furthermore, a hierarchical fusion strategy using adaptive gating and cross-attention mechanisms dynamically integrates cross-modality and cross-domain information, while a dedicated feature refinement module enhances robustness against environmental distortions and preserves structural feature. Extensive experiments on the Houston 2013 and MUUFL datasets demonstrate that MSFFRN achieves state-of-the-art performance, increasing the overall accuracy (OA) by 2.66% and 1.32% on the respective datasets.

title: A Dual Circularly Polarized Phased Array Antenna with Enhanced Polarization Purity for Multi-Azimuth Plane Scanning
authors: Yu-Hang Yang, Si-Cong Wang, Zhe-Jun Zhu, Yun-Hong Zhang, Ling-Kai Zhang, Xi-Long Lu, Shi-Gang Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents an 8×8 dual circularly polarized (DCP) phased array antenna and an associated analysis framework for achieving high polarization purity during wide-angle, multi-azimuth-plane circularly polarized (CP) beam scanning. First, polarization-incorporated array factors are formulated for 2×2 sequential-rotation (SR) subarrays and extended to large arrays, enabling explicit prediction of the right-handed and left-handed CP radiation patterns. The analysis shows that SR yields ideally pure circular polarization in the main beam direction under the simplifying assumption that, for a fixed elevation angle, the phase of the element RHCP component is invariant with respect to the azimuth angle φ (and analogously for the LHCP component) but inevitably generates cross-polarized (Cross-pol.) lobes in off-boresight directions, whose angular locations depend on the beam steering angle and inter-element spacing, whereas their peak magnitude is fundamentally bounded by the axial ratio (AR) of the array elements. Guided by this analysis, a compact self-phase-shifting DCP element operating at 5.7–5.9 GHz is developed, exhibiting port isolation exceeding 15 dB. An 8×8 DCP phased array composed of 2×2 SR minimum periodic subarrays is then designed, fabricated, and measured. Simulation results show that, during ±60° beam scanning in the φ = 0°, 45°, 90°, and 135° planes, the active VSWR remains below 2.0 within ±45° and below 3.0 within ±60°, while the AR in the main-beam direction is kept below 1.18 dB and Cross-pol. levels in the entire upper hemisphere are at least 15 dB lower than the peak co-polarized gain. Measurements confirm a slight (0.05 GHz) upward shift of the operating band and validate the predicted wide-angle, high-polarization-purity DCP performance.

title: Research on Online Identification and Compensation Methods for Uneven Damping in Hemispherical Resonator Gyroscopes
authors: Lishan Yuan, Zhennan Wei, Guoxing Yi, Qingshuang Zeng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Uneven damping can reduce the measurement accuracy, stability, and output accuracy of a hemispherical resonator gyroscope. A targeted calibration method has been proposed to reduce the uneven damping of gyroscopes. This method identifies the parameters of uneven damping online through amplitude control force, and obtains the specific characteristics and data of uneven damping in real time. On this basis, a virtual precession compensation force is constructed based on the identification results, and this compensation force is used to actively counteract the standing wave drift caused by uneven damping, thereby weakening the impact of uneven damping on the gyroscope output. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed calibration method, relevant experiments were conducted. The experimental results show that this calibration method can accurately identify the damping non-uniformity error parameters of the gyroscope, and effectively compensate for the error through virtual precession compensation force, significantly reducing the standing wave drift caused by uneven damping, and ultimately further improving the output accuracy of the hemispherical resonator gyroscope.

title: Automated Generation and Evaluation of Synthetic Dataset for Urban Tree Perception
authors: Sofia Cedenilla Aguado, Beatriz Martin Molina, Hafsa Iqbal, Jaime Godoy Calvo, Alejandro Salazar Gomez, Daniel Serrano Dominguez, Abdulla Al-Kaff, Fernando Garcia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Object detection in an urban environments is essential for autonomous driving, yet collecting and annotating real-world datasets is resource-intensive. This paper presents an automatic annotation pipeline using the CARLA simulator to generate a synthetic dataset of urban trees across various environments and weather conditions. A perception model is then trained for tree detection, and multiple training strategies are employed for systematic evaluation, including pretraining with synthetic data, fine-tuning with real-world data, and sequential fine-tuning. Performance is assessed using precision, recall and F1 score across real-world data. Results show that pretraining with synthetic dataset substantially reduces the amount of real data required to achieve high performance, with as little as 10% of real data needed to double the F1 score compared to training on synthetic data alone. Furthermore, sequential fine-tuning, starting from COCO-pretrained weights, followed by synthetic and real data, achieves the highest accuracy. These findings highlight the effectiveness of synthetic data and fine-tuning for efficient and robust urban object detection.

title: Study on Robotic Arm Operation for the Panel of Simulated Aircraft Cockpit Based on Two-Stage Visual Localization
authors: Jibao Dai, Chao Li, Maosong Ma, Kai Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: When performing precise operations of small-scale, high-density keys on aircraft simulation cockpit panel, the installation offset of the robotic arm can lead to insufficient key positioning accuracy. This paper proposes a two-stage visual localization method to guide the robotic arm to perform precise operations. First, in the global field of view, the target area is quickly located through the first template matching. Secondly, perform a second template match after the robotic arm has moved above the target area. Since the simulation cockpit panel contains circular and rectangular keys, different strategies are used to extract the central pixel coordinates based on the differences in their geometric features. After obtaining the two-dimensional (2D) pixel coordinates, convert them to the three-dimensional (3D) operating space coordinate system of the robotic arm via the eye-in-hand calibration transformation matrix and the robotic arm kinematics coordinate conversion chain. Taking the A320 Flight Control Unit (FCU) panel as the experimental object, the results show that when the FCU undergoes a horizontal translation of 50 mm and a rotation of 6° in the horizontal plane, the visual recognition success rate remains above 95%, and the robotic arm operation success rate remains above 93%.

title: Integrated Quadruped–UAV Robotic Platform for Efficient Construction Site Inspection
authors: Yan Zeng, Zhou Song, Shiyu Tian, Guozhong Cheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) play an important role in construction site inspection due to their mobility and wide field of view. However, limited endurance severely restricts their continuous operation. In this paper, a quadruped-UAV integrated inspection system is proposed. The quadruped robot provides autonomous charging services for UAVs while also conducting ground-level inspection. For enhanced performance, we upgraded the UAV's battery power management unit, which decreased charging time by 50% and elevated the efficiency of automated inspection protocols.

title: Analysis and identification of physiological profiles for cognitive load modeling in conditioned autonomous driving using unsupervised analysis and clustering
authors: Evelyn Vásquez, Alejandra Feo, Edgael Negron, Jorge Colon, Juan Peña, Juan Felipe Medina-Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: In conditional autonomous driving systems, one of the primary challenges is ensuring that drivers respond in a timely and safe manner when their intervention is required, especially if they have lost situational awareness. This study investigates the variation in physiological indicators among individuals during autonomous driving. To this end, simulated scenarios were designed in which participants experienced two conditions: autonomous driving with active environmental observation, and autonomous driving while performing cognitive distraction tasks. Electrocardiogram signals and electrodermal activity were collected to identify activation patterns during the experiment’s progression. These findings provide valuable information for the development of artificial intelligence models that can estimate a driver’s attentional state in real-time, thereby improving safety and human-machine interaction. The results show significant differences in physiological responses among individuals, highlighting the importance of considering personalized profiles.

title: An Ultra-Thin, Miniaturized and Broadband Design of Metasurface Absorber
authors: Jiajie Yuan, Wenhua Gu, Yanghui Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: To address the electromagnetic interference issue in miniaturized microwave systems, this paper proposes a high-performance microwave metamaterial absorber with ultra-thin, ultra-small period, and broadband absorption characteristics. Using a Polygonal-shape indium tin oxide (ITO) conductive structure as the upper surface resonant layer, the designed absorber has an overall thickness (0.4 mm) equivalent to only 0.04 times the central absorption wavelength (29.3 GHz), and a periodic length (0.5 mm) equivalent to just 0.05 times the central absorption wavelength. It achieves an absorption rate exceeding 90% within the (27.0-31.6)GHz frequency range.

title: Cooperative Dubins-Based Task Planning for Multiple UAVs in Complex Obstacle Environments
authors: Huizhong Liu, Yankun Wang, Mingxue Tang, Dong Zhu, Weiran Yao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: The cooperative planning of multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAV) for multi-target missions has gained increasing attention in recent years. This problem comprises three interdependent subproblems: task allocation, path planning, and cooperative optimization Under multiple constraints, these three subproblems are inherently coupled, influencing the overall effectiveness of the cooperative mission. This paper presents an integrated approach to address these challenges. First, a fair and optimal task allocation strategy is proposed, leveraging a distributed auction mechanism and optimization modeling to achieve balanced task distribution among UAVs. Second, a pruning-bridging-backtracking Dubins path planning framework is developed to facilitate smooth trajectory generation in complex environments with obstacles. Finally, particle swarm optimization (PSO) combined with local search is employed for cooperative path optimization. Simulation results confirm that the proposed method effectively enhances safety and synchronization in multi-UAV multi-target synchronous planning within complex obstacle-laden environments.

title: Comparative Study of Hands-on-Wheel Detection Using Wearable LSTM and Camera-Based Vision Models for Driver Monitoring
authors: Juan Camilo Peña, Alanis Negroni Santiago, Diego Martínez García, Evelyn Vásquez, Juan Felipe Medina-Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Hands-on-wheel detection plays a critical role in improving safety within Autonomous Driving Systems, as it helps verify the driver’s readiness to retake control when necessary. This becomes especially important in intermediate levels of automation (such as SAE Levels 2 and 3), where the vehicle is not fully autonomous and cannot manage all driving situations. In such cases, timely driver intervention is required to ensure safe operation during transitions between automated and manual control. This paper presents and compares two different methodologies for automatic Hands-on-wheel detection. The first leverages wearable sensors, specifically, wrist-mounted devices to capture motion data, which is then processed using a Long Short-Term Memory neural network for binary classification. To validate the performance of the proposed system, it was compared with a camera-based computer vision system trained with convolutional models to detect hand presence from visual input. Experimental results showed that wearable-based systems provide a viable alternative to vision-based solutions, offering benefits such as enhanced user privacy. These findings position wearable devices as a viable alternative for integration into real-time driver monitoring frameworks.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Weather-Induced Sensor Occlusion on BEVFusion for 3D Object Detection
authors: Sanjay Kumar, Tim Brophy, Eoin Martino Grua, Ganesh Sistu, Valentina Donzella, Ciarán Eising
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Accurate 3D object detection is essential for automated vehicles to navigate safely in complex real-world environments. Bird’s Eye View (BEV) representations, which project multi-sensor data into a top-down spatial format, have emerged as a powerful approach for robust perception. Although BEV-based fusion architectures have demonstrated strong performance through multimodal integration, the effects of sensor occlusions, caused by environmental conditions such as fog, haze, or physical obstructions, on 3D detection accuracy remain underexplored. In this work, we investigate the impact of occlusions on both camera and Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) outputs using the BEVFusion architecture, evaluated on the nuScenes dataset. Detection performance is measured using mean Average Precision (mAP) and the nuScenes Detection Score (NDS). Our results show that moderate camera occlusions lead to a 41.3% drop in mAP (from 35.6% to 20.9%) when detection is based only on the camera. On the other hand, LiDAR sharply drops in performance only under heavy occlusion, with mAP falling by 47.3% (from 64.7% to 34.1%), with a severe impact on long-range detection. In fused settings, the effect depends on which sensor is occluded: occluding the camera leads to a minor 4.1% drop (from 68.5% to 65.7%), while occluding LiDAR results in a larger 26.8% drop (to 50.1%), revealing the model’s stronger reliance on LiDAR for the task of 3D object detection. Our results highlight the need for future research into occlusion-aware evaluation methods and improved sensor fusion techniques that can maintain detection accuracy in the presence of partial sensor failure or degradation due to adverse environmental conditions.

title: Adaptive AI Systems for Personalized Cancer Treatment Plans
authors: Selvapandian, Monali Gulhane, Shweta Jain, Nitin Rakesh, Vishal Salve, Nilesh P. Sable
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Personalised cancer treatment plans are very important for better patient results because they adapt medicines to each person's genetics, lifestyle, and illness. This essay talks about the creation and use of adaptable AI systems that are meant to make personalised plans for treating cancer. Machine learning methods, especially deep learning models, are used to handle huge amounts of clinical, genetic, and medical imaging data. By combining different types of data, flexible AI systems can always improve treatment suggestions, making drug regimens, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy more effective. These systems use predictive analytics to guess how the tumour will grow and how well the treatment will work, which lets therapy plans be changed in real time. AI models can also help find signs that can be used to find cancer early and predict how a patient will react to certain treatments, which makes precision medicine better. This flexible framework makes sure that treatment plans don't stay the same, but change as new patient data and clinical insights are added. This makes cancer care very personalized. Incorporating adaptable AI into cancer treatment plans could also help with the problems caused by different types of cancer and treatment resistance. The end goal of this AI-driven way is to help cancer patients live longer, have fewer side effects, and have a better quality of life generally.

title: D-TRACK: A Framework for Complexity Risks in Railway Digital Transformation Projects
authors: Maricruz Solera Jimenez, Giacomo Barbieri, Jan Braaksma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: While Digital Transformation (DT) in railways promises significant benefits, it also introduces substantial complexity across technical, organizational, and institutional domains. These challenges must be recognized and addressed from the front-end phase of DT projects, where early risk identification is critical to project success. In response to the absence of a framework tailored to the unique characteristics of railway DT initiatives, this paper introduces D-TRACK (Digital Transformation RAilway Complexity frameworK) – a structured tool designed to support the early identification of complexity-related risks in railway DT projects. Building on the UK National Audit Office (NAO) Delivery Environment Complexity Analytic (DECA) framework, D-TRACK integrates domain-specific sources and practitioner insights to reflect the distinctive realities of the railway sector. The framework comprises twelve complexity factors organized into four overarching dimensions, each supported by guiding questions that enable a structured and systematic risk identification process. To validate D-TRACK, a serious game (SG)-style workshop was conducted with eleven experts in digitalization and railway operations. The workshop confirmed that D-TRACK effectively met its three core design objectives: railway relevance, digitalization compatibility, and risk identification support. In addition, participant feedback underscored the broader value of SGs – not only as validation tools but also as enablers of team alignment during the formative stages of complex projects.

title: Towards Robust IoT Security: An ML and DL-Based Threat Detection Framework
authors: Sachin Shankarao Ajmire, Aniket Wankhade, Karuna Vivekanand Agarkar, Shailesh Thakare, Kanak Kishor Shahale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The exponential growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem has enhanced automation, interconnectivity, and real-time monitoring across multiple domains. However, this massive expansion has also introduced complex cybersecurity challenges due to the heterogeneous and distributed nature of IoT devices. Traditional signature-based security methods fail to address these evolving threats effectively. This research presents a hybrid framework integrating Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) models to detect and classify cyber threats in IoT environments. The framework combines anomaly detection and classification subsystems for improved identification of both known and novel attacks. Experiments conducted using benchmark datasets such as UNSW-NB15 and BoT-IoT demonstrate that the hybrid approach achieves superior accuracy, precision, and recall compared to conventional models. The proposed framework establishes a foundation for building adaptive, real-time, and scalable IoT security mechanisms.

title: Sparse Structure Learning via ADMM in Networks Obeying Conservation Laws
authors: Rohith Reddy Mada, Rajasekhar Anguluri
abstract: Learning the edge connectivity structure of networked systems from limited data is a fundamental challenge in many critical infrastructure domains, including power, traffic, and finance. Such systems obey steady-state conservation laws: x = L<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∗</sup>y, where x and y ∈ ℝ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</sup> represent injected flows (inputs) and potentials (outputs), respectively. The sparsity pattern of the p×p Laplacian L<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∗</sup> encodes the underlying edge structure. In a stochastic setting, the goal is to infer this sparsity pattern from zero-mean i.i.d. samples of y.Recent work by [1] has established statistical consistency results for this learning problem by considering an ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>-regularized maximum likelihood estimator. However, their approach did not develop a scalable algorithm but relies on solving a convex program via the CVX package. To address this gap, we propose an alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM), which is transparent and fast. A key contribution is to demonstrate the role of an algebraic matrix Riccati equation in the primal update step of ADMM. Numerical experiments on a host of synthetic and benchmark networks, including power and water systems, show the efficiency of our method.

title: Optimal Power Dispatch from Battery and Engine of a Hybrid Vehicle through Multiparametric Mixed-Integer Programming
authors: Uthraa K. Ramesh, Parth R. Brahmbhatt, Gavin D. Quam, Styliani Avraamidou, Hari S. Ganesh
abstract: Optimal control of hybrid vehicles involving a battery and a combustion engine is necessary for efficient energy management, and this optimal control problem (OCP) can be formulated as a mixed-integer program (MIP). The real-time deployment of MIPs is challenging due to their computational complexity. As the number of integer variables increases, the solution space increases exponentially, requiring computationally expensive methods to solve. Although machine learning-based strategies help reduce computation time, they provide approximate, but not exact, solutions to MIPs and may even involve expensive one-time training, employing heavy computational resources. In this work, a multiparametric (mp) programming framework is used to improve the computation time of an OCP for hybrid vehicles while getting the exact solution; furthermore, the mp-programming framework allows for implementation through low-cost hardware like a chip without needing a computer. In the mp-programming approach, the solution is expressed as a set of piecewise linear functions in terms of the uncertain parameters that change with time. During online calculations, the optimal solution is determined through a point location search procedure. This framework is compared with the state-of-the-art branch-and-bound method in the Gurobi solver and a neural network solver model developed in this work.

title: Efficient Grasp Detection via Knowledge Distillation: A Lightweight Generative Grasping Convolutional Neural Network Framework
authors: Sheng-Kai Chen, Jie-Yu Chao, Po-Lien Wu, Jr-Yu Chang, Po-Chiang Lin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Despite the effectiveness of deep neural networks in robotic grasp detection, deploying them on resource-constrained platforms remains challenging due to high computational demands.
