title: Machine Learning - Based Analysis of Driving Performance and Fatigue - Induced Behavioral Factors
authors: Passawich Boonnuch, Manida Swangnetr Neubert, Pisit Jarumaneeroj, Kultida Rojviboonchai, Peerapon Vateekul, Nuksit Noomwongs, Pramual Suteecharuwat
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Fatigue remains a critical safety concern among long-haul truck drivers, often compromised driving capability. This study proposes a machine learning-based approach that integrates AI camera-detected behavioral events, demographic and occupational characteristics to predict fatigue-related performance degradation. Data were collected over 300 days from 85 truck drivers. Their performance was labelled into three classes: Normal, Reduced, and High-Risk Capability, based on predefined deviation in driving responses. Three data conditions were examined: system-detected, weighted, and verified events. A total of 43 machine learning algorithms with default settings were used for multi-class classification across various timeframe (15, 30, 45 and 60 minutes) before performance deviation occurred. Results showed that demographic and work-related factors improved accuracy in all conditions. The best performance (over 80%) was achieved under the verified-event condition with a 15-minute timeframe, indicating the benefit of short-timeframe monitoring for early fatigue detection. Feature importance analysis identified yawning and continuous driving as primary behavioral indicators, while age, driving experience, shift, and to a lesser extent, habitual alcohol consumption were key demographic and occupational factors associated with fatigue-induced capability reduction. These findings demonstrate the value of integrating validated event data, driver characteristics, and monitoring time window for effective fatigue risk assessment in transport operations.

title: Disturbance Analysis with Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control for UAVs
authors: Sunil Kumar, Asifa Yesmin, Twinkle Tripathy, Arpita Sinha, Anirban Guha
abstract: This paper presents a disturbance analysis for a quadcopter system using various disturbance models. A super-twisting sliding mode controller (STSMC) is developed to address the disturbances modeled by the Von Karman wind turbulence model (VKWTM), Dryden wind turbulence model (DWTM), and a time-varying disturbance (TVD) profile. These disturbance models are employed to simulate turbulent wind gusts for disturbance modeling. The stability of the proposed control scheme is rigorously verified using Lyapunov stability theory. The performance of VKWTM, DWTM, and TVD, in terms of tracking error and control effort, is evaluated through a comparative table. A series of simulations are conducted in MATLAB, incorporating each disturbance model to evaluate the controller’s performance. The simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed control strategy under different disturbance conditions.

title: Efficient Multi-designated Receiver Authenticated Broadcast Encryption for Group Messaging
authors: Zhao Zhang, Chunxiang Xu, Chuhan Ma
abstract: Communication protocol is a fundamental component of modern networking. With proliferation of networking and communication, users have become more concerned about privacy. This leads to development of end-to-end encrypted messaging systems which provides confidential communication. Besides confidentiality, there is an increasing demand for additional security properties such as unforgeability, anonymity, off-the-record (OTR), and consistency. However, efficiently achieving these properties simultaneously, especially on resource-constrained mobile devices, remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose MERIT, a novel multi-designated receiver authenticated broadcast encryption scheme that satisfies all the above security guarantees in a highly efficient manner. MERIT ensures the following key properties: (i) unforgeability prevents unauthorized parties from generating valid messages; (ii) privacy safeguards the messages and identities of the sender and receivers from non-designated parties; (iii) OTR ensures that receivers cannot later prove the origin of the messages even with their secret keys; and (iv) consistency ensures that all designated receivers obtain identical decrypted messages and identities. The core building block of MERIT is a practical multi-designated verifier signature (PMDVS), which might be of independent interest. We employed a novel batched cut-and-choose technology to prove that the ciphertext is well-formed. This results in an order-of-magnitude efficiency improvement in our scheme compared to its counterparts that rely on general-purpose zero-knowledge proofs. We then show how MERIT leverages PMDVS to provide unforgeability, privacy, OTR, and consistency in the scenario of group messaging. We provide security analysis to demonstrate that MERIT satisfies these security guarantees. We also conduct a thorough performance implementation, and the experimental results demonstrate that MERIT is highly efficient for deployment on mobile devices.

title: A Method for Generating Elevator Detection Video Texts Based on Semantic Recognition
authors: Hongyi Chen, Yuhui Peng, Yixiang Yuan, Zhanbin Zhang, Yujie Chen, Jianhong Gan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: When retrieving and checking elevator inspection videos, manual processing has problems, such as low efficiency, strong subjectivity. This paper proposes a video-to-text method based on semantic segmentation and other language models. The model converts elevator inspection videos into texts by means of keyframe extraction, semantic recognition and segmentation, dual-path feature encoding, and text generation using the Blip model. It uses dual-path feature encoding. By fusing the encoded Mask features from UNet and the features of the input images, the model provides image semantic support for accurate text generation. A collaborative loss function is proposed, which weights the cross-entropy losses of UNet, BLIP model, and real labels. Experimental results show that the proposed model has better performance in terms of CIDEr and SPICE, such as BLIP2 and LLaVA. The CIDEr is 123.7, which is 2.7 to 5.4 times higher than other models. The SPICE is 18.9, which is 2.7 to 5.4 times higher than other models. It can accurately identify elevator parts (such as drive motors) and generate professional descriptions. It effectively improves the quality and efficiency of generating inspection text and provides technical support for smarter elevator inspection.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Adaptive Voltage Support for Grid-Forming Converters
authors: Kamran Moradi, Qobad Shafiee, Hassan Bevrani
abstract: Maintaining PCC voltage in statutory limits in active distribution networks with high inverter-based resources (IBRs) is challenging due to high R/X feeders, stochastic load/generation, and frequent topology changes that render fixed droop parameters suboptimal. This paper formulates PCC voltage support as real-time reactive power regulation grid-forming converters (GFMCs) subject to inverter current limits and uncertain operating conditions, without reliance on an accurate network model. The paper proposes an online reinforcement learning-based control strategy for adaptive voltage support of GFMCs. A state–action–reward–state–action agent dynamically adjusts the proportional-integral coefficients of the outer reactive power control loop of supervisory layer to regulate the PCC voltage via reactive power injection. The controller is model-free and learns an optimal policy in real-time, balancing voltage regulation with operational constraints such as inverter current limits. The proposed controller has been verified in MATLAB/SIMULINK environment. Relative to a fixed-gain droop baseline with out the supervisory layer, the method exhibited faster and better-damped reactive power response and reduced voltage deviation, while respecting inverter capability constraints.

title: Value-Based Reinforcement Learning for Mapless Navigation of a Mobile Robot
authors: Dilli Bhaskar, Ayyappadas Rajagopal, Nandagopan Kalathil, Shaikshavali Chitraganti
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has demonstrated excellent performance in various domains. However, learning continuous control is a challenging problem as it requires a relatively more samples for training. Many DRL methods aim to improve sample efficiency through various exploration methods and state-of-the-art actor-critic and policy gradient methods. However, this often comes at the cost of a high amount of computational resources. Motivated by the success of value-based methods for approximating state-action values, such as the radial basis function deep Q-network (RBF-DQN), we explore the potential of value-based DRL for learning continuous control for mobile robot navigation using sparse LiDAR findings. Our comparative study against the state-of-the-art actor-critic algorithm reveals the potential of the value-based DRL for learning continuous robotic navigation tasks through action maximization and accurate value function approximation. The findings highlight the RBF-DQN model’s superior performance, comparable to state-of-the-art actor-critic methods, and its enhanced sample efficiency in achieving successful navigation and goal completion in both simulated and real-time mapless navigation.

title: A Style Transfer-Based Method for Land Cover Segmentation in Power Grid Project Remote Sensing Images
authors: Wei Li, YangYi Zhou, Kang Ding, YanJun Guo, KeYang Sun, Jian Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Substation Site Selection and Transmission Line Route Planning represent a complex systems engineering task involving multiple natural and socio-geographical factors. Traditional manual survey methods face limitations such as low efficiency and high costs, while existing deep learning approaches for land cover segmentation in remote sensing imagery encounter two major challenges: firstly, insufficient model generalization capability due to geographical, meteorological, and sensor variations; secondly, the inability of conventional pixel-level segmentation results to directly generate the vector data required for engineering design.To tackle these issues, this paper proposes a deep domain adaptation method for remote sensing image-based land cover classification. The approach begins by employing a style-transfer network to reduce apparent disparities between source and target domains at the pixel level. Subsequently, a dual-branch semantic segmentation architecture is utilized to achieve domain adaptation at the feature level, significantly enhancing the model's generalization capacity in new geographical regions. Addressing engineering application needs, an innovative land cover vectorization module has been developed to enable direct conversion from pixel-level segmentation to georeferenced contours.Validation tests conducted on a proprietary dataset demonstrate that the proposed two-stage domain adaptation mechanism – integrating style transfer and feature alignment – effectively mitigates performance degradation caused by weather, seasonal, and regional factors. This method successfully resolves the dual challenges of cross-domain generalization and engineering applicability, providing reliable technical support for the digital design of power transmission and transformation projects.

title: A High Parameters Tolerance CPT System with Constant Voltage Output
authors: Haiyun Xu, Zhiping Zuo, Lei Zhao, Xiaohuan Wang, Xiao Yang, Haoyang Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Electric-field coupled wireless power transfer systems offer advantages such as low eddy current loss, minimal electromagnetic radiation, and a simple structure, which makes it suitable for UAVs wireless charging. However, when the electrode plates are misaligned, it can cause parameter disturbances, and frequency splitting may occur when the spacing between the electrode plates decreases. This paper proposes a PT-CPT architecture based on parity-time (PT) symmetry theory, clearly defining the coupling mechanisms of plate misalignment, capacitance perturbation, and frequency drift. This paper optimally selects the push-pull inverter and bilateral LC compensation topology. The mechanisms of system detuning and frequency splitting are analyzed, and the conditions and efficiency expressions for the bilateral LC compensated PT-CPT system under PT symmetry are derived, verifying that the system can achieve constant power and constant efficiency output in a PT-symmetric state. The overall design of the PT-CPT scheme is completed. Additionally, LTspice circuit simulations validate the effectiveness of the theoretical model, The system is capable of maintaining a stable output voltage when the resistance changes from 20 to 100 ohms and the coupling coefficient varies from 200 to 1200. The research results provide new theoretical foundations and technological pathways for the design of high parameter tolerance CPT systems.

title: Decoupling Analysis of Carbon Emissions and Economic Growth in the Power Sector
authors: Congcong Mu, Jingyu Fan, Zhenkun Wang, Yujing Xue, Pengsheng Liu, Hailiang Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This work investigates the dynamic coupling relationship between carbon emissions and economic growth in the power sector from 2000 to 2022, with a focus on its evolutionary characteristics and driving factors. A decoupling index model is constructed by integrating the Tapio elasticity approach and the OECD decoupling index, through which the decoupling states of carbon emissions and economic growth are examined. Furthermore, the Logarithmic Mean Divisia Index decomposition method is employed to identify the major determinants of carbon emissions. The results reveal that the relationship between carbon emissions and economic growth in the power sector is complex and has shifted across different states, including expansion negative decoupling, strong decoupling, expansion coupling, and weak decoupling. Specifically, population growth and economic development are the dominant forces driving the increase in carbon emissions, while improvements in energy intensity and energy structure partially mitigate this effect. These findings provide policy implications for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality targets, such as optimizing the energy mix, enhancing energy efficiency, and strengthening environmental regulations.

title: Assessing the Probability of Detection in a Frequency-Selective EMD Detector: A Design Perspective
authors: Xinting Xue, Tim Claeys, Davy Pissoort
abstract: Electronic devices exposed to complex electromagnetic environments can fail at specific frequencies. Early, frequency-selective detection of such “weak spots” is therefore desirable, whereas time-domain field probes provide only broadband indications and may over-trigger. This article presents a frequency-selective detector based on software-defined radio with field-programmable gate array acceleration, which transforms time-domain samples into spectra with reduced latency. The study focuses on narrowband burst electromagnetic disturbances and develops closed-form expressions for the probability of detection as a function of front-end bandwidth, frequency span, dwell time, hopping time, frequency resolution, and disturbance duration. The analysis is corroborated by Monte Carlo simulation and conducted measurements across 70 MHz–6 GHz. Results reveal how design choices and hardware latencies bound the attainable detection probability and delineate the hopping-limited regime. This article concludes with practical boundary conditions and design guidelines to maximize detection performance under resource constraints, offering a configurable alternative where high-end real-time analysers are impractical.

title: Beyond Black Boxes: Trustworthy and Energy-Efficient IoT Systems for Extended Lifespan and Reduced Bias in Remote Health Monitoring
authors: Constantino Álvarez Casado, Mehdi Safarpour, Le Nguyen, Jacobo Cabaleiro, Sasan Sharifipour, Praneeth Susarla, Manuel Lage Cañellas, Abhishek Kumar, Matteo Pedone, Miguel Bordallo López
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: The growing demand for real-time, continuous health monitoring in clinical and human-machine interaction contexts motivates local, on-device video analysis using edge computing and artificial intelligence (AI) on resource-constrained hardware. A key challenge lies in the computational and energy costs of monolithic end-to-end deep learning models, which often exceed the capabilities of Internet of Things (IoT) devices. We argue for a hardware-aware, modular design that integrates efficient deep models for well-defined perceptual tasks (e.g., face detection) with physiology-grounded algorithms for sensitive, data-scarce inferences such as affective state. As a case study, we implemented a lightweight pipeline for depression detection using remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) and traditional regression, comparing it to a monolithic deep learning baseline on embedded hardware. The lightweight pipeline maintains 30 frames per second and more than doubles the battery life, while the deep learning model did not meet real-time constraints, highlighting the practical advantage of a modular sustainable design. Beyond efficiency, this approach enhances trustworthiness and privacy by enabling transparent signal processing and reducing the need to transmit raw video. We conclude with design principles grounded in human-centered and value-sensitive perspectives, emphasizing interpretability, modularity, and energy efficiency for scalable and privacy-preserving physiological monitoring on the edge.

title: Modeling and Control of an H-Configuration Quadrotor with Foldable Arms
authors: Neelam Verma, Armaan Bhandari, Sathyanarayanan Seshasayanan, Soumya Ranjan Sahoo, Abhilash Patel
abstract: This paper presents the dynamic modeling and control design for an H-configuration quadrotor equipped with folding arms. This morphing mechanism enables decoupled lateral motion and roll angle control, which is not achievable in a conventional quadrotor. The proposed control architecture employs a two-loop orientation control and a single-loop position control using PID controllers. A constant control allocation matrix is used to map the desired control forces and moments to actuator inputs. This approach enhances computational efficiency by allowing the allocation matrix to be hardcoded into the controller. MATLAB simulations are carried out to validate the proposed control scheme and demonstrate accurate tracking of all five degrees of freedom.

title: Prompt Complexity and Plan Stability: Benchmarking On-Device Language Planning for Robots
authors: Dennis Lehmann, Roman Laas, Marko Harasic, Adrian Paschke
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper investigates whether publicly available small-and medium-scale language models, used without task-specific fine-tuning, can serve as a language-based planning layer for robotic manipulation entirely on-device. We present a reproducible pipeline on an embedded GPU platform (NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin with Ollama) that maps natural language instructions to a minimal action vocabular and incorporates a validation/feedback loop with bounded retries. The framework records completion, latency, and corrective steps to support systematic analysis. For controlled evaluation, we construct a 100-prompt benchmark spanning sorting, stacking, and transport tasks, and introduce a Prompt Complexity Index that aggregates linguistic and procedural factors to stratify instructions into simple, medium, and complex tiers. Our cross-scale analysis characterizes feasibility and the inherent quality-latency trade-offs of language models operating at the edge, and suggests that stronger structural cues in prompts can improve plan stability.

title: Research on Efficiency Optimization and Constant Voltage Output Composite Control of WPT System Based on Topology Switching
authors: Yijing Cheng, Xin Dai, Zhankun Feng, Wenbo Shi
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: A composite control method is proposed to reduce the optimal efficiency offset and constant voltage output in response to the problem of large measurement errors caused by compensating network losses and circuit internal resistance in magnetic coupling wireless power transfer (MC-WPT) systems. Firstly, the optimal load offset results of LCC-LCC and SS compensation topologies caused by the active bridge loss model are analyzed. Using topology switching, a method is proposed to achieve gain measurement without the need for primary and secondary communication measurement systems using dual active bridges, which can identify mutual inductance and coil internal resistance in a symmetrical parameter structure. Experiments have shown that the optimal load after considering the active bridge loss model is closer to the actual measured optimal load. Compared with traditional methods, the optimal load error is reduced by 28.8%, and the maximum efficiency is improved by about 1.5%. And it can achieve maximum efficiency tracking and constant voltage output when the load changes.

title: A Hierarchical Combined Fault Injection-Based Resilience Evaluation Method for Heterogeneous Power Terminals
authors: Xu Dong, Tianle Yao, Jiaming Liu, Jiakai Hao, Xianzhou Gao, Ruxia Yang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The rapid development of distributed energy systems and smart grids has led to the large-scale deployment and heterogenization of terminal devices, increasing the vulnerability of power systems to user-level software failures, network anomalies, and cross-layer cascading faults. Considering that existing evaluation methods fail to simultaneously simulate multi-layer and multi-type anomalies while quantifying terminal resilience, this paper proposes a resilience evaluation method based on hierarchical combined fault injection. The proposed method constructs a multi-layer injection framework covering the hardware, system, and application layers, and designs a two-level indicator system composed of diagnostic accuracy (DA), detection delay (DD), resource overhead (RO), service recovery time (SRT), and resilience index (RI). Single and combined fault injection experiments are conducted on Raspberry Pi, x86-based industrial PCs, and QEMU virtual nodes. The results show that SRT, DD, and RO are key factors influencing RI; resilience significantly decreases under combined fault scenarios, and resource-constrained terminals exhibit the highest vulnerability during cascading failures. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in characterizing complex fault response and recovery behaviors of heterogeneous terminals, providing a quantitative basis for terminal selection and resilience optimization strategies.

title: Safety Certification in the Latent space using Control Barrier Functions and World Models
authors: Mehul Anand, Shishir Kolathaya
abstract: Synthesising safe controllers from visual data typically requires extensive supervised labelling of safety-critical data, which is often impractical in real-world settings. Recent advances in world models enable reliable prediction in latent spaces, opening new avenues for scalable and data-efficient safe control. We introduce a semi-supervised framework that leverages control barrier certificates (CBCs) learned in the latent space of a world model to synthesise safe visuomotor policies. Our approach jointly learns a neural barrier function and a safe controller using limited labelled data, while exploiting the predictive power of modern vision transformers for latent dynamics modelling.

title: Machine Learning-Based SoC and RUL Estimation Applied to an Electric Bus Fleet
authors: Andrea Di Martino, Simone Volturno, Michela Longo, Wahiba Yaici, Dario Zaninelli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Energy transition in transportation sector is experiencing a rapid growth. Although massive renewals of outdated vehicle fleet with Electric Vehicles (EVs), battery management remains one of its main weaknesses. For this reason, research in this field is increasingly expanding, with the target of developing technologies able to combine improved performance with reduced environmental impact. This paper explores the challenging application of Machine Learning (ML) techniques for estimating the battery State of Charge (SoC) without relying on the electrical input data, typically required by classical model-based approaches. Following the set-up and optimization phases of ML models being able to associate vehicle speed to battery SoC, discharging profiles were extrapolated and analyzed to estimate the Remaining Useful Life (RUL). The proposed ML models achieved accurate results, with performance comparable to a traditional observer, despite relying on fewer and simpler variables. These results highlight the potentialities of data-driven approaches for realizing a scalable and easier battery monitoring.

title: Criticality Metrics for Relevance Classification in Safety Evaluation of Object Detection in Automated Driving
authors: Jörg Gamerdinger, Sven Teufel, Stephan Amann, Oliver Bringmann
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Ensuring safety is the primary objective of automated driving, which necessitates a comprehensive and accurate perception of the environment. While numerous performance evaluation metrics exist for assessing perception capabilities, incorporating safety-specific metrics is essential to reliably evaluate object detection systems. A key component for safety evaluation is the ability to distinguish between relevant and non-relevant objects — a challenge addressed by criticality or relevance metrics. This paper presents the first in-depth analysis of criticality metrics for safety evaluation of object detection systems. Through a comprehensive review of existing literature, we identify and assess a range of applicable metrics. Their effectiveness is empirically validated using the DeepAccident dataset, which features a variety of safety-critical scenarios. To enhance evaluation accuracy, we propose two novel application strategies: bidirectional criticality rating and multi-metric aggregation. Our approach demonstrates up to a 100% improvement in terms of criticality classification accuracy, highlighting its potential to significantly advance the safety evaluation of object detection systems in automated vehicles.

title: Label Anything, Train Nothing: 2D Zero-Shot Annotation via Generative VLMs, Zero-Shot Object Detectors and Foundation Models
authors: Daniel Serrano Dominguez, Alejandro Salazar Gomez, Alejandro Barrera, Jaime Godoy, Fernando Garcia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Supervised 2D detection methods rely heavily on large amounts of labeled data to enable robust model generalization. However, manually annotating such datasets is inherently unscalable and prohibitively expensive. We propose a fully automated, training-free approach for 2D object annotation, built upon the capabilities of pre-trained zero-shot models. Our approach integrates a Vision-Language Model (VLM) for class extraction, Grounding DINO for zero-shot object detection, and the Segment Anything Model (SAM) for mask generation. A key contribution is the use of the VLM not to query against a full class list, but to first identify the specific object categories present in an image, drastically improving detection quality. Furthermore, we introduce a refinement step using Non-Maximum Suppression (NMS), eliminating duplicate predictions. We evaluate our pipeline on diverse benchmarks, including PASCAL VOC and COCO, demonstrating its effectiveness and generalization capabilities without any task-specific training. Our method offers a practical path towards accelerating dataset creation with minimal human supervision.

title: Towards Holistic Safety Engineering for Automated Driving via the Scenarios as Specification Approach
authors: Mohamed Essayed Bouzouraa, Sinan Hasirlioglu, Dariusz Szymanski, Jan David Schneider, Angus Riddoch, Gero Kempf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: For the verification and validation of Automated Driving System features, vehicle manufacturers use scenario-based approaches to break down the world into more manageable traffic scenarios. Since this approach is typically independent from systems engineering processes such as requirements engineering, the Scenario as Specification approach was proposed, which unifies both approaches by using scenarios as a central development artifact. This work focuses on the integration of a technology-independent and technology-dependent safety engineering to the Scenario as Specification approach.Therefore, we present (1) an extension of the Scenario as Specification approach by introducing a technology-independent feature-level and a technology-dependent system-level view, (2) a deeper integration of Functional Safety and Safety Of The Intended Functionality, (3) the corresponding adaptations of the scenario structure, and (4) an end-to-end practical example with a focus on safety.Our work aims to lay the foundation for a unified scenario-based approach in industry and research communities for the development and deployment of Automated Driving System features.

title: Multi-Objective Path Planning of Robots in Nuclear Environments Based on Improved Ant Colony Algorithm
authors: Kai Wang, Yu Deng, Chengdong Yuan, Yiming Gou, Junfeng Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: In view of the limitations of traditional Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) in path planning for robots in nuclear environments—such as slow convergence, suboptimal routes, and local stagnation—this paper proposes a hybrid algorithm, A*_ Directed Ant Colony Optimization (A*_DACO). The method employs the A* algorithm to provide an initial directional path and pheromone seeding, while an improved ACO performs further optimization. A multi-objective heuristic function jointly considers path length, radiation dose, and energy consumption, and a differentiated pheromone update strengthens elite paths and penalizes poor ones to accelerate convergence and enhance path smoothness. Simulation studies in diverse radiation environments show that A*_DACO achieves shorter paths, lower dose accumulation, and reduced energy cost compared with ACO and Improved ACO (IACO). A robot experiment in a nuclear radiation field further confirms the algorithm’s practicality, demonstrating safer and more efficient path planning in complex radioactive scenarios.

title: Multi-Pass Streaming Lower Bounds for Approximating Max-Cut
authors: Yumou Fei, Dor Minzer, Shuo Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In the Max-Cut problem in the streaming model, an algorithm is given the edges of an unknown graph $G=(V, E)$ in some fixed order, and its goal is to approximate the size of the largest cut in G. Improving upon an earlier result of Kapralov, Khanna and Sudan, it was shown by Kapralov and Krachun that for all $\varepsilon\gt 0$, no $o(n)$ memory streaming algorithm can achieve a $(1 / 2+\varepsilon)$-approximation for Max-Cut. Their result holds for single-pass streams, i.e. the setting in which the algorithm only views the stream once, and it was open whether multi-pass access may help. The state-of-the-art result along these lines, due to Assadi and N, rules out arbitrarily good approximation algorithms with constantly many passes and $n^{1-\delta}$ space for any $\delta\gt 0$. We improve upon this state-of-the-art result, showing that any non-trivial approximation algorithm for Max-Cut requires either polynomially many passes or polynomially large space. More specifically, we show that for all $\varepsilon\gt 0$, a k-pass streaming $(1 / 2+\varepsilon)$-approximation algorithm for Max-Cut requires $\Omega_{\varepsilon}\left(n^{1 / 3} / k\right)$ space. This result leads to a similar lower bound for the Maximum Directed Cut problem, showing the near optimality of the algorithm of [Saxena, Singer, Sudan, Velusamy, SODA 2025]. Our lower bounds proceed by showing a communication complexity lower bound for the Distributional Implicit Hidden Partition (DIHP) Problem, introduced by Kapralov and Krachun. While a naive application of the discrepancy method fails, we identify a property of protocols called “globalness”, and show that (1) any protocol for DIHP can be turned into a global protocol, (2) the discrepancy of a global protocol must be small. The second step is the more technically involved step in the argument, and therein we use global hypercontractive inequalities, and more specifically strong quantitative versions of the level- d inequality for global functions.

title: Research on Coupling Task Scheduling for Four-Way Shuttle-Based Systems
authors: Junjie Sun, Weimin Wu, Zhengchen Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Automatic Storage and Retrieval Systems (AS/RS) are essential components in flexible manufacturing and highdensity warehousing, where effective task scheduling is critical to overall system performance. This study focuses on a four-way shuttle-based AS/RS and proposes a spatiotemporal constraintdriven mathematical model to coordinate shuttle and elevator operations. The model aims to minimize delay penalties, travel distance, and makespan through an integrated objective function. To solve the resulting complex scheduling problem, we develop a Coupling-Enhanced Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (CEALNS) algorithm that incorporates a diverse set of destroy and repair operators tailored to the system's coupling constraints. Simulation results confirm that CEALNS significantly outperforms existing methods in both solution quality and scalability.

title: Zonotopic Stability Conditions via Set-Invariance for Delay Difference Equations
authors: Manu Priyam, Ashish Kothyari
abstract: Computer controlled and networked control systems are often modeled as delay difference equations (DDE). Ensuring stability through appropriate controller design for such systems is a challenging task. As has been shown in multiple works, set invariance and classical stability theory have close links. A popular set invariance concept for DDEs is the ${\mathcal{D}}$-invariance condition. In this paper, we propose ${\mathcal{D}}$-invariance conditions by making use of zonotopes as set representations. Compared with polytopes, zonotopes provide a compact representation and favorable properties under various set operations, like Minkowski addition. Our ${\mathcal{D}}$-invariance conditions using zonotopes not only allow for testing feasibility of a given set, but also allows for efficient computation of invariant sets in a particular template. We also use our zonotopic ${\mathcal{D}}$−invariance conditions to formulate robust ${\mathcal{D}}$−invariance conditions and a computationally efficient controller design algorithm that optimizes simultaneously the rate of convergence and the amount of control energy used by a candidate controller. Finally, we show the efficacy of our results using numerical examples.

title: Cyber-Secure Self-healing Secondary Voltage Control Method in Isolated AC Microgrids under FDI Attacks on Communication Links
authors: Amirhossein Solat, Gevork B. Gharehpetian, Amjad Anvari-Moghaddam, Aref Pirmoradi
abstract: With the advancement of communication networks, MGs increasingly function as cyber-physical systems (CPSs), making them more vulnerable to cyber-attacks. Faults and cyber-attacks (CAs) can severely disrupt the operation of microgrids (MGs), impacting critical parameters and threatening overall system stability and security. To mitigate these risks, a cyber-secure control approach is required. The integrity of the system can be undermined through the injection of falsified data within inter-controller communication links To address these challenges, this paper introduces a cyber-secure self-healing secondary voltage control method that enhances the resilience of isolated AC MGs against cyber threats. The proposed distributed architecture minimizes system vulnerability while maintaining the performance of secondary controllers under false data injection (FDI) attacks. The method is validated through MATLAB/Simulink simulations. Results indicate that the proposed approach not only preserves MG stability with rapid response but also efficiently suppresses small voltage disturbances, restoring the system to its pre-attack operating state.

title: Near-Optimal Analytical Terminal Descent Guidance for Lunar Landers under State and Control Constraints
authors: Aditya Rallapalli, Suraj Kumar, Rijesh M P, Ashok Kumar Kakula, Bharat Kumar GVP
abstract: Recent successful lunar landings have renewed interest in developing next-generation lunar landers capable of achieving pinpoint landing accuracy. The confirmed presence of water ice near the Moon’s south pole has further motivated multiple space agencies to plan missions targeting this scientifically and strategically important region. However, the south polar environment poses significant challenges due to extremely low sun elevation angles and hazardous terrain, resulting in limited or no visual navigation support during the primary deceleration phase. This leads to substantial divert requirements and increased navigation uncertainty in both vertical (altitude) and horizontal channel near the landing site. Additionally, to ensure continuous surface tracking, it is essential to maintain lander attitude within altimeter operational limits throughout the terminal descent. This constraint imposes further requirements on the lander’s permissible attitude maneuvers, particularly during large lateral divert actions to cater for navigation (horizontal) errors. In this paper, we propose a near-fuel-optimal terminal descent strategy coupled with analytical guidance formulation under state and control constraint to allow precise landings with high divert capability. The terminal descent is divided into two stages: (i) a minimum vertical thrust phase, during which the lander leverages lunar gravity to increase vertical velocity, thereby mitigating the effect of vertical navigation errors; and (ii) a terminal braking phase initiated at an optimal altitude ensuring state and control constraints are met with online non-iterative prediction algorithm. The resulting descent profile approximates a near bang-bang thrust solution, achieving fuel-efficient performance while satisfying state and control constraints. Numerical simulations are presented to evaluate the proposed strategy and compare its performance with ground-based trajectory optimization results, demonstrating the effectiveness, fuel efficiency and robustness to navigation uncertainty.

title: Adaptive Hybrid Prediction-Correction with Trust-Region and Dynamic Line Search for AC/DC Load Flow
authors: Deepi Singh, Hongbo Sun, Shunsuke Kawano, Arvind Raghunathan, Yusuke Takaguchi, Fang Luo
abstract: Hybrid AC/DC power systems are gaining importance due to the rising penetration of Distributed Energy Resources (DERs) and the widespread deployment of Voltage Source Converters (VSCs). Analyzing power flow in such systems remains challenging due to unbalanced operating conditions, strong nonlinearities, and strict operational limits. This paper presents an Adaptive Hybrid Prediction-Correction algorithm with Trust-Region and Dynamic Line Search (AHPC-TRDLS) for reliable and efficient load flow computation in large-scale hybrid systems. The framework couples a Newton-Raphson-based prediction stage with a Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient (PCG) correction, bounded adaptively by a trust-region radius. A dynamic line search mechanism is incorporated as a fallback whenever the PCG convergence stalls, ensuring numerical stability. Additional features include adaptive preconditioning, enforcement of voltage and reactive power limits, and the use of symmetrical components for unbalanced system modeling. The algorithm is implemented in MATLAB and evaluated on different hybrid AC/DC test systems of varying scales. Case studies confirm that the proposed approach offers improved convergence, robustness, and scalability under stressed, ill-conditioned, and unbalanced scenarios.

title: Retraction Notice: Histogram based Human Computer Interaction for Gesture Recognition
authors: Dharmaraj Ojha, Rajesh George Rajan
publish: 2019 3rd International conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Computer remains as the inevitable part of our daily life, or we can say that, the computer is used by every person in their work. In this project, our main aim is to make computers easily understand the human language. This paper introduces a technique for human computer interaction using open CV and python. We have first detect, pre-processing and recognize the hand fingers and the count. Then with the help of recognized fingers count, it is act as a mouse to perform the different operations and this hand mouse interface known as a "virtual monitor". The hand mouse is controlled by the virtual monitor provides a virtual space. The accuracy of the proposed algorithm is 80%. This envisioned concept controlling a system by hand has been implemented successfully with effective efforts.

title: A 0.29 pJ/b 5.27 Tb/s/mm UCIe Advanced Package Link With 2.5-D CoWoS Interposer and a 0.52 pJ/b 0.448 Tb/s/mm UCIe Standard Package Link With Organic Substrate in 3 nm FinFET
authors: Didem Turker Melek, James Vandersand, R. Navin Kumar, Pyare M. Sarkar, Prakash BS, Adrian Leuciuc, Kevin Geary, Shaojun Ma, Chirag M. Mehta, Basant Bothra, Shashi Jain, Pawan Sabharwal, Ranjan Vaish, Kirti Bhanushali, Yutong Ding, Craig Frost, John Annunziata, Krishanu Sadhu, Dimitris Kyritsis, Jeff Bostak, Ming Li, Steve Williams, Ken Chang
abstract: This work presents two die-to-die (D2D) wireline transceivers, one compliant with the UCIe advanced package (UCIe-AP) and the other with the UCIe standard package (UCIe-SP) standard, developed in 3 nm FinFET. The Universal Chiplet interconnect express (UCIe)-AP link has 64 RX and 64 TX data lanes in one PHY module and is packaged with a CoWoS interposer, while the UCIe-SP has 16 RX and 16 TX data lanes and is packaged with an organic substrate. Both PHYs support 4–16 Gb/s/pin operation, use a ping-pong RX front end, employ a TX driver that can be configured as (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P+N$</tex-math> </inline-formula>)/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math> </inline-formula> or <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P$</tex-math> </inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math> </inline-formula> depending on the TX output swing setting, and feature a low latency TX clock domain crossing (CDC) solution. The measurements of the UCIe-AP link were obtained with 8.192Tb/s data traffic on eight links to demonstrate performance in a noisy environment with crosstalk and exhibit 0.29 pJ/bit power efficiency with 5.27Tb/s/mm bandwidth density and 3.5 ns measured FDI-to-FDI latency. The UCIe-AP link has a measured 0.29UI eye opening at 1E-15 BER and 0.03UI at a BER of 1E-27, for 16 Gb/s/pin operation. The UCIe-SP link performance was measured for 5, 15, and 25 mm channel lengths, and yields a 0.448Tb/s/mm beachfront bandwidth density while only consuming 0.52 pJ/bit. Measured FDI-to-FDI latency is 4.0 ns. With a 25 mm organic substrate channel, an aggregate 0.372UI eye opening at BER of 1e<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−15</sup> and 0.108UI at BER of 1e<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−27</sup> is measured at 16 Gb/s/pin operation. A background maintenance mode improves the aggregate eye width (EW) by up to 0.156UI across + 5% to −5% voltage and −40 to 125 C temperaturedrift.

title: ARViP: Adversarial Regularization in Visuomotor Policies for Robotic VLA Purpose
authors: Haoji Wang, Bo Wu, Suibing Zheng
abstract: With the development of embodied intelligence, current vision-language-action (VLA) models are difficult to deploy due to their large number of parameters thus high computational load, while the vision-based action models suffer from insufficient action accuracy in grasping tasks. To address these issues, this article proposes a novel Adversarial Regularization in Visuomotor Policy (ARViP) model. First, a proposed conditional variational autoencoder generative adversarial network architecture is applied to the existing generative action models. By discriminator distinguishing between real and generated samples, the generator is forced to produce increasingly realistic outputs, thereby increasing the accuracy of grasping. Second, to address the issue of causal confusion, we introduce a target detection model incorporating prior knowledge of grasped objects as the vision backbone. It allows the vision backbone to have prior knowledge of the feature space for grasped objects, which strengthens the object localization capabilities, and, in turn, improves vision understanding and processing capabilities. Finally, to address the issue of current models typically using uniform time-step optimization for all robotic arm joints, we propose a time-based joint regularization method. It introduces specialized loss functions tailored to the individual joint states at different time steps, thereby improving the prediction accuracy, smoothness, and robustness of motion sequences. In several real-world experiments, including assembling, disassembling, and stacking tasks, the proposed ARViP model improves grasping accuracy by 32% compared to the studied models.

title: The inNuCE Research Infrastructure and the Neuromorphic MLOps for AIoT prototyping
authors: Gianvito Urgese, Vittorio Fra, Andrea Pignata, Giuseppe Fanuli, Walter Gallego Gomez, Riccardo Pignari, Michelangelo Barocci, Benedetto Leto, Salvatore Tilocca, Nicola Cassetta, Paolo Montuschi, Enrico Macii
abstract: Neuromorphic computing promises significant improvements in latency and energy efficiency for machine intelligence at the edge. However, its adoption in the IoT domain is still limited by the heterogeneity of the HW, the immaturity of the toolchains, and the poor reproducibility of experiments. The present paper sets out the inNuCE RI, a two-pillar facility composed of a physical inNuCE Lab and a cloud-based inNuCE HPP. The purpose of the inNuCE RI is to enable developers to prototype, evaluate and compare neuromorphic and conventional end-to-end digital solutions. From a methodological perspective, we formalize the adaptation of MLOps to event-driven sensing and brain-inspired computation as NMLOps. We illustrate how inNuCE RI instantiates NMLOps through containerized toolchains orchestrated with Kubernetes and Slurm-managed heterogeneous resources (neuromorphic chips, FPGAs, GPUs, MCUs). The approach is analyzed on representative AIoT use cases, including HAR, Braille reading, event-based gesture recognition, Hi-Co semantization of memories, navigation tracking, and constraint satisfaction problems. The development of inNuCE RI has been driven by the need to facilitate the transition from prototype (in nuce) to engineered AIoT systems for lower entry barriers and enforce reproducibility. This paves the way for future system-of-systems engineering.

title: SCAW: Exploring Semantic Structures of Radio Signals via Soft Top-k Contrastive and Adaptive Consistency with Wavelet Refinement
authors: Yong Zu, Shuyuan Yang, Zhixi Feng, Xinlei Zhang, Yanbin Lu, Shuai Chen, Jun Liu, Qiukai Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) methods have recently been applied to cognitive radio technology (CRT), yielding promising results by utilizing unlabeled data. Nevertheless, most existing SSL approaches primarily focus on a single aspect, either adopting contrastive paradigms that emphasize discriminative feature learning or generative paradigms that excel at extracting the semantic structure of fine-grained information. In this paper, we introduce a novel SSL method, Soft Top-k Contrastive and Adaptive Consistency with Wavelet-Based Refinement (SCAW), which effectively integrates the advantages of both discriminative feature learning and semantic, fine-grained structural information extraction, thereby enhancing robustness and generalization in CRT scenarios. First, a wavelet-based feature refinement module is incorporated into the encoder to enable full-frequency and fine-grained semantic feature extraction. Second, a soft top-k contrastive loss is introduced to exploit inherent inter-sample relationships, thereby preserving discriminative capability and enhancing the semantic structural integrity of the learned representations. Moreover, an adaptive consistency loss is formulated to mitigate noise-induced perturbations while maintaining the underlying structure of the representations. The effectiveness of SCAW is evaluated on four public datasets across multiple downstream tasks. Experimental results show that SCAW consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: IoT Service Orchestration in Edge-Cloud Continuum with 6G: A Review
authors: Hafiz Faheem Shahid, Bilgehan Akdemir, Johirul Islam, Ijaz Ahmad, Ijaz Ahmad, Erkki Harjula
abstract: The development of 6th-generation (6G) mobile networks brings advancements in wireless communications, including lower latency, higher data rates, and improved spectral efficiency, as well as enhanced facilitation for the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies, integrated communications, sensing, and renewable energy sources. To harness this potential, a scalable framework integrating edge and cloud computing is needed to provide a robust computing continuum for various IoT applications and services. This paper analyses the strengths and weaknesses of existing and emerging distributed computing frameworks—ranging from traditional centralized IoT architectures, through fog, edge, and local-edge architectures, to the full three-tier edge–cloud continuum—in terms of IoT service orchestration and diverse application requirements. We emphasize the latest evolutionary step, three-tier edge-cloud continuum, which aims to resolve the most significant limitations of the previous frameworks, recognized in the literature. It enables efficient IoT service orchestration by utilizing distributed resources and computation closer to end users, while taking full advantage of the centralized resources at data centers. We evaluate the maturity of these frameworks, considering factors such as scalability, resource efficiency, adaptability to changes, resource availability, security and privacy, as well as robustness and resilience. Overall, this study aims to serve as a roadmap for researchers, network architects, and industry stakeholders to make informed decisions on implementing the computing continuum in 6G networks.

title: Game Plot Design With an LLM-Powered Assistant: An Empirical Study With Game Designers
authors: Seyed Hossein Alavi, Weijia Xu, Nebojsa Jojic, Daniel Kennett, Raymond T. Ng, Sudha Rao, Haiyan Zhang, Bill Dolan, Vered Shwartz
abstract: We introduce GamePlot, an LLM-powered assistant that supports game designers in crafting immersive narratives for turn-based games, and allows them to test these games through a collaborative game play and refine the plot throughout the process. Our user study with 14 game designers shows high levels of both satisfaction with the generated game plots and sense of ownership over the narratives, but also reconfirms that LLM are limited in their ability to generate complex and truly innovative content. We also show that diverse user populations have different expectations from AI assistants, and encourage researchers to study how tailoring assistants to diverse user groups could potentially lead to increased job satisfaction and greater creativity and innovation over time.

title: SFTCN: Scale Fusion Temporal Convolutional Network for Time Series Forecasting
authors: Leya Feng, Xin He, Yun Zhu, Zhongning Ding, Jianyu Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Real-world time series often exhibit multi-scale periodicity, necessitating the joint modeling of short-term fluctuations and long-term trends. Traditional temporal convolutional networks (TCNs), constrained by a single receptive field, struggle to capture such heterogeneous scales. We propose the Scale-Fused Temporal Convolutional Network (SFTCN) to address this limitation. SFTCN employs parallel convolutional branches with distinct kernel sizes to extract features at multiple temporal resolutions, and introduces a cross-scale fusion module that performs weighted aggregation to jointly encode short-term dynamics and long-term patterns. Extensive experiments on ETT, Electricity, Weather and Traffic datasets show that SFTCN generally outperforms baseline models on both short-term and medium-to-long-term forecasting tasks, especially when the data exhibit strong periodicity. Ablation studies confirm that the multiscale branches and the cross-scale fusion mechanism are both essential to SFTCN's superior ability to capture complex temporal dynamics.

title: Smooth Spatiotemporal Tube Synthesis for Prescribed-Time Reach-Avoid-Stay Control
authors: Siddhartha Upadhyay, Ratnangshu Das, Pushpak Jagtap
abstract: In this work, we address the issue of controller synthesis for a control-affine nonlinear system to meet prescribed time reach-avoid-stay specifications. Our goal is to improve upon previous methods based on spatiotemporal tubes (STTs) by eliminating the need for circumvent functions, which often lead to abrupt tube modifications and high control effort. We propose an adaptive framework that constructs smooth STTs around static unsafe sets, enabling continuous avoidance while guiding the system toward the target within the prescribed time. A closed-form, approximation-free control law is derived to ensure the system trajectory remains within the tube and satisfies the RAS task. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through a case study, showing a significant reduction in control effort compared to prior methods.

title: Tube-Based Robust Obstacle Avoidance and Following Control for Vehicle Formations
authors: Wenxian Wang, Deyuan Meng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper presents a robust planning and control framework for vehicle formations, by proposing a safety-aware obstacle-avoidance planner and a formation-following controller. Specifically, a tube-based model predictive controller is designed based on a robust positively invariant (RPI) set for nonholonomic vehicles. Leveraging the RPI set together with the vehicle size and planning position mismatch, a safe region can be constructed for each follower. Subsequently, this region is actuated in a robust rapidly exploring random tree star planner via safety-aware collision checking. The overall scheme exhibits strong robustness in both planning and control, as validated by simulations.

title: Automation of Machine Learning Model in Dynamic Production Environment
authors: Neelam Jain
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Deploying machine learning models in production environments, especially in agriculture, is a complex and resource-intensive task which requires significant manual effort to manage unseen data and maintain consistent performance. This research addresses these challenges by developing innovative approaches to automate model deployment in the context of precision agriculture, leveraging scripting techniques to simplify and accelerate the deployment process. The primary objectives of this study are to create a comprehensive framework for efficient and reliable automation, implement dynamic data preprocessing for unseen agricultural data, and establish an intelligent monitoring system to ensure consistent and accurate predictions in real-world farming environments. Additionally, this research incorporates Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques to enhance interpretability and promote transparency in AI-driven agricultural decision-making. Integrating a Streamlit-based interface facilitates interactive visualization of model explanations, enabling farmers and agricultural stakeholders to comprehend the reasoning behind recommended decisions. These improvements are consistent with recent advancements in XAI-enhanced smart farming systems, as illustrated in the companion study “XAI Streamlit-Based Enhancing Crop Recommendation System with Advanced Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Smart Farming ”Combining automation and explainability, this study contributes to developing a robust, transparent, and scalable framework that bridges the gap between advanced AI techniques and their practical application in sustainable agriculture.

title: Cross-View Trace Link Prediction with Multi-Feature GNNs: Creating and maintaining Traceability from Requirements to Components
authors: Fabian Hanke, Oliver von Heißen, Markus Feld, Tim Heuwinkel, Aschot Hovemann, Roman Dumitrescu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The realization of AI-augmented Systems Engineering (AI-SE) requires an Integration Layer that unifies heterogeneous engineering data into a consistent, machine-interpretable representation—the Knowledge Graph (System Model 2.0). This paper investigates Trace Link Prediction (TLP) as an intelligent induction mechanism for populating and maintaining this Knowledge Graph by inferring missing relationships across RFLP views. We present a multi-feature TLP approach that integrates semantic, numerical, and geometric descriptors through artifact-specific Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) headers and evaluate its performance using both classical and graph-based learning methods. Four Graph Neural Network (GNN) architectures—GCN, GraphSAGE, GAT, and GIN—are systematically benchmarked against strong baselines (Random Forest, MLP) under varying conditions of graph directionality, class imbalance, and inductive (node-disjoint) evaluation. Results on a mechatronic demonstrator reveal three key findings: (1) feature-rich inputs dominate performance, with classical models often matching or surpassing GNNs on single-relation graphs; (2) undirected modeling yields marginal numerical gains but violates domain semantics, highlighting the need for relation-aware designs; and (3) inductive evaluation provides more realistic generalization estimates. Overall, the study establishes multi-feature TLP as a practical and scalable mechanism for continuously enriching Knowledge-Graph-based Digital Threads, forming the semantic foundation for AI-augmented Systems Engineering.
