title: IoT-Enabled Sleep Monitoring and Cognitive Assessment for Evaluating Teacher Well-Being
authors: Anwar Ahmed Khan, Shama Siddiqui, Mehar Ullah, Indrakshi Dey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Sleep quality is an important indicator of the efficient cognitive function for high school teachers. Due to the high work stress and multi-tasking expectations, the teachers often face issues with their sleep quality and cognitive function, which has a clearly negative influence on their teaching abilities. In this work, we propose a unique but simple method of deploying Internet of Things (IoT) technology to monitor the sleep quality of high school teachers at Pakistan. Smart watches embedded with pulse rate and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S p O}_{2}$</tex> sensors were used to collect data and categorize the sleep quality as “poor”, “fair” or “good”. Moreover, we used a psychological tool, Cognitive Assessment Questionnaire (CAQ) for the self-assessment of teachers' cognitive function. The study was conducted over 208 high school teachers from across Pakistan. It has been found that most of the teachers had a poor sleep quality and cognitive function; The link between these two variables indicate that the workload and other factors must be improved for the teachers to ensure their well-being, which will in turn have a positive impact on their teaching quality.

title: Load Profile Estimation of Power Distribution Transformers Based on Limited Smart Meter Data
authors: Mohammad Reza Dehbozorgi, Mohammad Rastegar
abstract: Estimating distribution transformers’ hourly load profiles is important for planning and operation. However, many transformers have no real-time monitoring due to the sparsity of smart meters. This paper estimates the transformer load profiles using smart meter data, billing records, and GIS mapping of customers to the transformers. First, customers’ smart meter readings are pre-processed and normalized. Discrete wavelet transform (DWT) is utilized to extract features. The features from DWT are then grouped into typical load profiles (TLPs) using k-means clustering. To allocate a TLP to customers without smart meters, k-nearest neighbor is used, which utilizes monthly energy consumption, seasonal and monthly share of consumed energy, and, if applicable, share of energy received based on customers’ tariff. Next, the TLPs are scaled using customers’ monthly energy consumption and are aggregated to reconstruct the hourly transformer loads. The performance of the method using real data is evaluated, and it shows that the mean absolute percentage error is under 10%.

title: Integrating Sentiment Analysis and Technical Indicators for Stock Price Prediction Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Vijay Kumar Vishwakarma, Narayan Pandurang Bhosale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Exact stock price prediction strategies are basic for financial specialists and budgetary educators in today's ever-changing money-related environment. To determine the stock costs of the Nifty50 index, which is recorded on the National Stock Exchange, India, twelve machine learning models, such as ridge regression, decision tree regression, elastic net regression, random forest regression, linear regression, LASSO regression, gradient boosting regression, Bayesian regression, stochastic gradient descent regression, least angle regression, multilayer perceptron regression, and support vector regression, are executed. Sentiment analysis and technical feature extraction are added to enhance the prediction accuracy. The call ratio-based sentiment score, relative strength index, and moving averages are added as new features in the dataset. The experiment shows that the ridge and linear regressions work better than the other methods for foreseeing Nifty50 information. The execution of these models was assessed via performance measures such as adjusted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex>-square, root mean squared error, mean Poisson deviation, median absolute error, mean Gamma deviation, mean squared logarithmic error, explained variance score, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex>-square, mean absolute percentage error, mean absolute error. The information that speculators pick up from utilizing machine learning models to foresee stock costs, not as they were, makes a difference in making taught choices, such as buying, offering, or holding onto stocks. Nevertheless, it makes a difference for them to maximize their venture returns while minimizing any misfortunes. These expectation models are exceptionally supportive in characterizing patterns within the stock showcase and make a difference in constructing solid hazard administration plans.

title: ShipSense: Live Shipment Monitoring and Alerting via Mobile-Integrated IoT System
authors: Vaishali Mangrulkar, Aditi Kurhekar, Aditya Umesh, Anushka Poddar, Sharvari Kulkarni
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time shipment tracking device designed to monitor logistics cargo by integrating GPS, GSM, and environmental sensors. Built around an ESP32 microcontroller, the system tracks live location and monitors temperature and humidity conditions of shipments. All data is transmitted to Google Firestore and displayed on a mobile application, allowing users to access real-time shipment information. GPS provides accurate tracking, while GSM ensures communication in areas with limited internet connectivity. A key feature is the threshold-based alert mechanism, which generates SMS and app notifications when environmental parameters exceed safe limits or when the cargo deviates from its route. This functionality improves supply chain transparency, minimizes losses, and enhances logistics efficiency. By leveraging IoT, cloud computing, and mobile communication, the device offers a smart and scalable solution for cold chain logistics and high-value cargo transportation.

title: Secure Framework for Privacy and Risk Mitigation in IoT-Enabled Health Insurance
authors: Jagvinder Singh, Arvinder Singh, Kanika Manchanda, Amarpreet Kaur, Kulbir Kaur, Ravneet Sethi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The growing convergence of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies and digital health insurance platforms has introduced a new landscape of intelligent, real-time services. Insurers now rely on continuous streams of biometric and behavioural data from wearable devices, mobile health apps, and edge-connected diagnostics to design adaptive policies, monitor patient wellness, and automate claim processing. However, this evolution has simultaneously amplified vulnerabilities to data breaches, regulatory non-compliance, and unauthorized access—posing significant threats to patient privacy and institutional credibility. This study presents a secure, multi-layered architectural framework designed specifically for IoT-enabled health insurance systems. The proposed model integrates advanced end-to-end encryption protocols, blockchain-based smart contract enforcement, AI-powered anomaly detection systems, adaptive multi-factor authentication (MFA), and embedded compliance auditing aligned with HIPAA and GDPR standards. Each security mechanism is positioned at a distinct operational layer—device, network, application, and governance—to ensure both horizontal and vertical protection across the system. To evaluate the proposed framework, a simulation testbed was constructed replicating realistic insurance scenarios with twenty emulated IoT endpoints. Five common cyberattack vectors were introduced, including SQL injection, man-in-the-middle interception, biometric spoofing, zero-day malware, and smart contract exploitation. Security performance was measured using key indicators such as detection accuracy, mitigation response time, data exposure volume, and regulatory compliance adherence. The results demonstrate that the integrated framework improved threat detection to 97.1%, reduced data leakage by over 80%, and maintained 98% compliance under regulatory audit conditions. These findings affirm the viability of a modular, regulation-ready defence architecture capable of protecting sensitive health data in dynamic IoT-driven insurance environments

title: An Ensemble Approach to Stock Price Prediction: LSTM and Random Forest Integration
authors: Md Ashifuddin Mondal, Ritwika Mukherjee, Pranta Saha, Arijit Mondal, Pratik Dutta, Ayan Chel
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Predicting stock prices has attracted a lot of attention since it can help with investing choices and reduce financial risks. Because financial markets are dynamic and non-linear, it is difficult to make accurate forecasts, which calls for the use of sophisticated approaches. By utilizing Random Forest's feature selection skills and Long Short-Term Memory's (LSTM) sequential learning strengths, this study suggests a unique ensemble model for stock price prediction. Ten years' worth of historical stock data was gathered from Yahoo Finance, preprocessed, and utilized to train the models. With an accuracy of 99 % and a mean squared error (MSE) of 12.12, the ensemble model fared better than conventional methods like ARIMA, Linear Regression, and standalone Random Forest. Superior performance in identifying non-linear patterns and temporal dependencies in stock data was shown by the combination of Random Forest and LSTM. To increase forecast accuracy and market responsiveness even more, future developments will include sentiment analysis and real-time flexibility. According to the findings, hybrid models have great potential for financial forecasting and decision-making.

title: Weighted Eligibility-Based Product Recommendation System
authors: Julie Koon Koon, Vinayak Sharma, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: In the finance and banking industry, product recommendation systems play an important role in enhancing customer engagement and driving cross-sell and upsell opportunities. However, traditional recommendation models often fail to account for product eligibility constraints and customer-specific suitability, leading to irrelevant suggestions. This paper introduces a novel hybrid framework that combines rule-based eligibility filtering, customer segmentation, and machine learning to generate personalized, actionable product recommendation. The goal of this paper is to predict the most suitable financial product for a customer by mimicking human reasoning. To achieve this, our research employs a hybrid approach that combines fuzzy logic rule-based eligibility filtering with a supervised machine learning model to estimate adoption probabilities and recommend the next best product for the customer. Key features such as income, risk, credit score, and employment status are used together with other engineered features such as customer segment, balance to income ratio and eligibility scores to rank products for each customer. A weighting mechanism is introduced to prioritize recommendations that align with both customer needs and business constraints. Evaluation of synthetic data generated to mimic real-world data shows that the incorporation of eligibility and behavioral characteristics significantly improves the relevance of the recommendation and predictive performance. This system presents a scalable and interpretable solution for financial institutions that aims to optimize customer targeting while maintaining operational feasibility. Ideally, recommending the right product to the right customer.

title: Automated EARS-Based Requirements Generation with Lightweight Large Language Models
authors: Muhammad Huzaifa Imran, Touseef Tahir, Bilal Hassan, Hamid Jahankhani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Software requirements are typically written in natural language, which is prone to issues such as ambiguity, wordiness, and vagueness. These requirements issues cause faults in software development processes. In the past, a well-known EARS (easy approach to requirements syntax) template has been proposed to mitigate these issues by specifying the requirements in semiformal format. The requirements specification in the EARS format requires an understanding of the EARS and requirement engineering domain. This requires manual labor, where each requirement needs to be manually transformed, looked at, rewritten, and transcribed by a requirement engineer. We propose a novel framework for fine-tuning light-weight LLMs that can automatically rewrite the requirements from scratch. We designed and implemented a pipeline that transforms the raw requirements to EARS format by fine-tuning four LLMs, that is, BART, DistillGPT2, GPT2, T5-Small with BART using data set of 9141 raw requirements. The BART-base provides the lowest score BLEU Score (0.405) and average BLEU score (0.708) as well as the lowest final training loss (0.34), indicating strong performance in transforming the EARS requirement.

title: A Comprehensive Survey of Underwater Image Enhancement: Trends in Physics-Based, Visual Prior, Data-Driven, and Hybrid Approaches
authors: Srushti Gunthe, Latika Pinjarkar, Sumit Chakravarty
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Underwater image enhancement (UIE) conveys a vital aspect of computer vision that focuses on refining the pictorial excellence of images taken in aquatic environments. The need for robust UIE techniques is increasingly imperative because of their applications in marine ecosystem assessment, oceanographic research, underwater surveillance, autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) Though, underwater images frequently suffer with degradation because of scattering, absorption, and non-uniform lighting. To address these challenges, a diverse range of methodologies has emerged, including physics-based models, visual prior-based techniques that exploit statistical regularities in natural images, deep learning and data-driven approaches leveraging convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformers, and hybrid strategies that integrate both domain knowledge and data adaptability. Recent research has explored the use of generative models, corresponding Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) also diffusion models, synthesis in highly degraded underwater scenes. This survey synthesizes findings from recent peer-reviewed papers and categorizes them into four principal approaches like Physics-Based, Visual Prior, Data-Driven, and Hybrid. This study analyzes their contributions, innovations, strengths, and limitations, while also identifying future directions.

title: An Adaptive $L_{1}$-And- $L_{2}$-Normed Latent Factorization of Tensors Model for Imputing Water Quality Monitoring Data
authors: Xuke Wu, Lan Wang, Chentao Mao, Kun Shan, Bing Yang, Mingsheng Shang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Water quality monitoring (WQM) data collected through wireless sensor networks offers an essential decision support for aquatic resource management and pollution prevention. Nevertheless, extensive missing values caused by equipment malfunctions in WQM data frequently result in unreliable hydrological analysis outcomes and compromised environmental policy-making precision. A latent factorization of tensors (LFT) proves to be an efficient imputation approach. Yet, most existing LFT-based models use a single distanceoriented loss function (e.g., one based on the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{2}$</tex> norm), ignoring the characteristics of WQM data that can be better captured by alternative metrics like the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{1}$</tex> norm. To tackle this problem, the study proposes an Adaptive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{L}_{\mathbf{1}}$</tex>-and- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{L}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>-normed LFT (AL <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\mathbf{3}}$</tex> FT) model, guided by two core ideas: 1) integrating the stability of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{2}$</tex> norm and the robustness of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{1}$</tex> norm into its loss function, and 2) realizing its hyper-parameter adaptation via a fuzzy controller effectively. Comparing with advanced LFT models on real-world WQM datasets, the experimental results demonstrate that the proposed AL <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\mathbf{3}}$</tex> FT model realizes significant gains in imputation accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: CPED-NCBFs: A Conformal Prediction for Expert Demonstration-based Neural Control Barrier Functions
authors: Sumeadh M S, Kevin Dsouza, Ravi Prakash
abstract: Among the promising approaches to enforce safety in control systems, learning Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) from expert demonstrations has emerged as an effective strategy. However, a critical challenge remains: verifying that the learned CBFs truly enforce safety across the entire state space. This is especially difficult when CBF is represented using neural networks (NCBFs). Several existing verification techniques attempt to address this problem including SMT-based solvers, mixed-integer programming (MIP), and interval or bound-propagation methods but these approaches often introduce loose, conservative bounds. To overcome these limitations, in this work we use CPED-NCBFs a split-conformal prediction based verification strategy to verify the learned NCBF from the expert demonstrations. We further validate our method on point mass systems and unicycle models to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed theory.

title: A Non-intrusive Load Monitoring Using a VMD-EMD Signal Processing and BiGRU-BiLSTM Deep Learning Approach
authors: Behrooz Taheri, Seyed Amir Hosseini, Mostafa Sedighizadeh
abstract: In the present study, a hybrid method based on the deep learning model BiGRU-BiLSTM along with the VMD-EMD feature extraction method is presented for use in non-intrusive load monitoring applications. By utilizing the strengths of the deep learning model and the features of the combined signal processing model, the proposed method has been able to very effectively estimate the complex patterns of household appliance signals with high accuracy. To analyse how well the proposed technique performs, the open-access UK-DALE dataset has been used. According to the simulation results, the developed method shows a high capability in estimating the power signal generated by household appliances. This paper, by presenting an approach based on deep learning and combined feature analysis, is considered a significant advancement in the field of non-intrusive load monitoring.

title: Algorithm of Data Generation for Transmission to the Operator During Manipulation Operations with a Limited-Bandwidth Communication Channel
authors: Alexander Yurmanov
abstract: Performing underwater manipulation operations on underwater objects using autonomous unmanned underwater vehicles (AUVs) equipped with manipulators is challenging due to uncertainties when working with deformed or silted objects. Solving this problem requires operator supervision, which, in the open sea, is only possible using a hydroacoustic communication channel with severely limited bandwidth. This paper presents an algorithm designed to generate data for transmission to the operator, based on which the accuracy of automatic systems for identifying previously known objects is analyzed. The essence of the algorithm is to describe an identified defect on the object's surface using primitive shapes, information about which is transmitted in several stages. The operator first receives a generalized map of defects and deviations with quantitative characteristics. Based on this map, additional information is requested, which is transmitted in the form of adaptively generated sets of primitive geometric shapes. The parameters of these shapes are dynamically adjusted to the current bandwidth of the communication channel. As a result, this approach allows transmitting information sufficient for the operator under the conditions of low bandwidth of the hydroacoustic communication channel, while also maintaining functionality in case of data packet loss.

title: Dry Hot Rock Geothermal Energy Development and Utilization Technology:A Patent Landscape Review
authors: Xiaoli Wang, Weijian Song, Xin Wang, Yang Chen
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This article utilizes the PatSnap global patent intelligence analysis platform to analyze the patent application trends, technological strength of various countries, the distribution of technical fields, the patent value of each institution and innovation hot technologies in the field of dry hot rock geothermal energy development and utilization technology. The results show that the number of patents for the development and utilization of dry hot rock has continued to grow since 2013, and China and the United States are the main producers of this technology, and the development and utilization technology of dry hot rock is concentrated in three major fields: new energy (Y), thermal engineering (F) and fixed structure (E). The total patent value of Eavor is more than $15 million, far exceeding that of other institutions. This paper contributes to the knowledge system by providing a comprehensive overview of the current status and trends of dry hot rock development and utilization technology.

title: Research on Equivalent Inertia Prediction Method for Wind Turbine Generators Based on Temporal Convolutional Network and Multi-Head Attention Mechanism
authors: Yajun Zhang, Qian Feng, Jun Yan, Yufan Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: By adjusting the power output of wind turbine generators (WTGs) to simulate the inertial dynamic response of traditional synchronous generators, virtual inertia technology serves as a crucial means to enhance the frequency support capability of wind power. Furthermore, the equivalent inertia prediction of WTGs enables the advance grasp of the inertial characteristics of the units, providing a key data foundation for the precise regulation of this technology. This study proposes a method for predicting the equivalent inertia of WTGs based on the temporal convolutional network (TCN) and multi-head attention mechanism. This method makes full use of multi-dimensional time-series data such as wind speed, power output, and power grid frequency. It focuses on capturing the short-term dependencies of multi-dimensional time-series data and extracting deep-seated data features through TCN. Meanwhile, it employs the multi-head attention mechanism to calculate the attention weights of multiple subspaces, thereby accurately identifying the long-term dependencies of the data. On this basis, the method extracts key features related to virtual inertia on a global scale, achieving the accurate prediction of the inertia time constant of WTGs. Experimental results show that the proposed prediction method has an average mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.0284 s and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.0368 s, exhibiting high prediction accuracy. It provides necessary decision-making information for the optimal dispatching of wind power and the stability control of power grid frequency.

title: Research on Inertia and Additional Power Compensation Control of Photovoltaic Energy Storage DC Microgrid
authors: Chaosheng Li, Luo Huang, Li Zhang, Chang Liu, Huijuan Wang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Under the background of China's new power system construction, the DC microgrid, as an important part of it, is increasingly receiving attention. Unlike AC power grids that have stability constraints such as phase angle and frequency, the stability of DC microgrids is only reflected in the DC bus voltage. In order to solve the problem of low inertia in DC microgrids caused by the integration of a large number of power electronic devices, firstly, by analogizing the active frequency control of AC power grids, the Analog Virtual Synchronous Generators (AVSG) control suitable for Energy Storage (ES) converters is obtained; Then, in order to improve the dynamic characteristics of the bus voltage, based on the voltage balance relationship when the DC microgrid is in a steady state, the variables that affect the output current of the ES converter are derived, and an adaptive power compensation control is designed and added to the current inner loop of the ES converter to weaken the influence of the above variables and improve the dynamic characteristics of the bus voltage; Secondly, in order to accelerate the speed of restoring stable bus voltage, an Extended State Observer (ESO) is introduced in the AVSG control loop, which estimates power disturbances through ESO and compensates them to the AVSG control loop, accelerating the speed of restoring stable bus voltage; Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy was verified through Matlab/Simulink simulation analysis.

title: Energy Management for Fuel-Cell-Range-Extender Buses Based on Dynamic Programming and Neural Network
authors: Carolin Schiefer, Maren Frederike Stumpf, Eric Sax
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Decarbonizing the traffic sector requires public transport to switch to alternative drive technologies. Despite the increasing spread of electric vehicles, there are still challenges in the electrification of public transport. These challenges are particularly pronounced for electrified 18m-buses. Due to the limited range of 18m-buses, they are not suitable as a direct replacement for their diesel equivalents, making scheduling difficult for bus operators. A promising approach to extending the range is the integration of an additional energy source on board. This approach is implemented in fuel cell range extender (FC-REX) buses. It combines a battery and a fuel cell power supply, whereby the energy is mainly provided by the battery. The power distribution of the two energy sources is controlled by an energy management system (EMS).This paper first proposes an offline Dynamic Programming (DP) approach to determine the optimal fuel cell load in the EMS using a simulation of an FC-REX bus. The aim of DP is to find out whether the energy efficiency can be improved and thus the range can be increased. To enable a real-time capable EMS without prior knowledge of the route, a neural network is subsequently investigated to approximate that optimal control strategy by training based on DP data. The control strategy is referred to as Neural Network based on Dynamic Programming (DP-NN). DP-NN is intended to combine the advantages of DP in finding the global optimum with the computationally efficient real-time control of neural networks. For evaluation purposes, DP and DP-NN are compared with a constant fuel cell power supply operating close to its most efficient load.

title: Virtual Decomposition Based Safety-Critical Control with Joint Position Constraints for Multi-DOF Robotic Manipulator
authors: Songlin Tan, Shu Li, Yan-Jun Liu, Lei Liu, Dapeng Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: This paper studies the problem of safe trajectory tracking control for a virtual decomposition manipulator system with joint disturbances and joint position constraints. For the joint and link subsystems based on virtual decomposition control (VDC), a robust tracking control strategy integrating parameter adaptive and saturation function sliding mode terms is proposed to enhance the system’s ability to suppress external disturbances. Secondly, stability analyses were conducted for the subsystems and the entire machine system, respectively. Based on this, in combination with the core idea of virtual decomposition, input-to-state safety high-order control barrier functions (ISSf-HOCBF) were designed for each subsystem with different joint position constraints. This approach ensures that the safety sets of each subsystem after disturbance expansion remain forward invariant under the conditions of external disturbances and differentiated joint state space constraints. In addition, a quadratic programming (QP) framework for optimizing control input was constructed, with system safety as the primary constraint. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed safety-critical control strategy was verified through a simulation experiment of a three-degree-of-freedom robotic manipulator based on a virtual decomposition model.

title: DynaRyde: Optimizing Public Transit with Dynamic Routing and User Requests
authors: Anjali Sharma-Tiwari, Priyank Sharma-Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Traditional fixed-route public transit systems often struggle with inefficiency in suburban areas characterized by low population density and fluctuating demand. This paper presents and validates DynaRyde, a framework for optimizing suburban public transit by integrating dynamic route scheduling with on-demand passenger requests using well-established algorithms. Our approach utilizes the Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) clustering algorithm to group spatially and temporally proximate ride requests, generating "virtual stops" in real time. Routes are then dynamically computed using a Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP)-like optimization heuristic, incorporating both mandatory transit hubs and virtual stops. We implemented and evaluated the DynaRyde system using the Simulation of Urban MObility (SUMO) traffic simulation environment on a realistic suburban road network under various demand scenarios. Performance was benchmarked against an enhanced fixed-route system and a non-clustering on-demand model. Results demonstrate that our integrated system significantly improves service quality and efficiency, achieving up to a 19% increase in service coverage and a 15–35% reduction in average waiting times compared to a resource-equivalent fixed-route baseline. These findings highlight the substantial potential of integrating on-demand clustering and dynamic routing strategies to create more adaptable and passenger-centric public transit solutions.

title: Predefined time consensus of leader-follower multi-agent systems under reward mechanism
authors: Hechen Shang, Hui Zhao, Qingfang Meng, Lixiang Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: This paper discusses the predefined time consensus problem for a class of nonlinear leader-follower multi-agent systems in which new control gains dependent on reward values are constructed. The research mainly includes the following work: firstly, a control gain update strategy based on reward mechanism is designed. Secondly, the designed reward mechanism is applied to the construction of the controller, which ensures the control gain can achieve non-monotonic change. Finally, numerical simulation show the effectiveness of the controller in different situations and have good performance when facing fixed topology. In the case of partial communication link failure, the controller still performs stably. The effectiveness and adaptability of the controller are verified.

title: UPEDM: Underground Parking Entrance/Exit Detection Method Based on Multi-Source Non-Visual Sensor Fusion
authors: Yongbo Zhuang, Yiyun Guo, Guangxiao Shao, Wennan Chai, Qingdang Li, Yongkang Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Accurate entrance and exit detection in GNSS-denied underground parking lots is crucial for seamless indoor–outdoor localization and autonomous navigation. This paper proposes an underground parking entrance/exit detection method based on multi-source non-visual sensor fusion. The system leverages the built-in sensors (GNSS receivers, light sensors, and Wi-Fi modules) in intelligent mobile platforms (such as smartphones and modern vehicles) and uses a sliding window mechanism to capture sensor signal variations in real-time. It employs a combined KAN and MLP model to identify parking lot entrances and exits. This approach significantly enhances detection accuracy and robustness in complex environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system achieves high precision (with a minimum position error of 2.83 meters) and robustness in multiple real-world scenarios. Compared to GNSS-based methods, the proposed system achieves position accuracy improvements of up to 30.30%.

title: Service Disruption of a Vehicular ECU Through UDS Extended Diagnostic Requests
authors: Humberto B. Cunha-Junior, Abel G. Silva-Filho, Divanilson R. Campelo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Although prior works reported vulnerabilities introduced in vehicle diagnostics, finding specific service disruption time intervals through diagnostic sessions of protocols such as the Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS) remains unaddressed. In this paper, we report that sending a large volume of Extended Diagnostic Session (EDS) requests to an Electronic Control Unit (ECU) of a passenger car can lead to a Denial-of-Service (DoS) situation. We demonstrated our findings on the Body Control Module (BCM) ECU of a 2015 SUV model. The attacks were conducted using a prototype dongle attached to the OBD-II port, primarily designed for diagnostic purposes. Our findings highlight that sending a large volume of EDS requests at 0.6 ms and 1.0 ms time intervals can result in a DoS situation, which might compromise crucial tasks of vehicular diagnostics, ranging from monitoring I/O functions to ECU firmware updates.

title: Benchmarking Transformer Models for Fine-Grained Assamese Hate Speech Detection in Social Media
authors: Basab Nath, Krishna Kant Pandey, Hilal Ahmad Shah
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Hate speech detection in low-resource languages is a critical challenge in natural language processing, particularly for languages like Assamese that lack large-scale annotated datasets. This paper investigates the performance of transformerbased models for fine-grained, multi-class hate speech detection in Assamese social media text. We leverage an existing multi-class Assamese hate speech corpus containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5, 0 0 1}$</tex> social media comments labeled across categories such as religionbased, political, and other forms of hate. We conduct systematic experiments using IndicBERT, mBERT, and XLM-Roberta to establish baseline results for this challenging classification task. Our experiments show that IndicBERT achieves the highest macro F1-score of 0.72, outperforming XLM-Roberta (0.68) and mBERT (0.66). We further analyze the linguistic properties of the dataset, including code-switching, domain-specific slurs, and class imbalance, and present qualitative error analyses to understand factors influencing model performance. Our results provide a first set of robust transformer-based benchmarks for Assamese multi-class hate speech detection, and highlight challenges and opportunities for future research in low-resource, fine-grained hate speech modeling.

title: Instance-Optimal Uniformity Testing and Tracking
authors: Guy Blanc, Clément L. Canonne, Erik Waingarten
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In the uniformity testing task, an algorithm is provided with samples from an unknown probability distribution over a (known) finite domain, and must decide whether it is the uniform distribution, or, alternatively, if its total variation distance from uniform exceeds some input distance parameter. This question has received a significant amount of interest and its complexity is, by now, fully settled. Yet, we argue that it fails to capture many scenarios of interest, and that its very definition as a gap problem in terms of a prespecified distance may lead to suboptimal performance. To address these shortcomings, we introduce the problem of uniformity tracking, whereby an algorithm is required to detect deviations from uniformity (however they may manifest themselves) using as few samples as possible, and be competitive against an optimal algorithm knowing the distribution profile in hindsight. Our main contribution is a polylog(opt)-competitive uniformity tracking algorithm. We obtain this result by leveraging new structural results on Poisson mixtures, which we believe to be of independent interest.

title:
Bug Hunting in the RISC-V SoC: The 1
                    <sup>st</sup>
                    Integrated Circuit Security Challenge
authors: Lei Peng, Jiacheng Zhu, Qizhi Zhang, Shibo Tang, Xingxin Wang, Xinyu Zheng, Yaxuan Zhao, Aijiao Cui, Wei Hu, Jiaji He, Peng Fei Qiu
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Hardware security vulnerabilities pose a critical threat to modern system-on-chip (SoC) designs, yet their detection remains challenging due to low-level semantics and limited runtime observability. To address this gap, we organized the 1st Integrated Circuit Security Challenge (ICSC) in 2024, leveraging the open-source OpenPiton SoC platform. We introduced SecRisBen, a novel benchmark suite featuring realistic Register Transfer Level (RTL)-vulnerabilities systematically injected into the processor core and peripheral modules using five structured strategies. A multidimensional evaluation framework was developed to rigorously assess competing analysis tools. Two leading teams demonstrated state-of-the-art detection capabilities, employing information flow-based formal verification and semantic-driven property generation to uncover multiple high-impact vulnerabilities. The challenge successfully fostered collaboration and advancement in hardware security tools. Building on this momentum, we plan to hold subsequent competitions to further accelerate the progress in hardware security research and tool development.

title: On the Impossibility of SNARGs with Short CRS : (or: Revisiting Gentry-Wichs Barrier in the Non-adaptive Setting)
authors: Liyan Chen, Zhengzhong Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We study the inherent barriers to constructing non-adaptively sound succinct non-interactive arguments (SNARGs) for NP with a CRS whose length is sublinear in the witness length. Our results cover both the standard SNARGs and SNARGs with an additional updatable feature (i.e. incrementally verifiable computation for NP).•For updatable SNARGs, we show a black-box separation from falsifiable assumptions for uniform polynomial-time reductions, assuming sub-exponential hardness of learning with error.•For general SNARGs, we show a black-box separation from falsifiable assumptions for non-uniform polynomial-time reductions that only make one query to the adversary, assuming the existence of sub-exponentially secure super-bit generators. We observe that all known SNARG constructions from polynomial hardness of standard assumptions have 1-query soundness reductions. Thus, our result complements existing constructions.Previously, the seminal work [Gentry-Wichs, STOC’11] showed a black-box separation of SNARGs from falsifiable assumptions in the adaptive soundness setting. We explore whether any barriers exist in the non-adaptive setting. To obtain our result, we derive a simulation lemma for unbounded polynomial-length auxiliary inputs assuming super-bit generators.

title: How Global Calibration Strengthens Multiaccuracy
authors: Sílvia Casacuberta, Parikshit Gopalan, Varun Kanade, Omer Reingold
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Multiaccuracy and multicalibration are multi-group fairness notions for prediction that have found numerous applications in learning and computational complexity [HKRR18]. They can be achieved from a single learning primitive: weak agnostic learning. A line of work starting from [GKR+22] has shown that multicalibration implies a very strong form of learning. Here we investigate the power of multiaccuracy as a learning primitive, both with and without the additional assumption of calibration. We find that multiaccuracy in itself is rather weak, but that the addition of global calibration (this notion is called calibrated multiaccuracy) boosts its power substantially, enough to recover implications that were previously known only assuming the stronger notion of multicalibration. We give evidence that multiaccuracy might not be as powerful as standard weak agnostic learning, by showing that there is no way to post-process a multiaccurate predictor to get a weak learner, even assuming the best hypothesis has correlation 1/2. Rather, we show that it yields a restricted form of weak agnostic learning, which requires some concept in the class to have correlation greater than 1/2 with the labels. However, by also requiring the predictor to be calibrated, we recover not just weak, but strong agnostic learning. A similar picture emerges when we consider the derivation of hardcore measures from predictors satisfying multigroup fairness notions [TTV09], [CDV24]. On the one hand, while multiaccuracy only yields hardcore measures of density half the optimal, we show that (a weighted version of) calibrated multiaccuracy achieves optimal density. Our results yield new insights into the complementary roles played by multiaccuracy and calibration in each setting. They shed light on why multiaccuracy and global calibration, although not particularly powerful by themselves, together yield considerably stronger notions.

title: NNUF: Nearest Neighbor Union-Find Decoder for Quantum Error Correction
authors: Yuhang Gu, He Li
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: The realization of fault-tolerant quantum computers is critically dependent on efficient and accurate quantum error correction. For topological codes such as the surface code, the decoder often becomes a performance bottleneck. This paper presents an optimized nearest-neighbor union-find decoder, named NNUF, a novel algorithm designed to accelerate the traditional union-find (UF) decoder. NNUF leverages pre-computed nearest-neighbor information to form preliminary error clusters, which streamlines the subsequent decoding stages. We evaluated NNUF against standard benchmarks and demonstrated that it reduces the decoding time while maintaining the high error correction performance of the original UF decoder. Specifically, for large code distances where $d \geq 7$, our results reveal a speedup of up to $1.14 \times$ compared to a standard UF implementation. This establishes NNUF as a valuable tool for quantum systems requiring fast and reliable decoding, representing a practical step towards real-time error correction in large-scale quantum processors.

title: Learning quantum Gibbs states locally and efficiently
authors: Chi-Fang Chen, Anurag Anshu, Quynh T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Learning the Hamiltonian underlying a quantum many-body system in thermal equilibrium is a fundamental task in quantum learning theory and experimental sciences. To learn the Gibbs state of local Hamiltonians at any constant inverse temperature, the state-of-the-art provable algorithms fall short of the optimal sample and computational complexity, in sharp contrast with the locality and simplicity in the classical cases. In this work, we present a learning algorithm that learns each local term of a n-qubit Hamiltonian on any bounded-degree graph to a constant additive error with the optimal sample complexity $\mathcal{O}(\log n)$. The protocol uses parallelizable local quantum measurements that act within bounded neighborhoods of the graph and near-linear-time classical post-processing. We also give a learning algorithm for lattice Hamiltonians with near-optimal scaling on the learning precision and the inverse temperature. At the heart of our algorithm is the interplay between locality, the Kubo-MartinSchwinger condition, and the operator Fourier transform at arbitrary temperatures.

title: A Throughput-Enhanced Voltage-Domain Non-Volatile CIM Architecture with Pipelined Compute-Quantize Operation and Two-Step Sub-Ranging ADC
authors: Zhen Kong, Junjie He, Zhengke Yang, Xuye Wang, Haoran Lyu, Yiqing Lan, Yida Li, Longyang Lin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: Compute-in-memory (CIM) has emerged as a promising solution to the data-movement bottleneck of von Neumann architectures, and resistive non-volatile-memory–based CIM (nvCIM) has become particularly attractive for data-intensive neural inference thanks to its multi-level conductance states, high density, and negligible standby power. Building on these advantages, voltage-domain nvCIM further alleviates the IR-drop errors and static power issues inherent in current-domain designs, but its throughput remains fundamentally constrained by the bit-line (BL) settling time required to resolve small voltage differences. This paper presents a throughput-enhanced architecture for voltage-domain non-volatile CIM systems, which leverages a pipelined compute-quantize operation together with a two-step sub-ranging ADC to significantly reduce compute latency while preserving high output precision. Post-layout simulations of a 32-Kb RRAM CIM macro under 180nm process demonstrate a compute latency of 30 ns and a normalized throughput of 2.184 TOPS/bit at 1.8V, achieving a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.34 \times$</tex> overall throughput improvement over the convectional baseline. The proposed 6-bit two-step sub-ranging ADC further attains DNL <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$< \pm 0.6$</tex> LSB and INL <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$< \pm 0.4$</tex> LSB, confirming its suitability for accurate analog-MAC quantization.

title: A High-Voltage, High-Output-Current Rail-to-Rail Operational Amplifier with Integrated Protection Circuits
authors: Yong Guo, Weilin Xu, Mengru Chen, Baolin Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: In applications such as industrial controls, automotive electronics and power management, the power supply for high-voltage operational amplifiers often reaches <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 30 V$</tex>. Although high-voltage LDMOS devices can withstand drain-to-source voltages of several tens of volts, their gate-to-source voltage is typically limited to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 5 V$</tex>, which complicates the integration of on-chip digital logic. To address this issue, we have designed a high-voltage, high-output-current rail-to-rail power operational amplifier based on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> BCD process, incorporating an integrated protection circuit. Two internal low-voltage power rails are generated by a floating LDO structure to power the digital logic and protection circuitry, thereby resolving the LDMOS gate-source-voltage limitation and enabling full on-chip integration of logic and protection circuits. The amplifier supports rail-to-rail input and output across a wide supply range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 4 \mathrm{V}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 30 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, delivers up to 422 mA output current, and achieves low noise <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(13.46 \text{nV} / \sqrt{\text{Hz}}\ {@}\ 1\ \text{kHz})$</tex> and high slew rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\pm 50 \mathrm{V}/\mu \mathrm{s})$</tex>.
