title: Influence of digital marketing strategies and customer loyalty in an entertainment company in Trujillo
authors: Leidy Lucia Méndez-Gutiérrez, María Del Rosario Quichca-Vilchez, Joselling Milagros Navarrete-Rivasplata, Kevin Frederick Paredes-Olivera
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The objective of this study was to determine the relationship between digital marketing strategies and customer loyalty in an entertainment company in Trujillo in 2024. A questionnaire was administered to 371 customers of the entertainment company. The results showed a Spearman correlation coefficient of 0.824 and a bilateral significance of 0.000 (ρ < 0.05), indicating a strong direct correlation between digital marketing strategies and customer loyalty. Additionally, it was demonstrated that flow, functionality, and feedback are significantly related to customer loyalty, with coefficients of 0.692, 0.727, and 0.720 respectively, and a bilateral significance of 0.000 (ρ < 0.05). The study concluded that the correct and timely implementation of digital marketing strategies significantly enhances customer loyalty levels.

title: Interannual Dynamics of Thermal Conditions in the Kuril Islands Region And Changes in Sardine And Saury Aggregation Site Formation
authors: Zhanna Tskhay, Viktor Filatov
abstract: An analysis of sea surface temperature and the distribution of Pacific saury Cololabis saira and Far Eastern sardine Sardinops melanostictus fishing grounds in the northwestern Pacific Ocean was conducted for the period 2014-2024. The study revealed upward trends in mean monthly temperatures within the saury and sardine fishing zones, with the most pronounced warming occurring over the last three years. These temperature trends reflect shifts in current dynamics and water mass distribution, which have influenced the spatial patterns of saury and sardine aggregations. Notably, no overlapping schools of the two species were observed, contradicting the hypothesis that food competition displaced saury from their traditional feeding grounds near the southern Kuril Islands to areas off the northern Kuril Islands and the Aleutian gyre region.

title: Digitalisation in Reverse Logistics: Risk Strategies for Circular Supply Chains
authors: Aditya Pawar, Olumide Olajide Ojo, Syed Mehmood Hasan, Satya R Shah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The current research has focused on the analysis of the role of reverse logistics in supply chain management operations. Reverse logistics can be regarded as an essential process of supply chain management that is associated with the movement of goods from the customers to the sellers or the manufacturers. It is associated with the return and recycling of the products. It is an essential part of supply chain operations to maintain an efficient flow of goods that is also associated with the cost-saving, value creation, and risk mitigation of the companies associated with the supply chain operations. The study has focused on the analysis of the factors influencing the implementation of reverse logistics within a company, the current trends and technologies used in the reverse logistics process, the profitability aspect of this process to the company, and finally, finding the ways to improve the process.

title: Evaluating Deep Learning Architectures for Decision Support in Early CRC Detection
authors: Zaeem Memon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Existing colorectal cancer (CRC) detection practices have historically relied on manual examination and conventional imaging, hindered by subjectivity and variability. Recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), including convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformer-based models, have enhanced automated polyp detection, yet challenges such as variable polyp sizes, poor lighting, and noisy colonoscopy backgrounds persist. Early CRC detection is pivotal, significantly boosting survival rates and reducing the need for invasive treatments through prompt polyp identification and intervention. Accurate and efficient segmentation of colorectal polyps from colonoscopy images is essential for advancing CRC outcomes. We present an innovative DeepLabv3+ segmentation framework, integrating channel-spatial attention modules, attention gates, and cascaded dilated convolutions, complemented by a boundary-aware loss function. This architecture tackles the complexities of variable polyp sizes, suboptimal lighting, and background noise across public datasets: Kvasir-SEG, CVC-ClinicDB, and ETIS-Larib. Our model achieves Dice coefficients of 0.924, 0.912, and 0.881, respectively, surpassing or matching the outcomes of existing CNN and transformer-based approaches which are regarded as the standard in this use case. An ablation study confirms the efficacy of these components in enhancing segmentation performance. By enabling precise polyp delineation, this model supports early detection, equipping clinicians with actionable insights for confident decision-making. The model’s precise boundary accuracy strengthens intelligent decision-support systems, optimizing treatment strategies and elevating patient care.

title: Modification of the Inverse Dynamics Algorithm for an Underwater Multilink Manipulator
authors: Nikita Krasavin
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of improving the accuracy of solving of the underwater multilink manipulator inverse dynamics problem. The proposed modification of the algorithm accounts for the hydrodynamic interaction of the links in the incident fluid flow. The modification also considers that the drag forces depend not only on the velocities of the links but also on their mutual configuration. In particular, the influence of the wake generated by some links on others is taken into account. This is achieved through preliminary flow simulations of a manipulator link in SOLIDWORKS Flow Simulation at different velocities. The obtained experimental data are used to refine the velocities of the oncoming flow, which can also be influenced by underwater currents. The refinement is applied to those links that fall into the wake. Numerical simulations were performed to evaluate the implemented modification, using a Matlab/Simulink model of a multi-degree-of-freedom manipulator mounted on an unmanned underwater vehicle. The simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm modification in enhancing the accuracy of underwater manipulation tasks.

title: Non-Invasive Diagnosis of Huntington's Disease Through EEG Signal Interpretation and Deep Learning
authors: Madhumithra V S, Sanjeevi Sharma S, Sivarama Krishna M, Ramesh Munirathinam
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Huntington's disease (HD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by an abnormal expansion of CAG repeats in the HTT gene. It usually begins to show symptoms bewteen the ages of 30 and 50. Early detection is essential for timely intervention and improving patients outcomes. Despite being caused by genetics, the condition is hard to diagnose and monitor because symptom onset varies and clinical features often resemble those of other disorders. Epidemiological data indicate a global HD occurs at a rate of about 0.48 cases per 100,000 persons-years, with significantly higher prevalence observed in Europe and North America compared to Asia. Traditional diagnostic methods rely heavily on motor symptoms and genetic testing, often delaying intervention until the disease is advanced. This study leverages EEG signals and deep learning, Using the Lancaster university dataset comprising 69 participants across four groups such as symptomatic HD, Pre-symptomatic HD, and their respective controls. EEG signals were filtered using a band-pass filter to isolate specific frequency ranges and spectrograms were generated using S-transform. Squeezenet and Neural network architectures were applied for stage-wise classifications. Results show the highest classification accuracy of 89.9% in the Beta band at the P8 channel using the NN-T-S model.

title: Artificial Intelligence and Customer Experience: A Systematic Review Across Industries 2021 - 2025
authors: Leidy Lucia Méndez-Gutiérrez, Jorge Eugenio Espinoza-Castro, Edilson José Jiménez-Pachas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This systematic review synthesizes empirical evidence on how Artificial Intelligence (AI) shapes corporate customer experience (CX) across industries between 2021 and 2025. Following PRISMA procedures, we screened peer-reviewed studies indexed primarily in Scopus and complemented with reference chasing. Forty-one articles met the inclusion criteria. The synthesis indicates that AI augments CX through hyper-personalization, conversational interfaces chatbots and voice assistants, recommendation and prediction engines, and real-time analytics that orchestrate omnichannel journeys. Benefits cluster around higher satisfaction, trust, convenience, conversion, loyalty, and lower churn; yet outcomes depend on transparency, explainability, data quality, ethical safeguards, and cultural fit. Boundary conditions include sector banking, retail, hospitality, public services, task complexity, customer digital literacy, and perceived risk. We propose an integrative framework in which AI capability with perceived usefulness, personalization, effort reduction and CX outcomes, moderated by trust, privacy control, and service context. Managerial and policy implications and an agenda for future research are discussed.

title: Aggregator Scheduling and PV Utilization Optimization Strategies for Low-Density EV Regions
authors: Liangsong Guo, Jianguang Zhao, Xiaoan Zhang, Kaifeng Wang, Zhihui Meng, Yonglei Han, Feng Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Against the backdrop of rapid renewable energy development in China, photovoltaic (PV) integration in remote regions faces significant temporal mismatches and grid regulation challenges. This study focuses on low-density, widely distributed EV resources in the Hotan region of Xinjiang and proposes a hierarchical aggregation and robust scheduling approach. The model differentiates between two-/three-wheeler EVs with unidirectional charging and four-wheeler EVs with bidirectional V2G capability. By incorporating user charging behavior and geographic distribution characteristics, and introducing capacity commitments, penalty mechanisms, and user compensation, the framework maximizes aggregator profit. Through scenario generation and reduction, adaptive aggregation radius, and two-stage optimization, the approach effectively addresses the dispatchability of low-density, heterogeneous resources. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances dispatchable capacity and PV energy absorption during daytime PV peak periods while maintaining stable profits, providing a feasible pathway for renewable energy integration and EV resource aggregation in frontier regions.

title: A Source–Grid Coordinated Planning Model Integrating Grid Strength Constraints
authors: Xiaohu Zhang, Chao Sun, Ling Xu, Mengyao Zhang, Lu Liu, Haozhong Cheng
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address the challenges of applying the short-circuit ratio (SCR) metric and its critical threshold in receiver-end power system (RPS) planning, this study proposes a source–grid coordinated planning that integrates equivalent short-circuit ratio (ESCR) constraints. Initially, an equivalent network impedance model incorporating transmission line decision variables is constructed, enabling the derivation of a reduced-order equivalent nodal model. On the basis, a critical equivalent short-circuit ratio (CESCR) model is formulated by analyzing the coupling relationships among nodal voltages and reactive sensitivity factors. Subsequently, a bi-level coupled planning framework is proposed, embedding the ESCR constraints within the source–grid coordination process. Finally, the validity of the ESCR and CESCR models is assessed, and the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed planning framework are demonstrated through case studies on the IEEE RTS-79 system.

title: Multi-electrode suction cup based probe with surgical margin visualization for minimally invasive surgery
authors: Jing Guo, Feng Xue, Zexuan Lin, Min He, Xiaobing Jiang, Zhuoqi Cheng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: In cancer surgery, accurately assessing surgical margins is critical for reducing the risk of tumor recurrence and ensuring complete resection. Intraoperative margin detection plays an important role, particularly in the context of minimally invasive surgery (MIS), where visualization and access are inherently constrained. Current methods, such as frozen section analysis and imaging modalities like fluorescence and optical coherence tomography, face limitations including time inefficiency, limited spatial resolution, and difficulty in integrating seamlessly with MIS workflows. To address these challenges, this study proposes a sensing probe aiming for non-invasive, real-time and onsite margin detection. Based on the electrical bioimpedance (EBI) modality, the proposed probe is designed as a multi-electrodes embedded suction cup, which ensures reliable electrodes-tissue contact and reduces the influence caused by superficial body fluids. Algorithm based on tetrapolar configuration and the Fresnel equation is also developed for calculating tissue resistivity and margin visualization. Experiments based on simulations, standard salines, and ex vivo animal tissues are conducted and demonstrate the high accuracy and strong noise resistance of the designed probe. Additionally, a pre-clinical study on ex vivo human brain tissues shows the system’s great potential for neurosurgical margin detection between glioma and healthy tissue.

title: AgriBot: A Hexapod-Based Autonomous Robot for Precision Agriculture and Sustainable Farming
authors: Suhas Bhise, Sarthak Sujitkumar Deshmukh, Atharv Chougule, Shreyas Dambalkar, Harshavardhan Desai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The need for automating agriculture has fueled a progress of intelligent robotics applications focused on streamlining repetitive and laborious work. In this paper, the authors describe AgriBot," a novel agricultural robot that is capable for automated driving and multiapplication in agriculture. The robot utilizes servo hexapod motion and ultrasonic and flame sensors to detect obstacles and monitor fire for ensuring safety and operational efficacy of the robotpolypedal robot in the agricultural fields. The hardware of the AgriBot comprise of 18 servos and maintains stable movement even on rough muddy lands, similar to the farming areas. The predefined motions such as forward, back and turning make the work be done effectively. The 15 cm ultrasonic sensor monitors obstacles causing the flight system to take corrective measures to avoid a collision and the flame sensor enables instantaneous fire detection to minimise crop damage. The robot is programmed with an Arduino microcontroller board and has a Python based Flask application that allows remote controlling via an HTML page. Commands can be invoked by users directly or by using a chatbot to send natural language commands, which makes it easier for non technical users to use the tool. Furthermore, the live video feed from the built-in IP camera enables real-time monitoring for high accuracy operations, such as crop inspection and irrigation scheduling. AgriBot is an affordable alternative for weed eradication, soil health monitoring, and early fire alerts. It is also a modular framework for future integration of ML algorithms for crop condition analysis and data-driven agriculture advice. The study demonstrates AgriBot's capability to increase productivity, save labor, and promote sustainable agriculture, connecting rural agriculture with automation machinery.

title: A Resilient Federated Learning Framework for Privacy-Preserving Smart Cities
authors: Arvinder Singh, Pardeep Kaur, Kanika Manchanda, Jagvinder Singh, Anika Garag
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The rapid evolution of smart cities has created a highly interconnected digital ecosystem where millions of Internets of Things (IoT) devices generate vast quantities of sensitive, high-dimensional data. Harnessing this data through machine learning enables intelligent decision-making in domains such as transportation, healthcare, and environmental monitoring. However, traditional centralized machine learning approaches are increasingly unsuitable for these environments due to the dual challenges of data privacy regulations and system scalability. While federated learning (FL) offers a decentralized alternative, conventional implementations often struggle with non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, high communication overhead, heterogeneous resource availability, and susceptibility to adversarial manipulation. This paper introduces a Resilient Federated Learning Framework specifically designed for privacy-preserving smart city infrastructures. The proposed framework integrates four complementary mechanisms: differential privacy to protect local updates, secure aggregation to guarantee encrypted communication, adaptive client participation to balance load across heterogeneous devices, and Byzantine-resilient filtering to defend against poisoning and inference attacks. Together, these modules establish a secure and scalable pipeline that ensures compliance with stringent data protection regulations while maintaining learning efficiency. The framework is experimentally validated using three real-world datasets MIMIC-III for healthcare, municipal traffic flow records for transportation, and the UCI Air Quality dataset for environmental monitoring on a GPU enabled federated testbed with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> simulated clients. Results demonstrate that the proposed design achieves a 32 % reduction in communication overhead relative to baseline FedAvg, accelerates convergence by 12 %, and maintains over 90 % of model accuracy even with 15 % of clients acting maliciously. Privacy-utility trade-off analysis further confirms that meaningful privacy guarantees (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon=1, \delta=10^{-5}$</tex>) can be achieved with less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 \%}$</tex> accuracy loss.

title: ‘DAANSETU’ a Machine Learning-Based Platform for Enhancing NGO-Donor Interactions
authors: Lalit Patil, Dipali Himmatrao Patil, Pankaj Hadole, Siddhi Pokale, Swaraj Deshpande, Archana Jadhav
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Surplus food, clothing, medicines, and educational materials are frequently discarded while millions lack access to them. Existing donation channels are fragmented and inefficient, resulting in low resource utilization and reduced social impact. DAANSETU is an end-to-end digital platform that connects donors with verified NGOs in real time using structured workflows, real-time monitoring, and predictive analytics. The platform supports multiple donation categories, including food relief, apparel, medical supplies, study materials, and disaster-relief items. By centralizing donation management, applying machine learning for demand forecasting and matching, and providing end-to-end traceability, DAANSETU reduces wastage, improves allocation efficiency, and strengthens accountability in the donation process.

title: EEG-Powered Brain-Computer Interface for 3D Hand Gesture Control
authors: Ketaki Dabade, Lavanya Singh, Saurabh Advani, Manav Chandak, Abhishek Chunawale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: EEG is widely used in Brain Computer Interfacing (BCI) applications. This work aims to develop an EEG-powered BCI model that translates neural signals associated with hand movements into control mechanisms for a 3D hand model simulation. This study focuses on developing a simulation environment where the 3D hand model reacts to cognitive commands based on pre-processed EEG data. The Emotiv EEG headset is used by the system to record raw brainwave data, with a special emphasis on motor imagery signals associated with hand movements. Nine volunteers, aged 20 to 22 years, had their brain waves captured using Emotiv EPOC X 14 channel EEG headset. Four different hand gestures—fist open, fist close, index and victory—were considered. A full processing pipeline was implemented, which included data collection, preprocessing, feature extraction and model creation for accurate classification. The EEG data was then mapped to a 3D hand model in Blender tool to simulate movement. The classification of EEG-based motor imagery gestures was done using Multilayer Perceptron that achieved a test accuracy of approximately 96.6 % and the KNN classifier that reached 97.63 % cross-validation accuracy, outperforming other traditional models. Future work will focus on real-time processing and implementation, integrating mechanical and robotic components for practical applications. By providing an intuitive, hands-free method for controlling virtual systems through cognitive commands, the project demonstrates the feasibility of BCI technologies in enhancing user interaction with digital environments.

title: Faster Mixing of the Jerrum-Sinclair Chain
authors: Xiaoyu Chen, Weiming Feng, Zhe Ju, Tianshun Miao, Yitong Yin, Xinyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We show that the Jerrum-Sinclair Markov chain on matchings mixes in time $\widetilde{O}\left(\Delta^{2} m\right)$ on any graph with n vertices, m edges, and maximum degree $\Delta$, for any constant edge weight $\lambda\gt 0$. For general graphs with arbitrary, potentially unbounded $\Delta$, this provides the first improvement over the classic $\widetilde{O}\left(n^{2} m\right)$ mixing time bound of Jerrum and Sinclair (1989) and Sinclair (1992). To achieve this, we develop a general framework for analyzing mixing times, combining ideas from the classic canonical path method with the “local-to-global” approaches recently developed in high-dimensional expanders, introducing key innovations to both techniques.

title: Breaking a Long-Standing Barrier: 2-ε Approximation for Steiner Forest
authors: Ali Ahmadi, Iman Gholami, MohammadTaghi Hajiaghayi, Peyman Jabbarzade, Mohammad Mahdavi
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: The Steiner Forest problem, also known as the Generalized Steiner Tree problem, is a fundamental optimization problem on edge-weighted graphs where, given a set of vertex pairs, the goal is to select a minimum-cost subgraph such that each pair is connected. This problem generalizes the Steiner Tree problem, first introduced in 1811, for which the best known approximation factor is 1.39 by [Byrka, Grandoni, Rothvoβ, and Sanità, 2010]. The celebrated work of [Agrawal, Klein, and Ravi, 1989], along with refinements by [Goemans and Williamson, 1992], established a 2-approximation for Steiner Forest over 35 years ago. Pioneering iterative rounding techniques by [Jain, 1998] later extended these results to higher connectivity settings. Despite the long-standing importance of this problem, breaking the approximation factor of 2 has remained a major challenge, raising suspicions that achieving a better factor might indeed be hard. In this paper, we break the approximation barrier of 2 by designing a novel deterministic algorithm that achieves a $\mathbf{2} \mathbf{- 1 0}^{\mathbf{- 1 1}}$ approximation for this fundamental problem. As a key component of our approach, we also introduce a novel dual-based local search algorithm for the Steiner Tree problem with an approximation guarantee of 1.943, which is of independent interest.

title: Modular NAS Protocol Design for 6G
authors: Devaki Chandramouli, Martin McGrath, Peter Leis, Rainer Liebhart, Jari Mutikainen, Josep Colom Ikuno, Markus Amend, Christopher Joul, DongJin Lee
abstract: 6G aims to provide significant advantages compared to 5G while being designed to be energy-efficient and quantum-safe from the start. Goals for 6G include superior radio performance, ubiquitous connectivity using Satellite (Non-Terrestrial Networks, NTN) and Wi-Fi, native artificial intelligence (AI) support, a modular design enabling delivery of new features in a modular manner and scalable networks for diverse device types. In this paper, we present a modular Non-Access Stratum (NAS) approach allowing new NAS features to be upgraded and deployable without impacting other NAS features that are already deployed. We include a high-level view of the 6G System architecture, and a detailed view of modular NAS protocol stack, including NAS message routing, User equipment (UE) identifiers and NAS security architecture. We conclude with an outlook for future work.

title: DeepRS: LLM-Driven Deep Reasoning for Multi-Granularity Remote Sensing Scene Interpretation
authors: Cheng Yang, Jia Zhang, Qiujun Li, Wang Guo, Haifeng Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have achieved remarkable results in remote sensing scene interpretation. However, existing models primarily rely on a single-step reasoning paradigm, which suffers from Incomplete Perception and Granularity Limitation when confronting complex tasks requiring comprehensive, multi-granularity visual contexts. To overcome these bottlenecks, we propose DeepRS, a training-free, LLM-driven Deep Reasoning Framework. This framework leverages the logical planning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) to restructure the reasoning process into a hierarchical, iterative Reason-Observe-Re-reason cycle. Specifically, we construct a dynamic reasoning tree where the LLM recursively decomposes the problem into fine-grained queries, actively guiding the perception module to mine visual clues. Subsequently, a multistage reflection mechanism consolidates these multi-level contexts to derive the final conclusion. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DeepRS significantly outperforms both single-VLM baselines and collaborative baselines in accuracy and robustness. Furthermore, our framework generates clear, traceable reasoning paths, substantially enhancing interpretability in complex remote sensing scenarios.

title: Multi-Scale Attention and Adaptive Loss for Blood Cell Detection
authors: Chenyu Wang, Jing Tang, Longjun Wu, Yuhan Xie
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: To address the detection challenges caused by the significant scale variations, dense distribution, and complex background of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in blood cell images, This paper presents an enhanced version of the YOLOv11s model by integrating a Multi-Scale Attention Aggregation (MSAA) module and an Adaptive Threshold Focal Loss (ATFL) function. To alleviate the original model's shortcomings in multi-scale feature fusion and hard sample learning, MSAA module and ATFL function are incorporated. The MSAA module enhances multi-scale spatial feature representation and channel-wise information fusion through parallel spatial refinement and channel aggregation paths. Meanwhile, the ATFL adaptively adjusts the weights of hard samples, improving the model's ability to distinguish overlapping and morphologically abnormal cells. Experimental results on a blood cell detection dataset show that the improved model achieves mAP50 and mAP50:95 scores of 95.5% and 69.9%, respectively, representing improvements of 1.6% and 1.5% over the original YOLOv11s. Visualization results further confirm the higher detection accuracy and robustness of the proposed method in complex cell scenarios.

title: FOOOF-Based EEG Spectral Parameterization for Automated Consciousness Assessment
authors: Pengyu Wang, Fei Wang, Yongkun Guo, Rui Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Assessment of consciousness levels in patients with prolonged disorders of consciousness (pDOC) is a critical step in clinical management. Traditional behavior-based scales (e.g., Coma Recovery Scale–Revised(CRS-R)) are highly subjective, creating an urgent need for objective, automated, and intelligent assessment methods. Resting-state electroencephalography (EEG) provides rich neural information but conventional power spectral density (PSD) methods fail to dissociate periodic from aperiodic activity.This study employed the Fitting Oscillations and One-Over-F (FOOOF) method to parameterize EEG spectra from 135 pDOC patients, extracting TotalPower, PeriodicPower, AperiodicPower, offset, and exponent. Four analyses were conducted: (1) correlation between EEG features and CRS-R scores; (2) group comparisons between vegetative state (VS) and minimally conscious state (MCS); (3) classification of consciousness states using support vector machine (SVM) models; and (4) prediction of CRS-R scores using ridge regression models.Results consistently demonstrated that AperiodicPower outperformed traditional spectral features across all tasks, exhibiting stronger correlations, better group separation, higher classification accuracy, and lower regression errors. These findings establish AperiodicPower as a robust biomarker and highlight its potential as a core feature for intelligent diagnostic systems.By embedding FOOOF-derived features into automated monitoring and decision-support platforms, this study lays the foundation for smart healthcare solutions such as real-time patient tracking, closed-loop rehabilitation robotics, and adaptive neuromodulation.The proposed framework not only advances EEG-based biomarker research but also provides methodological contributions to the development of automatic disease diagnosis systems in clinical neuroscience.

title: Transfer Learning for LiDAR-based Roadside 3D Object Detection by Leveraging Multi-Source Vehicle-Side Detectors
authors: Atong Luo, Chin Long NG, Yafei Wang, Bowen Wang, Jiaming Sun, Zexing Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Vehicle-infrastructure cooperation, as a crucial development direction for future intelligent transportation and autonomous driving systems, demonstrates significant potential for roadside perception systems in expanding sensing coverage and enhancing robustness. However, the high annotation costs of quality 3D point cloud data, coupled with substantial differences in sensing perspectives, static backgrounds, and scene feature distributions across various road segments, make it challenging to directly apply detection models trained on specific scenarios to other roadside environments. This study proposes a pre-training method with multi-source vehicle data. Through our designed Multi-source Shared Domain Enhancement Learning strategy, we integrate rich object semantic features from diverse vehicle-mounted datasets to strengthen the generalization capability of source domain branches for roadside scenarios. Experimental results on large-scale public vehicle-roadside datasets show that without requiring target domain annotations, our method achieves 14.73% improvement in AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BEV</inf> detection accuracy for the most adaptable source domain branch compared to the best-performing single source domain model.

title: CRAR: Coherent Risk-Aware Regulation for DRL-Based Mapless Robot Navigation
authors: Shaojie Jian, Changyun Wei, Shunyu Tian, Xiangyu Wu, Ze Ji
abstract: Navigating without prior maps poses significant challenges for robots, especially in complex environments populated with pedestrians and obstacles. In such settings, achieving a balance between safety, socially compliant behavior, and path efficiency is critical. To address this, we propose a novel deep reinforcement learning-based approach, termed Coherent Risk-Aware Regulation (CRAR), tailored for Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs). Our method incorporates a risk prediction network that enables the robot to anticipate potential hazards arising from pedestrians or obstacles. Furthermore, by integrating risk assessment and correction mechanisms, CRAR facilitates rapid learning of avoidance strategies, thereby reducing training duration. Consequently, the robot can identify navigation paths that are both safer and more efficient. Simulation results demonstrate that, in open environments, CRAR achieves an average success rate improvement of 25.33% and reduces navigation time by 10.85% compared to baseline methods. In dense environments, these benefits are amplified, with a success rate increase of 30.46% and a navigation time reduction of 21.75%. Additionally, CRAR ensures greater safety margins from obstacles and smoother trajectories, underscoring its efficacy in navigating dense and dynamic settings. Finally, we validate the performance and practicality of the proposed method through real-world experiments. A video demo is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://youtu.be/j0-pEd7_gr8</uri>.

title: Human-Agent Collaborative Wargame Decision-Making Via Reinforcement Learning
authors: Sirui Li, Xuan Yang, Zizhuo Xuan, Xianzhong Zhou, Liang Geng, Yuxiang Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This study proposes a reinforcement learning-based framework for human-agent collaborative wargame decisionmaking. A cooperative system integrating human decisionmakers and Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (MAPPO) agents is constructed on a wargame simulation platform. A task allocation mechanism based on initial battlefield situational awareness is designed, accompanied by a multidimensional evaluation system encompassing operational effectiveness assessment, risk prediction, and decision robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed human-agent collaborative strategy significantly outperforms pure AI adversarial baselines in core metrics such as mission completion rate and decision quality index, validating the efficacy of the framework. This work establishes a novel methodological paradigm for intelligent decisionmaking in deterministic battlefield environments. Future research will focus on multimodal situational representation learning, generalization capability optimization of allocation strategies, and fault-tolerant mechanisms for adversarial environments, aiming to enhance the adaptability of collaborative systems.

title: A Differential Game Approach to Collision-Aware Multi-Agent Target Defense in 3D UAV Systems
authors: Vijaysubramanian S., Yalla Ananda Kumar, Sharad Kumar Singh
abstract: This paper presents a differential game-based framework for defending a stationary target in three-dimensional (3D) space using autonomous unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The scenario involves a single attacker attempting to reach the target while multiple defenders coordinate to intercept it. Each agent is modeled using position-level single-integrator dynamics for high-level control design. The interaction is cast as a continuous-time zero-sum game with a quadratic cost functional, where optimal strategies are derived using a time-varying Riccati differential equation. To ensure safe coordination during close-proximity operations, collision avoidance is incorporated via repulsion-based augmentation of defender controls. Furthermore, the high-level control inputs are tracked using a low-level proportional-derivative (PD) controller within a realistic 6-DOF UAV dynamic model implemented in Simulink. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in achieving successful interception while maintaining defender safety and realistic trajectory tracking.

title: Analytical Derivation of the Permissible Initial Position Error Region of a Cylindrical Part for Grasping with a Rotary Chuck-type Three-Fingered Hand
authors: Yoshinori Takahashi, Hiroki Dobashi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: In jig-less robotic assembly of industrial products, the initial pose (position and orientation) of each supplied part may be uncertain, and thus it is necessary to know how large uncertainty can be absorbed for ensuring an accurate grasp toward assembly. In this paper, focusing on the initial position of a cylindrical part, which is commonly handled in assembly tasks, we discuss analytical derivation of its permissible initial position error region (PIPER), which represents absorbable uncertainty in the part’s initial position through the grasping process with a rotary chuck-type three-fingered hand.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning based Control Design for Aircraft Recovery from Loss-of-Control Scenario
authors: Imran Sayyed, Aayush Konar, Nandan Kumar Sinha
abstract: Loss-of-control (LOC) remains a leading cause of fixed-wing aircraft accidents, especially in post-stall and flat-spin regimes where conventional gain-scheduled or logic-based recovery laws may fail. This study formulates spin-recovery as a continuous-state, continuous-action Markov Decision Process and trains a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) agent on a high-fidelity six-degree-of-freedom F-18/HARV model that includes nonlinear aerodynamics, actuator saturation and rate coupling. A two-phase potential-based reward structure first penalizes large angular rates and then enforces trimmed flight. After 6,000 simulated episodes, the policy generalities to unseen upset initializations. Results show that the learned policy successfully arrests the angular rates and stabilizes the angle of attack. The controller performance is observed to be satisfactory for recovery from spin condition which was compared with a state-of-the-art sliding mode controller. The findings demonstrate that deep reinforcement learning can deliver interpretable, dynamically feasible manoeuvres for real-time loss of control mitigation and provide a pathway for flight-critical RL deployment.

title: Rapid Fault Detection Strategy for Synchronous Generators Connected to The Power Grid
authors: Alireza Nezamzadeh, Mohammadreza Esmaeilidehkordi
abstract: Reliable and fast detection of small actuator faults in synchronous generators (SGs) is challenging: the signatures are weak, transients are short, and high sensitivity often amplifies noise. We present a bank of adaptive extended state observers (AESOs) that produces mode-discriminative residuals for healthy and faulty dynamics, paired with a principled moving-window L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf> decision test. The observers lump modeling error and fault effects into an extended state while using error-driven, nonlinear gains to boost sensitivity only when needed, thus avoiding noise blow-up near the origin. Under mild boundedness assumptions, the estimation error admits a Lyapunov-style negative semi-definite bound, ensuring practical stability of the adaptive scheme. On standard SG (SMIB) simulations with multiplicative actuator loss (u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">faulty</inf> = q u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">healthy</inf>), the method consistently reduces detection delay and estimation error versus high-gain and conventional ESOs; faults are flagged within ≈0.5 s of onset in representative tests (e.g., t<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> ∈ [0.52, 0.58] s), while maintaining smooth residuals that curb false alarms. The design is modular (drop-in before existing controllers), requires no plant re-identification, and comes with practical tuning rules for window length, gains, and thresholds—making it directly applicable to protection and condition-monitoring layers in grid-connected SGs.

title: Edge-Aware Dual-Stream Dynamic Fusion Network for Building Extraction in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Yangyang Li, Xiang Zheng, Zhenghong Gao, Ronghua Shang, Licheng Jiao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The extraction of buildings from high-resolution remote sensing images faces significant challenges due to complex urban scenes, including spectral ambiguities, geometric diversity, and boundary uncertainties. Despite progress in deep learning-based methods, buildings' varied shapes and sizes complicate edge extraction, making it difficult for existing approaches to balance the global context with local details and leverage edge priors effectively, especially for adjacent buildings. In response to these issues, we propose an edge-aware dual-stream dynamic fusion network called EA-DSFNet. It follows the encoder-decoder paradigm, where the encoding component utilizes a dual-path setup integrating convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Transformer modules. First, we design a feature reuse and fusion (FRF) module that dynamically integrates local information extracted by the CNN with global contextual features extracted by the Transformer at the encoder stage to achieve a comprehensive multi-scale feature representation. Second, a feature selection gate (FSG) is developed to adaptively emphasize discriminative features during cross-branch fusion while suppressing redundant information. Aiming to improve the model's utilization of building edge information, the decoder network introduces a multitask edge-directed decoder (MTEDD). This architecture optimizes edge extraction and segmentation tasks jointly through hierarchical supervision, enabling the decoder to fully assimilate edge information. Additionally, the foreground and background enhancement module (FBEM) explicitly utilizes geometric priors to guide segmentation, thereby improving the boundary accuracy of the segmentation results. We perform extensive testing across three standard reference datasets to assess the performance of our method. The experimental results demonstrate that EA-DSFNet surpasses current leading techniques in segmentation.

title: An Efficient Fast Beamforming Algorithm for Sidelobe Suppression and Gain Loss Limitation
authors: Xiaoyu Yao, Quan Gao, Zhanwen Wang, Li Wei, Lan Lan, Wei E. I. Sha
abstract: This work investigates a deterministic transmit beamforming algorithm for sidelobe suppression under a predefined mainlobe gain loss. By enforcing the unit-norm constraint via the Lagrange multiplier method, the problem is formulated as a quadratic eigenvalue problem that yields a numerical solution without iterative optimization. The algorithm also supports asymmetric sidelobe control and null steering, offering flexible beampattern shaping. Simulation results under various gain loss constraints demonstrate that the proposed method achieves up to 28.70% relative reduction in the sidelobe power compared with classical tapering window functions and 16.13% compared with gradient-based algorithms, while achieving comparable peak sidelobe levels.

title:
S
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    -DETR: Hierarchical Sparse-to-Spatial Attention Enhanced DETR for Traffic Participant Detection in Sparse Autonomous Driving Scene
authors: Zhenbo Zhang, Zhiguo Feng, Aiqi Long, Zhiyu Wang, Xingqiang Tian, Wei Xiang, Zhenyin Tu
abstract: Multi-scale detection is vital for autonomous driving. In sparse scenarios such as highways, where targets often appear small, distant, and susceptible to substantial background interference, traditional models suffer from feature distortion, leading to missed detections and compromised safety. This study proposes S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-DETR to address these challenges, featuring an innovative hierarchical Sparse-to-Spatial Attention Mechanism (S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>AM), which synergistically integrates a Dynamic Sparse Attention Module (DSAM) for coarse-grained sparse feature enhancement with a Spatial Attention Module (SAM) for fine-grained refinement. This design is particularly effective for enhancing the representation of small and hard-to-detect targets in complex visual environments. We further designed a Cross-scale Attention Pyramid Module (CAPM) that embeds S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>AM within a dual-path architecture inspired by Feature Pyramid Networks and Path Aggregation Networks, replacing RT-DETR’s original fusion module to optimize multi-scale feature representation. Extensive ablation studies validated our S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>AM and CAPM designs. Comparative experiments confirmed S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-DETR’s superiority: on public and self-built sparse datasets, it achieved accuracy improvements of 8.7% and 14.1%, respectively, over its RT-DETR baseline, with only a 7.5% speed trade-off. These results establish an improved accuracy-speed balance, notably for challenging small and multi-scale targets. The source code will be released on GitHub to foster further research in traffic participant detection for autonomous driving.

title: Tracking Fast by Learning from Slow: An Event-based Hand Tracker Leveraging Knowledge in RGB Domain
authors: Chuanlin Lan, Ziyuan Yin, Arindam Basu, Rosa H. M. Chan
abstract: Event cameras offer micro-second temporal resolution and thus excel in fast-hand-tracking scenarios where conventional RGB cameras suffer from motion-blur artifacts. However, the scarcity of annotated datasets for fast hand motion limits the development of learning-based event solutions. To overcome this data-shortage problem, we propose a unified framework that leverages knowledge distillation and transfer learning. We first release a real-world multimodal dataset with synchronized event and RGB streams. Our framework then employs two key strategies: (i) cross-modal knowledge distillation that trains an event-based student network using reliable RGB predictions on slow-motion sequences, and (ii) domain adaptation that transfers the learned features from slow to fast motion. Experiments on our fast-motion benchmark show improvements over both RGB-based and previous event-based approaches in fast hand tracking tasks. Beyond hand tracking, the proposed slow-to-fast distillation paradigm offers a generic pathway for dynamic-vision tasks that lack high-speed annotations. Code and dataset will be made publicly available

title: Forecasting Population Trends and Socioeconomic Impacts in Asian Tiger Economies Using Stochastic and Machine Learning Models
authors: King For On, Kong Sing Hu, Chun Hin Liu, Aquil Mirza Mohammed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: The Four Asian Tigers—Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan—experienced rapid industrialization from the 1950s to the 1990s, with annual growth rates exceeding 7 %, driven by economic development and urbanization. Despite extensive historical research, existing demographic models lack accuracy in projecting future population trajectories under dynamic social and policy environments, creating a gap for sustainable urban planning. This study introduces a novel, AI-driven framework that leverages forecasting models, sensitivity analysis, and stochastic simulations implemented via Python to analyze historical demographic data and generate future projections. The results identify key demographic patterns, including aging populations, declining fertility rates, and the influence of socioeconomic factors. These findings provide actionable insights for policymakers and urban planners to optimize infrastructure, resource allocation, and social services. The primary contribution of this work is advancing demographic modeling through the integration of AI techniques, offering a practical and adaptable tool for guiding long-term urban sustainability in these rapidly evolving economies. This research not only fills a critical gap in demographic forecasting but also demonstrates the potential of AI applications in urban and social policy development.

title: Black Start of the Islanded Microgrid with Grid-forming PMSG-based Wind Turbines As Main Power Sources
authors: Jingqian Hao, Yue Ding, Heng Lin, Kangfa He, Yiyang Cai, Shun Sang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: With the widespread application of distributed energy, the Grid-forming (GFM) control technology for islanded microgrids has garnered increasing attention. Traditional control strategies for islanded microgrids primarily rely on distributed energy sources with stable input power. Additionally, conventional black-start schemes often require large-capacity energy storage devices, resulting in poor system economy and limiting their practical application and promotion. To address those issues, this paper proposes a novel GFM strategy for islanded microgrids, which uses permanent magnetic synchronous generator (PMSG)-based wind turbines (WTs) as the main power sources. The droop control structure between the output power of the machine-side converter (MSC) and the DC voltage is presented, allowing multiple WTs to automatically allocate load capacity based on the droop coefficient. Moreover, the frequency of the microgrid bus can be automatically adjusted with changes of load capacity, enabling the WTs to perform primary frequency regulation in the microgrid. Based on the PSCAD/EMTDC simulation platform, the proposed control strategy is validated.

title: HDFE-net: A Novel Approach for Medical Skeletal Point Cloud Registration
authors: Jing Guo, Wenlin Huang, Yang Zhou, Peng Chen, Zhantian An
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Deep learning-based point cloud registration models like GeoTransformer advance bone surgical navigation but face challenges like the efficiency-accuracy trade-off. We propose HDFE-Net, a hierarchical dynamic feature-enhanced framework, to address this. On 3DMatch and ModelNet benchmarks, HDFE-Net achieves competitive results,, surpassing GeoTransformer in key metrics. Notably, in femoral registration, it achieves an average rotational error of 0.741° and a translational error of 2.165 mm. Compared to traditional methods, HDFE-Net significantly boosts inference speed while maintaining high, millimeter-level accuracy.

title: Retraction Notice: Prevention of Rushing Attack in AOMDV using Random Route Selection Technique in Mobile Ad-hoc Network
authors: Hussein Abdumalik Ibrahim, B.Barani Sundaram, Asedo Shektofik Ahmed, P. Karthika
publish: 2021 5th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Ad Hoc Network is wireless networks that get more attention from past to present. Mobile ad hoc network (MANET) is one of the types of ad hoc networks, it deployed rapidly because it infrastructure-less. A node in a mobile ad hoc network communicates through wireless links without wired channels. When source nodes want to communicate with the destination outside its transmission range it uses multi-hop mechanisms. The intermediate node forwards the data packet to the next node until the data packet reaches its destination. Due wireless links and lack of centralized administration device, mobile ad hoc network is more vulnerable for security attacks. The rushing attack is one of the most dangerous attacks in the on-demand routing protocol of mobile ad hoc networks. Rushing attack highly transmits route request with higher transmission power than the genuine nodes and become participate between source and destination nodes, after that, it delays or drop actual data pass through it. In this study, the researcher incorporates rushing attack in one of the most commonly used mobile ad hoc network routing protocols namely Ad hoc on-demand multipath distance vector and provides a rushing attack prevention method based on the time threshold value and random route selection. Based on the time RREQ arrives a node takes a decision, if the RREQ packet arrives before threshold value, the RREQ packet consider as came from an attacker and discarded else RREQ packet received then randomly select RREQ to forward. In this study performance metrics like packet delivery ratio, end-to-end delay and throughput have been evaluated using Network simulation (NS-2.35). As a result of simulation shows newly proposed prevention mechanism improves network performance in all cases than the network under attacker. For example, the average packet del

title: Retraction Notice: Advancements in Cloud-Based Solution for Medical Imaging: A Survey
authors: Priyang Patel, Dipak Ramoliya, Mahir Thumaar, Amit Nayak
publish: 2021 5th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Through the growing use of electronic health record systems around the world, as well as the rich mix of multimedia included in the EHR, and the increasing level of detail due to advances in medical imaging, an ever-increasing amount of data for individual patients can be stored. Cloud computing technologies, that are already constantly emerging, have shown to be an impactful strategy for developing cost-efficient, high-performance, adaptable, and resourceful local medical imaging services. The paper started by inspecting the qualities of cloud computing and characterizing clinical imaging. The pertinence of cloud computing in clinical imaging was likewise featured in the article. Further, the article features Picture documenting and correspondence frameworks (PACS) just as the effect and benefits of cloud computing in the area of research. At last, there are moral and security worries with getting to information by means of a cloud arrangement.

title: Retraction Notice: A Robust medical data sharing application with a collaborative hypothesis and Elastic net regression model
authors: J.N.S.S Janardhana Naidu, E.N Ganesh, Nagaraj Doddam Reddy, Mahesh Sankaran
publish: 2021 5th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Clinical data and records are the main data to help various customized applications like clinical proof, protection, digital data and criminal personality. Different blockchain and conventional methodology have been created, which are obsolete in this example. Progressed clinical information imparting to security and protection are along these lines required in saving related procedures. This study develops an adaptive blockchain approach and a machine-learning model based on elastic net regression. The preceding two ways give the classified data of brain cancer in the general hospital of Sowjanya greater safety and privacy. This is better than previous mechanisms, with precision 98.56%, detection rate 97.34%, error rate 0.023, sensitivity 98.38% and output 97.28% competing with existing approaches.

title: Multi-objective Optimization of Energy Hubs and Pareto Front Decision Making Using Large Language Models
authors: Ali. Darvishi, Mohammad Reza Mansouri, Amir Reza Setayesh Matin, Reza Gharibi, Rahman Dashti
abstract: Energy hub optimization depends on compromises between multiple conflicting objectives. The result of this process is not a unique solution, but a set of optimal solutions constituting the Pareto front. The next step is to choose the best solution from the available optimal points. The most effective approach can differ according to the conditions and preferences. In this paper, a large language model (LLM) is used to select the most efficient approach in the Pareto front. LLMs, due to their ability to understand human language, can take into account existing conditions and preferences. This capability allows LLMs to be employed in decision-making to select the best approach without the need for mathematical or formulaic complexities. To evaluate the performance of the LLM, an energy hub was optimized, and its Pareto front was provided to the model. The LLM selected the best solution based on user preferences and conditions. The results were compared with the fuzzy satisfaction method, demonstrating flexible and effective decision-making.

title: Combining Variable Admittance with Finite-Time Sliding Mode Control for a Pediatric Gait Exoskeleton: A Human-in-the-Loop Framework
authors: Sushant Kumar, Jyotindra Narayan, Krishna Prakash, Santosha K. Dwivedy
abstract: Lower-limb exoskeletons offer effective active-assist solutions for rehabilitating individuals with gait and mobility impairments. This study proposed a human-in-the-loop control framework for a 3-DOF unilateral exoskeleton for the active assistance of a pediatric gait. The proposed HIL strategy incorporates the variable admittance control in the outer loop and non-singular terminal sliding mode (NSTSM) in the inner loop to enhance the trajectory tracking and offer safety and flexibility to the user. The variable admittance control modulates the admittance parameters of the exoskeleton using a simple adaptive law based on the human-exoskeleton interaction, while the NSTSM control provides a robust and accurate gait tracking at different walking speeds. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the HIL framework with variable admittance control effectively improves the safety and flexibility for pediatric users under human-exoskeleton interaction compared to the HIL framework with fixed admittance control. The fixed admittance parameters of stiffness (100 Nm/rad) and damping (2 Nms/rad) appear misestimated, as compliance modulation suggests varying parameters (65–95 Nm/rad and 1.8–2.7 Nms/rad) for improved adaptability to interactions.

title: Blockchain-Enabled and Multiple Linear Regression-Assisted Energy Trading Framework for Electric Vehicles in Next-Generation Smart Grids
authors: Hossein Shahinzadeh, Zahra Mostafavi, Farshad Ebrahimi, Amir-Emad Poursaeid, S. Mohammadali Zanjani, Gevork B. Gharehpetian
abstract: This paper presents a blockchain-driven and data-analytics-assisted framework for secure and efficient energy trading among electric vehicles (EVs) within a next-generation smart grid ecosystem. In the proposed system, EVs can function as both prosumers and consumers, enabling decentralized peer-to-peer energy exchange. The framework leverages sixth-generation (6G) communication technologies to achieve ultra-low latency, high reliability, and large-scale connectivity, ensuring seamless real-time interactions among EVs and grid entities. To model and forecast the dynamic energy demands of EVs, a Multiple Linear Regression (MLR)-based predictive model is utilized, which allows the smart grid to optimize energy allocation and maximize overall trading benefits. The blockchain layer ensures data immutability, transaction transparency, and tamper-proof trading records. A comparative performance analysis demonstrates that the proposed system significantly enhances latency, scalability, and profitability for both producer and consumer EVs when compared to conventional 4G/5G-based trading infrastructures. The findings indicate that the proposed blockchain-integrated approach offers a secure, reliable, and economically viable solution for intelligent EV energy markets.

title: Event-Triggered Polynomial Model Predictive Control for Multi-Agent Navigation
authors: Harini V, Anusree Rajan, Pavankumar Tallapragada
abstract: This paper proposes an event-triggered polynomial model predictive control method for collision-free point-to-point multi-agent navigation. In this control method, each control input to each agent is a polynomial whose coefficients are updated in an event-triggered manner. For each agent, we design an event-triggering rule that guarantees non-Zeno behavior of inter-event times. At each event, the controller updates the coefficients of the polynomial control law corresponding to a subset of agents by solving one or more finite horizon optimization problems. We also ensure feasibility of the optimization problems solved at each event. Through numerical simulations, we illustrate the results and compare the proposed method with other existing methods.

title: Relative Side-Bearing Angle-Based Circumnavigation of a Target Using Unmanned Aerial Vehicle with Boundary Constraints
authors: Ranit Roychowdhury, Anoop Jain, Jayant Kumar Mohanta
abstract: This paper studies the problem of target circumnavigation by an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) while confining its trajectories within a specified region. Our solution approach relies on controlling the relative side-bearing angle of the UAV and the radial distance to the target to fulfill these control objectives. Under some mild assumptions on initial state variables, we propose the lateral acceleration command applied to the UAV, based on a Barrier Lyapunov Function (BLF)-based formulation. Using Lyapunov stability theory, we prove that, under the proposed lateral acceleration command, the UAV follows the desired circumnavigation path and its trajectories remain bounded within the specified region. We also characterize the feasible initial conditions and present simulations to illustrate the proposed strategy.

title: Securing the Industrial Control Systems: A Layered Perspective on Cyber Threats and Countermeasures
authors: Amirhosein Imani, Alireza Keshavarz-Haddad
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) play a central role in automating operations across critical infrastructure sectors and large-scale industrial facilities. Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) are key components of these systems, responsible for controlling actuators in industrial environments. To lower costs and enhance efficiency, PLC-based systems increasingly incorporate commercial off-the-shelf components and external networks such as the Internet. The central role of PLCs, combined with insufficient security considerations in the design of industrial control networks, has made them attractive targets for Internet-based attackers. Recent cyber incidents affecting major industrial infrastructures underscore the urgent need for further scientific investigation. This paper investigates vulnerabilities and security attacks targeting PLCs and classifies them according to their origin. Additionally, security measures to mitigate these threats are reviewed and categorized based on their location within the system architecture and the scope of their impact.

title: A review of the role of smart metering systems in electricity distribution networks in Isfahan province, situations and challenges
authors: Ehsan Aghababagoli
abstract: Smart meters are new measuring devices that can provide experts in various fields with more information than old meters, in addition to creating visibility in the electricity distribution company system. These meters have advantages that have caused a huge change in improving processes in the electricity distribution system. On the other hand, the development of these facilities requires new management to control the challenges associated with advanced measurement infrastructure. Given that Isfahan Province Electricity Distribution Company has been one of the leading companies in using smart meters, the improvement and effectiveness of this issue in various fields such as human resources, operation, consumption management, and economic fields is very tangible. In this article, an attempt has been made to briefly describe the effects and results of these devices in improving processes and increasing productivity in the Isfahan Province Electricity Distribution Company and the existing challenges, citing the necessary examples.

title: Retraction Notice: Proficient energy hole prevention scheduling in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: G. Balu Narasimharao, A Jaya Lakshmi, P. Sai Kiran

title: OmniHD-Scenes: A Next-Generation Multimodal Dataset for Autonomous Driving
authors: Lianqing Zheng, Long Yang, Qunshu Lin, Wenjin Ai, Minghao Liu, Shouyi Lu, Jianan Liu, Hongze Ren, Jingyue Mo, Xiaokai Bai, Jie Bai, Zhixiong Ma, Xichan Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The rapid advancement of deep learning has intensified the need for comprehensive data for use by autonomous driving algorithms. High-quality datasets are crucial for the development of effective data-driven autonomous driving solutions. Next-generation autonomous driving datasets must be multimodal, incorporating data from advanced sensors that feature extensive data coverage, detailed annotations, and diverse scene representation. To address this need, we present OmniHD-Scenes, a large-scale multimodal dataset that provides comprehensive omnidirectional high-definition data. The OmniHD-Scenes dataset combines data from 128-beam LiDAR, six cameras, and six 4D imaging radar systems to achieve full environmental perception. The dataset comprises 1501 clips, each approximately 30-s long, totaling more than 450 K synchronized frames and more than 5.85 million synchronized sensor data points. We also propose a novel 4D annotation pipeline. To date, we have annotated 200 clips with more than 514 K precise 3D bounding boxes. These clips also include semantic segmentation annotations for static scene elements. Additionally, we introduce a novel automated pipeline for generation of the dense occupancy ground truth, which effectively leverages information from non-key frames. Alongside the proposed dataset, we establish comprehensive evaluation metrics, baseline models, and benchmarks for 3D detection and semantic occupancy prediction. These benchmarks utilize surround-view cameras and 4D imaging radar to explore cost-effective sensor solutions for autonomous driving applications. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our low-cost sensor configuration and its robustness under adverse conditions. The dataset is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://www.2077ai.com/OmniHD-Scenes</uri>.

title: HFLAD: AI-Driven Hierarchical Fusion Learning for Predictive Anomaly Detection in Consumer-Centric Systems
authors: Wei Liu, Hongbo Zhao, Nan Chen, Xu Yang, Jiwu Shu, Hui Cui, Xiaoding Wang, Md. Jalil Piran
abstract: Audit logs, crucial for service auditing and security, capture user and system activities, which can be effectively represented as multivariate time series data to enable efficient log analysis, such as behavior analytics for anomaly detection. However, it is technically challenging to analyze such data due to its high dimensionality and strong time correlation. To address these challenges and enhance predictive security for consumer applications, we propose an AI-driven anomaly detection model named HFLAD. This model comprehensively considers the feature and time correlation of multivariate time series data. It employs causal and dilated convolutions for encoding to capture multi-scale temporal dependencies, and utilizes an HVAE (Hierarchical Variational Autoencoder) generator for information reconstruction. Then, it identifies anomalies by leveraging the difference between the reconstructed data and the original data. By leveraging hierarchical fusion learning, HFLAD proactively detects deviations in consumer-related system activities and audit logs, aligning with modern security demands in smart devices, IoT, and online services. Experimental results demonstrate that HFLAD outperforms other existing techniques in identifying anomalies, thereby improving the effectiveness of predictive security measures for consumer systems.

title: Neural Network Augmented Koopman Explicit Model Following Control for Robotic Manipulators
authors: Oğuz Kaan Hancioğlu, Mehmet Önder Efe
abstract: This paper introduces a Neural Network Augmented Koopman Explicit Model Following Control (NNKEMFC) framework designed for robust trajectory tracking of robotic manipulators that exhibit nonlinear and uncertain dynamics. The proposed method integrates an offline-identified extended-state Koopman operator within an Explicit Model Following Control (EMFC) framework to produce a data-driven feedforward control action while maintaining a model-following structure. To tackle modeling errors, friction effects, external disturbances, and parametric uncertainties, an online neural network control structure is integrated to estimate unmodeled dynamics in real time. The final control input includes the Koopman-based feedforward torque, a filtered tracking-error feedback term, neural network compensation, and a robustifying signal to enhance robustness. The proposed approach is evaluated using a multi-degree-of-freedom robotic manipulator in several scenarios that include friction, external loads, and parameter uncertainties. Simulation results indicate that the NNKEMFC outperforms the classical computed torque control and KEMFC and achieves notable reductions in joint-space RMS tracking errors, particularly in nonlinear conditions. These results highlight the advantages of incorporating a Koopman-based model followed by online neural residual learning to enhance the robust tracking of robotic manipulators.

title: A Novel Filtering Antenna via Electric and Magnetic Coupling on a Transversal Topology
authors: Jia-Xiang Hao, Lei Zhu, XuZhou Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this article, a novel filtering antenna based on a transversal topology is presented. The design incorporates both electric coupling (EC) and magnetic coupling (MC) feeding techniques. By leveraging their distinct phase characteristics, an out-of-phase condition is created in the stopband to generate out-of-band radiation nulls, while an in-phase condition is maintained in the passband to prevent radiation cancellation. The integration of both feeding schemes into the transversal layout yields a simple and compact structure without extra feeding circuits. Furthermore, λ/4-length patch elements are adopted, whose opened and shorted ends facilitate EC and MC feeding, respectively, allowing a single radiator type to support dual excitation and further simplify the geometry. A synthesis approach is applied to align the radiation quality factor of each element with the filter's external quality factor, enabling flexible adjustment of fractional bandwidth and radiation null locations. A third-order antenna prototype with dual stopband zeros is in final designed, fabricated, and measured, exhibiting well-defined filtering performance, a compact single-layer profile, and promising practicality for modern wireless systems.

title: Bézier Curve-Based Optimization Framework for Multirobot Motion Planning in Unknown Environments
authors: Amna Mazen, Mariam Faied, Mohan Krishnan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: In recent years, multirobot systems (MRSs) have witnessed significant growth because of their capability of solving complex problems involving collaborative missions. A two-phase approach is typically employed in such applications, encompassing task planning and assignment among the robots, followed by motion planning to execute the assigned tasks. This work focuses on the motion planning phase, which facilitates the optimal navigation of multiple robots from their initial to desired goal configurations. A novel multirobot Bézier curve-based trajectory planner (MrBTP) is proposed. MrBTP generates optimal trajectories for multiple robots navigating in an unknown environment, including the polygonal characterization of the available open space. The optimization process is based on using a weighted objective function that combines the navigation time of each robot and the length of its trajectory, allowing for various path optimization strategies. The effectiveness of MrBTP has been evaluated in various scenarios, and its performance is compared with that of a selected trajectory planner based on three performance metrics. Over the three robots used in the test, MrBTP reduced the navigation time by 21%–49% and the trajectory length by 10%–18% compared to the selected benchmark trajectory planner.
