title: Harnessing Artificial Intelligence for Strategic Management: Transforming Decision-Making, Agility, and Competitive Advantage
authors: Vijay Kulkarni
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming strategic management in the dynamic business landscape of India to enable organizations to make decisions based on data, achieve operational agility and competitive edge. The study examines the connection between AI-applications and SDM in SMEs in India and the mediating role of DL in that connection. The study is quantitative in nature and the data is obtained using a structured questionnaire of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 0}$</tex> Indian SME entrepreneurs on the following variables: AI adoption, digital leadership, and strategic decision-making. Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), regression, and PROCESS V4 were used to test the mediation of the data. The findings suggest that the use of AI applications boosts SDM significantly, and digital leadership significantly mediates the relationship, which also makes organizations more agile and adaptable. The research finds that incorporation of AI within an effective digital leadership can facilitate a strategic decision-making process and thereby provide Indian SMEs with a sustainable competitive advantage that can be of interest to entrepreneurs and managers seeking to use technology to strategically develop.

title: AI Metaverse in Healthcare: Opportunities, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Vaishali Gaikwad, Reena Chavan, Shubhangi Gaikwad, Chidanand Patil
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) with Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), Mixed Reality (MR), and digital twins is shaping the emergence of an AI-enabled healthcare metaverse. Unlike conventional telemedicine, the metaverse enables persistent, collaborative, and intelligent three-dimensional (3D) environments for medical education, clinical care, and patient engagement. Evidence shows that VR can reduce pain and anxiety by 20–35%, accelerate training by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-40\%$</tex>, and improve rehabilitation outcomes. In India, representative Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) confirm VR's value in pediatric dentistry and labor analgesia, while pilot deployments such as Apollo Hospitals' immersive counseling programs and MediSim VR nursing labs illustrate early adoption. Policy frameworks including the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM) and the Digital Personal Data Protection (DPDP) Act 2023 provide enabling infrastructure and governance. This review proposes a roadmap emphasizing multi-center clinical validation, low-cost Extended Reality (XR) innovation, Federated Learning (FL) for privacy, Edge Artificial Intelligence (Edge-AI) for real-time deployment, and ethical inclusivity in avatars, language, and digital twin design. The AI-metaverse has the potential to transform healthcare delivery if pursued with rigor, equity, and interdisciplinary collaboration.

title: Advancements in Hybrid Deep Learning for Stroke Classification: A Comprehensive Review of Genetic Algorithms and Bilstm Networks
authors: Balasaheb S. Waidande, Sanjeev J. Wagh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Timely diagnosis and treatment planning are crucial in improving patient outcomes, making stroke classification a vital area of research. Recent advancements in hybrid deep learning frameworks have shown promise in enhancing classification accuracy by integrating powerful methodologies. This paper comprehensively reviews the integration of Genetic Algorithms (GA) for feature optimization and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks for learning complex temporal dependencies in medical data. GA enables the selection of relevant features from high-dimensional datasets, while BiLSTM improves predictive performance by modeling sequence information in both forward and backward directions. By analyzing existing hybrid models, we identify strengths, limitations, and areas of improvement. This review not only consolidates current progress but also critically examines overlooked challenges in clinical deployment, including high computational costs, lack of interpretability, ethical considerations, and generalizability across diverse datasets. Furthermore, it outlines future directions such as integrating explainable AI, lightweight model architectures, and robust validation protocols. The findings demonstrate that GA-BiLSTM hybrid models hold significant potential for creating reliable, accurate, and clinically viable stroke diagnostic tools.

title: Deep Learning in Healthcare
authors: Aman Kumar, Abhisekh Tewary, Aditya Raj, Shruti, Pravin Kumar Samanta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Deep learning is reshaping healthcare across medical imaging, clinical text, time-series physiology, and genomics. This review synthesizes methods and applications with emphasis on model families (CNN/UNet/ViT; RNN/Transformers), datasets and evaluation practices (AUROC/AUPRC, Dice, calibration, external validation). We summarize benefits—earlier detection, consistent triage and personalized decision support—alongside persistent challenges including data quality and shift, fairness, interpretability, privacy and regulatory alignment. To support responsible translation, we propose a practical evaluation checklist covering robustness, calibration, subgroup performance and workflow integration. We conclude with near-term research priorities: self-supervised and federated learning for data efficiency and privacy, multimodal modeling for holistic patient state and prospective validation with post-deployment monitoring. This synthesis aims to guide researchers and practitioners toward clinically credible, trustworthy AI systems.

title: A Framework for Emergency Situational Awareness: Formal Representation, Modeling and Validation
authors: Zhaoquan Zhu, Xianzhong Zhou, Yuxiang Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: In an era marked by heightened uncertainty, the increasing frequency and severity of emergency events pose significant challenges to societal stability and public safety. Situational awareness (SA) is a critical prerequisite for effective emergency decision-making in response to such major incidents. To address the current lack of systematic interpretation within existing SA theories and methodologies, this study proposes a unified “state-potential” representation framework to enhance the modeling of emergency scenarios. Grounded in a structured paradigm of “risk sources-risk exposures-mitigation factors–environment”, we extract key situational elements and formally define both the static “state” and dynamic “potential” of emergency events. A novel modeling approach is introduced to capture the current scenario characteristics and forecast its possible evolution. Experimental validation demonstrates the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed model, offering theoretical and practical support for improved emergency decision-making.

title: Enhancing Automation in Robotic Coreless Filament Winding through Camera-based Teach-in
authors: Matthias Marquart, Samed Ajdinović, Siddieq Mansour, Friedrich Dorsch, Armin Lechler, Alexander Verl
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Robotic coreless filament winding (RCFW) offers significant potential in sustainable lightweight construction. In the process considered here, resin-impregnated fibers are wound around pins of a winding frame using an industrial robot. An Autonomous Mobile Robot (AMR) delivers the winding frame to the robot. Due to the limited positioning accuracy of the AMR and the manufacturing tolerances of the winding frame, precise knowledge of the pin positions is essential for robot path planning and the robot-AMR collaboration. This paper presents a concept for camera-based detection of pin positions and automated generation and adaptation of the robot path. To this end, a vision system is integrated into an existing robot cell, the necessary processing algorithms are developed, and the accuracy achieved is examined. Furthermore, a control architecture is suggested that allows camera-based teach-in without changing the industrial robot’s controller and interfaces. As a result, manual teach-in is no longer required, the degree of automation of the winding process is significantly increased, and robot-AMR collaboration is enabled.

title: Estimation of Steady-State Speed of AUV Motion Based on Rotation Frequency of Cruise Thrusters
authors: Vladimir Kostenko, Irina Mokeeva
abstract: An approach to assessing the speed of steady-state forward motion of an autonomous unmanned underwater vehicle relative to water based on the measured rotation frequency of the propellers of its propulsion units has been proposed and tested in practice. The approach is based on the analysis of the dependence of the AUV’s hydrodynamic resistance calculated using its 3D model and the rotation frequency of its propulsion units required for forward motion on the speed of the oncoming flow. These dependencies were determined for the MMT-3500 AUV developed at the IMTP FEB RAS based on the results of virtual testing of its 3D model, the analysis of which revealed the constancy of the relative pitch of the cruise thrusters propellers in the entire range of speeds of steady motion. In this case, to calculate the required rotation frequency of the propulsion units for the AUV’s movement, an analytical representation of the propeller thrust coefficient from the relative pitch was used. The speed of the oncoming flow is estimated based on the average rotation frequency of the four propulsion units, taking into account the constancy of the relative pitch of the propellers revealed during the computational experiment. During the analysis of the results of full-scale tests of the MMT-3500 AUV in steady-state motion mode, estimates of the effectiveness of the proposed approach were obtained.

title: Intelligent YOLOv11 Multi Sensor Image Analysis for Maritime Search and Rescue on Unmanned Surface Vehicles
authors: Hung Nguyen Van, Hai Duong Nguyen Duc, Dang Bui Hai, Ninh Pham Quang, Kien Do Trung
abstract: In recent years, ensuring maritime safety has been one of the most critical issues. During an incident, people falling into the sea are very difficult to detect with the eye, especially in adverse meteorological conditions such as strong winds, storms, high waves and low light conditions. Therefore, there is a need for new methods to support and apply Artificial Intelligence (AI) in the search and rescue process to ensure rapid and reliable results. This article proposes a method to detect drowning people based on the You Only Look Once (YOLOv11) deep learning model that combines data from Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) sensors, AI cameras and thermal cameras. Meanwhile, the intelligent human detection algorithm allows for calculating the estimated location, distance and condition of the victim to provide timely rescue plans. In addition, the Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) model and maritime scenarios developed in Unity 3D can be tested to ensure the safety of human life. As a result, YOLOv11 achieved a higher mAP compared to previous YOLO versions and maintained real-time speed. The multi-sensor fusion method showed superior performance compared to single models when applied to the USV system in sea rescue operations, enabling rapid and accurate detection of victims or hazardous objects.

title: Understanding Stakeholder Perspectives on Online Education: A Data-Driven Approach
authors: Chesta Malkani, Neetu Mittal, Subhranil Som
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The online education system has become a common way to reach students, but there are still major obstacles - namely, low student engagement and lack of effective communication and feedback - that must be overcome to achieve a truly online learning society. This research collected and analyzed the perceptions of relevant stakeholders regarding these issues. Using a mixed-methods approach, this study builds a mostly primary dataset from a survey of and interviews with students, educators, and administrators. A secondary dataset complements the analysis. Four major themes emerged from the dataset: engagement, barriers (to technology and communication), instructional effectiveness, and feedback mechanisms. The major set of recommendations is aimed at overcoming barriers to communication bottlenecks and making the online learning experience more engaging for students. This set of recommendations includes the use of formative assessments and addresses problems identified with current e-learning platforms.

title: Evaluating Sequential Deep Learning Networks for Next Word Prediction: A Focus on LSTM and RNN
authors: Gundam Ritesh Reddy, Babita Tiwari, Monika Dandotiya, Lav Upadhyay
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The next word prediction can increase the typing speed and be useful for people with spelling disorders or disabilities. This research is conducted using deep learning approaches and the focus is made on the English language which is generally spoken by most of the world population. There have been several methods of creating word prediction tools that can make typing easier, for example, in mobile devices, it can suggest words that the user may be planning to write. These tools enhance the writing process, support the development of writing skills and allow for free text entry. Also, they assist in the construction of coherent language patterns and are employed in popular programs including Grammarly. In this paper, we are going to discuss N-gram modeling, CNNs, recurrent neural networks and some advanced deep learning approaches for enhancing the word prediction. This paper aims at comparing N-gram modeling, CNNs, recurrent neural networks and advanced deep learning methods for word prediction and provides results, analysis and methodology.

title: Exploring circular economy and business models across countries: A Systematic Review
authors: Méndez-Gutiérrez Leidy Lucia, Luis Gerardo Ortiz-Yataco, María Del Rosario Quichca-Vilchez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The systematic review of circular economy and business models highlighted the importance of practices in enhancing corporate sustainability. From eco efficient product design to comprehensive waste management, companies were able to reduce their environmental print and strengthen operational efficiency. Various circular business models to different industries and markets were identified, each contributing to resource minimization and the promotion of socially responsible practices. Despite progress, organizations still faced technological and regulatory constraints when attempting to implement circular practices. The review highlighted that continued innovation, together with targeted educational initiatives, was essential for strengthening adoption both at the organizational level and within broader society. In addition, the analysis drew attention to the relevance of public policies that actively supported the transition, particularly through incentives, regulatory frameworks, and programs designed to accelerate the move toward more sustainable and resilient economic models.

title: X-Change: An RGB-Inspired Spectral-Aware Framework for Multi-Task and Explainable Change Captioning
authors: Busra Tuzlupinar, M. Fatih Amasyali, Ali Can Karaca
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Remote sensing change captioning describes land surface changes between bi-temporal images. However, models trained on RGB inputs often underperform compared to multispectral (MS) counterparts due to limited spectral awareness. We present X-Change, an RGB-inspired spectral-aware framework that achieves MS-level descriptive quality while jointly performing multi-task segmentation to predict change, NDVI, and NDWI masks—indicating where and how change occurs. Unlike prior RGB-based methods, X-Change employs rule-based spectral supervision from bi-temporal Sentinel-2 data, enabling its shared encoder to internalize NDVI/NDWI-related cues for both captioning and segmentation tasks. Experiments on the MOSAIC-SEN2-CC dataset show that X-Change surpasses state-of- the-art RGB-based models and matches or slightly exceeds those trained on multispectral inputs, producing spatially consistent change and index maps. Overall, X-Change bridges the gap between RGB and MS modalities, offering an interpretable and practical framework for spectral-aware, multi-task, and explainable change captioning. The codebase will be publicly released at https://github.com/ChangeCapsInRS/X-Change.

title: BoostTransformer: A Lightweight Transformer for Remote Sensing Image Captioning
authors: Tiancheng Bo, Yuandong Ma, Qing Song
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Remote sensing image captioning (RSIC) aims to translate remote sensing images (RSIs) into textual descriptions, where Transformer-based approaches have attained remarkable performance. However, the prohibitive computational costs of self-attention and cross-attention on high-resolution features compel existing RSIC methods to rely on pre-trained backbones or prerequisite tasks to compress input RSIs, resulting in the loss of multi-scale semantic information and hindering end-to-end training and inference. To address this challenge, we propose an Attention Matrix Expansion Mechanism, which endows the approximation of large-scale global self-attention and cross-attention with negligible computational overhead (e.g., only +0.173 GFLOPs). Building on this mechanism, we design BoostTransformer, a RSIC framework constituted by two core components: BoostEncoder, a lightweight Transformer encoder that directly processes raw RSIs to achieve panoramic feature extraction, and BoostDecoder, a lightweight Transformer decoder that extensively integrates multi-scale encoder features, thereby boost the quality of generated captions. We further derive a training paradigm from experiments for end-to-end training RSIC model from scratch. Extensive experimental results demonstrate our end-to-end lightweight model achieves competitive performance without pre-training. The code will be available at https://github.com/ACT-WAVE/BoostTransformer.

title: Inverse Reinforcement Learning via a Modified Kleinman Iteration Approach
authors: Jiacheng Wu, Hao Shen
abstract: The Kleinman iteration is a policy iteration method for solving Riccati equations and forms the basis of many reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. However, its direct application to inverse RL problems is limited by its reliance on known cost functions. To overcome this limitation, we propose a modified Kleinman iteration algorithm that simultaneously estimates the cost weight and the value function matrix during policy evaluation without an additional update step for the cost weight, thereby improving computational efficiency and reducing the number of iterations. Moreover, we develop a data-driven inverse RL algorithm by introducing a piecewise constant, persistently exciting input during the data collection phase. This design avoids the use of Kronecker product operations by reducing the dimensionality of the matrices. The convergence properties and solution non-uniqueness of the proposed method are rigorously analyzed. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms is demonstrated through simulations on a power system model, with performance comparisons against existing approaches.

title: MeG-DiffSAR: Diffusion-Guided Synthesis of Realistic SAR Sea-Ship Scenes
authors: Tianyi Zhang, Jiyuan Liu, Tao Zhang, Jin Ma, Feiming Wei, Wenxian Yu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The synthesis of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images, particularly for mixed scenes, has significant potential in addressing data scarcity to support the training of deep-learning-based SAR models. In this letter, we present MeG-DiffSAR, a diffusion-based network for synthesizing SAR sea–ship scenes. First, we introduce a localized generation strategy that formulates high-fidelity mixed-scene synthesis as an inpainting task, focusing primarily on the boundary regions between ships and the surrounding sea surface. In order to enhance the realism of synthesized images, then a mask-enhanced multi-head self-attention mechanism (MeMSM) is proposed to guide the network’s focus toward masked regions, thereby generating contextually consistent inpainting results. At last, a gradient-aware loss is incorporated to improve the textural fidelity and visual quality of synthesized images. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. Especially, compared to the state-of-the-art method Ship-Go, MeG-DiffSAR reduces FID by 13.64 and improves PSNR by 14.17dB.

title: ARXPUF: A Modeling Attack Resilient Lightweight Strong PUF based on Add-Rotate-Xor
authors: Zhenzhe Chen, Weirong Dong, Kunyang Liu, Takashi Sato
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Strong Physically Unclonable Functions (PUFs) provide a large challenge-response space for authentication, but must minimize area while remaining resistant to machine-learning-based modeling attacks. This work presents ARXPUF, a lightweight strong PUF design supporting 128-bit challengeresponse pairs (CRPs), employing Add-Rotate-Xor (ARX) operations for entropy mixing to achieve compact hardware implementation and high statistical performance. Implemented in 180 nm CMOS, ARXPUF takes only $2.8 \mathrm{MF}^{2}$, making it suitable for resource-constrained systems. Statistical evaluations, including NIST tests, min entropy, and autocorrelation, confirm high randomness and independence. Furthermore, ARXPUF demonstrates strong resilience to modeling attacks, where predictive accuracy remains close to random guessing even when trained with 30M CRPs.

title: Voltage Sensing Based Open Switch Fault Detection in Five Level Modified CHB Multilevel Inverter
authors: Sushant Y. Suryawanshi, Gopinath S.
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Multilevel inverters (MLIs) are advanced power electronic systems that generate high-quality AC voltage using multiple DC voltage levels. They are widely used in renewable energy integration, motor drives, and grid-tied applications due to their efficiency, reduced harmonic distortion, and ability to handle high voltages. Different types of multilevel inverters exist, including diode-clamped, flying capacitor, and cascaded Hbridge inverters, each with its own specific characteristics and suitability different applications. However, their complex structure comprising numerous switches, capacitors, and DC sources makes them susceptible to faults that can disrupt performance or cause system failure. In order to reduce the complexity, size and cost, many modified configurations of multilevel inverter have been proposed by researchers. In this paper, a five level modified cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) inverter is selected and open switch fault is identified and located by evaluating mean value and RMS value of the output voltage.

title: Solar-Powered Electrolyzer for Green Hydrogen: Design, Integration, and Experimental Evaluation
authors: Amirmohammad Badahang, Yahya Kabiri-Renani
abstract: The growing demand for sustainable energy carriers has positioned hydrogen as a cornerstone of the low-carbon economy. Water electrolysis powered by renewable energy is the most effective way to generate high-purity green hydrogen . The purpose of this paper is to explore how renewable resources can be integrated with electrolyzers and to present the design and experimental validation of a low-cost solar prototype. A brief review of electrolysis technologies highlights their advantages and limitations . Now, special attention is given to the opportunities and challenges of coupling intermittent renewables, where direct photovoltaic integration is promising in solar-rich regions. The proposed prototype demonstrates feasibility using readily available materials, offering insights into performance and economic aspect . This paper presents the design, integration, and experimental evaluation of a laboratory scale solar powered electrolyser as the most possible solution for green hydrogen production . The findings contribute to advancing green hydrogen technologies and their role in energy transition.

title: Impact Angle and Input Constrained Guidance Against Stationary Targets
authors: Vinay Kathiriya, Saurabh Kumar, Shashi Ranjan Kumar
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of guiding an interceptor to intercept a stationary target at a prescribed impact angle while respecting input constraints arising from actuator limitations. Although classical guidance laws ensure target interception, imposing a specific impact angle and input constraints can significantly improve the effectiveness of the guidance strategy. To this end, we propose a guidance strategy that employs nested saturation functions to ensure that the interceptor’s lateral acceleration remains within bounded limits. The guidance law was developed for the case of a zero-degree impact angle, which can be extended to any arbitrary impact angle through a coordinate transformation. Numerical simulations under various initial conditions validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: The Role of Touch: Towards Optimal Tactile Sensing Distribution in Anthropomorphic Hands for Dexterous In-Hand Manipulation
authors: João Damião Almeida, Egidio Falotico, Cecilia Laschi, José Santos-Victor
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: In-hand manipulation tasks, particularly in human-inspired robotic systems, must rely on distributed tactile sensing to achieve precise control across a wide variety of tasks. However, the optimal configuration of this network of sensors is a complex problem, and while the fingertips are a common choice for placing sensors, the contribution of tactile information from other regions of the hand is often overlooked. This work investigates the impact of tactile feedback from various regions of the fingers and palm in performing in-hand object reorientation tasks. We analyze how sensory feedback from different parts of the hand influences the robustness of deep reinforcement learning control policies and investigate the relationship between object characteristics and optimal sensor placement. We identify which tactile sensing configurations contribute to improving the efficiency and accuracy of manipulation. Our results provide valuable insights for the design and use of anthropomorphic endeffectors with enhanced manipulation capabilities.

title: Multi-UAV Path Planning in Complex 3D Terrain Using Genetic-Enhanced Nutcracker Optimization
authors: Xiao Dou, Cheng Gao, Qi Kang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly deployed in complex missions such as reconnaissance, delivery, and search operations. Effective path planning is critical for enabling UAV autonomy, especially in multi-agent scenarios involving complex terrain and operational constraints. This paper addresses the problem of collaborative path planning for multiple UAVs operating in mountainous environments. The problem is formulated as a constrained multi-objective optimization model that simultaneously considers path length, constraint violations, and trajectory smoothness. To solve this, we propose the Genetic-Enhanced Nutcracker Optimization Algorithm (GNOA), a hybrid metaheuristic that integrates genetic algorithm operators into the Nutcracker Optimization Algorithm (NOA) to improve search diversity and convergence performance. GNOA introduces a crossover-enhanced foraging strategy, a mutation-driven cachesearch recovery mechanism, and adaptive boundary constraints to ensure feasibility. Experimental results demonstrate that GNOA achieves superior performance compared to existing algorithms in generating collision-free and energy-efficient trajectories in complex three-dimensional environments.

title: Some Limitations of Structure-Based Methods for Deadlock Detection Problems of $\mathrm{S}^{4} \text{PR}$
authors: Yue Su, MengChu Zhou, Remigiusz Wiśniewski, Liang Qi, ShouGuang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: As a subclass of Petri Nets (PNs), Systems of Sequential Systems with Shared Process Resources (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}^{4} \text{PR}$</tex>) have been widely used in modelling and analyzing automated manufacturing systems (AMS). Multiple tasks competing for limited shared resources may lead to deadlocks, affecting the desired operation of AMS. Popular methods for deadlock detection are based on traversing a PN's reachability trees/graph from initial markings, but their computational complexity increases exponentially with the number of possible states (markings). To avoid state space analysis, researchers propose various methods for characterizing deadlocks of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}^{4} \text{PR}$</tex> with structural objects. However, the existing structure-based methods may obtain some fictitious deadlocks, i.e., those that AMS never enters. This paper analyzes the performance of structure-based methods for deadlock detection in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}^{4} \text{PR}$</tex> through case studies. We show that deadlocks obtained with those techniques are not guaranteed reachable from an initial marking. Hence, additional analyses are required.

title: Modeling the Effect of Angular Velocity on Volleyball Serve Accuracy with Magnus Effect
authors: Ethan Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Serving is one of the most critical skills in volleyball and places a large emphasis on consistency. This study explores how angular velocity influences serving accuracy through the Magnus effect. A physics-based simulation of the Mikasa V200W volleyball is developed, modeling drag, gravity, and spin-induced forces under realistic launch conditions. Spin rates from 80 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$140 \text{rad} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> are tested, and landing accuracy is evaluated by spread as well as in-bounds percentage. Results show that higher spin rates consistently reduce landing variability without diminishing the probability of successful serves. These findings confirm the stabilizing effect of topspin and provide quantitative support for training strategies that emphasize spin generation.

title: Analysis of a High-Boost DC-DC Circuit Featuring a Coupled Inductor for Renewable Energy Applications
authors: Reyhaneh Nazarzadeh, Seyed Hossein Hosseini, Ebrahim Babaei, Mehran Sabahi
abstract: In this study, a high step-up DC-DC structure using a single power switch is introduced. The suggested configuration employs a pair of magnetically-coupled inductors with tunable winding ratios and capacitor-based energy transfer paths, enabling improved voltage boosting capability while keeping the voltage stress across semiconductor elements low. The overall voltage amplification can be adjusted by modifying the duty ratio of the switching device as well as the turn proportions of the coupled inductors, offering operational adaptability under various load or input conditions. The main attributes of this architecture include straightforward control with one active switch, reduced power dissipation due to lower switching and conduction losses, continuous current at the input side, and a shared ground reference for input and output terminals. Simulated evaluations on a 200-Watt laboratory prototype at 50 kHz, supplied by 20 V and delivering 160 V at the output, verify proper functionality and high efficiency of the converter, indicating its effectiveness for integration in clean-energy and renewable-source systems.

title: Toward a Next-Generation Data Center Management System: Enabling Application-Aware Integration
authors: Hussain Kahil, Talal Saleh, Petri Välisuo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Data centers are emerging as critical infrastructure in the digital era, providing the essential computing power needed to run smart applications within the modern communities. To meet the demands of these applications, data center must be designed as high-performance facilities, achieving both high energy efficiency and operational resilience. However, the growing volume of data collection and the need for real-time decisionmaking by applications running in the data center information and communication (ICT) devices, require an evolution of Data Center Management System (DCMS). The DCMS must be capable of optimizing the resilient operation of internal subsystems while seamlessly integrating external services. This paper introduces a conceptual framework for a next-generation DCMS, detailing its architectural layers, the inter-dependencies among subsystems, and integration with the application layer. The proposed framework is analyzed in the context of advanced artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, aiming to achieve key DCMS objectives such as minimizing energy consumption and carbon emissions, enhancing operational resilience, and optimizing resource allocation. Key challenges related to this integration are addressed, alongside an exploration of emerging trends and future research directions. This study provides a foundational framework for DCMS, highlighting the central role of data centers in enabling adaptive, efficient, and robust operation of the smart critical applications of today's digital society.

title: An Improved Current Sharing Method in Two-Phase Interleaved LLC Resonant Converter
authors: Alireza Shokripour, Omid Hosseini, Teymoor Ghanbari, Ebrahim Farjah
abstract: Multi-phase interleaved LLC resonant converters have been introduced as a promising solution to meet the growing demands for high power density, reduced current rating of each module, and improved efficiency. However, operating multiple LLC modules at the same switching frequency often leads to significant current imbalance due to the component tolerances in the resonant tanks. This results in degraded output quality, output current imbalance, and reduced reliability. To overcome the stated challenges, a twophase LLC converter is demonstrated in this study, in which current balancing is achieved by independently adjusting a variable inductor to tune the frequencies associated with the resonances of individual modules and reduce the effects of component mismatch. Simulation results using ANSYS Maxwell and MATLAB Simulink confirm the effectiveness of the proposed technique in enhancing the performance of interleaved LLC converters.

title: Retraction Notice: Generative Adversarial Network (GAN): a general review on different variants of GAN and applications
authors: Karthika. S, M. Durgadevi
publish: 2021 6th International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: Deep learning plays a very important role in the research area in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) and many models have been developed based on GAN applications. Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) is an unsupervised learning method which is based on a very popular logic known as zero-sum game theory for two players. The main objective of Generative Adversarial Networks is to calculate the distribution of original samples using discriminator and the work of Generator is to generate new samples from the real data samples. In current years, Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) has made big development essentially withinside the area of computer vision, image classification, speech and language processing and so on. The paper explains about the basic introduction of GAN and different types of GAN were introduced with its applications. Original GAN version and its changed classical variations has been surveyed. The problems and limitations of GAN and the future work of GAN models were discussed.

title: Field Validation of a Heat-Optimized Active Battery Balancing Architecture With Integrated Communication for Grid Energy Storage Systems
authors: Dominique Weyen, Peter Coenen, Geert Jacobs, Roeland Van Praet, Paul Van Tichelen, Serge Peeters, Guillaume Thenaisie
abstract: This article presents an active balancing architecture that unifies energy transfer and communication on a single AC bus, using pulse-frequency modulation for broadcast control and daisy-chained UART for feedback. By operating balancing on the mandatory communication line, the system leverages redundancy already required by functional-safety standards while reducing wiring complexity. The architecture was validated across three contexts: sodium-ion modules from the NAIMA project, an NMC pack in CurrentDirect, and a 180S4P industrial LFP ESS operated for over 9000 hours. Across all systems, the platform maintained stable operation and consistent voltage-spread control. A key advantage is the low thermal footprint of the Voltage Balancing Units (VBUs), which remained below 45<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\circ}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C under continuous operation. This behavior supports high-density packaging and positions the approach as a strong candidate for integrated, IC-ready BMS designs.

title: Retraction Notice: Device Free Human Body Fall Detection to Aid Senior Citizen
authors: Kavali Janardhan, P. Parthasarathi, Nagarjuna Karyemsetty, Arunkumar K, R. Krishnamoorthy, K. Umapathy
publish: 2022 6th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology
abstract: Recently, the risk of fatal falls among the elderly has grown. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), falls are a substantial contributor to both fatal and non-fatal injuries. Slipping and falling may appear innocent, but they can cause serious injuries or even death in elderly people. To make fall prevention commonplace, the CDC launched the Stopping Elderly Accidents, Deaths, and Injuries campaign. The systems underlying bodily action and idleness differ, and they are not effectively maintained. Additionally, exercise largely avoids accidents, so take precautions. We are building a system where the patient's whole activity is tracked using a sophisticated accelerometer sensor, and where the patient's predetermined alert can be identified and alerts can be sent to the patients. A body-mounted sensor is used in this instance. Devices for tracking motion that meet the high performance, low cost, and low power needs of smart wearable sensors. In this, the data processing unit is provided the decided data. title: Smart Hospitals: Integrating IoT, Automation, and AI to Redefine Patient Care – an Indian Perspective
authors: Sheetal Barde, Sonia Daniel Rangari, Sumit Rane, Apoorva Kulkarni, Prachi Awasthi, Nikita Yadav
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: India's healthcare system is undergoing a significant transformation with the emergence of smart hospitals, driven by the integration of Internet of Things (IoT), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and automation. These technologies are enhancing patient care, streamlining clinical operations, and addressing long-standing challenges such as overcrowded wards, limited skilled personnel, and urban-rural healthcare disparities. This narrative review explores the current landscape and future prospects of smart hospitals in India, highlighting key implementations, enabling technologies, and barriers to widespread adoption. IoT-enabled solutions such as smart beds, continuous vital sign monitoring, and RFID-based asset tracking facilitate real-time data collection, remote monitoring, and automated clinical alerts. AI-driven tools support diagnostics in radiology and pathology, while robotic process automation (RPA) improves efficiency in scheduling, billing, and data management. Institutions like AIIMS Delhi, Narayana Health, and Apollo Hospitals have implemented these technologies to reduce hospital-acquired infections, optimize emergency resource allocation, and improve diagnostic accuracy. Government initiatives such as the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM) are promoting digital integration and interoperability across India's healthcare system. However, challenges persist, including high implementation costs, inadequate infrastructure in smaller cities, data privacy concerns, and limited digital literacy among healthcare workers. To fully harness the potential of smart hospitals, India must invest in public-private partnerships, capacity building, and robust regulatory frameworks. Smart hospitals hold the potential to build a future-ready, efficient, and inclusive healthcare system in India.

title: Determinants of Financial Inclusion in Morocco: The Role of Digital Financial Services
authors: Achmaoui Amina, Yerrou Hafssa, Benrokiya Oumaima
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This paper examines how digital financial services—mobile money, mobile banking, and mobile phone experience—shape financial inclusion in Morocco. Based on survey data from 139 respondents and analyzed using multiple regression and structural equation modeling (SEM), the study finds that mobile banking and mobile money have significant positive effects on financial inclusion, while mobile phone experience shows only a modest effect and perceived financial cost is not significant. The results are strongest among unbanked and rural users. Policy implications emphasize expanding rural connectivity, enhancing digital literacy, and strengthening interoperability rather than prioritizing fee reductions. The study extends the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and Diffusion of Innovation (DOI) theory by integrating perceived financial cost and mobile experience into the Moroccan context. Limitations include the use of a convenience sample and reliance on self-reported measures; future research should employ nationally representative or longitudinal data.

title: A systematic mapping review on usage of artificial intelligence in project stakeholder management
authors: Robert T. Hans
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Stakeholders, through their vested interest in a project hold the key to project success. Therefore, the management of them is crucial and mandatory. However, tasks involved in stakeholder management is not that simple and thus require tools to perform them. The challenge is that some of the existing methods, techniques and tools are incapable to fulfil the performance of these tasks. The evolvement and sophistication of project stakeholders do not make the situation easier too. In an attempt to address this challenge, researchers have developed software tools for effective and efficient of management stakeholders. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a technology that permeates and revolutionizes almost every business sector in terms of automation of tasks and efficiency improvement. AI has also found usage in various areas in project management. Although there is a wealth of research on the benefits of AI, little is known about how using AI tools has assisted project managers to manage stakeholders better. This study sought to address this research gap by conducting a systematic mapping review. The study found that AI has benefited the stakeholder management knowledge area by improving stakeholder identification, analysis, classification, particularly with the use of unsupervised machine learning algorithms for this task and risk management processes. However, the study also established that there is a need for much research in certain research categories such as, evaluation, proposal solution, philosophical, opinion and experience papers pertaining stakeholder management.

title: Enhancing Financial Decision-Making Loan Approval Prediction Using Machine Learning
authors: Niteesha Shrama, Sowjanya Yerramaneni, Ramesh Babu Pittala, T Asha Latha, G. L. Anand Babu, N. Nagalakshmi, Y. Lakshman Naidu, M. Venkata Nagireddy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The primary objective of this study is to develop an accurate and interpretable loan eligibility prediction system that empowers financial institutions to make well-informed lending decisions. Utilizing a range of machine learning techniques, including traditional algorithms such as Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting, the study evaluates their effectiveness in classifying loan eligibility. While these models demonstrated reasonable performance, the introduction of a hybrid TabNet+LR model significantly enhanced prediction accuracy, achieving an impressive 90 %, the highest among all tested approaches. This outcome underscores the strength of combining TabNet's deep feature extraction capabilities with Logistic Regression's interpretability, resulting in a robust and transparent solution for financial risk assessment. The proposed model not only improves predictive accuracy but also ensures model clarity, making it highly suitable for deployment in real-world financial applications.

title: AI-Driven Tuberculosis Detection in Chest Radiographs
authors: Abhay Bhatnagar, Sanjay Kumar Singh, Divyanshu Yadav, Pranshu Saxena
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Tuberculosis (TB) continues to be a leading cause of death globally, primarily affecting resource-constrained regions. Conventional diagnosis based on chest X-rays has limitations in being dependent on trained radiologists and subject to variability in manual interpretation, leading to delays in the diagnosis. This paper proposes an automated TB detection system based on CNN, classifying chest X-rays as either TB-positive or TB-negative. The model is preprocessed with the resizing, normalization, and augmentation stages for higher robustness. The CNN architecture mainly uses layers of convolution that extract the features, pooling layers to reduce the dimensionality of the feature maps, and fully connected layers to class the images. Optimization was achieved through regularization and early stopping with a validation accuracy of 97.5 %. This automated approach helps achieve a scalable solution to reduce overburdened healthcare systems and decrease diagnostic delay accuracy.

title: Continuous Multimodal Biometric Authentication using Face and Iris with Periodic Validation
authors: Manasi Sadhankar, Ashish Sasankar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Continuous authentication provides strong protection for long sessions but has neither been fully explored nor implemented. Generally, a few multimodal systems use static benchmarks; more importantly, they either have no periodic re-authentication or require some lesser-known coercion from the user. This paper proposes a face-iris continuous authentication framework, combining dual-camera live acquisition, an automatic scheduler with periodicity of 15 min, and presence detection, along with adaptive neural scorelevel fusion. Testing on public datasets with subject-disjoint splits and transfer across datasets shows that the system performs at an accuracy of 98.6 % and EER of 1.4 %, outperforming unimodal and recent multimodal baselines. The system gives an equal emphasis on security, user experience, and deployment feasibility, while at the same time drawing attention towards promising research avenues in visible-light iris, adaptive re-authentication intervals, spoof resilience, and privacy-preserving template protection.

title: Constant Approximation of Arboricity in Near-Optimal Sublinear Time
authors: Jiangqi Dai, Mohsen Ghaffari, Julian Portmann
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We present a randomized algorithm that computes a constant approximation of a graph’s arboricity, using $\tilde O(n/\lambda )$ queries to adjacency lists and in the same time bound. Here, n and λ denote the number of nodes and the graph’s arboricity, respectively. The $\tilde O(n/\lambda )$ query complexity of our algorithm is nearly optimal. Our constant approximation settles a question of Eden, Mossel, and Ron [SODA’22], who achieved an O(log<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> n) approximation with the same query and time complexity and asked whether a better approximation can be achieved using near-optimal query complexity.A key technical challenge in the problem is due to recursive algorithms based on probabilistic samplings, each with a non-negligible error probability. In our case, many of the recursions invoked could have bad probabilistic samples and result in high query complexities. The particular difficulty is that those bad recursions are not easy or cheap to detect and discard. Our approach runs multiple recursions in parallel, to attenuate the error probability, using a careful scheduling mechanism that manages the speed at which each of them progresses and makes our overall query complexity competitive with the single good recursion. We find this usage of parallelism and scheduling in a sublinear algorithm remarkable, and we are hopeful that similar ideas may find applications in a wider range of sublinear algorithms that rely on probabilistic recursions.

title: Fine-Tuned Large Language Models for Equitable and Accurate Document Analysis in Recruitment
authors: Neha Pandey, CRS Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Manual document verification in recruitment incurs high costs, averaging 50 dollars per hour per reviewer with 15 percent error rates. The IDoc system, an Intelligent Document Processing framework, leverages fine-tuned Large Language Models such as LayoutLMv3, DONUT, and LiLT to achieve 95 percent text extraction accuracy and reduce demographic biases by 60 percent compared to untuned LLMs. This novel integration of adversarial debiasing and reinforcement learning in a multilingual IDP framework addresses gaps in existing systems. Evaluated on RVL-CDIP, XFUND, PubTables-1M, and a custom dataset, IDoc reduces processing time by 40 percent while ensuring GDPR and DPDP compliance through AES-256 encryption. Its optimization objective balances accuracy, fairness, and efficiency, making it a robust solution for recruitment automation. Beyond recruitment, IDoc's applications span finance, healthcare, and education, with future enhancements targeting handwritten text recognition and additional languages. This work advances equitable AI-driven document analysis, offering a scalable, fair, and efficient framework for intelligent document processing in diverse domains.

title: Solving Linear Inequalities over the Space of Convex Sets & its Applications to Cryptography and Hydrodynamics
authors: Saugata Basu, Hamidreza Amini Khorasgani, Hemanta K. Maji, Hai H. Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Is a two-party function, possibly with randomized output, securely computable? We provide a finite procedure to answer this question, thereby settling a foundational, three-decade-old open problem in secure computation and information complexity.Beaver-Chor-Kushilevitz [11], [22], [8] answered this question for deterministic output functions. Basu et al. [3] recently gave a geometric characterization of randomized functions securely computable with bounded communication complexity. Randomized functions can have arbitrarily high communication complexity, even for fixed input-output sets [5]. Without an upper bound on the communication complexity, the decidability of the question of whether a given two-party function with randomized output is securely computable was a formidable challenge.We reduce answering this question to proving specific lamination hulls are semi-algebraic. Lamination hulls are an infinite union of recursively defined sets independently motivated by the hydrodynamics literature. We connect this technical objective to solving a system of linear inequalities over convex sets in high dimensions, where inequalities represent the natural containment relation. We present a Gaussian elimination-inspired algorithm to compute the smallest simultaneous solutions to such systems. After that, using these solutions, we prove that our lamination hulls are semi-algebraic.Our technical solution introduces a novel set operator called positive geometric join. In our application context, it characterizes algebraically well-behaved sets that generalize polytopes, which we call hemihedra. The positive geometric join operator and hemihedral sets should interest the broader mathematics and computer science community. These advancements should help further information complexity investigations more broadly via the recently established connection by Basu et al. [3].

title: Protecting Deep Learning Channel Estimation in Wireless Networks with Defensive Distillation Against Adversarial Attacks
authors: Niteesha Shrama, Sowjanya Yerramaneni, T Asha Latha, Ramesh Babu Pittala, Gudepu Sai Krishna, Bema Rajeshwari, G. Abhishna, G. Akhil
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: In this paper, flight delays are predicted using several traditional machine learning approaches and highly sophisticated neural networks. The main aim is to tag flights as delayed or on-time using important factors like when they leave, how many miles they travel and present weather conditions. Among the applied models are NODE (Neural Oblivious Decision Ensembles), MLP (Multilayer Perceptron), XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) and AutoGluon, a framework that can work with several models and determine the best practices automatically with minimum human supervision. Processing of the dataset was done in stages, dealing with missing values, engineering features related to time and scaling numerical attributes to help the model perform well. Among each model, the results of AutoGluon were best, reaching an accuracy of 95 % which linked to its ability to identify difficult feature links and improve model parameters. It shows that AutoML can greatly improve how machine-learning models are made for structured data and still achieve excellent levels of performance in flight delay prediction. Index Terms-MLP Neural Network, Random Forest, Bagged Trees, AdaBoost, Gradient Boosted Trees, and XGBoost.

title: Mediation model of Strategic Foresight influencing Innovation Ambidexterity
authors: Abdelati Hakmaoui, Wafaa Harandou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to study the interactions between Strategic Foresight (SF) and Innovation Ambidexterity (IA) with the proposition of three mediating variables that could affect this relationship, namely: Knowledge Management (KM), Dynamic Capabilities (DC) and Perceived Organizational Support (POS). The current literature points to the existence of connections among SF, IA, KM, DC and POS. However, there are hardly any studies that analyze the dynamism inherent in these interactions and specifically how the combination of KM, DC and POS can explain the relationship between SF and IA from a holistic perspective. Based on selective review of prior literature on the main streams, and supported by theoretical bases rooted in resource based view RBV, SF, POS and DC theories, this research fills such a gap allowing, through an abductive reasoning, the development of 4 research propositions forming our proposed framework. This conceptual study aims to contribute to advance the theories of foresight and innovation bodies by providing new insights on how the potential mediating variables proposed herein further enhance the links between SF and IA.

title: Crime Investigation Tracker with Suspect Prediction
authors: Amol Kadam, Devdatta Mokashi, Priti P Yadav, Kiran Bibhishan Naikwadi, Sagar Baburao Patil, Vinayak N Patil
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Criminal investigations often begin from the ground up, relying heavily on clues collected at the crime scene and the testimonies of eyewitnesses. These inputs are crucial for initiating the investigative process. To assist law enforcement and ease their workload, we have developed a Criminal Investigation Tracking System with Suspect Prediction. This system is designed to accelerate case resolution by analyzing digital records such as individuals connected to the case, historical criminal data, and physical evidence gathered. It allows officers to efficiently track case progress online and update records with relevant information as it becomes available. The system incorporates an intelligent suspect prediction algorithm that ranks potential suspects based on logical inference, thereby enhancing the speed and accuracy of investigations.

title: An Auto-profiling Side-Channel Attack against NTT Hardware Implementations
authors: Yiting Wang, Zelin Lu, Gang Qu, Md Tanvir Arafin
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Due to its effectiveness and efficient implementation, lattice-based cryptography becomes a leading solution to quantum computing attacks. However, many successful side-channel attacks (SCA) against lattice-based post-quantum cryptography (PQC) have demonstrated their security vulnerabilities. Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) is the basic sub-block in latticebased cryptography and a common target for SCA. Unlike the heavy investment on NTT software implementation against SCA, there is little reported study of its hardware implementation. In this paper, we propose an unsupervised learning-based belief propagation attack to break the NTT operation by leveraging power leakages captured from NTT hardware implementations (on Xilinx Artix-7). Our attack only requires the collection of 5000 power traces for profiling and the building of four templates. Based on this, we are able to apply belief propagation with only 20 power traces to reveal half of the input of a 256 -point NTT. This allows the retrieval of the secret coefficients in lattice-based cryptographic protocols.

title: A Mobile Robot Tracking Control Method based on Admittance Second Order Nonlinear Active Disturbance Rejection
authors: Zhigang Zhang, Guanrui Shao, Jing Li, Yuan Zhang, Xiaoxia Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: A following control strategy is essential to ensure compliant and safe tracking for mobile robots. However, existing human-robot following control methods exhibit high sensitivity to external disturbances, resulting in sluggish closed-loop responses and susceptibility to oscillations. There remains room for improvement in control compliance and precision. To address these limitations, this study proposes a second-order nonlinear active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) strategy based on admittance control. First, a human-robot following motion model was established based on spatial human-robot interaction theory. Next, the motion model was integrated with an admittance control framework, where carefully tuned admittance parameters ensured compliant tracking behavior. Finally, a second-order nonlinear ADRC controller was employed to regulate positional deviations, effectively suppressing disturbances caused by unstructured terrains on human-robot distance maintenance. This approach significantly enhanced the control accuracy of the mobile robot when tracking a target pedestrian. Simulation results demonstrated that the proposed algorithm achieved a compliance index of 0.031 and a tracking accuracy of 0.049 under external disturbances, outperforming both admittance-PID and model predictive control (MPC). Physical experiments further validated the method, with the robot exhibiting superior compliance and precision metrics, thereby realizing safe, compliant, and user-friendly human following.

title: Efficient Regression-Based Verification Methodology for Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulation Models
authors: David Schlatzer, Nick Schade, Jürgen Pannek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Hardware-in-the-Loop (HiL) simulation is a well-established technique for system validation in automotive development. As autonomous vehicles become more prevalent, the ability to demonstrate the credibility of these HiL systems becomes increasingly important. A key factor influencing this credibility is the verification of the simulation models used as a subsystem within the HiL environment. The increasing complexity of vehicle software leads to more complex simulation models, which in turn significantly raises the effort required for their verification. At the same time, with the shift towards software-defined vehicles, the demand for faster and more frequent incremental software updates is growing. This trend presents a substantial challenge for providers of HiL simulation models, who must keep pace without impairing the ability to demonstrate and document the credibility of the simulation models for every release. In this context, regression testing plays a crucial role in incremental development processes of simulation models, as it ensures that newly introduced changes do not negatively impact existing system behavior. To address this, this paper introduces a regression-based test case selection method to increase the efficiency of the verification of HiL simulation models. The approach performs graph-based signal flow analysis, identifies differences between consecutive simulation model releases, and selects reusable vehicle-level test cases for regression testing of a new simulation model increment.

title: Mechanism Modeling and Simulation of a 300 MW Compressed Air Energy Storage System
authors: Junlian Sun, Zhou Dong, Guangping Liang, Chang Peng, Jitong Hu, Zhiqiang Yu, Yang Bu, Sien Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) technology, as an efficient, environmentally friendly, and large-scale energy storage solution, plays a critical role in enhancing power system stability and promoting the efficient integration of renewable energy. This study develops a mechanism model for a 300 MW CAES system using MATLAB/Simulink, which comprehensively covers core processes and accurately simulates thermodynamic and dynamic responses. Model validation shows that key parameters exhibit a relative error < 1% versus design values. Simulation analysis reveals the dynamic variations of pressure, temperature, power, and rotational speed during energy storage and release phases, and elucidates energy conversion mechanisms in multi-stage compression and expansion. Sensitivity analysis demonstrates that rotational speed regulation and inlet temperature optimization significantly impact system efficiency. The proposed model accurately simulates operational characteristics, providing valuable reference for CAES optimization studies.

title: Sensor Importance towards Observability Degree via Shapley Values
authors: Vishal Cholapadi Ravindra
abstract: Sensor selection is an often under-appreciated aspect of state estimator or Kalman filter design. The basic minimum requirement for the choice of a sensor set while designing Kalman filters is that all states are observable. In addition, the sensors should be chosen with a view towards estimating the states with a desired accuracy. Often observability is treated as true/false check during filter design. Beyond observability — the observability degree — which measures how observable the states are, has been used as the metric of choice to for sensor selection or placement applications. The higher the degree of observability, the better the possibility of designing Kalman filters that achieve the desired state estimation accuracy and consistency requirements. When a wide variety of sensors are available, sometimes with cost and physical constraints involved, sensor selection plays a crucial role in filter design. In such situations it is important to know the expected contribution of each sensor towards observability degree. Shapley values, developed in cooperative game theory for fair allocation of the payout of a multi-player game to individual players, are widely used in machine learning to assess feature importance. This paper shows that Shapley values can indeed be leveraged to quantify the expected marginal contribution of each sensor in any given sensor set towards the observability degree. This quantification of the fair contribution of each sensor towards the observability degree can be leveraged by filter designers for sensor selection, placement and filter (state estimator) design.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Time-Series Deep Learning Forecasting Models for Peak Electric Load Demand
authors: Hamid Reza Pilehvar Javid, Mahan Ahmadi Rahmatabadi, Behrooz Zaker, Hamid Reza Baghaee, Gevork B. Gharehpetian
abstract: The continuing development of smart grids highlights the critical importance of accurate peak electric load demand forecasting, which is essential for enhancing the reliability and economic efficiency of power system operations. This study uses RNN, LSTM, GRU, and BiLSTM models to predict day-ahead peak load. This study presents a comparative analysis of these four models using a real-world dataset from the Iran Grid Management Company (IGMC). Following thorough preprocessing, the data has been statistically analyzed before being introduced to the model. The models ’ hyperparameters have been optimized using a GridSearch algorithm. Model performance has been evaluated using R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, MAE, MSE, RMSE, and MAPE. The Simple RNN model achieved the best results, with the highest R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and the lowest errors, indicating that it is more suitable for this dataset than more complex architectures. The study provides valuable insights for model selection in energy demand prediction and highlights the importance of empirical evaluation under consistent conditions.

title: Switching-Based Network Topology for Enhancing Cybersecurity in Distributed Control of AC Microgrids
authors: Abbas Ahmadi, Mahdieh S. Sadabadi, Qobad Shafiee
abstract: Control systems in AC Microgrids (ACMGs) are more at risk of different types of cyberattacks. While most existing studies focus on enhancing security and resilience within microgrids (MGs) control layers, this paper introduces a network security-by-design approach aimed at improving privacy in distributed ACMG control. The proposed method employs a dynamic communication network topology to mitigate passive attacks risks and strengthen privacy protection against potential attacks. By continuously reconfiguring the network topology, the approach serves to conceals source and destination IP addresses, thereby hindering eavesdropping attempts. Simulation results show that the proposed method is effective for distributed secondary control in ACMGs.

title: Formal Guarantees for Incremental Stability in Piecewise Smooth Cascaded Switched Systems
authors: Bhabani Shankar Dey, Indra Narayan Kar, Pushpak Jagtap
abstract: This paper deals with the problem of incremental stability in interconnected systems, specifically focusing on nonlinear switched systems connected in cascade. Guaranteeing stability in an overall interconnected nonlinear system is challenging, even if the individual subsystems are stable independently. In this context, the paper establishes a set of sufficient conditions that ensures incremental stability in the interconnection. To achieve this, the contraction theory as a tool is utilised to achieve incremental convergence, which ensures a formal guarantee. The paper uses computationally feasible matrix-measure-based conditions. Two case studies are presented to validate the proposed results.
