title: Exploring Barriers to Digital Inclusion in Indian Agriculture: Designing a Platform for Farmer Empowerment
authors: Atharva Zagade, Jayshree Patnaik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: India’s agriculture sector is vital for employment and the economy, but it faces several challenges despite digital initiatives. The sector is unorganised, fragmented, and lacks integrated social networking, hindering collaboration. This study used a qualitative, exploratory design with semi-structured interviews of ten agri stakeholders. The thematic analysis identified four key barriers: unreliable information channels, weakening institutional trust, unstable income generation, and market inefficiencies that disempower farmers. This research contributes to a deeper understanding of the digital needs of Indian farmers and their current agri ecosystem. This study further explores digital interventions that can be integrated into the current agri-ecosystem. Future researchers can build upon the findings of this work to develop prototype ideas and test them in the market, thereby gaining an in-depth understanding of the impact of such interventions.

title: Distributionally Robust Optimization for Scrap Blending in EAF Steelmaking
authors: Caroline Schmidt
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of scrap blending optimization in electric arc furnace steelmaking under uncertain scrap compositions. To mitigate the risk of violating material specifications, we develop a distributionally robust optimization (DRO) framework that combines the Wasserstein metric with a Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) risk measure. Alloying constraints are expressed in terms of scenario-wise violations, and a robust CVaR bound is imposed that holds for all probability distributions within a Wasserstein ball around the empirical sample distribution. The resulting convex program minimizes expected blending costs while explicitly controlling the risk of specification violations. Numerical experiments with synthetic data show that increasing robustness through the Wasserstein radius can compensate for limited training data and ensures feasibility even for out-of-sample scenarios that deviate from the assumed distributions. In contrast to existing chance-constrained or bounded-uncertainty approaches, the combined Wasserstein–CVaR formulation captures both distributional ambiguity and tail-risk behavior in a single convex program.

title: A Multi-Charging Station Coordinated Scheduling Optimization Model for the Stable Operation of Distribution Networks and Simulation Analysis
authors: Di Wu, Bin Zhu, Zhi Li, Yongyu Zhang, Lizheng Yi, Bin Xue, Yi Long, Tingting Xu
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: With the continuous increase in the penetration rate of renewable energy and the large-scale popularization of electric vehicles, the randomness of Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) access and the volatility of new energy output pose challenges to the stability of distribution networks. Moreover, traditional static scheduling struggles to meet the dynamic regulation needs of the system. To address this issue, this paper proposes a multi-objective scheduling optimization method for distribution networks and constructs a system encompassing a regional smart grid model, a scheduling framework, and a V2G scheduling model.This method clarifies the coordinated operation relationship among multiple charging stations connected within the same distribution network area, classifies V2G charging and discharging entities into two categories —energy storage batteries and charging pile clusters within charging stations — and quantifies their power characteristics. Three objectives are set: "maximizing the net profit of charging stations", "minimizing power grid fluctuations", and "minimizing equipment loss". Meanwhile, constraints such as capacity, power balance, and total discharge volume are incorporated to ensure feasibility.The Multi-Objective Genetic Particle Swarm Optimization (MOGPSO) algorithm is adopted to solve high-dimensional problems, and Pareto optimal solutions are maintained through an external archive. Simulation verification based on typical daily power curves shows that this method can shift the power generation period of charging station clusters to flat periods and the charging period of electric vehicles to the early-morning valley period. It effectively mitigates the peak-valley difference of grid loads, improves the absorption capacity of renewable energy, and ensures V2G user benefits, thereby providing technical support for large-scale V2G aggregated scheduling and multi-agent collaborative operation of smart grids.

title: Automated Defect Detection in Pulse Compression Favourable Gaussian Windowed Frequency Modulated Thermal Wave Imaging
authors: Priyanka Das, Ravibabu Mulaveesala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Signal Processing (ICGSP)
abstract: Infrared thermography has potential usage in Thermal Non-Destructive Testing and Evaluation (TNDT&E) methodologies as it is a non-contact, whole-field imaging technique and allows fast, remote and safe inspection that can efficiently identify surface and subsurface anomalies in the materials. In this paper, Linear Frequency Modulated (LFM) signal is imposed on a Glass Fibre Reinforced Polymer (GFRP) sample having flat bottom holes to capture the hidden defect signatures. A Gaussian window function is applied to the incident LFM heat flux for spectral reshaping as a post processing technique to enhance defect detectability. The defect detection capabilities of pulse compression of Gaussian windowed LFM signal have been compared with the conventional pulse compression technique using Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) as a figure of merit. The current work emphasizes the use of mean intensity profiles along the axes of the post-processed thermograms for automated defect detection to determine the potential capabilities of the proposed windowing scheme to analyze the depth and diameter variations along the intensity profiles.

title: Active Alignment Control for Contact-Based Inspection with a Single Range Sensor on Micro Quadrotors
authors: Sandeep Gupta, Anuj Nandanwar, Narendra Kumar Dhar, Suvendu Samanta, Laxmidhar Behera
abstract: Accurate alignment is critical for stable physical contact operations such as wall perching or inspection using quadrotors. Misalignment at the moment of contact can induce rotation about the contact point, often leading to perching failure or damage. To address this, we present a minimal-sensing control framework that uses a single forward-facing range sensor to estimate the wall angle in real time via a yaw sweep maneuver. The estimated angle is then used to regulate the quadrotor’s yaw and approach velocity, ensuring perpendicular alignment before contact. The method is implemented on a micro quadrotor and validated through docking experiments on vertical surfaces. Results show a significant improvement in the estimation of yaw angle and stable contact with the vertical surface. The proposed method achieves over 90% success rate and maintains estimation errors within ±2° compared to open-loop alignment. This work demonstrates that combining simple sensing with active control enables robust physical interaction in unstructured environments.

title: Enhanced-Control-Set Model Predictive Control for DC-DC Converters with Improved Dynamic Performance in DC-Microgrids
authors: Sayed Abulanwar, Zheng Yin, Fujin Deng, Weiheng Zeng, Yaqian Zhang, Yunqing Hu, Sahar S. Kaddah, Abdalbasit Mnider, A. S. Ayub
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: When applying conventional model predictive control (MPC) for dual-active-bridge (DAB) DC-DC converter, the dynamic performance of DAB DC-DC converter under single-phase-shift modulation is affected by the performance of the candidate phase-shift-angle. To address this issue, an enhanced-control-set model predictive control (ECS-MPC) for DAB converters is proposed in this article, where an enhanced candidate phase-shift-angle is designed for boosting the voltage regulation range. The proposed ECS-MPC strategy effectively enhances the system’s dynamic capability without increasing the number of candidate phase-shift-angle. A simulation on the DAB DC-DC converter is carried out for the purpose of validating the feasibility and operational performance of the proposed ECS-MPC.

title: Accelerated Lifetime Testing and Statistical Analysis of Adhesive-Coated Strips Using Arrhenius-Normal model
authors: Alhanouf Al Sayed, Omar Kittaneh
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This study advances the use of the recently developed Arrhenius–Normal model to evaluate the reliability of adhesive-coated strips under thermal stress conditions using accelerated lifetime data. While the same dataset was previously analyzed by ASTM (2024) using the classical Arrhenius–Weibull model, it is reexamined here to demonstrate that the failure times at each stress level closely follow a normal distribution. The Arrhenius–Normal model provides an excellent fit to the relationship between lifetime and temperature, enabling accurate extrapolation of service life under normal operating conditions. The analysis shows that although both the mean and standard deviation of lifetime decrease with increasing stress, their ratio—the coefficient of variation—remains constant, consistent with observations reported in recent literature.

title: Rigid Body Attitude Control with a Time-Varying Morse Function
authors: Neon Srinivasu, Amit K. Sanyal, Eric A. Butcher
abstract: The use of Morse functions on the Lie group SO(3) of rigid body rotations as Lyapunov functions for rigid body attitude control leads to almost globally asymptotically stable (AGAS) control laws. A Morse function on SO(3) has four critical points. When used as a Lyapunov function, it leads to a globally continuous state-dependent feedback control scheme with the minimum as the AGAS equilibrium of the feedback system. It is known that Morse functions give the largest possible domain of convergence with state-dependent and globally continuous feedback control laws. In this work, we explore the use of time-varying Morse functions for rigid body attitude control. This strategy can be used to parametrically stabilize desired equilibria or destabilize undesired equilibria of the feedback system. The positive gains of this Morse function are each the sum of a constant and a sinusoidal function of time. Linearization of the dynamics around the equilibria of the feedback system leads to decoupled Mathieu oscillators. Careful selection of these control gains can give parametric stability of the equilibria while varying these gains can lead to interesting behavior like period-doubling bifurcations. Numerical simulations of the nonlinear feedback system with control gains selected according to the linearized analysis show that the trajectory for an initial state on the stable manifold of an unstable equilibrium of this feedback system can be successfully stabilized.

title: Comprehensive Optimization Framework for Smart Distribution Networks with Multi-Resource Integration
authors: Kamran Taghizad-Tavana, Mohammad Yasinzadeh, Mehrdad Tarafdar Hagh, Hossein Shahinzadeh, Hamed Nafisi, Hassan Niazi
abstract: In this paper, an optimization framework is presented for the operation of smart distribution networks considering renewable energy sources, battery energy storage systems, combined heat and power (CHP) units, and fuel cells. The primary objective of this study is to reduce dependency on the upstream network, minimize power losses, and improve the voltage profile in distribution networks. The proposed model is simulated using GAMS software on the IEEE 33-bus standard network. The performance of the model is analyzed under four different operational scenarios. In the first scenario, the network operates solely with renewable energy sources. In the second scenario, battery energy storage systems are integrated into the network. The third scenario includes CHP units, while in the fourth scenario, fuel cells are incorporated into the system. The findings indicate that, compared to the base case, the presence of battery energy storage systems reduces the power drawn from the upstream network by 12.76%, CHP units lead to a 95.96% reduction, and fuel cells result in a 28.22% reduction. These results demonstrate that integrating distributed generation and energy storage systems can significantly decrease dependency on the upstream grid and enhance the stability and efficiency of the power system. Moreover, the results reveal that CHP units have the most significant impact on reducing network losses, achieving an 87.96% reduction, while battery energy storage systems contribute to a 31.04% reduction in losses. These findings highlight the importance of optimally integrating energy resources to improve network efficiency.

title: Real-Time Control of Battery-Integrated Modular Multilevel Converters Using Extended Kalman Filter-Based Estimation for Transportation Applications
authors: Ali S. Tabarestani, Gevork B. Gharehpetian, Mohammad Monfared, Davood Arab Khaburi
abstract: Battery-Integrated Modular Multilevel Converters offer numerous advantages for electric transportation and battery energy storage systems. However, practical implementations involve battery modules with non-uniform states of charge, which lead to voltage imbalances and increased circulating currents. These effects, in turn, compromise overall efficiency and reduce battery lifespan. Despite their significance, a comprehensive study of these challenges remains lacking in literature. This paper proposes a real-time control strategy that employs extended Kalman filter for precise SOC estimation and balancing. To this end, the converter power and control blocks are analyzed, with particular focus on the power flow between submodules as well as between arms and legs. Furthermore, the relationship between the state of charge and the circulating current is derived. The discrete model of battery is extracted, upon which parameter estimation using the extended Kalman filter is reviewed. The simulations are conducted with the system connected to a permanent magnet synchronous motor. The results indicate that the proposed method reduces the RMS circulating current by 5% and improves overall efficiency by 2% compared to the most recent literature. The system’s charge and operating times, defined as the duration from full charge until the batteries reach the minimum allowable level under constant load, are extended by 5%, thereby enhancing the driving range in traction applications.

title: Safe Indoor Exploration and Sparse Topological Mapping with Integrated Planning and Control
authors: Krutarth Trivedi, Utsab Karan, Advaith Sudarshan, Leena Vachhani
abstract: Autonomous exploration in complex, unmapped indoor environments presents critical challenges related to safety, coverage, and feasible motion planning. In such settings—particularly in the absence of global positioning systems—exploration strategies become highly deployment-specific, and ensuring safety becomes a significant concern. Traditional grid-based mapping approaches are often sensitive to localization drift and inconsistencies in range measurements, limiting their reliability in real-world scenarios. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a robust exploration strategy that leverages a sparse topological representation to achieve reliable global exploration while ensuring safety. The proposed approach uses integrated planning and control with gap-based graph formation method to avoid trapping in dead-ends and other trap-like configurations—scenarios where purely reactive control is insufficient to guarantee safety. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the strategy in generating sparse, safety-aware topological maps that enable efficient and reliable navigation, rendering comparable results as conventional resolution-rich grid map-based methods in terms of feasibility and robustness. Index terms - Mapping, Graph exploration, Topological maps, Gap-Based navigation, Feedback control, Planning, Safety

title: Coupled vs. Decoupled Motion Planning for Four-Robotic Arm Manipulation in a Shared Workspace: An Empirical Study
authors: El Ghazi Younes, Subrin Kévin, Mouchere Harold, Cardin Olivier
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Multi-robot manipulator systems are increasingly used in industrial settings for tasks like coordinated assembly and pick-and-place operations. In such shared workspaces, multiple robotic arms must plan collision-free motions that account for each other’s movements. This multi-robot motion planning problem is computationally challenging, as the joint configuration space grows exponentially with the number of degrees of freedom (DoF). We study motion planning for a four-arm industrial cell (KUKA KR6, KUKA KR10, UR10, UR5) operating in a shared workspace under ROS/Gazebo/MoveIt. We compare a coupled planner in a 24-DoF composite space using OMPL RRT-Connect against a decoupled pipeline that plans per arm and then time-coordinates trajectories with a Detect-and-Pause heuristic. The heuristic discretizes the workspace into voxels, builds a spatio-temporal occupancy matrix, detects inter-arm conflicts in advance, and resolves them by pausing the robot with larger remaining execution time. To ensure a fair comparison, task allocation and grasp configurations are fixed across methods, and identical controller and planning parameters are used. Benchmarks span three clutter levels defined by minimum interobject distance d<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">min</inf> ∈{30,20,10}cm. We generate 10 randomized instances per level. Results show the decoupled approach dominates: 100% success at all clutter levels (vs. ∼81.7% for coupled), a −28.9% reduction in median planning time on average, and −26.1% median makespan on average. Gains are largest at 20cm, where interactions are frequent. These findings suggest that time-based coordination on fixed single-arm paths is a simple, robust, and scalable alternative to centralized planning for multi-arm manipulation in shared workspaces.

title: An Improved Polar Format Algorithm with Out-of-Plane Motion Compensation for Earth-based Radar Imaging of the Moon
authors: Guangwei Zhang, Zegang Ding, Zhe Li, Gen Li, Rui Zhu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The Polar Format Algorithm (PFA) is widely regarded as an efficient imaging algorithm, typically performing well when either the out-of-plane motion of the radar is negligible or the imaging scene is approximately planar. However, in Earth-based radar imaging of the Moon, these conditions are often violated. The unavoidable out-of-plane motion of the radar and the non-planar terrain of the lunar surface introduce space-variant phase errors that cause geometric distortion and defocus. To address this issue, an improved PFA with out-of-plane motion compensation is proposed in this Letter. First, an optimal focus plane is selected to eliminate the linear component of the out-of-plane motion and the resulting geometric distortion errors. Then, based on the mapping relationship of phase errors between the phase history domain and the wavenumber domain, space-variant filters are designed in the azimuth wavenumber domain to efficiently compensate for the space-variant defocus errors in PFA images. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is validated by the results obtained from experimental data.

title: A Novel Fusion Attention-Based Lightweight Model for Pipeline Weld Multiscale Defect Detection
authors: Songyuan Zhang, Chuang Wang, Hongli Dong, Xuefeng Zhao, Chuang Guan
abstract: Weld defect detection is critical for maintaining the safe operation of natural gas pipelines. While computer vision-based approaches have emerged as a promising research focus, existing deep learning models inevitably face the problem of limited detection accuracy in multiscale welding defect detection, especially in recognizing tiny welding defects. To overcome the above challenges, this article proposes a novel DySample-guided lightweight feature aggregation fusion network (DyLFA-Net) for weld defect detection in natural gas pipelines, aiming to improve detection accuracy and computational efficiency while preserving a compact architectural design. The DyLFA-Net model consists of two key components. 1) The IB-SCSA module at the P5 layer, which enhances multiscale semantic extraction via spatial-channel attention. The IB module enhances feature expressiveness through channel expansion and depthwise convolution, supplying the SCSA mechanism with semantically enriched input features. 2) A high-resolution detection head at the P2 layer to improve tiny defect recognition. Experiments show that the proposed model achieves an mAP@0.5 of 89.9%, outperforming mainstream detectors. Additionally, with just 1.31 M parameters and 6.6 GFLOPs, the proposed model offers high accuracy and low complexity, enabling real-time deployment on resource-limited edge devices.

title: Multi-view Contrastive Learning with Tensor Low-Rank Factorization for Integrated Clustering
authors: Qi Miao, Jingyu Wang, Tingquan Deng, Ming Yang
abstract: Existing multi-view clustering methods often separate feature learning from clustering, leading to suboptimal preservation of global structure and increased reliance on heuristic post-processing. Recently risen tensor-based approaches better model cross-view correlations but still fail to fully capture intrinsic sample relationships. To tackle these shortcomings, we propose a unified one-step multi-view clustering framework (MCOC) that combines contrastive learning, tensor-based self-representation, and nonnegative symmetric matrix factorization. View-specific self-representation matrices are obtained via contrastive learning and arranged along the third mode to form a third-order tensor to capture global consensus across multiple views, then view-specific self-representation matrices are symmetrized to construct affinity graphs. Joint factorization of degree-normalized affinity matrices yields a shared nonnegative indicator matrix, enabling direct cluster assignment. Experiments on real-world datasets validate the superior clustering performance of the proposed method, effectively fusing local view-specific and global structural information.

title: Direct Product Theorems for Randomized Query Complexity
authors: Shalev Ben-David, Eric Blais
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We establish two new direct product theorems for the randomized query complexity of Boolean functions. The first shows that computing n copies of a function f, even with a small success probability of $\gamma^{n}$, requires $\Theta(n)$ times the maximum distributional query complexity of f with success parameter $\gamma$. This result holds for all success parameters $\gamma$, even when $\gamma$ is very close to 1/2 or to 1. As a result, it unifies and generalizes Drucker’s direct product theorem (2012) for $\gamma$ bounded away from $\frac{1}{2}$ and 1 as well as the strong direct sum theorem of Blais and Brody (2019) for $\gamma \approx 1-1 / n$. The second establishes a general list decoding direct product theorem that captures many different variants of “partial computation” tasks related to the function $f^{n}$ consisting of n copies of f. Notably, our list decoding direct product theorem yields a new threshold direct product theorem and other new variants such as the labelled-threshold direct product theorem. Both of these direct product theorems are obtained by taking a new approach. Instead of directly analyzing the query complexity of algorithms, we introduce a new measure of complexity of functions that we call discounted score. We show that this measure satisfies a number of useful structural properties, including tensorization, that make it particularly suitable for the study of direct product questions.

title: Adaptivity Gaps for Stochastic Probing with Subadditive Functions
authors: Jian Li, Yinchen Liu, Yiran Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In this paper, we study the stochastic probing problem under a general monotone norm objective. We are given a ground set $U=[n]=\{1,2, \ldots, n\}$, where each element i is associated with an independent nonnegative random variable $X_{i}$ (with a known distribution). We may probe these elements adaptively, and upon probing an element i, its value $X_{i}$ is realized. The sequence of probed elements must satisfy a prefix-closed feasibility constraint $\mathcal{F}$, such as a matroid, an orienteering constraint, or any other downward-closed constraint. We also have a monotone norm function $f: \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$. Let $P \subseteq U$ be the set of probed elements. Then the reward is $f\left(X_{P}\right)$, where $X_{P}$ is an n-dimensional vector whose i-th coordinate equals the realized value of $X_{i}$ if $i \in P$ (i.e., element i is probed), and 0 otherwise. Our objective is to design a probing strategy that maximizes the expected reward $\mathbb{E}\left[f\left(X_{P}\right)\right]$. We study the adaptivity gap of the problem, defined as the ratio between the expected reward of an optimal adaptive strategy and that of an optimal non-adaptive strategy. A small adaptivity gap allows us to focus on designing nonadaptive strategies, which are typically simpler to represent and analyze. Establishing tight adaptivity gaps is a central challenge in stochastic combinatorial optimization and has been studied extensively for stochastic probing problems with various objective functions. In this paper, we resolve a central open problem in this line of research, posed in [1], [2], by proving that the adaptivity gap for stochastic probing with general monotone norms is bounded by $O\left(\log ^{2} n\right)$. With a refined analysis, we can further strengthen the bound to $O(\log r \log n / \log \log n)$ where r is the maximum length of a sequence in the feasibility constraint ($2 \leq r \leq n$). As a by-product, we obtain an asymptotically tight adaptivity gap $\Theta(\log n / \log \log n)$ for Bernoulli stochastic probing with binary-XOS objectives, matching the lower bound in [1]. We also obtain an $O\left(\log ^{3} n\right)$ upper bound for Bernoulli stochastic probing with general subadditive objectives. Furthermore, for monotone symmetric norms, we prove that the adaptivity gap can be bounded by $O(1)$, answering an open question posed in [3] and improving upon their $O(\log n)$ upper bound. Index Terms-stochastic probing, adaptivity gap, subadditive objective

title: Constant Rate Codes for Adaptive Broadcasts Do Not Exist
authors: Klim Efremenko, Gillat Kol, Dmitry Paramonov, Raghuvansh R. Saxena
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Can the n-party broadcast channel, where any symbol sent by one party is received by all, be made resilient to noise with low overhead? Namely, is it possible to construct interactive error-correcting codes that convert any protocol designed for the noiseless broadcast channel into one that works over the noisy broadcast channel and is not much longer than the original protocol?[12, STOC 2018] showed that such interactive codes with constant multiplicative overhead are possible under the assumption that the noiseless protocol being simulated is non-adaptive, meaning that it is restricted to have a pre-determined order of turns. Their noise resilient simulating protocols, however, require adaptivity, where each party can decide whether or not to broadcast given all the information available to them, including their input and received transcript. The question of whether such a simulation is possible for general, potentially adaptive, noiseless protocols was left open.We resolve this question negatively, proving that any interactive code that converts adaptive noiseless broadcast protocols into adaptive broadcast protocols resilient to stochastic errors must incur a multiplicative overhead of Ω(log n/ log log n), which is nearly tight.

title: CosineOpt: Optimization-Based Centralized Cooperative Speed Planning for Multiple CAVs Along Intersected Fixed Paths
authors: Fan Bu, Bai Li, Peng Chen, Guizhen Yu, Yunpeng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This paper focuses on cooperative speed planning for multiple connected and automated vehicles (CAVs) traversing along intersected fixed paths. Nominally, this task is formulated as an optimal control problem incorporating logical operators to represent collision-avoidance constraints. This formulation requires solving a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem, while handling non-differentiable integer variables remains challenging for gradient-based solvers. Instead of solving the MINLP, we propose a cosine-based method, a novel geometric strategy for formulating collision-avoidance constraints between CAVs. Constructing such a geometric model introduces potential approximation errors, which are mitigated by fitted correction terms designed to compensate for geometric deviations and refine the distance calculation. We propose a simulation-based planner to provide the speed profile with the globally optimal passing order, serving as a warm start for the solver. A lightweight iterative optimization strategy is also adopted to enhance robustness. Additionally, we propose a fault-tolerant strategy to ensure both system safety and operational efficiency. Extensive simulation results verify the proposed method, and comparative experiments demonstrate its efficiency.

title: Kinematic Coordination and Muscle Synergy Patterns of Grasping during Lower-limb Locomotion
authors: Linxi He, Rongli Wang, Yan Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Human motor behaviors typically require coordination between lower-limb rhythmic tasks and upper-limb voluntary tasks. This study investigates the synergy strategies of human motion at the joint and muscle levels to explore the control mechanisms of cooperative tasks, such as grasping during walking or running. We designed novel motor experiments and analyzed kinematic characteristics, ipsilateral joint angles and EMG signals. Using principal component analysis on joint angle trajectories and non-negative matrix factorization on 16-muscle activities, we extracted kinematic primitives and muscle synergies to reveal underlying synergy mechanisms. The results demonstrate that the kinematic and muscle synergy mechanisms of cooperative tasks exhibit significant grasp-position dependence, and strong correlations exist between weight coefficients and specific kinematic characteristics. Additionally, cooperative tasks can be explained by integrating pre-existing muscle synergy patterns derived from lowerlimb rhythmic and upper-limb voluntary tasks. The activation components of lower-limb locomotion are almost preserved, whereas those of grasping tasks are partially obliterated in some cases. These findings indicate that cooperative tasks induce functional coupling between lowerlimb and upper-limb movements at both joint and muscle levels, exhibiting significantly stronger inter-limb coordination than individual voluntary tasks. This work introduces novel experimental paradigms to systematically study inter-limb coordination strategies, providing valuable insights into human motion control mechanisms.

authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems

title: High-Power High-Efficiency K-Band Photodiodes via Depletion–Inductance Co-optimization
authors: Xiuqi Zhang, Yanjun Han, Bing Xiong, Changzheng Sun, Jian Wang, Zhibiao Hao, Lai Wang, Hongtao Li, Lin Gan, Yi Luo
abstract: A design methodology for modified uni-traveling-carrier photodiodes (MUTC-PDs) is presented to maximize RF output power under both bandwidth (> 20 GHz) and responsivity (> 0.8 A/W) constraints. The proposed approach simultaneously optimizes the epitaxial structure—particularly the depletion layer profile—and the microwave transmission electrode layout, thereby balancing the RC-limited and transit-time-limited bandwidths to provide enhanced design margin for power scaling. The optimized device exhibits a bandwidth exceeding 20 GHz across a photocurrent range of 10–110 mA, achieving a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 26.7% at 20 GHz and a responsivity reach 0.9 A/W under −6 V bias. At a higher bias of −7.5 V, a high RF output power of 24.1 dBm is demonstrated.

title: A Wide-Range Current Balanced Ultra-High-Gain Series-Capacitor Boost Converter With Symmetry-Integrated Step-Up Cells
authors: Yu Yang, Yang Qin, Dylan Dah-Chuan Lu, John Long Soon, Xin Huang, Ling Qin
abstract: Conventional ultra-high-gain series-capacitor boost converters typically employ common grounding of the input and output sides and switches, while achieving low voltage and current stresses. However, operating under symmetric control (i.e., equal duty cycles with a 360$^\circ$/m phase shift for m phases) with a duty cycle below a specific threshold (D$\leq$3/4 or 1/2, depending on the topology) leads to a loss of current balancing capability, decreased voltage gain, and increased switch voltage stress. To overcome these limitations, this paper establishes the conditions for current balancing in two-phase boost-converter-based topologies. Based on this analysis, a method is proposed to extend the duty-cycle range for automatic current balancing while simultaneously enhancing the voltage gain, in which N-stage switched-capacitor or quasi-Z-source step-up cells are symmetrically integrated into both output diode branches of the conventional two-phase series-capacitor boost converter. The switched-capacitor configuration (N=1) is taken as a representative example. Under symmetric control in continuous conduction mode (CCM) with D>1/3, the proposed converter maintains a constant voltage gain of 4/(1–D) with inherent inductor-current balancing. Moreover, the voltage stress of a single diode is limited to U$_{\mathrm{{o}}}$/2, whereas all remaining diodes and switches experience a reduced voltage stress of U$_{\mathrm{{o}}}$ /4. The operating principles and steady-state characteristics in CCM are comprehensively analyzed. In addition, small-signal models are developed together with controller design. A 24-60V/500W/50kHz experimental prototype is built and tested, which demonstrates an inductor-current imbalance below 1% and a peak efficiency of 98% under CCM operation with D>1/3.

title: Diffusion-based Signal Refiner for Speech Enhancement and Separation
authors: Masato Hirano, Ryosuke Sawata, Naoki Murata, Shusuke Takahashi, Yuki Mitsufuji
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Although recent speech processing technologies have achieved significant improvements in objective metrics, there still remains a gap in human perceptual quality. This paper proposes Diffiner, a novel solution that utilizes the powerful generative capability of diffusion models' prior distributions to address this fundamental issue. Diffiner leverages the probabilistic generative framework of diffusion models and learns natural prior distributions of clean speech to convert outputs from existing speech processing systems into perceptually natural high-quality audio. In contrast to conventional deterministic approaches, our method simultaneously analyzes both the original degraded speech and the pre-processed speech to accurately identify unnatural artifacts introduced during processing. Then, through the iterative sampling process of the diffusion model, these degraded portions are replaced with perceptually natural and high-quality speech segments. Experimental results indicate that Diffiner can recover a clearer harmonic structure of speech, which is shown to result in improved perceptual quality w.r.t. several metrics as well as in a human listening test. This highlights Diffiner's efficacy as a versatile post-processor for enhancing existing speech processing pipelines.

title: Feedback-Based Navigation on QBot Platform: A Comparison of LMPC and Pure Pursuit
authors: Amitesh Vatsa, Prathamesh Balsingrao Adhav, Jaynil Nirav Sheth, Baby Diana, Eram Taslima, Priyanka Singh, Shyam Kamal
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive implementation of path planning and feedback-based path tracking control strategies for Quanser QBot Platform, a differential-drive wheeled mobile robot. A series of 2D LiDAR scans are used to generate probabilistic occupancy maps of the environment with static obstacles. RRT* path planning algorithm is used to generate paths that circumvent any static obstacles present in the occupancy map, given the initial and final positions. Two reference paths considering different terminal points are generated for the path tracking problem. Pure Pursuit and Linear Model Predictive Control (LMPC) based path tracking controllers are experimentally implemented on QBot and achieved remarkable performance accuracy in real-time settings, i.e, MATLAB Simulink. The performance of Pure Pursuit and LMPC is compared based on state errors and form errors.

title: Adaptive Neuro Fuzzy Inference System -based Intelligent Control for a Flyback Converter LED Driver with Low THD and Output Ripple
authors: Abolfazl Raei Bidgoli, Nasser Masoumi, Atefehsadat Seyedolhosseini
abstract: In this study, an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) is employed to develop an intelligent control strategy for a flyback-based LED driver. The proposed system is modeled and simulated in MATLAB/Simulink under varying input voltages from 80 V to 290 V AC to assess both transient and steady-state performances. For comparison, conventional proportional-integral (PI) and hysteresis controllers are also implemented. Simulation results show that the ANFIS controller can maintain both voltage and current in the range of 32–46 V DC and 1 A current more consistently than PI and hysteresis methods, minimize ripple, and reduce total harmonic distortion (THD) to 1.8%. Moreover, the ANFIS-based control scheme enhances system stability and robustness against input fluctuations, outperforming traditional control methods. Overall, the findings indicate that an adaptive controller such as ANFIS can improve power-quality metrics and enhance the stability of LED drivers under wide input-voltage variations.

title: Smart Classroom Management Software for Enhanced Learning Environments
authors: Shivam Firodiya, Swaroop Saikar, Akshay Dhuke, Vishwajeet Rupnawar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This literature survey explores the role of artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and the Internet of Things (IoT) in enhancing smart classrooms through various data processing and automation systems. The first study presents an IoT-based face recognition algorithm utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for automating attendance, achieving a 97.9 percentage accuracy rate, and benefiting from edge computing for real-time performance. Another paper focuses on a Smart Timetable System that leverages AI and ML to optimize scheduling in educational institutions, using genetic algorithms to minimize conflicts and enhance resource utilization. Additionally, research on AI in smart classrooms provides a taxonomy of AI applications, examining data- driven insights from both teachers and students. Despite promising proposals, current AI implementations face challenges related to technological readiness, privacy concerns, and limited focus on improving learning outcomes. Collectively, these studies highlight the future potential of AI-driven systems to improve efficiency and the educational experience in smart classrooms, with ongoing development required for wider adoption and impact.

title: eSavior: An AI-Driven Framework for Sustainable E-Waste Management
authors: Aditya Shrivastav, Sunil Sankathala, Kashvi Chaturvedi, Atharva Saraf, Krutika Patre, Susanta Das, Ayushi Godiya, Khushbu Trivedi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: E-waste production is increasing significantly, with 62 million metric tonnes (Mt) generated worldwide in 2022 and less than a quarter being handled through formal recycling channels. Some of the greatest sources of e-waste come from schools, hospitals and IT firms but they're also the least equipped to handle these problems because of fast-paced advancements, scattered disposal systems and few chances for reprocessing. The eSavior system enables users to quickly and wisely decide when to upgrade devices, keep them functioning longer and choose the best way to recycle their old technology. The system relies on sophisticated machine learning algorithms, predictive analytics and its very own Chat Repair Assistant to streamline the handling of electronic devices throughout their entire lifespan. The solution draws upon the ideals of the UNSDGs and integrates data analysis, ethical decision-making and affordable strategies to effectively manage electronic devices throughout their lifecycles.

title: Implementation of Linear Programming Problem for Agricultural Development: A Study of Jalna District
authors: Bhagyashri S. Netke, Swati S. Desai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: In the context of an increasing population in India, the requirement for food is increasing daily. However, farmers face difficulties in developing their farms because of various factors affecting farming. For farmers with less average land holding, crop planning on a small land parcel is a very challenging and complex task. To increase production with the available optimal resources, Linear programming is a very useful and flexible tool for the decision makers to optimize the returns. Jalna district is located in a drought-prone area where low water availability is the most important factor affecting crop production. Therefore, decision-makers must plan for these resources. The study aims to develop a farm plan for the Jalna District by using Linear Programming to get maximum returns through the feasible cropping pattern. The results were obtained using LINGO 20.0.

title: A Water Quality Prediction Model Based on Low-Rank Multimodal Fusion Patch Transformer
authors: Xiankun Shi, Junqi Zhang, Yibo Li, Ziqi Wang, Renen Wu, Jing Bi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Accurate prediction of water quality parameters is essential for proactive environmental management and informed resource allocation. It also provides a scientific foundation for protecting aquatic ecosystems. Traditional prediction methodologies often struggle to capture seasonal fluctuations and longterm trends in water quality data. They also fail to effectively incorporate external factors such as precipitation. To address these challenges, this work proposes a novel model called Fusion Multimodal Patch Transformer (FMPT). This model improves water quality prediction accuracy through three innovative mechanisms: First, the model employs convolutional neural networks to process spatial precipitation patterns and Transformers to analyze temporal water quality data, enabling the extraction of spatio-temporal features. Second, FMPT applies patch-based decomposition to both modalities. This enhances the capture of local semantic information and expands the receptive field for more effective representation. Finally, it utilizes a low-rank multimodal fusion approach to integrate features from image and time series data, thereby obtaining a comprehensive representation of information from different modalities. Empirical validation was conducted using realworld hydrological datasets. The results show that the FMPT model performs better than existing state-of-the-art unimodal methods in water quality prediction tasks. It achieves an average improvement of 5.38 % in prediction accuracy compared to other benchmark models.

title: Depth-Wise Convolution is All You Need for a Lightweight Deep Learning Model for Image Denoising
authors: Hong Shen, Connor Cavarretta, Bingbing Li, Xiyi Hang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Signal Processing (ICGSP)
abstract: Image denoising aims to remove additive Gaussian noise from an image and has been extensively studied in the past five decades. While deep-learning-based image denoisers have achieved state-of-the-art results, their large model size may prevent them from being used in resource-limited environments, such as space computers and IoT devices. This paper proposes a lightweight CNN model based on depth-wise convolution for image denoising. Besides the skip connection from the input to the output, the model comprises three modules: shallow feature extraction based on regular convolution, deep feature extraction, and image reconstruction based on regular convolution. The deep feature extraction module consists of a stack of modified ResNet blocks formed by replacing regular convolution with a combination of depth-wise and dilated depth-wise convolutions. Despite being a lightweight model with only about 1.2 M parameters, extensive experiments show that our model can perform similarly to state-of-the-art deep learning models for image denoising.

title: Coordinated Game and Deep Q Learning-Based Distributed Control for Multi-Microgrid
authors: Rui Wang, Tianhuan Hu, Wei Liu
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Coordinating multi-microgrid (MMG) to maximize individual benefits while ensuring the overall interests of the entire system remains a key challenge in MMG control. To address this issue, this paper proposes a coordinated game and deep Q learning-based distributed control strategy for MMG. Each microgrid is modeled as an intelligent agent, and a distributed game-theoretic control architecture is established to enable effective coordination among them. By integrating potential game theory with deep Q learning, the balance between overall interests and individual interests has been achieved. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in improving the coordinated performance of MMG systems.

title: Design and Analysis of Vehicle-mounted Screen Mechanical Arm Joint Module
authors: Jiawei Chen, Xinbo Chen, Yungujian Bai, Liangyin Lu, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel joint module based on two serial friction pairs. The outer friction pair is connected with the frame of the module to prevent small amplitude loads such as random vibration from entering the transmission chain. The inner friction pair is connected to the self-locking motor output shaft, and enters the slipping state to disconnect the transmission chain in case of overload. To characterize the performance boundary of the joint module, constraints governing the output torque and friction moment of the module are established based on the transmission relationship, screw preload, and contact pressure. Given the nonstandard clearance fit between the motor output shaft and the central hole of the friction disc, this paper establishes a shaft-hole contact force model for non-eccentric conditions based on Hertz theory and geometric relationships. The effects of output shaft shape, rounded corner radius, and clearance on moment transmission capacity are investigated. Transient dynamics simulations are conducted on a 3-DOF mechanical arm composed of three joint modules to both investigate discrepancies between theoretical and simulated friction moment values and concurrently demonstrate the module’s anti-vibration and overload protection capabilities.

title: Cycle VS. Non-cycle, The Performance Comparison of Energy Charging Policies in Energy Internet
authors: Jinglong Wu, Yangyang Ming, Jie Yang, Zhiyong Xiong
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: In order to promote the performance of Energy Internet (EI) through source-load-storage coordination (belonging to bottom control means in energy management), we proposed two different energy charging policies based on whether considering the residue energy constraint at the end of previous day, i.e. cycle policy and non-cycle policy. In this paper, we designed the basic principles and proceeding of the two policies, and compared their performance through MatLab. From these results we can see, that both policies have comparable performance, and the running time of cycle policy is shorter than that of non-cycle one, but the designed complexity of inner compensating algorithm for non-cycle policy is less than that of cycle one. As basic function modules, these algorithms could be effectively used in upper-layer applications of EI coordination as preliminary innovations.

title: Research on Lightweight Intelligent Identification Algorithm for Small Current Grounding Faults Oriented to STM32
authors: Qingguo Zhang, Zhendong Li, Zhiheng Liang, Yitao Hu, Nianchang Huang, Xiaowei Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Aiming at the core problems in small current grounding system fault identification, including difficulty in negative sample collection, diversification of negative sample types, and limited computing power and storage of intelligent terminals, a lightweight intelligent identification algorithm based on Variational Autoencoder (VAE) is proposed. This study analyzes the hazards of small current grounding faults and the identification challenges caused by the complexification of distribution network topology, and clarifies the limitations of traditional steady-state component methods, transient component methods, and traditional deep learning methods. It quantifies the constraints of STM32 microcontrollers in terms of computing capability and storage resources, and demonstrates the necessity of lightweight algorithms. An STM32-adapted VAE network architecture is designed, which includes a five-level convolutional encoder, a five-level transposed convolutional decoder, and a weighted loss function. Weakly supervised fault identification is realized through "normal sample modeling - reconstruction error discrimination", and fault location is completed by combining the "partition locking - location refinement" logic. This algorithm does not require in-zone fault sample training, and its parameter scale and computational load are compatible with the hardware capabilities of STM32, providing a feasible solution for the front-end real-time identification of small current grounding faults.

title: Optimization of Home Demand Response Coordinating Vehicle-to-Home and Grid-to-Vehicle Under Uncertain Conditions
authors: Chengan Zeng, Yongxin Su, Ting Wang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) have the potential to charge during low-price periods (G2V) and discharge to households during high-price periods (V2H), making them flexible demand response (DR) resources for home energy systems (HES). However, HES DR optimization faces significant uncertainty due to variations in user behavior and environmental conditions. To address this, this study proposes an HES DR Optimization Scheme Integrating DRL, Considering User Travel Demands and EV C/D Applications. First, an HES management framework is established. Then, an EV dynamic energy-switching model based on predicted travel plans and appliance models are constructed. Finally, a twin delayed deep deterministic policy gradient (TD3) algorithm for HES DR optimization is designed to achieve adaptive control under uncertainty. Simulation results show that, on an i7-12700 processor, the proposed method reduces energy costs by 36.52% compared with non-DR schemes and converges within 553.4 s, requiring only one-third of the convergence episodes of PPO.

title: Research on the Intelligent Diagnosis Method of Photovoltaic Module Faults Based on Electrical Information and Image Information
authors: Tong Zhou, Honghua Wang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent diagnosis method of photovoltaic (PV) module faults based on electrical information and image information. When the PV module operates normally or different faults occur in the PV module, power optimizers with the function of PV module level monitoring and the related intelligent PV safety controller are used to acquire power optimizer input voltage information, power optimizer output voltage information and string current information. Due to the deficiency of the above electrical information in diagnosing PV module faults, PV module surface image information, the Histogram of Oriented Gradient (HOG) feature extraction technology, principal component analysis (PCA) and other image processing technologies are further integrated in the diagnosis process to improve the fault discrimination ability. On the basis of the above, when the PV module operates normally or different faults occur in the PV module under multiple meteorological conditions, the electrical information and the PV module surface image information acquired through power optimizers and other devices are collected, and then features are obtained, so as to establish the sample set. This paper divides the sample set into the training set and the test set, and then obtains Training Set 1 and Training Set 2 from the training set. On the basis of Training Set 1, this paper acquires the PCA results. This paper combines the PCA results, Training Set 1, Training Set 2 and support vector machine (SVM) to establish the diagnosis model of PV module faults, which is composed of two SVM models, so as to complete the construction of the diagnosis method, and the diagnosis effect of this method is tested through the test set. The research results verify the proposed diagnosis method. The proposed diagnosis method can provide a basis for PV module on-site maintenance.
