title: Active Support Control Strategy for Direct-driven Permanent Magnetic Synchronous Generator of Offshore Wind Power System using GFM-FBMMC
authors: Ruoning Tian, Ning Wang, Xiaorong Xie, Huibo Lou, Yue Dai, Xiaojing Wang, Wanglin Sun
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: As offshore wind resources become increasingly saturated, open-sea wind power generation technology is increasingly recognized. However, wind turbine generator system (WTGS) contains extensive power electronic devices, resulting in system with low inertia and weak grid characteristics. This makes it challenging for the generation side to maintain stable system frequency and voltage when subjected to disturbances such as wind speed or load abrupt change. Modular multilevel convertor (MMC) technology offers significant advantages in open-sea wind power generation. However, most of existing active support control schemes often rely solely on VSG control, neglecting the impact of submodule capacitors on system inertia. To address these problems, first the operation principles and steady-state characteristics of grid-forming MMC-based direct-driven permanent magnetic synchronous generator (PMSG) is analyzed. By utilizing submodule capacitor voltage as the intermediate DC link to simulate synchronous generator inertia, a submodule capacitor voltage-based grid-forming active support control strategy is proposed, which enhances voltage and frequency support for the onshore grid under disturbance conditions. Finally, simulations validate the active support performance of the proposed grid forming control scheme for open-sea wind power generation system during sudden changes in wind speed or loads.

title: Exact-Time Convergent Impact Time Guidance Against Moving Targets
authors: M. Kidron, Saurabh Kumar, Shashi Ranjan Kumar
abstract: This paper presents a nonlinear guidance strategy to neutralize a target, which is moving with a constant speed, at a prescribed impact time. The proposed approach leverages a trigonometric function-based formulation that ensures the convergence of relevant error variables to zero at a user-defined time (strictly earlier than the desired impact time). This convergence time can be preassigned independently of the initial engagement geometry, which is an alluring feature of the proposed solution. The guidance law is inspired from deviated pursuit guidance, known for its implementation simplicity. The effectiveness of the proposed strategy is demonstrated through numerical simulations across a diverse range of engagement scenarios.

title: GROOT: GPT-based Human-RObOT Interface
authors: Shobhit Maniar, Gilbert Tang, Marco Chacin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized the realm of Natural Language Processing (NLP). Their proficiency in planning and reasoning, combined with code generation capabilities, presents a novel avenue for robotics applications. This work introduces GROOT, a novel speech-based language-agnostic middleware that uses instructions and code examples as grounding principle to leverage Generative Pre-Trained Transformer’s ability to produce code for new and unseen tasks. Unlike methods based on language-conditioned robot policies, GROOT capitalises on auto-regressive code generation inspired by Code-as-Policy (CaP) and ProgPrompt. The aim is to create a human-robot interface using GROOT that enables the embodiment of an LLM to take user instructions like ’move in a square’, ’move 20 cm in front’, ’go to position ’X’ on the grid’ and return policy code based on robot API. In this paper, GROOT was used in a number of experiments to assess its performance to few-shot learning against spatial reasoning, logical reasoning and compound simulated tasks. This work reflects the potential of prompting code-based examples and API-based instructions as a grounding method to integrate large-language models with robotic platforms, envisioning seamless and intuitive human-robot interactions.

title: Energy Charging Optimization with Consideration of Island Lifetime for the Energy Internet
authors: Jinglong Wu, Yangyang Ming, Jie Yang, Zhiyong Xiong
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: During the operation of Energy Internet (EI), a prolonged lifespan under islanded conditions, coupled with the objectives of low cost and high revenue, is crucial for relevant operation scenarios. Building on previous research, we employ compensated charging samples and the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm to realize ESS (Energy Storage System) and whole micro-grid performance optimization. This is further integrated with an improved optimization objective that considers the accumulated significance of the charging amount in relation to the uniformed load level. In this way, it can effectively prolong the lifespan of islanded operation under main grid faults, while exerting only a minor influence on the relevant economic revenue. Therefore, the proposed algorithm can be extensively applied in micro-grid operation within the current EI through source-load-storage collaboration.

title: An Optimization Method for Substation Access Roads Based on an Improved A-star Algorithm and an Adaptive Cost Model
authors: Qiong Yang, Jingbo Liu, Tian Tian, Wei Li, Chenhao Ma, Kang Wen
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The scientific planning of substation access roads is crucial for ensuring the investment efficiency and construction safety of power grid projects. To address the limitations of traditional planning, such as high subjectivity and low efficiency, and the deficiencies of existing automated methods in satisfying engineering constraints and environmental adaptability, this paper proposes a path optimization method based on an adaptive cost model and an improved A-star algorithm. The method first constructs an adaptive composite cost model that dynamically adjusts grid resolution and slope evaluation criteria according to macro-geomorphic features. It also automatically interprets land-use types via a specially trained and validated high-accuracy PSPNet deep learning network to scientifically quantify economic, ecological, and policy-related costs. On this basis, the A-star algorithm is profoundly improved: firstly, by introducing an exponential elevation difference penalty function, the path can proactively avoid steep terrain; secondly, through a novel turning angle hard-constraint strategy, the minimum turning radius requirement is internalized as an algorithmic node expansion filtering mechanism, fundamentally ensuring the path's geometric smoothness. A case study demonstrates that the proposed method can automatically generate an optimized access road path in complex mountainous environments that strictly adheres to dual engineering constraints of slope and turning radius while effectively circumventing high-cost areas. This research provides a complete and efficient solution for the intelligent and fine-grained planning of substation access roads and other linear infrastructures.

title: Weighted Least-Squares Multi-Detection Fusion and Kalman Filter-Based Tracking for Collaborative Perception Systems
authors: Maryem Fadili, Louis Lecrosnier, Redouane Khemmar, Steve Pechberti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: In autonomous driving, research has been focusing on deep learning methods for collaborative perception to address the limitations of individual perception systems. While these algorithms achieve high accuracy, they require significant communication bandwidth and open access to each agent's object detection model design and parameters. Such requirements limit their applicability in real-time and real-world autonomous driving scenarios due to communication constraints and agents' need to preserve intellectual property rights over their solutions. To overcome this challenge, we propose a novel late collaborative framework for multi-detection fusion and multi-object tracking that only requires the 2 D bounding box category, size, position, and orientation in bird's-eye-view projection plane. We evaluate our solution using a custom collaborative dataset generated by adding noise to the ground truth annotations of the nuScenes database. This setup allows us to assess the impact of detection uncertainties on fusion and tracking performance in a constrained environment, evaluating the robustness of our approach in real-life scenarios where agents may provide varying levels of information quality. Our framework demonstrates robust quantitative and qualitative results compared to state-of-the-art methods, validating its effectiveness in realistic, noisy scenarios.

title: Feeder Level Non-intrusive Load Monitoring for Energy Distribution Observatories, based on a Weighted Summation Model Linear Equations
authors: Shaho Samadi, Nima Salek Gilani, Alireza Fereidunian, Amir Reza Yari, Meisam Nesary Moghadam, Habib Allah Ravaghi Ardabili
abstract: In this paper, a non-intrusive load disaggregation technique is proposed for medium voltage feeder-level monitoring in smart distribution networks. It is assumed that the aggregated feeder load is a weighted summation as linear combination of the representative load profiles of residential, commercial, and industrial consumers. Therefore, the estimated contributions of each load type are determined without intrusive metering or additional sensors, by solving a set of linear equations based on the measured feeder data. The proposed method is implemented in Python, and tested utilizing the simulated load data extracted from typical day consumption patterns. The results show that the estimated contributions for each load type are in complete agreement with their original values. Moreover, the reconstructed feeder load follows the measured data well, thus confirming the viability of the linear equation-based disaggregation technique. Further energy analyses indicate that the commercial sector constitutes the most portion in total daily energy consumption, followed by the industrial and residential sectors. Moreover, due to its simplicity and computational efficiency, and needless to complex measurement infrastructure, the proposed technique stands suitable in energy distribution observatories in smart cities for real-time feeder monitoring, demand analysis, and load management in smart city applications.

title: Mechanical Design and Mathematical Derivation of A Quad-Chamber Valveless Rotary Blood Pump
authors: Mengtang Li, Haoshen Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Mechanical circulatory support (MCS) devices, particularly total artificial hearts (TAH), offer an alternative to heart transplantation for patients with heart failure. However, many current MCS designs introduce complications stemming from the physiological impact of non-pulsatile flow and the elevated shear stress generated at operational speeds, in addition to problematic flow-structure interactions in valves. To address these challenges, a novel four-chamber valveless rotary pump is designed based on previous designs. Featuring a spherical shape, this pump is inspired by the conventional hydraulic gerotor pump architecture, where two relatively rotating "gears" alter the pumping chambers. This design provides a compact, spherical package ideal for a TAH, generates pulsatile flow similar to the human heart, eliminates the need for unidirectional prosthetic heart valves, and significantly reduces operating speed, potentially decreasing shear stress on blood. A detailed design methodology is presented, beginning with the derivation of fundamental mathematical equations governing the pump’s geometric shape. An analytical model is developed to size the pump and calculate the pumping chamber volume relative to the shaft angle, with validations from computer-aided design (CAD) simulations, which paves the foundations for future investigations.

title: A Sensorless Control Model for Humanoid Robot Joint Modules Using a Novel Switching Function and Dual Filters
authors: Boyu Chen, Shisong Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Developing sensorless control methods for motors is one of the effective ways to abandon traditional mechanical sensors and promote the further miniaturization of humanoid robot joint modules. However, in medium- and high-speed operating conditions, sensorless control methods still exhibit significant errors in speed and position control accuracy, making it difficult to meet the high-performance requirements of humanoid robot joint movements. For this purpose, a novel sensorless motor control model combining hyperbolic tangent function and dual low-pass filter is proposed. A permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) is used as an example for simulation analysis. First, a smooth hyperbolic tangent function replaces the traditional sign function to solve the chattering problem of the back electromotive force (back-EMF) signal. Second, a dual low-pass filter (LPF) is used rather than an LPF to remove high-frequency harmonics in the back-EMF signal. And a simulation model was built based on Simulink to verify the feasibility. Simulation data reveals that the proposed control model achieves error reductions of 86.2% in motor speed prediction and 75.1% in rotor position prediction compared to the traditional model. This research provides theoretical support for the future miniaturization of humanoid robot joint modules and the development of high-precision sensorless motor control.

title: A Diffusion Model-Based Landslide Detection Method for Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Liangxun Zhang, Jianjian Gao, Yuanchao Su, Xu Sun, Mengying Jiang, Jiaxin Cheng, Ronghua Liu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: As a frequent geological hazard, landslides pose significant challenges to deep learning-based detection methods due to their complex morphology and background blending. Most current object detection methods rely on empirical object priors or learnable object queries, which are difficult to fully adapt to the complexity and diversity of the landslide. To address this, we propose a diffusion model-based landslide detection method (DMLD) for optical remote sensing images. This method maps the object detection task to a denoising process. It starts from randomly generated noisy boxes that contain no learnable parameters. Then, it gradually refines these boxes to obtain the bounding boxes. To suppress background interference, we propose a gated feature fusion module (GFFM), which dynamically generates adaptive weights for fusing multi-stage features. Considering that diffusion models are fundamentally iterative processes, we develop a corrected sampling module (CSM) to improve the fast sampling precision of diffusion probabilistic models (DPMs). Experimental results demonstrate that DMLD outperforms other detection methods, confirming its effectiveness for landslide detection. The code is available at https://github.com/yuanchaosu/DMLD-GRSL.

title: A Wearable Textile-based Sensor for Breast Health Monitoring and Robust Tumor Discrimination Amidst Physiological Noise
authors: Zahra Yasaghi, Morteza Ahmadinasab, Amir Nader Askarpour
abstract: Continuous monitoring is vital for the early detection of breast cancer, particularly in high-risk populations. This work presents a compact, fully textile, ultra-wideband (UWB) antenna integrated with a 3×3 electromagnetic bandgap (EBG) array, operating from 4.5 to 11 GHz, for real-time, wearable breast health assessment. The lightweight denim-based design maximizes comfort and enables integration into a bra without restricting daily activities. Sensor performance was evaluated under 21 healthy scenarios—including displacement within the bra cup, rotation, and tissue deformation induced by typical daily movements—combined with physiological variations such as menstrual cycle and perspiration to emulate realistic conditions. Furthermore, 68 tumor datasets were synthesized by randomly distributing tumors within breast tissue, following anatomical likelihoods characteristic of stages 0, I, and II. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations were conducted in CST Microwave Studio, and two fabricated prototypes were experimentally validated using a breast phantom. Analysis of S<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</sub> parameters yielded five statistical features, with one-way ANOVA identifying area difference as the most robust discriminator between tumorous and non-tumorous (physiological noise) conditions. Skewed Gaussian modeling, time-domain correlation analysis, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) evaluation confirmed robust discrimination for Stage I–II tumors, achieving the highest classification confidence for stage II. However, detection of Stage 0 tumors requires further algorithm development. The dual-sensor configuration complied with IEC/FCC SAR limits (1.6–2 W/kg), supporting its safety for prolonged use. These results demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed system as a safe, comfortable, and effective solution for continuous daily breast health monitoring.

title: Tri-Hybrid Beamforming for Radiation-Center Reconfigurable Antenna Array: Spectral Efficiency and Energy Efficiency
authors: Yinchen Li, Chenhao Qi, Shiwen Mao, Octavia A. Dobre
abstract: In this paper, we propose a tri-hybrid beamforming (THBF) architecture based on the radiation-center (RC) reconfigurable antenna array (RCRAA), including the digital beamforming, analog beamforming, and electromagnetic (EM) beamforming, where the EM beamformer design is modeled as RC selection. Aiming at spectral efficiency (SE) maximization subject to the hardware and power consumption constraints, we propose a tri-loop alternating optimization (TLAO) scheme for the THBF design, where the digital and analog beamformers are optimized based on the penalty dual decomposition in the inner and middle loops, and the RC selection is determined through the coordinate descent method in the outer loop. Aiming at energy-efficiency (EE) maximization, we develop a dual quadratic transform-based fractional programming (DQTFP) scheme, where the TLAO scheme is readily used for the THBF design. To reduce the computational complexity, we propose the Lagrange dual transform-based fractional programming (LDTFP) scheme, where each iteration has a closed-form solution. Simulation results demonstrate the great potential of the RCRAA in improving both SE and EE. Compared to the DQTFP scheme, the LDTFP scheme significantly reduces the computational complexity with only minor performance loss.

title: Advanced Energy Management Strategy for Tractor-to-Home Electrification in Off-Grid Agricultural Microgrids
authors: Aissa Benhammo, Mohamed Amine Hartani, Ahmed M. Nassef, Hegazy Rezk
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive energy management strategy designed for an off-grid agricultural microgrid that integrates a PV array, Home Battery Energy Storage (HBES), and Electric Tractor Battery Energy Storage (TBES). The proposed tractor-to-home (T2H) system coordinates power flows among renewable generation, stationary storage, household loads, and the electric tractor’s battery to maximize renewable energy utilization, extend system autonomy, and enhance operational reliability. Key contributions include a dynamic load prioritization mechanism that adaptively manages demand, and a refined Flexible Power Point Tracking (FPPT) algorithm to optimize solar energy harvesting under variable irradiance. The tractor power emulator is incorporated to realistically replicate traction motor dynamics for Processor-in-the-Loop (PIL). Experimental results obtained using the real-time MicroLabBox control platform confirm the effectiveness of the proposed energy management strategy in sustaining energy balance, minimizing battery degradation, and providing reliable support for both agricultural operations and household power needs over extended durations. Furthermore, the system consistently maintains voltage regulation errors below 0.5% and achieves efficiency levels exceeding 96% across all operating modes. Collectively, these findings demonstrate substantial progress toward sustainable electrification for rural farming contexts, offering a robust and environmentally friendly alternative to conventional off-grid energy solutions.

title: Dual-Mode CMOS LIF Neuron With Subthreshold Efficiency and Saturation-Driven Robustness
authors: Abraham A. Salazar-Hernandez, Victor H. Ponce-Ponce, Herón Molina-Lozano, Juan H. Sossa-Azuela, Juan J. Ocampo-Hidalgo
abstract: We present a compact CMOS leaky integrate-and-fire neuron that operates natively in two regimes: subthreshold for ultra-low power and saturation for robust interfacing. This dual-mode functionality bridges the energy efficiency of the subthreshold operation with the connectivity advantage of saturation within a single circuit. The design leverages device-level parasitics and subthreshold conduction to minimize the energy consumption per spike and reduce silicon area. It also maintains sufficient headroom in the saturation region to drive or directly interface with non-subthreshold components and resistive memories. In addition to outlining the design methodology and sizing strategy that enable dual-mode operation without needing additional amplification stages, we introduce a mathematical model that captures the circuit dynamics. Under specified operating assumptions, this model allows us to predict the spiking frequency for various application targets. SPICE simulations validate the expected spiking dynamics and trade-offs between energy consumption and latency. We also compare our proposed neuron with recent CMOS implementations reported in the literature. While some earlier designs achieve lower absolute energy consumption, our approach features a significantly reduced transistor count and the ability to interface with other cells without dedicated amplification, offering a practical and integration-friendly solution. By converting unavoidable capacitive parasitics into advantages, thiswork presents a silicon-efficient method for low-power neuromorphic hardware, making both subthreshold efficiency and saturation-range connectivity key design objectives

title: A Portable and Hybrid Verification Framework Using C and UVM for Secure RISC-V SoCs
authors: Muhammad Yasir Farooq, Haroon Waris, Chenghua Wang, Muhammad Usman Akram, Jiatong Tian, Jiang Li, Weiqiang Liu
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Comprehensive functional verification at the System-on-Chip (SoC) level is a critical and time-consuming task. The growing adoption of open source RISC-V based cores with safety and security features has introduced new verification challenges that require scalable and reusable solutions. This paper presents a portable and hybrid verification framework using C and UVM for secure RISC-V SoCs. The proposed UVM based verification framework is designed to support both C/assembly level test cases and SystemVerilog based verification components, enabling a dual test strategy that enhances coverage and debugging capabilities. The VE includes verification components for core, cache and peripheral interfaces such as agents, predictors and scoreboards, making it applicable to a wide range of RISC-V standard extension cores. It also supports third-party VIP integration, regression analysis and functional coverage tracking for integer, multiplication, compressed and floating-point instruction sets of RISC-V core. As a case study, the framework is applied to a customized open source RISCV SoC enhanced with AES security features. The experimental results demonstrate that the framework achieves 90% functional coverage, 85% code coverage and 91% instruction coverage. The indigenously developed hybrid C/UVM test suites for UART, SPI and AES are easily configurable and reusable. In general, the proposed framework provides an automated, portable and extensible solution to verify secure RISC-V SoCs with reduced engineering effort and faster coverage closure. This work emphasizes practical integration of hybrid C/UVM testing across RISCV cores and peripherals and includes a comparative evaluation with existing platforms to highlight portability and reuse.

title: Time Series Analysis of Inter-Beat Intervals: Arima Forecasting and Hybrid CNN-KNN Approach
authors: Aryani Gangadhara, Santosh Borde
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The heart rate is a basic indicator of human body; it is significant to measure the heart rate uninterruptedly, consistently, and precisely. However, due to limitations in sensors measurement, it is difficult to measure the heart rate in diverse circumstances. To address this, we forecast inter beat intervals (IBI) to measure heart rate using various models. stochastic univariate time series models are used to forecast future times stamps on the learning from preceding time lags, assuming equally spaced intervals. Time series analysis is an important but challenging task in machine learning. In this study, we compared two methodologies applied to IBI data: stochastic processes (ARIMA models) and deep learning models. These approaches hold great assurance in time series analysis. The proposed model's performance was compared with stochastic models namely Naïve Bayes and ARIMA, as well as machine learning models such as CNN and KNN. Experimental results demonstrate that the ARIMA model achieved a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) 27 outperforming classic models in prediction accuracy. K-fold validation is used for all the models. Among deep learning models, proposed model given the lowest MAE of 0.054, surpassing advanced models like CNN and KNN. These results highlight that while stochastic models outperform the traditional models, the proposed model offers superior performance among deep learning approaches, achieving highest accuracy in IBI prediction

title: Generalized Flow in Nearly-linear Time on Moderately Dense Graphs
authors: Shunhua Jiang, Michael Kapralov, Lawrence Li, Aaron Sidford
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In this paper we consider generalized flow problems where there is an m-edge n-node directed graph $G=(V, E)$ and each edge $e \in E$ has a loss factor $\gamma_{e}\gt 0$ governing whether the flow is increased or decreased as it crosses edge e. We provide a randomized $\widetilde{O}\left(\left(m+n^{1.5}\right) \cdot \operatorname{polylog}\left(\frac{W}{\delta}\right)\right)$ time algorithm for solving the generalized maximum flow and generalized minimum cost flow problems in this setting where $\delta$ is the target accuracy and W is the maximum of all costs, capacities, and loss factors and their inverses. This improves upon the previous state-of-the-art $\widetilde{O}\left(m \sqrt{n} \cdot \log ^{2}\left(\frac{W}{\delta}\right)\right)$ time algorithm, obtained by combining the algorithm of [17] with techniques from [29]. To obtain this result we provide new dynamic data structures and spectral results regarding the matrices associated to generalized flows and apply them through the interior point method framework of [39].<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>The full version of this paper is available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.17740.

title: Explicit Lossless Vertex Expanders
authors: Jun-Ting Hsieh, Alexander Lubotzky, Sidhanth Mohanty, Assaf Reiner, Rachel Yun Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We give the first construction of explicit constantdegree lossless vertex expanders. Specifically, for any $\varepsilon\gt 0$ and sufficiently large d, we give an explicit construction of an infinite family of d-regular graphs where every small set S of vertices has $(1-\varepsilon) d|S|$ neighbors (which implies $(1-2 \varepsilon) d|S|$ unique-neighbors). Our results also extend naturally to construct biregular bipartite graphs of any constant imbalance, where small sets on each side have strong expansion guarantees. The graphs we construct admit a free group action, and hence realize new families of quantum LDPC codes of Lin and M. Hsieh [1] with a linear time decoding algorithm. Our construction is based on taking an appropriate product of a constant-sized lossless expander with a base graph constructed from Ramanujan Cayley cubical complexes.

title: Faster Logconcave Sampling from a Cold Start in High Dimension
authors: Yunbum Kook, Santosh S. Vempala
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We present a faster algorithm to generate a warm start for sampling an arbitrary logconcave density specified by an evaluation oracle, leading to the first sub-cubic sampling algorithms for inputs in (near-)isotropic position. A long line of prior work incurred a warm-start penalty of at least linear in the dimension, hitting a cubic barrier, even for the special case of uniform sampling from convex bodies. Our improvement relies on two key ingredients of independent interest. (1) We show how to sample given a warm start in weaker notions of distance, in particular q-Rényi divergence for $q=\widetilde{O}$ (1), whereas previous analyses required stringent $\infty$-Rényi divergence (with the exception of Hit-and-Run, whose known mixing time is higher). This marks the first improvement in the required warmness since Lovász and Simonovits (1991). (2) We refine and generalize the $\log$-Sobolev inequality of Lee and Vempala (2018), originally established for isotropic logconcave distributions in terms of the diameter of the support, to logconcave distributions in terms of a geometric average of the support diameter and the largest eigenvalue of the covariance matrix.

title: Pattern Matching under Weighted Edit Distance
authors: Panagiotis Charalampopoulos, Tomasz Kociumaka, Philip Wellnitz
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In Pattern Matching with Weighted Edits (PMwWE), we are given a pattern P of length m, a text T of length n, a positive threshold k, and oracle access to a weight function that specifies the costs of edits (depending on the involved characters, and normalized so that the cost of each edit is at least 1). The goal is to compute the starting positions of all fragments of T that can be obtained from P with edits of total cost at most k. PMwWE captures typical real-world applications more accurately than its unweighted variant (PMwE), where all edits have unit costs.Indeed, the textbook $\mathcal{O}\left( {nm} \right)$-time algorithm of Sellers [J. Algorithms'80], devised in the context of bioinformatics, already accounts for weights. Surprisingly, the understanding of PMWWE has not advanced in the last 45 years. In contrast, significant milestones for PMwE include an $\mathcal{O}\left( {nk} \right)$-time algorithm by Landau and Vishkin [STOC'86, J. Algorithms'89], an $\mathcal{O}(n + {k^4} \cdot n/m)$-time algorithm by Cole and Hariharan [SODA'98, SICOMP'02], and a recent $\tilde {\mathcal{O}}(n + {k^{3.5}} \cdot n/m)$-time solution by Charalampopoulos, Kociumaka, and Wellnitz [FOCS'22].In this work, we examine whether these results can be lifted to PMWWE even though (1) the underlying algorithms rely on combinatorial properties specific to the unweighted edit distance, and (2) under standard fine-grained complexity assumptions, computing the weighted edit distance is strictly harder than computing the unweighted edit distance [Cassis, Kociumaka, and Wellnitz; FOCS'23]. We obtain three main results:•a conceptually simple $\tilde {\mathcal{O}}\left( {nk} \right)$-time algorithm for PMWWE, very different from that of Landau and Vishkin;•a significantly more complicated $\tilde {\mathcal{O}}(n + {k^{3.5}} \cdot {W^4} \cdot n/m)$ time algorithm for PMWWE under the assumption that the weight function is a metric with integer values between 0 and W; and•an $\tilde {\mathcal{O}}(n + {k^4} \cdot n/m)$-time algorithm for PMWWE for the case of arbitrary weights. In the setting of metrics with small integer values, we nearly match the state of the art for PMwE where W=1.

title: Towards Sustainable Farming: An Intelligent Plant Disease Detection System Using Machine Learning
authors: Amol Kadam, Amol Suryawanshi, Sumati Jagdale, Shankar N Kadam, Sana M Bagban, Jyoti P Kharade
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The objective of the project “Farm Defender Using Machine Learning” is to bring a simple, effective, automated method to detect plant diseases to help maintain the health of plants and contribute to sustainable agricultural practices. Access to data over the years has enabled the development of various plant detection systems for use in agriculture, environmental management, and biodiversity conservation. Plant identification using traditional methods is often tedious, requiring considerable manual labor and expert knowledge, and is therefore both time and cost- intensive. Utilizing ML techniques, image recognition models specifically, this plant identification system seeks to automate the identification and quality assessment of the plants. The system implements the use of a conventional neural networks (CNN's) that has been trained on mega sets of plant images, which merely capture salient visual features like leaf shape, color and texture to identify plant species and even recognize symptoms of diseases. Transfer learning enables the fine-tuning of pre-trained models to perform plant detection, reducing the time and resources needed for training. Data augmentation methods (rotation, scaling, color adjustment, etc.) can help the model be more robust and adaptable to different environmental conditions at the same time, which ensures higher model accuracy and reliability. Detecting diseases in crops is a crucial but often time-consuming and challenging part of farming. It demands great time and skilled labor. In this paper, an intelligent and effective method is proposed to detect crop disease based upon computer vision and machine learning techniques. To create a project that is different from the others, 3 datasets were combined to create one large dataset. The proposed system is capable of recognizing 38 different diseases across 5 commonly grown plants, with an impressive accuracy of 93%. The dataset is divided into 70,295 images for training, 17,572 images for validation, and 33 images for testing.

title: Innovative Technologies for Green Banking: Integrating Sustainability into Financial Services through AI, IoT, and Blockchain
authors: Namita Rajput, Baljeet Kaur
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This study examines the impact of emerging technologies, namely, AI, IoT and Blockchain, on promoting sustainable banking practices and encouraging sustainable finance. With environmental concerns rising for financial institutions, this research explores how new technologies can cut down on carbon emissions, improve openness and support better choices in eco-finance. Using a multi-method empirical approach, the study analyzes data from 50 international banks over five years, drawing on ESG performance metrics, technology integration indices, and environmental impact disclosures. Regression analysis and machine learning techniques identify correlations and causations between technology deployment and measurable sustainability outcomes, such as energy savings, paperless transactions, and green lending growth. Findings reveal that AI-driven analytics improve green credit risk assessments, IoT systems optimize resource consumption in physical banking infrastructure, and blockchain enhances traceability in green bond issuance. The merging of these technologies results in an enhancement of ESG scores by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 - 2 5 \%}$</tex> for most of the sample organizations. This paper provides data-supported evidence that supports the use of intelligent technology in making the financial sector more environmentally accountable. The book also gives useful tips for policymakers, fintech innovators and executives working to grow projects in sustainable finance.

title: Origin of the Peculiar “Double-Step” Behavior in GaN MIS-HEMT Transfer Characteristics
authors: Liyan Huang, Youyang Wang, Sheng Jiang, Jingwen Guan, Xiaobo Zhu, Wenhua Gu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: A peculiar “double-step” phenomenon was observed in the transfer characteristics of AlGaN/GaN metal-insulator-semiconductor high electron-mobility transistors (MIS-HEMTs). This anomaly causes a 12-times increase in the subthreshold swing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(S S)$</tex>, which significantly degrades the switching performance of the devices. To pinpoint the physical origin of this anomaly, a combined approach integrating technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulations and experimental characterizations was employed. The study first utilized off-state leakage measurements and breakdown analysis. These techniques ruled out gate leakage and buffer leakage as potential causes, and indicated that the dominant leakage path was source-to-drain leakage through the GaN channel layer. Subsequent temperature-dependent transfer characterization and high-voltage capacitance-voltage (HV-CV) profiling revealed the significant influence of donor-like trap ionization within the channel. Finally, the results were rigorously calibrated with two-dimensional drift-diffusion simulations, which conclusively verified that the “double-step” behavior originated from trap states located approximately 0.36 eV below the conduction band edge (Ec-0.36 eV), with a distribution at the AlGaN/GaN heterointerface and within the GaN channel region. This work thus provides key insights for mitigating the “double-step” anomaly, which is essential for developing high-performance GaN HEMTs with superior switching characteristics for next-generation power electronics.

title: Multisensor Fusion for Efficient 3D Urban Pole Detection and Global Localization
authors: Jaime Godoy, Selin Yavuz, Andreu Folch-Company, Alejandro Salazar Gomez, Daniel Serrano Dominguez, Dániel Horváth, Hafsa Iqbal, Abdulla Al-Kaff, Fernando Garcia Fernandez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper presents a multisensor methodology for the detection and global localization of urban poles, using late-stage fusion of high-resolution camera images and LiDAR point clouds. The approach leverages state-of-the-art 2D object detection models, RT-DETR and YOLO11x, which are fine-tuned on semantically annotated data. Detected 2D bounding boxes are projected into 3D space using camera calibration matrices, then filtered, tracked, and globally localized using GPS-IMU fusion and an Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF). Evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates a recall of 0.936 and an F1-score of 0.897 for 3D pole global localization. These results highlight the effectiveness of the proposed pipeline for accurate and reliable urban pole mapping, even in the absence of publicly available 3D datasets.

title: Frequency Response Analysis of a Steer-by-Wire Feedback System
authors: Jonas Marxen, Daniel Killian, Norbert Nitzsche, Steffen Müller
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: The freedom in designing the feedback torque and gear ratio in a Steer-by-Wire system defines the main benefit to the driver. In this work, the control of the steering wheel system and thus aspects of the steering feel are investigated. The considered control is realized using admittance control, to impose a designed mass-damper feel perceived by the driver. In addition, a feedback torque is provided to the driver based on a dynamic vehicle model. The subsequent velocity control to enable the admittance control is implemented using a model predictive controller. To analyze the frequency response of the system and to provide design guidance, the system is divided into a steering feel and a velocity tracking loop. The velocity tracking loop optimization weights of the linearized model predictive controller provide the desired stability margin and bandwidth for the application if chosen as recommended. Further, the importance of the rejection of the driver’s torque in the velocity tracking loop is illustrated using different non-rejected driver models. Knowledge of the driver’s torque enables the rejection of this uncertainty, as demonstrated to be a necessity. When designing the damping feel the driver perceives, with the objective of an electric power steering system as a benchmark, the analysis shows a trade-off between the felt damping and the frequencies to which the steering system feels responsive to the driver.

title: Classification of Cloud Phases in Cold-Air Outbreak Events Based on Polarization Lidar and Cloud Radar Observations
authors: Yu Zhang, Haoran Li, Zhaolong Wu, Fuxin Yao, Zhuozhi Shu, Ming Yin, Yao Ge, Yongjie Huang, Zixu Wang, Weiguo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Cold air outbreak (CAO) clouds significantly impact regional weather, precipitation and aviation safety. This impact is especially pronounced in confluence zones, where cold continental air masses interact with warm, moisture-laden air currents emanating from oceans or lakes. In this paper, an objective classification algorithm of cloud phase was suggested using K-means clustering algorithm based on PollyXT lidar method and a gradient based cloud identification algorithm, in order to determine depolarization ratio threshold for supercooled water, mixed-phase and ice clouds. The analyses of cloud phase characteristics and vertical structure were conducted for cold air outbreak events over the Shandong Peninsula, a region frequently affected by sea-effect snow disasters, using the winter period of 2024-2025 continuous observation data from the Eastern CHina cold-air OutbrEak Snowfall (ECHOES) campaign. The results show: the supercooled water clouds were predominantly located above the ice clouds in the mid-to-upper troposphere, implying heterogeneous ice nucleation processes; the analysis of diurnal variation reveals that the probability of occurrence of supercooled water clouds remains constant during the whole day because of the stable atmospheric conditions; synergy of lidar and radar observations clearly demonstrates their complementary detection abilities: radar outperforming lidar in lower troposphere and daytime conditions; the high coverage of the supercooled water in the lower troposphere poses a significant safety threat for aircraft icing. These results provide observational basis for improving the cloud microphysics parametric schemes in numerical weather prediction and aviation safety.

title: Variation-Tolerant Circuit Design and Online Learning Framework for Memristor-Based Trace-STDP SNN
authors: Yi Zheng, Yuhan He, Ruisi Shen, Jie Li, Ruijia Wang, Deyu Wang, Li-Rong Zheng, Zhuo Zou, Jiawei Xu
publish: IEEE Journal on Emerging and Selected Topics in Circuits and Systems
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) demonstrate significant potential for energy-efficient neuromorphic computing, while trace-based spike-timing dependent plasticity (trace-STDP) serves as a biologically inspired learning rule to improve SNN temporal learning. Memristor-based implementations of trace-STDP SNN leverage device non-linearity to emulate synaptic dynamics, enabling highly energy-efficient computation. However, the mapping from trace-STDP to memristor arrays introduces inherent variations, which significantly degrade network accuracy, posing a critical challenge for the reliable deployment of memristor-based neuromorphic systems. To address this issue, efficient variation-tolerant strategies are essential. However, current approaches do not take the trace-STDP SNN characteristics into consideration, thereby limiting their algorithm-and hardware-level effectiveness. In this work, a variation-aware online learning framework for memristor-based trace-STDP SNN is proposed, with hierarchical simulations integrated across software, ASIC, memristor-array, and memristor-device levels. Through variation analysis experiments, it is observed that variations in near-zero trace values significantly impact network accuracy. To mitigate these effects, a tailored variation-tolerant strategy is developed, together with a configurable hardware clipping unit and an ASIC/memristor co-simulator. The proposed variation-tolerant design achieves up to a 16.97% accuracy improvement, with only a 0.02% extra power overhead and a 0.01% extra area overhead, while a parallel design ensures no additional latency overhead. Integrating the co-simulator into the proposed framework facilitates design space exploration, enhancing the robustness and efficiency of memristor-based neuromorphic computing.

title: Performance Improvement of Polar-Coded Offload Method for SD-FEC Complexity Reduction in Ultra-High-Bitrate Optical Fiber Transmission
authors: Zhiyuan Song, Takumi Takahashi, Yohei Koganei, Koji Igarashi
abstract: As an offload method to reduce the complexity of soft-decision (SD) FEC decoders, we consider polar coding with a CRC-aided successive cancellation (SC) list decoder to enhance decoding performance. While applying CRC error detection to candidate paths generated by multiple SC list decoders can improve performance, two critical issues arise. First, because a single CRC frame must cover the outputs of multiple SC list decoders, the number of path combinations grows exponentially, making exhaustive CRC error detection infeasible. Second, in optical fiber transmission systems without CRC-based error detection, the additional overhead introduced by CRC cannot be neglected. To mitigate the exponential growth of path combinations, we propose a method that limits the number of candidate path combinations by preferentially performing CRC error detection on less-reliable ones. Furthermore, we investigate the dependence on CRC parity length to identify suitable CRC codes for the polar-coded offload method. Numerical evaluations show that the proposed method suppresses the error floor of offloaded bit sequences not protected by SD-FEC to approximately one-tenth of that observed with a conventional SC decoder. This enables the application of various hard-decision FEC and SD-FEC codes with different overheads, thereby enhancing flexibility. We also evaluate the assignment of CRC parity bits in the optical transport network layer, showing that physical-layer overhead can be avoided.

title: Simultaneous scheduling of electricity and gas network operations considering energy markets and renewable-source uncertainty
authors: Sina Ahmadi, Shahab Lotfi, Mehrdad Setayesh Nazar
abstract: This paper presents a day-ahead scheduling framework for the simultaneous operation of electricity and gas networks that interact with each other. The electrical grid under study is a 24-bus system capable of interacting with the upstream grid. Additionally, the gas network comprises a 15-node system that enables gas sales through branches for the system’s operator. The proposed framework incorporates the modeling of both electricity and gas networks and accounts for all operating constraints of these two networks. Given the nonlinearity of the gas flow model and the diesel generator’s cost function, the equation is linearized to yield a completely linear model. Additionally, considering the presence of uncertain parameters—including wind, demands, and the prices of electricity and gas markets—a stochastic programming model is introduced. The study is examined through two case studies. In the first Case Study, the system is analyzed under the assumption that the electricity network is not available, while in the second Case Study 2, the system is analyzed assuming that the electricity network is available. Finally, to ensure the robustness of the results, a sensitivity analysis is conducted on the model.

title: A Novel Ferroelectric NAND Cell Structure Featuring Ultrathin IGZO Charge Trap Layer for Superior Endurance and Retention
authors: Hyunjun Kang, Hongrae Joh, Junhyeok Kwak, Giuk Kim, Hyojun Choi, Hoon Kim, Sanghyun Park, Kwangyou Seo, Kwangsoo Kim, Wanki Kim, Daewon Ha, Jinho Ahn, Sanghun Jeon
abstract: We present a ferroelectric <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nand</small> (FeNAND) cell incorporating an engineered InGaZnO (IGZO) charge trap layer (CTL) within a metal-gate interlayer (G.IL)-oxide semiconductor (OS)–ferroelectric (FE)-channel interlayer (Ch.IL)-semiconductor (MISFIS) gate-stack for highly reliable 3-D integration. Conventional MIFIS-based FeNAND cells suffer from endurance degradation driven by oxygen vacancy (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {O}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> accumulation and severe memory window (MW) loss during retention caused by charge emission at the G.IL/FE interface. To address these limitations, a 2-nm-thick IGZO CTL is introduced, functioning simultaneously as: 1) an oxygen reservoir that suppresses <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V} _{\text {O}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-induced endurance failure and 2) an energy barrier that mitigates charge loss during retention. Furthermore, in situ <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${N}_{{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> doping is employed to precisely tailor the trap profile, yielding deep-level dominant traps at an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${N}_{{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> flow rate of 2 sccm. The optimized MISFIS FeNAND cell achieves a wide MW of 9.4 V at an operation voltage below 17 V, stable triple-level cell (TLC) retention over ten years, and robust endurance exceeding 80k program (PGM)/erase (ERS) cycles. These results confirm that the IGZO CTL-based MISFIS architecture overcomes key reliability challenges of conventional FeNAND structures and represents a strong candidate for next-generation high-density 3-D FE memory technologies.

title: Retraction Notice: Detection and Segmentation of Brain Tumor Through MRI Images
authors: Bommisetty Anantha Sai Murali Krishna, R Revathi, Nandyala Vyshnavi Devi, Shaik Irfan Ahamed, Sk Hasane Ahammad
publish: 2021 5th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Medical imaging plays a valuable part, and countless individuals undergo brain tumours, treated as a critical and hazardous disease. Through medical imaging, an appropriate diagnosis of brain tumor and numerous tissue irregularities is provided. A huge count of brain tumor detection techniques is available through Magnetic Resonance Images (MRI) images with a reminder of various challenges that include location findings and tumor size in image segmentation to distinguish the tumor through the image of the brain. This study presents an image segmentation procedure to determine or detect tumours from brain images attained through magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Although different thresholding techniques exist still, it results from other images. Therefore, it is essential to develop a method that detects the tumor distinctively. Also, the dynamic advancement in the automated medical image segmentation enhances the role in the research of scientific knowledge to further assist the doctors in taking up the required medication in the simple way of creating rapid determination. The detection and segmentation of brain tumours are impetuous in research via Information technology with biomedical engineering. This paper aims to present the higher accurate detection, and segmented process of MRI attributed brain tumor approaches. With the focus on the modern tendency of automatic segmentation. Subsequently, it discusses the state-of-the-art procedures in light of to latest direction for fully automated segmentation. In conclusion, an evaluation based on the experimental investigation of the process is presented, highlighting the potential improvements towards normalizing MRI-based brain tumor segmentation techniques within everyday medical practice.

title: Fully Unsupervised Non-Intrusive Load Disaggregation for Refrigerator Energy Monitoring
authors: Mohsen Gitizadeh, Seyed Ali Saljooghian Rad, Abbas Zare Ghaleh Seyyedi
abstract: Identifying individual loads and their consumption using only the aggregated power signal, is of high importance in subjects like energy management and demand response. Non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) is a method that disaggregates the total power consumption into the power consumption of each appliance. Most existing NILM algorithms require large amounts of prior data, including power consumption profiles of every appliance collected by submeters. This requirement creates an obstacle that prevents usage of these methods in real-life applications. The proposed unsupervised NILM method focuses on detecting the household fridge without using any prior knowledge. This work proposes a NILM approach that uses event detection, event clustering, and event pairing to detect the refrigerator in a household. The method is tested on house 1 of the REDD dataset, and is compared to a supervised method. The numerical results show 18.6% improvement in F1 score and 42.3% improvement in mean absolute error metrics.

title: Distributed Triangle Detection is Hard in Few Rounds
authors: Sepehr Assadi, Janani Sundaresan
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In the distributed triangle detection problem, we have an n-vertex network G = (V, E) with one player for each vertex of the graph who sees the edges incident on the vertex. The players communicate in synchronous rounds using the edges of this network and have a limited bandwidth of O(log n) bits over each edge. The goal is to detect whether or not G contains a triangle as a subgraph in a minimal number of rounds.We prove that any protocol (deterministic or randomized) for distributed triangle detection requires Ω(log log n) rounds of communication. Prior to our work, only one-round lower bounds were known for this problem.The primary technique for proving these types of distributed lower bounds is via reductions from two-party communication complexity. However, it has been known for a while that this approach is provably incapable of establishing any meaningful lower bounds for distributed triangle detection. Our main technical contribution is a new information theoretic argument which combines recent advances on multi-pass graph streaming lower bounds with the point-to-point communication aspects of distributed models, and can be of independent interest.

title: Theoretical limitations of multi-layer Transformer
authors: Lijie Chen, Binghui Peng, Hongxun Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Transformers, especially the decoder-only variants, are the backbone of most modern large language models. Yet, we have a very limited understanding of their limitations (i.e., what tasks they cannot solve) besides the simplest 1-layer case. Due to the difficulty of analyzing multi-layer models, all previous work relies on unproven complexity conjectures to show limitations for multi-layer Transformers. In this work, we prove the first unconditional lower bound against multilayer decoder-only transformers. For any constant L, we prove that any L-layer decoder-only transformer needs a polynomial model dimension $\left(n^{\Omega(1)}\right)$ to perform sequential composition of L functions over an input of n tokens. As a consequence, our results give: (1) the first depthwidth trade-off for multi-layer transformers, exhibiting that the L-step composition task is exponentially harder for L-layer models compared to $(L+1)$-layer ones; (2) an unconditional separation between encoder and decoder, exhibiting a hard task for decoders that can be solved by an exponentially shallower and smaller encoder; (3) a provable advantage of chain-of-thought, exhibiting a task that becomes exponentially easier when the model is allowed to produce an intermediate sequence of tokens before outputting the final answer. On the technical side, we propose the multi-party autoregressive communication model that abstracts the key aspects of a decoder-only Transformer. In particular, lower bounds within this communication model imply lower bounds against decoder-only transformers, independent of their implementation details. To prove lower bounds in this communication model, we also introduce a new proof technique that finds a certain indistinguishable decomposition of all possible inputs iteratively. We believe our new communication model and proof techniques will be helpful to understand the computational power of transformers further.
