title: Functional Requirements for Ultrafast Thomson Coil Actuator in Arc Commutation Hybrid DC Circuit Breaker
authors: Philipp Wienkamp, Willem Leterme
abstract: Hybrid DC circuit breakers featuring an ultrafast Thomson coil actuator are a key technology for enabling envisioned medium voltage DC grids. Particularly, the design of the actuator is considered challenging and has therefore been addressed in research for more than 20 years. These investigations have focused on actuators in conjunction with current injection type DC circuit breakers. However, these results cannot be transferred to arc commutation hybrid DC circuit breakers. For this breaker topology, the interaction between actuator parameters and breaker performance is not well understood, yet it is essential in order to define functional requirements for the actuator. This paper provides the first investigation of this interaction, by integrating an analysis of the commutation process into the design consideration. New insights regarding the contact separation time of the actuator and its implications to the overall circuit breaker performance are presented. Resulting feasible operating regions of the actuator are established—combining requirements to contact separation time and average velocity—and it is discussed how these are influenced by different fault current scenarios, grid voltages and relay times. Through a demonstration case, we exemplify that an optimal actuator design features a trade-off between velocity and contact separation time.

title: ATTE: An Innovative Ensemble Learning Method With Age-Group-Guided Fine-Tuning for Improving Personalized Blood Pressure Estimation
authors: Yuhui Cen, Hongbo Wang, Xing Zhu, Chunlong Miao, Jingjing Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Precision medicine requires cuffless blood pressure (BP) estimation technologies to achieve high accuracy levels suitable for healthcare monitoring. Recent advances, notably in personalized BP estimation methods utilizing transfer learning, have partially met these requirements. However, traditional personalized fine-tuning pipelines often ignore key physiological factors across age groups, thus limiting their effectiveness. This study identifies an important fine-tuning principle: target subjects benefit most when fine-tuned using a source model pretrained on an age-matched group. We introduce a novel two-level ensemble learning method, ATTE, which integrates multiple BP models for cuffless BP estimation based on pulse waves. It first performs feature-level ensemble learning (FEL) to combine age-group-specific fine-tuned models and enrich representations, then applies an optimized Bayesian model averaging (BMA) method that adaptively weights model outputs to boost accuracy and reduce model-selection uncertainty. Using only 50 transfer samples, ATTE improved systolic and diastolic BP estimation accuracy by 6.55% and 5.58% on a public dataset, compared to the traditional fine-tuning paradigm. It also achieved improvements of 5.10% and 8.30% on a self-collected dataset, which has been preliminarily validated in an elderly care scenario. Ablation and interpretability analyses validated the age-matched fine-tuning principle, the effectiveness of ATTE, and its model-agnostic generalizability. This work represents a pioneering step in optimizing personalized BP estimation and underscores its significant potential for real-world healthcare applications.

title: FogZoneSim: A Zone-Based Simulator for Resource Management in Large-Scale IoT-Fog Networks
authors: Alireza Khorsandi, Kosar Bakhshi, Bardia Safaei, Ali Mohammad Afshin Hemmatyar
abstract: While cloud computing offers a more scalable and resource-rich alternative against localized edge and IoT device data processes, it falls short in latency-sensitive, safety-critical applications due to delays caused by geographical distance. In domains like healthcare, where real-time analysis of patient vitals and emergency alerts is essential, and in VANETs, where vehicles must instantly exchange data for collision avoidance and traffic safety, such delays can have serious consequences. To address these limitations, fog computing architectures are increasingly adopted to enable proximate, low-latency data processing, ensuring timely and reliable responses in both healthcare and intelligent transportation systems. However, adopting fog computing introduces additional complexities related to task offloading, task scheduling, resource management, heterogeneity, and scalability. While these scientific fields of study have gained significant attention in the past few years, the existing widely used simulation tools, e.g., FogWorkflowSim, cannot effectively address critical issues such as supporting large-scale IoT networks, handling environment partitioning for parallel execution, and managing diverse resource management policies. Furthermore, since they are written in Java, they do not support many of the existing Python-based Machine Learning (ML) libraries, which are significantly attractive to many researchers. To address these limitations, this paper introduces FogZoneSim, an advanced modular fog computing simulator specifically designed to manage large-scale IoT environments. FogZoneSim effectively simulates scalable IoT ecosystems by clearly modeling IoT resources, brokers, and the infrastructure, supporting dependent workflows, providing customizable policies, partitioning environments, and scaling across numerous IoT devices. Also, its seamless integration with ML algorithms through Python libraries is another strong point. According to an extensive set of simulations, FogZoneSim has demonstrated its ability to significantly enhance researchers’ capabilities in analyzing and optimizing resource management strategies, energy efficiency, execution time, and overall system performance.

title: Large Language Model-Empowered Resource Allocation in Intent-Driven Wireless Networks
authors: Haofeng Sun, Hui Tian, Jingheng Zheng, Wanli Ni, Qimei Cui, Dusit Niyato, Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Although large language models (LLMs) have the potential to automate resource allocation in wireless networks, generating high-precision allocation schemes remains non-trivial for cloud-based LLMs due to their inability of accurate numerical processes. The heavy re-training overhead of LLMs for handling the dynamic features of wireless networks also poses a challenge. This paper presents a new LLM-empowered framework for intent-driven wireless resource allocation. The framework features a dual-expert LLM architecture, consisting of an instruction expert for generating resource allocation instructions and a policy expert for obtaining numerically-precise policies. Both experts encompass lightweight adapters and collaborate with the locally deployed LLM for resource allocation. Decoupling the generation of instruction and policy benefits efficient adaptation and generalization under diverse task requests and dynamic network states. We further propose a new two-stage fine-tuning protocol to enhance the adaptability of LLM-empowered resource allocation through distillation and reinforcement. Experiments on two major application cases demonstrate the superior adaptability and generalization abilities of the proposed LLM-empowered resource allocation framework with two-stage fine-tuning, compared to existing schemes.

title: Real-Time and Noninvasive Monitoring of Transient Current for Printed Circuit Module Diagnosis
authors: Xueming Pang, Yongyi Tan, Qifeng Huang, Shasha Li, Chengyang Luo, Yishan Xiao, Wenxiao Fang
abstract: Noninvasive monitoring of transient currents is valuable for the diagnosis of industrial electronics. However, traditional noninvasive current probes fail to provide real-time transient waveform monitoring on printed traces. In this article, an integrated current probe is proposed, with well-designed passive sensing part and active integrator circuit. The integrated current probe offers a typical transfer impedance of 0.1637 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\Omega}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> in a 3-dB bandwidth spanning from 215 kHz to 720 MHz. Square-wave current (up to 50 MHz) and ISO 7637-2 Pulse 3A and 3B are selected to validate the real-time monitoring capability of the probe on the current along printed trace, with the error down to 1.62% compared with direct measurement. Finally, the probe is applied to a practical automotive protection circuit module, showing the successful noninvasive current monitoring with a low error of 2.97% compared with a commercial probe. The proposed probe can be a powerful tool for real-time and noninvasive current diagnosis on printed circuit modules.

title: Can We Automatically Label Expressive Robot Arm Motion Qualities? Open Dataset and Machine Learning Results
authors: Results Nnamdi Nwagwu, Damien Pearl, Naomi T. Fitter
abstract: Robot motion impacts onlooker perception of robots' social and functional goals, whether intentionally or unintentionally. Neighboring fields such as dance can help roboticists understand the impacts of motion using tools like the Laban efforts, one of the primary modes of annotating and interpreting motion expressivity, but many past efforts at the intersection of robotics and Laban movement analysis feature unscalable hand-designed motions or offer limited information about factors that influence each individual Laban effort. We sought to begin addressing these gaps by collecting, analyzing, and open-sourcing an expressive motion dataset comprising robot arm motion demonstrations (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N = 30$</tex-math></inline-formula> demonstrators, with 219 total viable demonstrations) that span the Laban effort axes. We demonstrate an 82.0-92.3% accuracy for expressive motion label classification (ranging slightly across expressive axes, approaches with vs. without feature reduction and approaches with sequential data). We propose that the most informative features may guide future methods for automatically generating expressive motion. Individuals with interest in robot expressive motion can benefit from the dataset itself, as well as the machine learning results.

title: A Novel Approach to Identification and Detection of Power Theft in a Real-Time Power System Network for Sustainable Development of Power Grid
authors: Suparna Pal, Alok Kumar Shrivastav, Maitrayee Chakrabarty, Sudipta Banerjee, Himadri Sekhar Das, Heranmoy Maity
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: A Novel Approach to Identification and Detection of Power Theft in a Real-time Power System Network for Health Monitoring for Sustainable Development of Power Grid is an innovative solution for modern power systems, including the detection of power theft, real-time monitoring, and the broader goal of maintaining a sustainable power grid. If grid power is balanced, only all the network sensors work correctly to control health care instruments correctly, and the leading grid network operates in balanced conditions. Power system operation and control are always maintained and balanced in the distribution network. Still, an uncertain load connection (Power Theft) makes the system unbalanced in every aspect, affecting the voltage magnitude and creating deviations in all parameters. So, power system health monitoring is essential for detecting every parameter and taking corrective actions, which is the aim of our research. Here, we are taking two areas (Kalyani & Durgapur and Asansol of W.B.S.E.B) of West Bengal, which is a hub of the healthcare center of their district. First, we test normal loads with simulation and analysis of all the parameters essential to power stability analysis. After that, the same model is tested with additional uncertain loads and gives a comparative study of parameters, which will help determine corrective measurement actions and balance the system. Power theft is a vital issue to the redundant progress of the power system. The main aim of the power system is to supply power to the distribution section uninterruptedly, reliably, and with a quality supply.

title: Classifying Segments to Be Translated or Transliterated
authors: Aditya Shah, Atharva Date, Maheshwar Bhosale, Samarth Mali, G. V. Kale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This paper aims to categorize text segments to translate or transliterate using a hybrid NLP technique. It uses the two-layer structure with a Named Entity Recognition (NER) model that identifies potential transliteration fragments initially and, subsequently, a Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging model to perform secondary validation. After extensive experimentation, RoBERTa was opted for NER based on its higher inference accuracy, whereas NLTK was utilized for POS tagging in balancing efficiency with approximate accuracy. This layered approach enhances precision in distinguishing segments requiring transliteration, improving multilingual text processing. A key problem while undertaking this task was limited training data specifically related to domains. To solve this, a custom LLMbased synthetic data generation pipeline was created that uses an Agentic-AI approach, adaptive model swapping, and hyperparameter tuning to enhance diversity and reduce redundancy in generated text. This process allowed for the production of a high-quality dataset to train models with, guaranteeing strong performance at segment classification.

title: Driving the Core Frontend with LiteBTB
authors: Roman K. Brunner, Rakesh Kumar
abstract: Branch target buffer (BTB) is a central component of high performance core front-ends as it not only steers instruction fetch by uncovering upcoming control flow but also enables highly effective fetch-directed instruction prefetching. However, the massive instruction footprints of modern server applications far exceed the capacities of moderately sized BTBs, resulting in frequent misses that inevitably hurt performance. While commercial CPUs deploy large BTBs to mitigate this problem, they incur high storage and area overheads. Prior efforts to reduce BTB storage have primarily targeted branch targets, which has proven highly effective — so much that the tag storage now dominates the BTB storage budget. We make a key observation that BTBs exhibit a large degree of tag redundancy, i.e. only a small fraction of entries contain unique tags, and this fraction falls sharply as BTB capacity grows. Leveraging this insight, we propose LiteBTB, which employs a dedicated hardware structure to store unique tags only once and replaces per-entry tags in BTB with compact tag pointers. To avoid latency overheads, LiteBTB accesses the tag storage and BTB in parallel. Our evaluation shows that LiteBTB reduces storage by up to 13.1% compared to the state-of-the-art BTB design, called BTB-X, while maintaining equivalent performance. Alternatively, with the same storage budget, LiteBTB accommodates up to 1.125× more branches, yielding up to 2.7% performance improvement.

title: Design and Implementation of an Autonomous Navigation Robot Using Ros and a Multi-Sensor Platform for Educational Applications
authors: Duong Dinh Tu, Ho Sy Phuong, Le Van Chuong, Dinh Van Nam, Phan Van Du, Le Ngoc Phuoc
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an autonomous navigation robot using the Robot Operating System and a cost-effective multi-sensor platform. The robot has been developed with legacy, low-cost sensors, including an RPLiDAR C1 and a Kinect for Xbox 360 depth camera, chosen for their affordability and compatibility with the ROS ecosystem. It is also readily available in our laboratory. We detail the hardware configuration and the ROS 1-based software architecture that enable simultaneous localization, mapping, and autonomous navigation in both 2D and 3D environments. The performance of the proposed system is evaluated through simulation in the Gazebo environment and real-world experiments. Results demonstrate that the robot can operate effectively, generating accurate maps and following planned trajectories. In ten repeated real-world trials, the maximum deviation in the generated 2 D maps was measured at 1.06 % in length and 1.75 % in width. The proposed robot offers significant potential for educational and research applications in mobile robotics due to its affordability, flexibility, and reproducibility.

title: Unsupervised Machine Learning for Climate Surveillance: Comparative Temperature Anomaly Detection in Northwestern Bangladesh
authors: Hasan Ahamed Alif, Md. Jisan Mashrafi, Urmi Haldar, Sebagat Selim, Ahsan Ullah, Md Mohibur Rahman
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Temperature anomalies are becoming more frequent and severe as climate change accelerates, endangering the stability of ecosystems and the economy, particularly in climate-sensitive regions such as northwest Bangladesh. With the aid of two cutting-edge unsupervised deep learning models-LSTM Variational Autoencoder (LSTM-VAE) and Anomaly Transformer-the proposed article aims to provide a state-of-the-art method for the identification and description of such temperature variations. We show how these models may be used to identify both rapid and slow climatic changes and provide fresh perspectives on the evolving nature of the global warming process by analyzing the temperature data gathered by Ishwardi and Rajshahi (19802024). Long-term and structural changes in temperature trends are best detected by the Anomaly Transformer, whereas high-intensity, impulsive, and short-term temperature spikes are best detected by the LSTM-VAE. Our findings show that, whereas temperatures in Rajshahi have fluctuated rapidly, those in Ishwardi have changed slowly, highlighting the growing need to address climate vulnerabilities. The research offers a robust multi-model framework for early warning systems and risk assessments, while also enhancing our understanding of climate change in the regions. This will enable policymakers and environmental planners to develop more knowledge-driven and proactive climate resilience agendas with the aid of such advanced models. The importance of forming new strategies for the uncertain and ever-changing future of the climate is highlighted in this essay.

title: Measuring AI Integration as a General Purpose Technology with Patent-Based Analysis
authors: Hyun-Jin Shim, Jeong-Dong Lee, Chulwoo Baek, Youwei He
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This study proposes a patent-based framework to measure the structural integration of artificial intelligence (AI) as a General Purpose Technology (GPT). Using global patent data from 1980 to 2020, we classify AI-related patents into Core AI and applied AI categories based on CPC codes and keyword extraction. The analysis reveals increasing cross-sectoral diffusion of AI, with notable variation across countries. This approach captures the depth and breadth of AI’s technological embedding, offering a complementary tool to existing AI indices for assessing national AI capabilities.

title: Facial Recognition to Multi-Omics: Next-Generation Diagnostic Strategies for Rare Genetic Disorders
authors: Anchal Negi, Jai Gopal Sharma
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Undiagnosed rare genetic disorders affecting millions of people around the world are known to exhibit complex phenotypes and diverse genotypes, making them extremely difficult to diagnose. This paper analyses the potential impact of implementing AI-driven facial recognition in conjunction with multi-omics approaches to mitigate these problems. Deep learning technologies such as Face2Gene® and VGGFace2 allow for faster analysis of dysmorphic features with stratified analysis of specific triaged syndromes, which decreases diagnostic time by 50 %. When combined with whole-genome sequencing and functional multi-omics validation, including RNA sequencing resolving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 2}-\text{3 6 \%}$</tex> of uncertain variants improving diagnostic accuracy. Clinical case studies reveal how this combination elucidates intricate mechanisms such as deep intronic MECP2 retrotransposons in atypical Rett syndrome, making precision treatments possible for 60 % of diagnosed patients. However, ethnocentric biases in training datasets and data privacy issues do arise, which require an adequate middle ground and fortified frameworks. New approaches, such as federated learning models and portable sequencers, can ensure global equity. Addressing computational phenotyping alongside multi-layered molecular approaches constructs a new frontier in personalized healthcare.

title: Using Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Fault Prediction and Maintenance on the Factory Floor
authors: Adhir Soechit, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: In the rapidly evolving landscape of Industry 4.0, predictive maintenance is crucial for maximizing operational uptime and efficiency. Traditional predictive maintenance approaches, often reliant on static models, face challenges in addressing novel anomalies and providing contextually rich, actionable insights. An innovative Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system is proposed, leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) for real-time anomaly detection and predictive maintenance. The system dynamically integrates machine sensor data with repair manual documentation and worker insights to generate highly relevant and interpretable diagnostic maintenance recommendations which are passed along in real-time to relevant personnel. The methodology aims to demonstrate the RAG system’s ability to enhance decision-making, optimize industrial operations and mitigate equipment failures in complex manufacturing environments.

title: Transfer Learning and Domain Adaptation Techniques in 3D Cultural Heritage Semantic Segmentation: A Systematic Review
authors: Ouail Choukhairi, Mouad Choukhairi, Ali Choukri, Youssef Fakhri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This systematic review offers an in-depth and critical examination of transfer learning and domain adaptation strategies as applied to the semantic segmentation of 3D cultural heritage data. The inherent complexity, variability, and heterogeneity of 3D heritage datasets often hinder the effectiveness of conventional segmentation models in terms of precision and generalization. To address these limitations, transfer learning and domain adaptation have gained prominence by enabling the reuse of knowledge from pre-trained models and mitigating domain shifts between source and target data. This review systematically categorizes and evaluates existing methodologies, with a particular emphasis on their application within the domain of cultural heritage. It encompasses a broad spectrum of topics, including 3D data acquisition techniques, the design and refinement of deep learning architectures, and the metrics employed for performance evaluation. Furthermore, the review discusses persistent challenges such as limited labeled data, variability in lighting conditions, material textures, and geometric scales. By integrating recent advances and synthesizing key contributions across the literature, this work aims to provide a foundational reference for researchers and practitioners seeking to improve the semantic segmentation of 3D cultural heritage objects and environments.

title: Dual Authentication Arduino-Based Door Lock System with Light Detection and Keypad Authentication
authors: Mohan B, Mahalakshmi S, Vigneshwaran P, CH CH V B Vasanth, J Relin Francis Raj, Sundaravadivel P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: This system presents the design and implementation of a password-based door lock system integrated with LED light control for enhanced security. The proposed system allows password entry only when the LED is activated, where the LED's state is controlled by a manually operated switch. The primary components include an Arduino microcontroller, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 2$</tex> LCD, a keypad, an LED, a buzzer, and a servo motor. The LED, activated via the switch, signals the readiness for password input. If the LED is off, the system denies access and triggers an audible alert using the buzzer. Users enter the password through the keypad, and upon verification, the system unlocks the door by actuating the servo motor. Incorrect password entries or attempts to access the system when the LED is off also activate the buzzer. The LCD provides real-time feedback, displaying statuses such as “Enter Password,” “Access Granted,” and “Incorrect Password.” By combining embedded systems with fundamental security principles, this project demonstrates a cost-effective and efficient approach to access control. The integration of the switch-controlled LED mechanism ensures the password entry process is only enabled when necessary, enhancing both security and user control.

title: Optimizing Urban Public Transportation Through AI-Based Bus Tracking and QR Code Ticketing
authors: Rithik A, Prabhu Shankar B, Govindharaj I, Dinesh Kumar K, Vadhana Kumar M, David R
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Chennai urban transport systems in India are still tackling some issues, including poor ticketing procedures, the absence of real-time commuter information, and constant delays. Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC), which manages a fleet of 729 buses, mostly bases its operations on paper-based ticketing, which, when added to unpredictable traffic conditions and poor digital infrastructure, translates into decreased efficiency of operations and customer dissatisfaction. The given paper introduces Sprint Bus, a project to modernize the services of the MTC in terms of public buses using high technology and digital solutions. The suggested system includes digital e-ticketing, use of a QR code to validate the trip, AI-based optimization of routes, and real-time tracking of buses. One of the interesting details is offline QR validation ability; this is aimed at working well in poorly connected spaces. In the effort of establishing the needs of commuters and their readiness to adopt the new technologies, a survey was carried out online and offline, and it was noted that commuters were interested in these technologies as cashless ticketing, shorter waiting times, and proper arrival times. The solution was constructed utilizing a methodical four-phase way of building a prototype. The first results reveal great potential to enhance the passenger convenience, the clarity of the operations, and portability in the scope of urban transport networks. The present framework proves that the application of emerging technologies has the potential to solve the time-old problems of inefficiency in public transportation, as well as the general commuter experience present in the increasingly crowded metropolitan cities.

title: Diversity-Preserved Constrained Multi-Objective Power Flow Optimization Using a Hybrid Improved MOABC-NSGA-II Metaheuristic Algorithm
authors: Abhishek Bajirao Katkar, Himmat Tukaram Jadhav
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources, variability in demand, and operational uncertainties have complicated the Multi-Objective Optimal Power Flow (MOOPF) problem, necessitating more robust and adaptive optimization strategies. This study presents a new hybrid metaheuristic framework that integrates an Improved Multi-Objective Artificial Bee Colony (IMOABC) algorithm with the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II). The IMOABC component, augmented by a Spherical Search (SS) mechanism, enhances global exploration and solution diversity. Concurrently, a Gradient Repair Method (GRM), formulated using the LevenbergMarquardt scheme with Broyden updates, reinstates the feasibility of infeasible solutions. An <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\epsilon$</tex>-constraint strategy is utilized for efficient constraint management. An Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) is employed as a post-Pareto analysis tool to enhance decision-making by identifying the Best Compromise Solution (BCS). The proposed hybrid underwent thorough testing on the IEEE 57-bus system, addressing multiple conflicting objectives such as the minimization of fuel costs, active power losses, and emissions. The comparative results indicate that the framework consistently exceeds both conventional and advanced algorithms regarding convergence speed, diversity preservation, and constraint satisfaction. The findings highlight the effectiveness, resilience, and scalability of the proposed IMOABC-NSGA-II framework as a decision-support tool for contemporary sustainable power system operation.

title: Screening and Identification of Potent Antimicrobial Compounds from the Rhizosphere
authors: Jyoti Srivastava, Nawneet Kumar Kurrey, Shankar Khade, Shweta Ukey, Muthu Sankar Aathi, Mohammed Shabab
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The rapid emergence of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has become one of the most pressing public health concerns of the 21st century, leading to a significant increase in treatment failures and mortality rates. Fungal infections pose a significant challenge to human health, agriculture, and food security. The emergence of antimicrobial resistance has exacerbated the problem, limiting the efficacy of currently available treatments. Natural sources, including medicinal plants, endophytic fungi, soil microorganisms, and marine organisms, offer promising avenues for discovering bioactive compounds with potent antimicrobial properties. This study aims to screen the microorganisms from the various natural sources like soils, waters from various locations. The screening has resulted in the successful isolation of antimicrobial compound-producing bacteria from rhizosphere of mint, which was identified as Bacillus velezensis by 16s RNA sequencing at NCIM, Pune. It was observed that Bacillus velezensis produces an antifungal compound by submerged fermentations (SMF), which shows activity against Candida albicans by agar-plate assay method and results in a zone of clearance of about 2.9 cm. The production medium will be further optimized by Taguchi DOE methodology, aiming to increase further the production of the extracellular antifungal compound. Further, the optimized medium will be validated by scaling up in the fermenter under a set of optimized physico-chemical environments. The purification of extracellular compound will involve the solvent-solvent extraction, column chromatography, upon further which the compound will be characterized to predict the structure by NMR and Mass spectrometry. Furthermore, the study will investigate the mechanism of action of these compounds and assess their potential for therapeutic applications in combating the fungal infections. The anticipated outcomes include the identification of novel antifungal compounds, improved understanding of their mechanisms, and the development of sustainable alternatives to synthetic antifungal agents. By contributing to drug discovery and agricultural disease management, this research aligns with global efforts to combat antifungal resistance and promote environmental sustainability.

title: LLMs’ Hallucination Mitigation Mechanism Used for Task Planning for NAO Humanoid Robot
authors: Shadi Abpeikar, Matt Garratt, Kathryn Kasmarik, Sreenatha Anavatti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid growth and development of Large Language Models (LLMs) have made them suitable for solving a wide range of problems, including those in robotics. However, despite their popularity and capabilities, LLMs face critical challenges that undermine trust in their efficiency and accuracy. One of the most significant challenges is hallucination, which stems from their strong generalisation abilities. This issue results in LLMs generating responses that lack evidence of correctness in reality.This paper analyses hallucinations in responses generated for robotic task planning. The NAO humanoid robot is selected as the platform for task planning experiments, and GPT-3.5, Llama 3.1, Gemma 3, and CodeX are used as the LLMs for response generation. The generated responses include YAML representations and Python 2 code. We introduce specific metrics to measure hallucinations in the context of robotic task planning.The core objective of this paper is to investigate how prompt engineering can mitigate hallucinations using these metrics. Experimental results demonstrate that incorporating prompt engineering—by providing additional context and information to the LLMs—reduces the occurrence of hallucinations in task planning responses.

title: Wayland Mechanism and Research on Migration to Non-Linux Architecture Operating System
authors: Xiangying Kong, Xinran Kong, Chuntian Hu, Dingqian Shen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Signal Processing (ICGSP)
abstract: As the core component of the operating system, the graphic system determines the degree of performance of the hardware function, the difficulty of the graphic application software design, and the friendliness of the information interaction between the device and the operator. In the past 30 years, with the rapid development and wide application of IT technology, embedded equipment including vehicle electronics, weapons and equipment have more and more requirements for human-computer interaction, embedded graphics system has become one of the most important components of embedded basic software stack. Wayland, as a new graphics protocol to replace X, has gradually become the mainstream of Linux graphics system, and some non-Linux architecture operating systems have also put forward demands for Wayland. This paper analyzes the mechanism of Wayland protocol, takes Weston as an example, discusses the migration work to non-Linux architecture operating system, and gives the transplantation process on VxWorks operating system.

title: Multiple UAV Allocation and Scheduling for Mine Dispensing Missions
authors: Lovesh Goyal, Joel Geroge M
abstract: This paper addresses a mine dispensing problem, wherein multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) transport mines from a base to a set of desired target locations. Each UAV operates on a shuttle basis, returning to the base after each delivery to collect the next mine. The primary objective is to minimize the total mission time. Since this problem involves allocation, which is NP-hard, we propose a heuristic algorithm, Farther Target First (FTF), to efficiently generate feasible solutions. To benchmark the quality of the heuristic solutions, we also formulate the problem as a binary integer program and solve it using standard optimization tools. Further to allocation, we introduce a scheduling algorithm to regulate safe UAV movements during mine dispensing. The algorithm adopts an Air Traffic Control-like approach, dividing the battlefield into sectors and altitude layers or corridors. The scheduling algorithm ensures that no two UAVs occupy the same altitude corridor within the same sector concurrently. Together with the FTF allocation heuristic, this yields a two-stage solution, where we ‘first allocate and then schedule’. Finally, we give an integrated allocation and scheduling algorithm to solve the mine dispensing problem. Comprehensive simulations demonstrate that the integrated approach consistently outperforms the two-stage method across various mission scenarios.

title: Event-Triggering Scheme in Adaptive Super-Twisting Controller Design
authors: Saikat Mondal, Mohamed Assaad Hamida, Franck Plestan
abstract: The primary concern of this research work is to design an adaptive super-twisting controller (ASTC) for uncertain nonlinear systems under resource-constrained scenario with a simplification in gain-tuning parameters. To address the resource-constrained issue, we introduce an event-triggering mechanism in the closed-loop setup, which transmits the output (sliding variable) information to the controller and then to actuator at irregular sampling intervals only. Here, the triggering rule is constructed with fewer triggering parameters compared to the existing event-based ASTC design approaches ( [1]–[3]). Also, we have shown that the proposed approach reduces the practical sliding motion band size. Furthermore, the gain adaptation law is constructed here based on the sampled output information to determine the dynamic gain, which addresses the over-estimation problem in designing the control gain for unknown disturbance bound. Finally, an academic example is simulated to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, and the comparison study is also included with the periodic sampling strategy.

title: Reinforcement Learning-based Control of a Full-body Biomechanical Model with Exoskeletons while Tracking Motion Capture Data
authors: Rugved Upaddhye, Vighnesh Vatsal, Kaushik Das
abstract: This paper presents a reinforcement learning-based control method for a human biomechanical system with exoskeletons that can be used in applications such as musculoskeletal rehabilitation, safety and ergonomics analysis, and industrial task simulation. We apply Reinforcement Learning (RL) to control a full-body biomechanical model consisting of two arms, two legs and a torso with a pivoted pelvis. It consists of a total of 212 muscles and 220 tendons. We also apply this method to concurrently control four motor-actuated exoskeletons located at the elbows and knees. These components collectively control 107 joints. As this is a highly overactuated system, uncorrelated exploration strategies for RL are unable to converge to controllers with acceptable tracking performance in a computationally efficient manner. To mitigate this, we apply Differential Extrinsic Plasticity for generating correlated noise during RL exploration. We incorporate this RL-based control method into a motion capture pipeline, allowing real-time tracking of human body movements during industrial and daily activities at a granular musculoskeletal level, going beyond kinematic tracking typical for motion capture studies. We evaluate the position tracking errors for motion capture data in conditions with and without the exoskeletons attached, and compare the corresponding activations in major muscles.

title: Retraction Notice: Smart Monitoring Instrumentation Design for Poultry Farmhouse
authors: G. Dency Flora, R. Sandhiya, P. Santhiya, G. Sindhu, K.G Sribavathaarani, U. Ramani
publish: 2022 7th International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: Poultry farms in India are mostly monitored and controlled manually. The most important and basic factors that need to be monitored and controlled in poultry farms are hotness, moisture, air value point, illumination, freshening, door magnetic sensor, light-dependent resistor, egg count, and food feeding. The point is to work on the creation of solid chickens and decrease the death pace of chickens to further develop efficiency via computerizing the course of observed and control utilizing the Internet of Things (IoT). When the above parameters exceed the edge esteems, the cycles are started naturally that can assist with decreasing the death pace of chickens on the ranch. The framework likewise sends a programmed ready warning to the client through message, E-mail, and online message App. A Web point of interaction is likewise made to screen and show these boundaries.

title: Retraction Notice: Early Stage Ischemic Stroke Prediction using Convolution Neural Network
authors: Dheeraj Gaddam, Chandra Mouli, Abhinav Borad
publish: 2022 7th International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: Stroke is the second leading cause of death worldwide, and it continues to be a major health issue for both people and public health systems. Stroke is a dangerous condition. When the blood flow to a portion of human brain is interrupted, cerebrum tissue is deprived of oxygen and nutrients, it results in a condition called stroke. Nevertheless, the brain cells begin to die in a matter of minutes. This research intends to infer a model condition for developing a stroke pre-analysis algorithm with the possibly modifiable risk factors. Ischemic embolic and haemorrhagic strokes represent the bulk of strokes. Consequently, the objective of the proposed research work is to apply the standards of Convolution Neural Network (CNN) over the huge existing datasets to predict the most likely life threatening risks that might follow the primary occurrence. Further the refinement in these algorithms could give immense utility in clinical settings and stroke treatment and furthermore provide more knowledge on the new advancements and utilization of CNN in neuroimaging focuses on analyzing the intense ischemic stroke and apply Le-Net CNN model to process the patient profile data.

title: DATRN: Adaptive Trajectory Learning from Demonstrations for Robotic Manipulation
authors: Archit Sharma, John Rebeiro, Dharmendra Sharma, Peeyush Thakur, Narendra Kumar Dhar, Laxmidhar Behera
abstract: Trajectory generation forms a crucial bridge between high-level decision-making and low-level control in robotics, enabling precise, repeatable, and adaptive motion for complex tasks across domains such as medical robotics and industrial automation. Traditional methods, such as dynamic movement primitives (DMP), effectively generate robot trajectories but require careful hyperparameter tuning for optimal performance. While this helps to some extent, the combined approach still struggles with complex, non-linear motion patterns, takes a lot of time to train, and often becomes unstable during long tasks. To address these challenges, a dynamic adaptive trajectory radial network (DATRN) is proposed for real-time trajectory generation in robotic manipulation tasks. This approach leverages radial basis function neural networks (RBFN). Our experiments on four representative tasks, pick & place, stacking, lateral pushing, and surface wiping, demonstrate that DATRN achieves higher reduction in training time, higher trajectory fitting accuracy, and better stabilization on long-horizon trajectories.

title: The 7Ds of Energy Transition in Smart Cities: A Framework for Empowering Energy Citizens
authors: Mahdi Nozarian, Ehsan Shahi, Paniz MohsenNia, Saeed Kafshdouzzadeh, Alireza Fereidunian, Fariba Mousavi
abstract: Confronting global environmental challenges, the urban energy landscape is undergoing a crucial transition toward sustainable models. This research employs a Complex Adaptive System of Systems (CASoS) approach grounded in Multi-Carrier Energy Systems (MCES) to examine the realization of seven fundamental principles in this energy transition, with the ultimate objective of enhancing smart grid efficiency in a bottom-up decentralized and people-centric approach. The investigation centers on seven interconnected pillars, each beginning with the letter D, that collectively drive this transformation: Decarbonization of energy sources, Digitalization of infrastructure, Decentralization of generation, Diversification of resources, Demand-side management strategies, accommodation of Dynamicity in energy flows, Democratization of energy systems. Together, these principles form a comprehensive framework for reimagining how cities can achieve a sustainable energy future through integrated smart grid solutions.

title: Generalized Distribution Aggregation Protocol for Federated Statistical Heterogeneity
authors: Mingwei Xu, Xiaofeng Cao, Ivor W. Tsang, James T. Kwok, Heng Tao Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Federated heterogeneity refers to the disparities in data distributions, model architectures, and communication capabilities across various devices or institutional entities. In real-world scenarios, statistical heterogeneity can often lead to ineffective aggregation, severely impacting generalization performance and resulting in biased or unstable model weights. Theoretically, distributional robustness analysis indicates that the generalization performance of a learning model can be bounded with respect to any heterogeneity distribution. This insight motivates us to reconsider the aggregation strategy in federated statistical heterogeneity scenarios, and we thus propose a new weighting aggregation protocol that considers the generalization bound disagreement of each local model. Specifically, we estimate the upper and lower bounds of the second-order origin moment of the shifted distribution for the current local model, and using these bound disagreements as the aggregation proportions for weights in each communication round. Our experiments demonstrate that this proposed aggregation protocol significantly improves the performance of several representative Federated Learning algorithms on benchmark datasets.

title: Retraction Notice: A Survey On Smart Electric Meter Using IOT
authors: M. Dhivya, K. Valarmathi

His obligation is to note down the reading in units, influencing passage in EB to card and EB office. Blunders like additional bill sum or invalid notice from power office are normal issue. title: Dual-Pass Autoencoder: Tackling Temporal Drift in Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Mohammadhossein Ghahramani, MengChu Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Detecting anomalies in multivariate time series remains difficult when data distributions shift over time. Existing approaches often struggle to remain effective under such temporal drift. We present a Dual-Pass Autoencoder, a new architecture that directly addresses this issue by learning two complementary perspectives of the data: one from the raw sequence and another from its temporal context. These dual representations are fused through a drift-adaptation mechanism, enabling the model to distinguish true anomalies from natural distributional changes. Unlike conventional autoencoder-based methods, our design explicitly incorporates temporal self-attention and adaptive latent fusion, resulting in drift-aware embeddings that are both expressive and robust. The reconstructed feature vectors, supported by an auxiliary classifier, provide strong discriminative capacity for anomaly detection. Comprehensive experiments on diverse real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms leading baselines in both accuracy and robustness, establishing Dual-Pass Autoencoder as an effective solution for anomaly detection in evolving temporal environments.

title: Integration of Net Metering with Demand Response for Load Balancing in Microgrids: A Case Study
authors: Amir Hadifar, Farzad Mohammadzadeh Shahir, Majid Majidi, Touhid Poursheykh Aliasghari
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources (RES) in modern power systems necessitates effective strategies for maintaining energy balance and grid stability. This study investigates the integration of net metering with demand response (DR) as a solution for load balancing in microgrids. A case study is conducted for a commercial facility in Pavia, Italy, evaluating the technical and economic feasibility of a photovoltaic (PV) system utilizing net metering and DR. The HOMER software is used to simulate energy flows, considering solar radiation, load demand, and financial parameters. The results indicate that 67.7% of the facility's energy demand is met through on-site PV generation, with 32.9% of excess energy exported to the grid. Net metering significantly reduces reliance on the grid, enhancing energy self-sufficiency and cost-effectiveness. Additionally, demand response strategies contribute to peak demand reduction and grid stability. The findings highlight the economic viability of integrating net metering and demand response, emphasizing their role in optimizing microgrid operations. Moreover, the study demonstrates that a 98% power exchange balance between the grid and the consumer is achieved, ensuring an efficient utilization of energy and further reinforcing the benefits of net metering in microgrid management.

title: A Neural Network Model Optimized by a Joint Evolutionary Algorithm for Water Body Recognition
authors: Peiyang Wei, Ji Zhang, Zhibin Li, Tinghui Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: With the rapid development of remote sensing technology, satellite remote sensing imagery has become an indispensable foundational data support for fields such as environmental monitoring, disaster early warning, resource management, and urban planning. Among them, water body information extraction holds critical scientific value and application significance in dynamic flood monitoring, refined water resource management, wetland ecological protection, and climate change research. However, water body recognition from satellite remote sensing imagery currently faces challenges due to the complexity of surface cover and the diversity of ground object spectra, which hinder effective characterization of the water body feature space. Differences in imaging conditions introduce noise that significantly reduces recognition accuracy. Traditional methods based on spectral thresholds or shallow machine learning struggle to achieve synergistic optimization of accuracy, efficiency, and generalization ability when processing high-resolution multi/hyperspectral data. To address these issues, this study constructs a U-Net deep learning framework integrated with multiple evolutionary algorithms. Through a hybrid search strategy combining multiple evolutionary computation algorithms, it achieves efficient optimization of network hyperparameter combinations, significantly improving the model's identification accuracy and anti-interference robustness for water body boundaries in complex scenarios. Furthermore, a Channel-Spatial Dual Attention Mechanism is embedded in the U-Net encoder-decoder structure. By adaptively learning feature weights in spectral and spatial dimensions, it effectively suppresses the spectral confusion effects of non-water ground objects and enhances the feature distinguishability between water bodies and background objects. Experiments using multi-source satellite datasets and evaluation metrics are conducted. Experiment Results show that the proposed model achieved significant advantages in key metrices, demonstrating superior feature representation capability, generalization performance, and convergence efficiency.
