title: Path Planning for AGVs: Balancing Computational Efficiency and Optimality
authors: Ata Jahangir Moshayedi, Atanu Shuvam Roy, Zeashan Hameed Khan, Shuxin Yang, Abolfazl Razi, Mehran Emadi Andani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) play a crucial role in industrial automation, streamlining material handling and logistics operations. This paper investigates the performance of eleven classical pathfinding algorithms—including Dijkstra, Depth First Search (DFS), Floyd Warshall, Binary Search, and Prim’s MST on an Ackermann steered electric vehicle (EV) based AGV navigating six charging stations in a simulated urban environment. Algorithms are classified into By Station and By Edge , with implementations adapted to meet their specific routing requirements. AGV performance is evaluated using conventional metrics runtime, travel distance, cost, speed, and station visitation alongside a novel Energy Consumption Score (ECS) that balances operational efficiency with computational overhead. Results show that classical algorithms can efficiently handle static, predictable networks, though some prioritize cost over station coverage. ECS provides a unified framework to rank algorithm suitability. The obtained results shows, Based on the tested algorithms: Floyd Warshall achieved the best overall performance in terms of minimal cost and ECS. For maximizing station coverage, TSP and Prim’s MST were the most effective. Edge-based algorithms proved reliable for navigating predefined routes but were generally less efficient in terms of overall cost and energy consumption.Future work will explore heuristic and hybrid approaches, dynamic networks, multi AGV coordination, and energy aware routing for improved urban path planning.

title: Relevance-Aware Risk Assessment for Pedestrian-Vehicle Interaction
authors: Ali Dehghani, Lucila Patino Studencki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Safe autonomous navigation in pedestrian-rich environments demands more than collision avoidance—it requires the prioritization of pedestrian and other vulnerable traffic participants. In this paper, we present a real-time framework that enables vehicles to make decisions based not only on predicted Time-To-Collision (TTC), but also on the relevance of each pedestrian’s intention within a multi-hypothesis predictive model. The system builds upon a multi-pedestrian, multi-intention tracker that employs a Probability Hypothesis Density filter enhanced with a Generalized Potential Field Approach (PHD-GPFA) to estimate multiple future trajectories and intentions per pedestrian. Each trajectory hypothesis is associated with a belief weight that captures intention confidence. Unlike traditional risk assessment methods that rely solely on TTC, we propose a joint relevance metric that fuses TTC with belief-based intention likelihoods, enabling the vehicle to identify and respond to the most critical interactions in the scene. At every simulation timestep, vehicle speed is dynamically adjusted based on the most relevant pedestrian hypothesis. We evaluate the system in a SUMO-based simulation across multi-agent pedestrian scenarios, where it demonstrates proactive and context-sensitive responses to dynamic pedestrian behaviors. Our results highlight the advantages of integrating intention confidence into risk-aware planning.

title: Vehicle Sideslip Angle Estimation Using a Zonotopic Kalman Filter Under Modeling and Measurement Uncertainties
authors: Fernando Viadero-Monasterio, Vicenç Puig, Miguel Meléndez-Useros, Beatriz López Boada, María Jesús López Boada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: The vehicle sideslip angle is a critical factor in ensuring safe and stable vehicle operation; however, it cannot be measured directly and easily during normal driving. Conventional estimation methods frequently disregard model and measurement uncertainties, offering point estimates that lack a quantitative assessment of their reliability. In order to address these limitations, the present paper proposes a sideslip angle estimator based on a zonotopic Kalman filter. This approach provides both an estimate and a guaranteed bound that accounts for system uncertainties. The approach under consideration explicitly models and propagates measurement noise and parametric uncertainties, resulting in bounded, reliable estimates over time. The validation process is executed through the implementation of co-simulations, employing CarSim, a high-fidelity vehicle dynamics simulator, which is integrated with MATLAB. The findings indicate that the estimated zonotopes consistently envelop the ground truth sideslip angle across a range of driving scenarios, thereby demonstrating the robustness and reliability of the estimator.

title: Distributed Drive Trajectory Tracking Control Considering Large Pitch And Roll
authors: YunFei Zha, Rong Huang, Xun Huang, YiXuan Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Due to the benefit of separate torque management, distributed drive electric vehicles have great promise for vehicle dynamic control. However, the dynamic vertical load transfer brought on by large-angle pitch and roll motions on uneven roads is frequently too much for the current trajectory tracking controllers to handle, which lowers control performance. To address this issue, a hierarchical control approach is suggested in this work. Presenting an enhanced vertical load prediction model that specifically takes big pitch and roll angles into account is its primary contribution. The upper-level controller determines the front wheel angle for path tracking using model predictive control. In order to optimize torque distribution and improve stability, the lower-level controller uses a linear quadratic regulator to achieve differential steering control based on the estimated vertical load. The efficiency of the suggested approach is confirmed by the simulation results under the rapidly accelerated double-shifting line condition. The approach suggested in this research improves tracking accuracy and stability by reducing the maximum lateral deviation by 2.34% and the average yaw velocity deviation by 5.91% when compared to the conventional load transfer methods.

title: Design and Construction of a Micro Soft Colonoscope Robot
authors: Yuhang Yang, Xinyu Ouyang, Chen Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: This study presents a novel three-stage soft robotic colonoscope system based on rocket staging principles. The 30mm-diameter sleeve integrates a rigid resin inner shell with a super-elastic silicone outer shell (Shore hardness 0), employing pneumatic anchoring and embedded micro motors (4 per stage) with worm gear transmission. Compatible with standard 10mm colonoscopes, the system utilizes ESPNOW wireless protocol (DL-30/WiFi dual mode) for remote control (<10ms latency). Experimental verification demonstrates reliable motor (MZ/MT/MF instructions) and pneumatic (PC/PF/PT instructions) operation. The design addresses key limitations of traditional colonoscopy - patient discomfort, intestinal looping, and operator fatigue - through enhanced stability and reduced tissue stress, showing significant potential for anesthesia-free procedures. Main contributions include: (1) a staged actuation mechanism improving propulsion control, (2) commercial compatibility with safety-enhanced materials, (3) robust dual-mode communication, and (4) modular actuation for painless examinations.

title: Coding for Reliable Packet Delivery Via Multiple Wireless Bufferless Servers With Delay Constraints
authors: Jiajun Chen, Chi Wan Sung, Eric W. M. Wong, M. F. Wong
abstract: The emerging mission-critical applications such as automated driving and remote robotics require mobile wireless networks to provide low latency and high reliability. This paper focuses on the design of coded multipath transmission in wireless networks, where both queue state information and channel state information are considered to reduce delay and packet loss. The latency-sensitive premium traffic is mission-critical, and each traffic packet is required to reach the user via multiple edge servers before a tight deadline. To reduce the packet loss due to queue blocking or channel fading, we apply MDS coding to the multipath transmission at the cost of slightly increasing the communication overhead. For homogeneous systems, we derive the optimal code parameter under the assumption of independent traffic at multiple paths. For heterogeneous systems, we propose greedy and greedy+ algorithms for load allocation. Simulation results show that with traffic dependency at multiple paths our proposed greedy+ algorithm outperforms equal allocation in most cases.

title: Towards Refining Developer Questions using LLM-Based Named Entity Recognition for Developer Chatroom Conversations
authors: Pouya Fathollahzadeh, Mariam El Mezouar, Hao Li, Ying Zou, Ahmed E. Hassan
abstract: In software engineering chatrooms, communication is often hindered by imprecise questions that cannot be answered. Recognizing key entities (e.g., programming languages and libraries) and user intent (e.g., learning or requesting a review) can be essential for improving question clarity and facilitating better exchange. However, existing research using natural language processing techniques often overlooks these softwarespecific nuances. In this paper, we introduce SoftwarE-specific Named entity recognition, Intent detection, and Resolution classification (SENIR), a labelling approach that leverages a Large Language Model to annotate entities, intents, and resolution status in developer chatroom conversations. To offer quantitative guidance for improving question clarity and resolvability, we build a resolution prediction model that leverages SENIR’s entity and intent labels along with additional predictive features. We evaluate SENIR on the DISCO dataset using a subset of annotated chatroom dialogues. SENIR achieves an 86% F-score for entity recognition, a 71% F-score for intent detection, and an 89% F-score for resolution status classification. Furthermore, our resolution prediction model, tested with various sampling strategies (random undersampling and oversampling with SMOTE) and evaluation methods (5-fold cross-validation, 10-fold cross-validation, and bootstrapping), demonstrates AUC values ranging from 0.7 to 0.8. Key factors influencing resolution include positive sentiment and entities such as Programming Language and User Variable across multiple intents, while diagnostic entities (e.g., Error Name) are more relevant in error-related questions. Moreover, resolution rates vary significantly by intent: questions about API Usage and API Change achieve higher resolution rates, whereas Discrepancy and Review have lower resolution rates. A Chi-Square analysis confirms the statistical significance of these differences.

title: An Experimental Study on Fine-Grained Bistatic Sensing of UAV Trajectory via Cellular Downlink Signals
authors: Chenqing Ji, Jiahong Liu, Qionghui Liu, Yifei Sun, Chao Yu, Rui Wang
abstract: In this letter, a dual-bistatic unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) tracking system utilizing downlink Long-Term Evolution (LTE) signals is proposed and demonstrated. Particularly, two LTE base stations (BSs) are exploited as illumination sources. Two passive sensing receivers are deployed at different locations to detect the bistatic Doppler frequencies of the target UAV at different directions according to downlink signals transmitted from their corresponding BSs, such that the velocities of the UAV versus time can be estimated. Hence, the trajectories of the target UAV can be reconstructed. Although both the target UAV and the sensing receivers are around 200 meters away from the illuminating BSs, it is demonstrated by experiments that the tracking errors are below 50 centimeters for 90% of the complicated trajectories, when the distances between the UAV and sensing receivers are less than 30 meters. Note this accuracy is significantly better than the ranging resolution of LTE signals, high-accuracy trajectory tracking for UAV might be feasible via multi-angle bistatic Doppler measurements if the receivers are deployed with a sufficient density.

title: TeleROP-VLF: Federated Vision-Language Model on Wearable Devices for Explainable Retinopathy of Prematurity Vascular Geometrical Feature Screening
authors: Meng Pan, Liyang Ji, Fei Chen, Zhenghan Chen, Mengqiao Xu, Wencui Wan
abstract: Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) remains one of the leading causes of blindness in children globally. Global screening for ROP is limited by the shortage of trained ophthalmologists and low access to care in resource-limited settings. Vision-Language Models (VLMs) can be utilized to analyze medical images. However, VLMs also have limitations for ROP screening, including patient data privacy concerns, computational requirements for point-of-care devices, and the need for clinically interpretable predictions. In this study, we present TeleROP-VLF, a federated learning framework for VLM collaboration to train and perform analysis across multi-wearable retinal imaging devices while preserving sensitive patient data from leaving the hospital. TeleROP-VLF contributes three distinct innovations to the literature: 1) a lightweight VLM architecture that fits within wearable retina imaging devices through structured pruning and knowledge distillation; 2) a federated aggregation protocol with provable convergence; and 3) an explainable module that provides vessel geometry analysis with clinical meaning, aligned with established ROP diagnosis criteria including plus disease indicators, zone classification, and tortuosity. Using TeleROP-VLF in five neonatal intensive care units, we observe diagnostic performance comparable to expert ophthalmologists at 87.6% accuracy ultimately producing on-device inference that processes within 2.3 seconds on an autonomous edge computing platform while providing differential privacy guarantees and retaining a privacy budget of ϵ = 1.8. Coupled with clinical validation of explainable vascular geometric features, TeleROP-VLF aids clinician trust and facilitates early interventions to prevent vision loss for vulnerable premature infants.

title: A Transformer-Based Computational Framework for Automated Burn Injury Segmentation and Severity Assessment
authors: Aaiza Nadeem, Bushra Bashir, Samman Khalid, Irum Matloob, Alishba Sajid, Syeda Minahil Zahra, Husnain Khan, Fatima Khalique, Ruhul Amin Khalil
abstract: Burn injuries are the fourth most common type of injury; they are usually caused when the skin comes in contact with fire, hot water, radiation, or dangerous chemicals. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), an estimated 180,000 deaths occur every year due to burns. Different types of burn injuries require different medical procedures and medications; therefore, it is essential to diagnose a burn injury as early as possible to ensure that the patient receives proper treatment. Burns are usually diagnosed through visual inspection, which is subjective to the doctor’s experience and is usually only 50-70% accurate. A delay in diagnosis and precise treatment may lead to severe complications and, in worst-case scenarios, may also cause death. Unfortunately, in remote areas of Pakistan, where only basic dispensaries, clinics, or Primary Healthcare Units (PHUs) are available, and due to the lack of burn experts and the absence of Laser Doppler Imaging (LDI) equipment, such accurate diagnoses are not possible. As a result, many burn victims are either left untreated or given incorrect treatment, leading to complications. In this research, we propose a deep learning-based approach to assess the severity of acute burns in terms of burn degree and the affected Total Body Surface Area (TBSA%) from 2D images. The primary objective of our work is to determine the degree of a burn injury (first-degree, second-degree, third-degree, fourth-degree, and mixed-degree) and, based on the classification, estimate the TBSA% to advise on the appropriate medication required for the affected area. To achieve real-time diagnosis, an Android-based system has also been developed, allowing users to capture images and obtain instant results on acute burns detected in the image, including their severity, TBSA%, and recommended treatment.

title: Hierarchical Motion Planning for MASSs: A COLREGs-Compliant Framework Integrating Offline Trajectory Optimization and Real-Time Coupled Course-Speed Decision-Making_supp3-3662992.mp4
authors: Hongguang Lyu
abstract: Autonomous path planning and collision avoidance (CA) in complex maritime environments are critical challenges for Maritime Autonomous Surface Ships (MASSs). This paper presents a novel hierarchical motion planning framework that integrates global and local path planning algorithms. For global path planning in static obstacle environments, a hybrid approach combining A*, Bezier curves, and particle swarm optimization (PSO) is proposed to enhance path search efficiency and ensure smooth trajectory optimization. For local path planning and collision avoidance with dynamic vessels, a multi-ship CA algorithm based on velocity prediction potential fields is introduced. A new collision-risk identification model is developed to ensure compliance with COLREGS and enable collaborative CA in complex multi-ship scenarios. The framework also addresses environments with both dynamic and static obstacles through a dynamic path planner that integrates global and local planning. A key innovation is the dynamic CA decision-making mechanism with alteration of course and/or speed (ACS), which provides robust real-time navigation strategies. Validation through simulations, real-ship model tests, and AIS-data analysis demonstrates the framework’s robustness and adaptability for MASS navigation. Compared to existing methods, the proposed approach significantly reduces collision-avoidance path length while maintaining safety, real-time performance, and COLREGS compliance. This work advances autonomous maritime navigation by addressing complex scenarios with a unified framework that balances efficiency, safety, and regulatory adherence.

title: A Global Hierarchical LLM Framework for Precise Responses through Subscriptions to Country LLMs
authors: Anthony Jairam, Tamika Ramkissoon, Kevin Baboolal, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The increasing adoption of Large Language Models (LLM) and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines is transforming information access, yet their efficacy is significantly hampered in developing regions by a scarcity of relevant, localized data and compute. Furthermore, reliance on centralized RAG architectures raises critical data governance concerns, as organizations and governments are reluctant to forfeit control of sensitive data, thereby centralizing economic benefits and exacerbating regional digital divides. To address these challenges, this paper introduces a novel framework that leverages a distributed network of specialized LLMs rooted in the principles of Distributed Retrieval-Augmented Generation (DRAG). Our proposed architecture eliminates the need for a centralized knowledge base, allowing data owners to retain full control over their assets. We detail an intelligent query-routing mechanism for efficient knowledge discovery within the network and, critically, propose a comprehensive incentive model to encourage the active participation of regional entities. By fostering a collaborative, yet decentralized, ecosystem, this framework facilitates equitable data governance and paves the way for a sustainable, regional data economy, empowering local communities and enhancing the accuracy of LLMs.

title: Improved Fireworks Algorithm for Multi-Skill Robot Multi-Objective Hybrid Disassembly
authors: Yujie Feng, Xiwang Guo, Liang Qi, Jiacun Wang, Weitian Wang, Shujin Qin, Bin Hu, Xu Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This work investigates a multi-skill robot multi-objective hybrid disassembly line balancing problem (MRHD), aiming to maximize profit and minimize the difference in workstation operating times. Based on practical applications, we propose a disassembly line balancing model for robots with different skill sets, allowing optimized task scheduling according to robot capabilities to improve disassembly efficiency and reduce labor costs. Specifically, we build a mixed-integer programming model and find its precise solution via IBM's mathematical programming solver CPLEX, thereby validating the correctness of the proposed model. Additionally, an improved fireworks algorithm (IFA) is proposed to find approximate optimal solutions for sizable MRHD. The optimal solution obtained by IFA is compared with the exact solution from CPLEX through a disassembly task. Experimental results and analysis demonstrate the competitive performance of the developed approach in high solution speed and good adaptability for multi-objective optimization and large-scale disassembly line problems, providing effective decision support for real-world remanufacturing applications.

title: A High-current IGBT Gate Driver IC featuring a Dual-NMOS Output Stage and Negative Gate Drive
authors: Yibo Yin, Xue-Quan Huang, Wenhao Liu, Hangyu Xu
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This paper presents a high-performance gate driver IC for Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBTs), fabricated in a 0.25μm Bipolar-CMOS-DMOS (BCD) technology. The driver addresses three critical challenges in modern power electronics: the need for high driving current, operation at 100% duty cycle, and robust noise immunity. The architecture features a dual N-channel LDMOS totem-pole output stage, delivering measured peak currents exceeding 9A/16A for rapid switching of large IGBTs. To overcome the limitations of conventional bootstrap circuits, a hybrid high-side supply is implemented, integrating a low-power charge pump that ensures stable gate voltage during 100% duty-cycle operation. A key innovation is the emitter-referenced negative turn-off scheme, which generates an effective -10V gate-emitter voltage by elevating the IGBT's emitter potential to +10V, thereby eliminating the need for a dedicated negative power supply rail and simplifying system design. Experimental results from the fabricated chip validate the high-current capability, full operational duty-cycle range, and the successful implementation of the negative biasing structure. The proposed driver offers a robust, highly integrated, and cost-effective solution for demanding industrial and automotive applications.

title: Direct Green Power Connection Project Component Configuration and Economic Analysis
authors: Meng Yang, Junhui Liu, Yihan Zhang, Wenjing Zu, Yao Lu, Minghao Cao
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To promote local renewable energy consumption and better meet corporate green energy demands, China has issued specialized policies to advance Direct Green Power Connection development. This study proposes operational simulation and economic assessment methodologies to ensure rational component configuration that meets policy requirements while maintaining economic viability. Empirical analysis is conducted for a typical industrial enterprise with power generation companies as investors. Five scenarios are evaluated: PV-only, PV+storage, wind-only, wind+storage, and PV+wind, assessing technical and economic indicators for each. Optimal configurations per scenario are identified through comparative analysis, followed by impact assessments on users and investors for the top three economic solutions. Finally, recommendations are provided for enterprises and governments to enhance project feasibility and economics.

title: Enhancing Trust Cues in Companion Robots for Older Adults: A Pet-Like, Friendly and Nostalgia-Driven Kansei Approach
authors: Chorong Park
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: The rapid introduction of conversational pet robots for older adults promises social connection and cognitive support, yet sustained adoption hinges on whether older adults trust these systems. Trust is a dynamic, context-dependent construct that, when misaligned, can lead to misuse or disuse. To investigate trust formation in age-friendly human–robot interaction (HRI), we conducted a mixed-methods study with 22 community-dwelling older adults who interacted with two commercial pet robots (EMO and Loona) in a field setting. Participants engaged in naturalistic interactions supported by a facilitator who previewed upcoming actions, explained robot responses, and encouraged reflection on the robots’ behaviors. Building on the ‘Kansei of the Elderly’ framework, we derive robot-specific design implications for trust cues. Behaviors supporting legibility, reciprocity, pace-matching, and controllability; such as brief previews and explanations for the robot’s actions, timely acknowledgements, slightly longer response windows, and easy undo functionality, were consistently associated with higher engagement and fewer help-seeking events. Participants often laughed and felt comfortable during the sessions; notably, facilitator interpretations of the robot’s behaviors frequently prompted discussions among peers. We conclude by outlining design guidelines for AI-enabled pet companion robots that translate these insights into actionable features, and situate our contributions within trust-preserving human-in-the-loop assistance and legible interaction frameworks.

title: An Isolated Multi-Winding Converter for Scalable Charging and Energy Balancing of Retired Battery Packs
authors: Hao Guo, Zhengqi Wei, C. Q. Jiang, Yibo Wang, Xiaosheng Wang, Hanqing Cao, Xiaoliang Yu
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Conventional battery equalization circuits require a large number of active switching devices when scaled to multiple channels. This not only limits efficiency improvement but also increases the complexity of control-loop design. This paper proposes an isolated charging and energy-balancing solution for retired battery packs. A multi-winding transformer connects the primary power source to multiple secondary battery modules, where each secondary winding is dedicated to one battery pack, thereby achieving voltage equalization during simultaneous charging. The proposed architecture features a wide input-voltage range, high scalability, low cost of expansion, and fully independent balancing channels. During system extension, no additional active switches are required, significantly simplifying the control-loop design. Furthermore, zero-voltage switching (ZVS) is implemented to enhance efficiency, and its realization process is described in detail. A simulation model for a three-cell balancing circuit is built to validate the proposed scheme. Two simulation cases with different initial battery states confirm the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed circuit.

title: Reliability Analysis of Concentrator III-V Triple-Junction Solar Cells Using Arrhenius-Normal Model
authors: M. U. Khonji, A. Ahmed, E. Barakat, M. A. Majid, O. Kittaneh, Abraz Ahmed
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This study builds upon the recently developed Arrhenius-Normal model to evaluate the reliability of commercial concentrator III–V triple-junction solar cells under thermal stress, based on accelerated lifetime data. The dataset, previously examined using the classical Arrhenius-Weibull and Arrhenius-Lognormal models, is reanalyzed to demonstrate that failure times at each stress level closely follow a normal distribution. The Arrhenius-Normal model exhibits an excellent fit to the stress–life relationship, enabling precise lifetime predictions under normal operating conditions. The analysis also confirms that while the mean and standard deviation of lifetime decrease with increasing stress, their ratio—the coefficient of variation—remains constant, aligning with findings in recent literature. The results are benchmarked against previously reported outcomes for validation and comparison.

title: Graphical Interface of an Intellegent Support System for the AUV Operator’s Activities
authors: Andrey Pugachev, Alexey Borovik, Konstantin Shilin
abstract: This article describes in detail the new graphical user interface (GUI) for the operator support system when planning mission of an autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV), developed at IMTP FEB RAS. It solves complex tasks using a multimodal approach combining natural language data processing (NLP), visual task mapping, and automated code generation in a specialized underwater research programming language (URPL). The graphical user interface consists of interconnected modules: a central control panel with a query history, a workspace for displaying and editing the mission code, and a mapping module for graphical route design. An important component is an intelligent conversational interface based on neural network models. This assistant allows operators to set and edit mission programs through voice interaction. The proposed interface option simplifies the process of assigning missions to the vehicle, which significantly reduces the time needed to prepare for deployment and reduces the likelihood of human error. The system reduces the level of operators' specialized programming knowledge, increasing the availability and efficiency of AUV mission settings.

title: Experimental Results of Autonomous Underwater Vehicle 2D-Hologram by a Vector Receiver
authors: Yuriy V. Matvienko, Sergey Pereselkov, Venedikt Kuz’Kin, Sergey Tkachenko
abstract: In this paper, a method for holographic signal processing (HSP) of a vector scalar receiver (VR) in the high-frequency range within shallow water environments is developed. The paper aim is experimental results of HSP-method for detecting and bearing estimation of autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) by using VR. The HSP-method involves generating a 2D-interferogram and 2D-hologram of the AUV. In that paper the experimental 2D-interferograms and 2D-holograms are analyzed for different VR channels, including acoustic pressure (P) and acoustic velocity components (V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">X</inf>, V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Y</inf>, V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</inf>). The experimental results demonstrate that HSP-method allows detect the source, estimate its direction, and filter the useful signal (AUV-noise) from obstacles.

title: Enhancing Power System Protection Through NSGA-III-Based Optimization
authors: Hossein Faramarzi, Abbas Ahmadvand, S. Maryam Eftekhari
abstract: The integration of distributed generation (DG) units into power systems challenges traditional directional overcurrent relay (DOCR) coordination by altering fault current magnitudes and directions, leading to potential miscoordination. This paper proposes a multi-objective optimization approach using the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm-III (NSGA-III) to determine optimal time multiplier settings (TMS), plug settings (PS), and relay characteristics for DOCRs. The method minimizes primary relay operating times, backup relay operating times, and coordination time interval (CTI) errors without requiring weighting factors. It accounts for DG impacts, near-end and far-end faults, and various relay characteristics per IEC standards. Tested on IEEE 3-bus and 8-bus systems, the approach is compared to NSGA-II. Results demonstrate reduced operating times and improved coordination, despite minor violations in larger systems. This enhances system reliability and mitigates DG-related protection issues.

title: Message from General Chair ICNSC 2025
authors: Juha Röning
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: As Head of the Biomimetics and Intelligent Systems Group (BISG) at the University of Oulu, it is my great pleasure to welcome you to ICNSC 2025, which we are proudly hosting in Oulu this year. The theme of this conference–“Autonomous Intelligent Systems”–speaks directly to the intersection where sensing, networking, control and autonomous decision-making meet.

title: Robust Control Design for a Small Scale Tilt-Augmented Quadrotor
authors: Sathyanarayanan Seshasayanan, Soumya Ranjan Sahoo
abstract: The existing control design for the tilt quadrotor often assumes that the derivative of the disturbance is zero and that the moment of inertia (MoI) is diagonal. However, in general the disturbance may be bounded but not constant. Also, due to the tilting of the rotors, the MoI may not be a diagonal matrix. To address this, we design a robust controller which handles the MoI matrix uncertainties and is capable of rejecting varying external disturbances. This proposed controller guarantees convergence to a desired bounded region in the existence of bounded external disturbances. In this work, we develop the first small-sized, over-actuated tilt quadrotor using 3D-printed parts. Using the proposed controller, experiments are performed on both conventional and tilt quadrotors. From these experiments, the tilt quadrotor demonstrates better response time, flight time, and lower energy consumption compared to the conventional quadrotor. Finally, the proposed controller’s robustness is validated for both position and attitude setpoints of the tilt quadrotor when subjected to wind. Experimental flight videos can be found at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqSZQRznc-c.

title: MCE-ERL:Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning Algorithm with Multi-Distribution Critics Evaluation
authors: Zuohao Wu, Guang Li, Zihao Li, Hongyu Ao, Mingsheng Shang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: By combining gradient-based reinforcement learning (RL) with gradient-free evolutionary algorithms (EA), evolutionary reinforcement learning (ERL) algorithms have shown effectiveness in continuous high-dimensional tasks. However, traditional ERL faces challenges such as distributional differences between EA and RL samples affecting critic evaluation, limited exploration due to reward-based metrics, and high interaction costs from low-quality samples. To address these issues, we propose MCE-ERL, an ERL algorithm with multi-distribution critics. We uses a value group and multi-distribution sampling to better cover the sample space, leverages uncertainty for exploration, and applies importance sampling to filter low-quality samples. Experiments on continuous control tasks show that MCE-ERL achieves faster convergence and better performance than baselines, offering insights for reducing sample collection loss in real-world robotic applications.

title: Frequency-Aware Multi-Modal Fusion for Sea Surface Temperature Prediction
authors: Ruijing Sun, Kefan Wang, Qi Kang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: In multi-modal sea surface temperature (SST) prediction, a critical challenge lies in effectively modeling the temporal misalignments and complex dependencies across heterogeneous modalities. Traditional spatiotemporal models predominantly rely on point-wise self-attention or local convolutional operations, which are often insufficient to capture long-range, nonsynchronous interactions between modalities. To address this, we propose a frequency-aware fusion framework that transforms multi-modal spatiotemporal data into the frequency domain via discrete Fourier transform (DFT). This transformation enables the disentanglement of modality-specific periodic patterns, allowing for more structured and interpretable cross-modal fusion. We construct a hyper-variable graph where nodes represent spatial locations and temporal sequences, and we introduce a gated softmax mechanism based on spectral energy to adaptively weight each modality's contribution. Furthermore, a piecewise soft-thresholding operation is applied in the spectral domain to suppress low-energy noise while preserving informative signals. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves superior prediction accuracy, outperforming existing baselines on both MSE and MAE across multiple forecasting horizons.

title: Retraction Notice: Application of Chatbot for consumer perspective using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Abhishek Savanur, Niranjanamurthy M, Amulya M P, Dayananda P
publish: 2021 6th International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: ChatBot can be described as software that can chat with people using artificial intelligence. A chatbot is a PC program that reenacts human discussion through voice orders or text visits or both. Chatbot, short for chatter-bot, is a man-made reasoning (AI) include that can be implanted and utilized through any significant informing applications. This software are recycled to achieve tasks such as rapidly responding to consumers, informing them, assisting to purchase products and providing better service to customers. This research paper showing how a chatbot can be created through demonstration as well as their applications of chatbots in numerous areas such as traveling, banking, health, customer call centers and e-commerce. Additionally, the results of an example chatbbot for online food order service developed in the e-commerce domain is presented using Dialog-flow engine and Facebook Messanger. This research work represents the Chat flow, components of a chatbot, Implementation using Dialogflow.

title: Kalman–Savitzky–Golay Filtering for Autonomous Turret Systems: Target Tracking and Engagement
authors: Puvvada Vamsidhar, Danda Vamsi Chakradhar, Raghavarapu Dharani, Ravishankar Prakash Desai
abstract: Autonomous turret systems are crucial to modern defence and security technology, with target tracking and attack capability needed. Turret mechanisms are subject to noise interference, high-speed targets, and interference, causing loss of accuracy and low reaction time. This paper presents a hybrid approach combining Savitzky-Golay smoothing algorithms with Kalman filtering for tracking stability improvement and attacking accuracy enhancement in autonomous turrets. The framework combines object detection via the light YOLOv3-tiny model, motion prediction via the Kalman filter, and trajectory smoothing via Savitzky-Golay filters. Extensive 2D and 3D space simulations are found to achieve high tracking precision for various target motions with up to 99.5% accuracy under general conditions and robust performance with excessive noise levels.

title: Predefined-Time UAV Circumnavigation via Lyapunov Vector Fields under Wind Disturbance
authors: Pallov Anand, A. Pedro Aguiar
abstract: This paper presents a predefined-time circumnavigation strategy for an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) modeled by nonholonomic kinematics, tasked with tracking a stationary and a moving target under wind disturbances. Unlike existing methods that offer asymptotic or finite-time convergence without explicit control over convergence time, our framework guarantees that the UAV reaches a desired circular path around the target within a user-specified time bound. We design a Lyapunov-based guidance vector field in the target-relative frame to drive the radial tracking error to zero in predefined-time. To maintain a constant commanded airspeed while compensating for wind and target motion, we derive a scaling factor that adjusts the guidance vector field while preserving its Lyapunov-based convergence properties. A nonlinear program is solved at each timestep to ensure the UAV’s heading converges to the desired heading angle within the predefined-time while respecting actuator limits. Numerous simulation results depicting various cases are presented justifying the efficacy of the proposed methodology.

title: Architectural Foundations and Standardization Outlook for AI-Enabled 6G Core Network
authors: Bahador Bakhshi, Tingyu Xin, DongJin Lee, Morteza Kheirkhah, Wonjung Kim, Malla Reddy Sama
abstract: 6G will provide a new opportunity to integrate Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into wireless communication. The current 5G Core (5GC) architecture possesses limitations that restrict its ability to effectively deploy AI functions, including the lack of a standardized, unified access layer for network data, limited service exposure models that cannot fully support AI feedback loops, and tight coupling between logic and signaling that inhibits the insertion of AI-based decision-making components. This paper explores approaches to address the 5GC shortcomings in the future 6G Core (6GC) network. Recommendations for architectural evolution and standardization are discussed to facilitate scalable, efficient, and adaptable AI-enabled 6G networks.

title: A Novel ISAC Waveform Based on Orthogonal Delay-Doppler Division Multiplexing with FMCW
authors: Kehan Huang, Akram Shafie, Min Qiu, Elias Aboutanios, Jinhong Yuan
abstract: In this work, we propose the orthogonal delay-Doppler (DD) division multiplexing (ODDM) modulation with frequency modulated continuous wave (FMCW) (ODDM-FMCW) waveform to enable integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) with a low peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR). We first propose a square-root-Nyquist-filtered FMCW (SRN-FMCW) waveform to address limitations of conventional linear FMCW waveforms in ISAC systems. To better integrate with ODDM, we generate SRN-FMCW by embedding symbols in the DD domain, referred to as a DD-SRN-FMCW frame. A DD chirp compression receiver is designed to obtain the channel response efficiently. Next, we construct the proposed ODDM-FMCW waveform for ISAC by superimposing a DD-SRN-FMCW frame onto an ODDM data frame. A comprehensive performance analysis of the ODDM-FMCW waveform is presented, covering peak-to-average power ratio, spectrum, ambiguity function, and Cramér-Rao bound for delay and Doppler estimation. Numerical results show that the proposed ODDM-FMCW waveform delivers excellent ISAC performance in terms of root mean square error for sensing and bit error rate for communications.

title: Electromagnetic and Thermal Design of Partially HTS Linear Motor: Analysis of Thrust Ripple Harmonics and Thermal Optimization
authors: Koichi Matsuda, Xueying Ma
abstract: The acceleration and heat loss of superconducting linear motors are the main limitations in their development. The electromagnetic and thermal design methods of a partially high-temperature superconducting linear motor (HTSLM) are proposed to increase acceleration and reduce heat loss. The electromagnetic design is based on a two-dimensional (2D) analytical model and a three-dimensional (3D) finite element model (FEM), whereas the thermal design is performed using a thermal network model (TNM) and a 3D FEM, under steady-state conditions. In this paper, both the mover and the stator are placed in a cryostat to reduce the air gap and increase the acceleration up to 9 g. After the proposed HTSLM system reaches thermal equilibrium, the stator operates at 52 K. The electromagnetic thrust is analytically derived and decomposed into the fundamental and ripple components. The harmonic analysis indicates that the ripple originates from the coupling between the AC and the (6i<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula> 1)-order harmonics of the air-gap field. The TNM and the 3D FEM are used to analyze the heat flow paths and to calculate the heat losses. The parametric effects of the mover temperature and the heat loss are studied. The parameters of the TNM and the 3D FEM are then improved to optimize the thermal design and to guide the selection of a cryocooler. The 2D model proposed in this paper for electromagnetic design, as well as the TNM for thermal design, have certain generality and can be used in the design of planar and rotary motor systems.

title: FIR Stabilizability Ensures Stabilizability by Non-FIR Controllers Having Integer Monic Characteristic Polynomials
authors: Mohammad Saleh Tavazoei
abstract: To avoid computational overflow in partially homomorphic encrypted control systems with dynamic LTI discrete-time controllers, it has been previously suggested to use controllers possessing integer characteristic polynomials. These controllers are divided into two categories: FIR controllers and non-FIR ones. In this paper, it is proved that each plant, which is stabilizable by FIR controllers, can be also stabilized by non-FIR ones having integer characteristic polynomials. Furthermore, the validity of this statement is verified by numerical examples. The theoretical achievement of this paper reveals the existence of a degree of freedom to choose between FIR controllers and non-FIR ones, when the aim of the control system designer is to use a dynamic controller with integer characteristic polynomial in partially homomorphic encrypted environments for avoiding computational overflow.

title: Retraction Notice: Ortho Vision: Autoencoder-CNN Fusion Approach for Fracture Detection
authors: S Abhiram, Amal Krishna K, Vaishnav G M, Anjali T, Abhishek S
publish: 2023 7th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: We propose an advanced framework for automated fracture detection in medical X-ray images., harnessing the power of hybrid deep learning methodologies. Through the fusion of autoencoders” adeptness in feature extraction and a convolutional neural networks (CNN) efficiency in recognizing the complex patterns., the proposed model achieves remarkable accuracy in identifying fractures. By integrating data augmentation and preprocessing strategies., the system demonstrates enhanced robustness in handling variations in image quality and presentation. This innovation holds substantial promise in revolutionizing the field of medical diagnostics by offering a reliable and efficient tool for clinicians to expedite fracture diagnosis., facilitate treatment decisions., and ultimately improve patient care. The amalgamation of diverse techniques not only establishes a robust fracture detection mechanism but also showcases the potential of interdisciplinary approaches. The proposed approach demonstrated excellent accuracy in fracture detection with a 92% percentage., which can greatly improve medical diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Approximating High-Dimensional Earth Mover’s Distance as Fast as Closest Pair
authors: Lorenzo Beretta, Vincent Cohen-Addad, Rajesh Jayaram, Erik Waingarten
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We give a reduction from (1 + ε)-approximate Earth Mover’s Distance (EMD) to (1 + ε)-approximate Closest Pair (CP). As a consequence, we improve the fastest known approximation algorithm for high-dimensional EMD. Here, given p ∈ [1], [2] and two sets of n points $X,Y \subset \left( {{\mathbb{R}^d},{\ell _p}} \right)$, their EMD is the minimum cost of a perfect matching between X and Y, where the cost of matching two vectors is their ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> distance. Further, CP is the basic problem of finding a pair of points realizing min<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x∈X</inf>,<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y∈Y</inf> ║x − y║<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>. Our contribution is twofold:• We show that if (1 + ε)-approximate CP can be computed in time n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2−ϕ</sup>, then a 1 + O(ε) approximation to EMD can be computed in time n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2−Ω(ϕ)</sup>.• Plugging in the fastest known algorithm for CP [5], we obtain a (1 + ε)-approximation algorithm for EMD running in time ${n^{2 - \tilde \Omega \left( {{\varepsilon ^{1/3}}} \right)}}$ for high-dimensional point sets, which improves over the prior fastest running time of ${n^{2 - \Omega \left( {{\varepsilon ^2}} \right)}}$ [13].Our main technical contribution is a sublinear implementation of the Multiplicative Weights Update framework for EMD. Specifically, we demonstrate that the updates can be executed without ever explicitly computing or storing the weights; instead, we exploit the underlying geometric structure to perform the updates implicitly.

title: Near-Optimal Algorithms for Omniprediction
authors: Princewill Okoroafor, Robert Kleinberg, Michael P. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Omnipredictors are simple prediction functions that encode loss-minimizing predictions with respect to a hypothesis class ℋ, simultaneously for every loss function within a class of losses ℒ. In this work, we give near-optimal learning algorithms for omniprediction, in both the online and offline settings. To begin, we give an oracle-efficient online learning algorithm that achieves (ℒ, ℋ)-omniprediction with $\tilde O\left( {\sqrt {T\log |\mathcal{H}|} } \right)$ regret for any class of Lipschitz loss functions ℒ ⊆ ℒ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Lip</inf>. Quite surprisingly, this regret bound matches the optimal regret for minimization of a single loss function (up to a $\sqrt {\log (T)} $ factor). Given this online algorithm, we develop an online-to-offline conversion that achieves near-optimal complexity across a number of measures. In particular, for all bounded loss functions within the class of Bounded Variation losses ℒ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BV</inf> (which include all convex, all Lipschitz, and all proper losses) and any (possibly-infinite) ℋ, we obtain an offline learning algorithm that, leveraging an (offline) ERM oracle and m samples from $\mathcal{D}$, returns an efficient (ℒ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BV</inf>, ℋ, ε(m))-omnipredictor for ε(m) scaling near-linearly in the Rademacher complexity of Th◦ℋ, the class of all binary threshold functions on ℋ.

title: Shortest Paths on Convex Polyhedral Surfaces
authors: Haitao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Let $\mathcal{P}$ be the surface of a convex polyhedron of n vertices. We consider the two-point shortest path query problem for $\mathcal{P}$: Constructing a data structure so that given any two query points s and t on $\mathcal{P}$, a shortest path from s to t on $\mathcal{P}$ can be computed efficiently. To achieve $O(\log n)$ query time (for computing the shortest path length), the previously best result uses $O\left(n^{8+\epsilon}\right)$ preprcessing time and space [Aggarwal, Aronov, O’Rourke, and Schevon, SICOMP 1997], where $\epsilon$ is an arbitrarily small positive constant. In this paper, we present a new data structure of $O\left(n^{6+\frac{2}{3}+\epsilon}\right)$ preprocessing time and space, with $O(\log n)$ query time. For a special case where one query point is required to be on an edge of $\mathcal{P}$, the previously best work uses $O\left(n^{6+\epsilon}\right)$ preprcessing time and space to achieve $O(\log n)$ query time. We improve the preprocessing time and space to $O\left(n^{5+\frac{1}{4}+\epsilon}\right)$, with $O(\log n)$ query time. If both query points are on the edges of $\mathcal{P}$, then we can answer each query in $O(\log n)$ time with $O\left(n^{5+\epsilon}\right)$ space and preprocessting time. Furthermore, we present a new algorithm to compute the exact set of shortest path edge sequences of $\mathcal{P}$, which are known to be $\Theta\left(n^{4}\right)$ in number and have a total complexity of $\Theta\left(n^{5}\right)$ in the worst case. The previously best algorithm for the problem takes roughly $O\left(n^{6} \log n \log ^{*} n\right)$ time, while our new algorithm runs in $O\left(n^{5+\epsilon}\right)$ time.

title: A Study of Traffic Sign Information Acquisition Methods for Safe Bicycle Navigation
authors: Tomotaka Nagaosa, Akihiro Tada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: In this paper, we study a method of acquiring sign information for the purpose of determining safe routes in a bicycle navigation system. The proposed methods of acquiring sign information are based on Google Street View and a method using a drive recorder. YOLOv8, a real-time object detector, is used for image recognition. In preliminary experiments, we evaluated the recognition accuracy of signs from drive recorder videos based on driving videos on motorways. As a result, it was determined that the recognition accuracy using the YOLOv8 model with 100 training cycles was the most suitable, and a comparison of the two methods was conducted using this weight file. The comparison results showed that both methods have the same recall (78%), but the precision is 41% for the conventional method and 19% for the proposed method, indicating that the use of a drive recorder often results in false positives.

title: An ROI-aware LiDAR Point Cloud Compression Method in Autonomous Driving
authors: Yakun Yang, Hu Yuan, Anhong Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: In autonomous driving, efficient transmission and precise detection of objects from LiDAR point clouds are essential yet challenging due to high data volume and computational complexity. This paper proposes an ROI-aware octree-based point cloud compression network tailored explicitly for object detection tasks. We introduce a ring-grid module to effectively eliminate redundant ground points, significantly reducing the data size and emphasising regions of interest (ROIs). Subsequently, we apply hierarchical octree encoding to the retained ROI points, utilising a contextual entropy model that integrates ancestor, neighbour, and sibling-child node information. This approach not only achieves a compact representation of the point cloud but also preserves essential semantic context for accurate object detection. Experimental evaluations on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that our method reduces bitrates by over 10% compared to state-of-the-art techniques while simultaneously enhancing object detection precision by approximately 1%, confirming its effectiveness in balancing efficient compression and high detection accuracy.

title: Discovery of Novel PINK1 Activators: Virtual Screening of Niclosamide-Like Compounds for Potential Parkinson's Disease Therapy
authors: Preeti, Pravir Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2^{\text {nd }}$</tex> leading neurodegenerative diseases that impact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> of people globally, is a condition in which dopaminergic neurons deteriorate. Although there is presently no cure for Parkinson's disease, there are medicines that can only manage its symptoms. Since the majority of the PD-related mutations affected PINK1 activity, it was hypothesized that micro compounds that induce the activation of PINK1 would preserve mitochondrial quality control and provide beneficial neuroprotective effects. This paper uses a drug repurposing approach & utilizes the ZINC database to find novel PINK1 activators for possible PD treatment based on niclosamide, an FDA-approved anthelmintic drug which is a well-known PINK1 activator. To assess binding affinities and interactions, molecular docking was carried out against the structure of the PINK1 protein (8uyf). The physicochemical properties and drug-like characteristics of the top-scoring molecules were evaluated further. When compared to niclosamide, a number of potential candidates showed better predicted binding affinity and drug-like characteristics. We used the drug's ADME analysis to further confirm its pharmacokinetic characteristics.

title: Quantum-Resistant Blockchain Framework for Data Anonymization in IoT-Based Smart Agriculture
authors: Baidyanath Ram, Vikash Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) in smart agriculture generates vast datasets, offering significant benefits but also raising critical privacy concerns. Traditional anonymization methods often prove insufficient against advanced analysis and emerging quantum computing threats, while centralized data management introduces vulnerabilities. This research proposes a novel framework that integrates quantum-resistant blockchain technology (BCT) with advanced data anonymization techniques to ensure privacy preservation in agricultural IoT ecosystems. The proposed approach leverages the decentralized and immutable nature of Blockchain for secure data management and access control, combined with quantum-resistant anonymization methods to protect sensitive agricultural data against both classical and future quantum attacks. This research will explore the design, implementation and evaluation of such a framework, analyzing its performance in terms of privacy guarantees, data utility, computational efficiency, and scalability through simulations and potential real-world case studies. The findings will contribute to the development of secure and privacy-preserving solutions for the responsible adoption of IoT in smart agriculture, addressing the specific needs of various stakeholders in the agricultural value chain.

title: Rapid Mixing on Random Regular Graphs beyond Uniqueness
authors: Xiaoyu Chen, Zejia Chen, Zongchen Chen, Yitong Yin, Xinyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: The hardcore model is a fundamental probabilistic model extensively studied in statistical physics, probability theory, and computer science. It defines a Gibbs distribution over independent sets of a given graph, parameterized by a vertex activity λ > 0. For graphs of maximum degree ∆, a well-known computational phase transition occurs at the tree-uniqueness threshold ${\lambda _c}(\Delta ) = \frac{{{{(\Delta - 1)}^{\Delta - 1}}}}{{{{(\Delta - 2)}^\Delta }}}$, where the mixing behavior of the Glauber dynamics (a simple Markov chain) undergoes a sharp transition: it mixes in nearly linear time for λ < λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>(∆), in polynomial but super-linear time at λ = λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>(∆), and experiences exponential slowdown for λ > λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>(∆).It is conjectured that random regular graphs exhibit different mixing behavior, with the slowdown occurring far beyond the uniqueness threshold. We confirm this conjecture by showing that, for the hardcore model on random ∆-regular graphs, the Glauber dynamics mixes rapidly with high probability when $\lambda = O\left( {1/\sqrt \Delta } \right)$, which is significantly beyond the uniqueness threshold λ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>(∆) ≈ e/∆. Our result establishes a sharp distinction between the hardcore model on worst-case and beyond-worst-case instances, showing that the worst-case and average-case complexities of sampling and counting are fundamentally different.This result of rapid mixing on random instances follows from a new criterion we establish for rapid mixing of Glauber dynamics for any distribution supported on a downward closed set family. Our criterion is simple, general, and easy to check. In addition to proving new mixing conditions for the hardcore model, we also establish improved mixing time bounds for sampling uniform matchings or b-matchings on graphs, the random cluster model on matroids with q ∈ [0,1), and the determinantal point process. Our proof of this new criterion for rapid mixing combines and generalizes several recent tools in a novel way, including a trickle-down theorem for field dynamics, spectral/entropic stability, and a new comparison result between field dynamics and Glauber dynamics.

title: Adblockers vs. Digital Advertising: Implications for Marketers and Publishers
authors: Sanjay Kumar Aggarwal, Jagvinder Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The widespread adoption of ad blockers has emerged as a disruptive force in the digital advertising ecosystem, fundamentally altering the dynamics between users, marketers, and publishers. Ad blockers empower users by enhancing their browsing experience—eliminating intrusive, irrelevant, and excessive advertisements—but simultaneously create significant challenges for advertisers and publishers. Marketers face reduced visibility for their campaigns, incomplete audience data, and higher costs to reach their target demographics. Publishers, on the other hand, grapple with declining ad revenue streams, threatening their ability to fund quality content and sustain operations. This paper delves into the complex relationship between ad blockers and digital advertising, highlighting the implications for the industry at large. It explores key drivers behind the rise of ad blockers, such as user dissatisfaction with invasive ads and privacy concerns, while analyzing their financial and operational impact on stakeholders. Furthermore, it investigates adaptive strategies that marketers and publishers can employ to counteract these challenges—ranging from ethical advertising practices that prioritize user experience to alternative monetization models such as subscription-based services or “ad-light” experiences. By striking a balance between respecting user preferences and innovating within advertising frameworks, this paper argues that marketers and publishers can not only mitigate the adverse effects of ad blockers, but also foster a more sustainable and mutually beneficial digital ecosystem. Ultimately, this study underscores the importance of rethinking traditional advertising approaches to align with evolving consumer expectations in an increasingly privacy-conscious era.

title: Binary Codes for Computationally Bounded Errors Under Standard Crypto Assumptions
authors: George Lu, Jad Silbak, Daniel Wichs
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We study error-detection and error-correction codes for computationally bounded adversarial channels. We consider seeded codes where the polynomial-time encoding and decoding procedures share a public random seed, but are otherwise deterministic. An adversarial channel gets this seed and can perform arbitrary polynomial-time computation to adaptively select both the message to be encoded and a bounded number of errors to be added to the resulting codeword. The goal is to detect or correct such errors with overwhelming probability, while achieving better trade-offs between rate and error tolerance than those possible for computationally unbounded channels. For large alphabets, prior work (ITCS ‘25) achieves essentially optimal parameters under minimal cryptographic assumptions. However, for the binary alphabet, prior works (TCC ‘20, EUROCRYPT ‘25) either only achieved a weaker notion of selective security under the learning with errors (LWE) assumption, or relied on non-standard cryptographic assumptions to get the full notion of adaptive security. In this work, we construct binary codes that achieve the full notion of adaptive security assuming trapdoor hashing, which can in turn be instantiated under a variety of standard cryptographic assumptions such as LWE, or Decisional DiffieHellman (DDH), or Quadratic Residuosity (QR), or Decisional Composite Residuosity (DCR). For error detection, our codes get essentially optimal rate $R \approx 1$ and relative error tolerance $p \approx \frac{1}{2}$. For error correction, they can uniquely correct $p\lt1 / 4$ fraction of errors with a rate R matching that of the best known list-decodable codes for this error tolerance. As a central technical tool of potentially independent interest, we construct multi-input correlation intractable hashing for “shifted output relations” under the standard cryptographic assumptions above.

title: Hybrid Cooling Strategies Using Electrohydrodynamic Pumping for Compact Semiconductor Modules
authors: Yazhini S, Srithar B M, Yoganathan K, Vinoth P, Surya K
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Efficient thermal management is essential for high-performance, miniaturized semiconductor modules. This paper presents a novel hybrid cooling system combining electrohydro-dynamic (EHD) pumping with microchannel heat sinks. Existing cooling systems like fan-based and pumped-liquid cooling suffer from high energy usage, noise, and limited scalability. These limitations hinder their effectiveness in compact, high-density electronic applications. Traditional air and water loop systems offer limited heat flux dissipation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-65 ~\mathrm{W} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>) and increased form factor. They are inadequate for high transient loads and miniaturized system-on-chip platforms. The proposed hybrid EHD + microchannel method achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$135 ~\mathrm{W} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex> heat flux dissipation with low surface temperature rise (5.4°C) and excellent temperature uniformity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{1. 7 ^ { \circ }} \mathbf{C}$</tex>). Multiphysics simulations were conducted to model electrostatic force-coupled fluid motion and heat transfer within a compact system architecture. Results were verified through lab-scale prototyping and real-time measurements. COMSOL Multiphysics and MATLAB were employed for simulation, and IR thermography, thermocouples, and power meters were used for experimental validation. Compared to EHD-only (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$97 ~\mathrm{W} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>) and passive microchannel (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$88 ~\mathrm{W} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>) systems, the hybrid approach enhanced COP to 14.22 with zero noise and high reliability (MTBF: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1, 2 0 0 ~ h r s}$</tex>). The results validate the hybrid strategy as an energy-efficient, scalable cooling solution for compact electronics, ideal for next-gen processors, edge devices, and embedded systems.

title: BERT-Based Myers-Briggs Type Indicator Personality Qualification from Social Media Texts
authors: Megico Mejora Maria Nayagam, Khadija Naveed, Sonjoy Ranjon Das, Bilal Hassan, Touseef Tahir
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Accurately predicting personality traits based on unstructured social media text can be widely applied, such as in psychological profiling and personalized digital services. The proposed study works on a deep learning model to predict personality types using the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) personality model. The model trains four binary classifiers (associated with the MBTI dimensions: introversion/extraversion, sensing/intuition, thinking/feeling, and judging/perceiving) based on the BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) models. In contrast to the earlier solutions resting on one data source or performing traditional machine learning tasks, this study combines and preprocesses two social media sources exhibiting different multifaceted nature PersonalityCafe and Reddit, emphasizing robustness and generalizable aspects. Class imbalance (like in lemmatization and context-aware data augmentation) can be used to obtain more semantic features. The results of the evaluation of the experiments show robust performance, especially in imbalanced datasets, computed using F1-score and AUC. The work demonstrates the power of transformer-based models in the predictive application of personality and preconditions the approach towards building scalable and cross-platform psychological modeling.

title: Temporal Variability of Vertical Profiles of Chlorophyll-a and Dissolved Organic Matter Concentrations in the Water Column Obtained with the Autonomous Moored Profiling Probe Winchi
authors: Pavel Salyuk, Nadezhda Lipinskaya, Igor Stepochkin, Maxim Gorbov, Iulianna Shambarova, Evgeny Ivanchenko
abstract: This paper presents the results of high-resolution measurements of the temporal dynamics in the vertical structure of seawater bio-optical properties, conducted using the autonomous moored profiling probe "Winchi". This unique underwater system enables automated, multiparametric oceanographic measurements within the upper 0–50-meter layer and transmits data via a mobile network in near real-time. The described field experiment was conducted in Vityaz Bay (Sea of Japan) over a period of approximately two weeks in June 2025. The high-resolution data obtained with this profiling system allowed for the analysis of multi-scale processes within the water column. The study primarily focuses on identifying and characterizing diurnal and quasi-inertial oscillations at various depths, as well as tracking changes in the vertical stratification of optically active constituents’ characteristics (phytoplankton through chlorophyll-a fluorescence, dissolved organic matter through corresponded fluorescence, and suspended particulate matter through turbidity). Furthermore, the system is highly valuable for collecting satellite validation (match-up) data and for aquaculture monitoring applications, particularly with the integration of additional sensors.

title: Design and Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Fusion Strategies for Detecting Deepfakes
authors: Pawan Jagannath Aru, Pratik Ishwardas Kolhe, Jaykumar Ashok Lokhande, Soma Niloy Ghosh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Deepfakes—synthetically manipulated videos or im- ages generated with advanced deep learning techniques—pose significant ethical, security, and privacy risks. To address these challenges, we propose a hybrid convolutional framework that integrates ResNet50, MobileNetV2, and EfficientNetB0 features, fused through a dropout-regularized classification head. Un- like prior single-backbone detectors, our approach leverages complementary feature representations to improve robustness against compression and visual distortions. Experiments on the Celeb-DF v2 benchmark demonstrate that the fusion model achieves 97.03 % accuracy with strong generalization, while Xception serves as a competitive baseline for comparison. The study further reproduces recent baselines, explores augmentation strategies, and outlines future directions including adversarial robustness and multi-modal fusion.

title: AI Against Smishing in Kenya: Culturally Adapted SMS Scam Detection for Digital Trust
authors: Japheth Kiplang’at Mursi, Salim Mwarika, Hamid Nach, Naomi Bukusi, Angel Musomba, Wangechi Murimi, Michelle Kiboi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Kenya’s mobile-financial ecosystem, driven by M-Pesa and a mobile penetration rate above 133%, has advanced commerce and financial inclusion but also exposed users to SMS-based scams exploiting linguistic diversity, cultural trust, and psychological manipulation. Existing fraud-reporting mechanisms such as keyword filtering and manual reporting, remain reactive and inadequate against these evolving threats. To fill this gap, this study develops a culturally adapted, machine learning–driven approach to SMS scam detection tailored to Kenya’s multilingual environment. Using a crowdsourced dataset of 738 SMS messages (427 scams, 311 legitimate), XGBoost achieved 83.8% accuracy with strong precision and F1-scores, while Logistic Regression offered superior recall (91.8%) in detecting fraudulent content. SHAP analysis revealed urgency cues, code-switching features, and social proof language as the most influential predictors of scams. The proposed model, designed for integration via APIs into USSD platforms, enables real-time detection and fosters user confidence through explainable alerts. This study provides a scalable, context-aware framework for fraud prevention in mobile-first economies and actionable insights for telecom operators, fintech platforms, and policymakers seeking to strengthen digital trust.

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Secure Hardware Verification and Analysis
authors: Yifang Zhao, Weimin Fu, Yi-Xiang Hu, Shijie Li, Xiaolong Guo, Yier Jin
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern system-on-chip development and its distributed design workflows introduces significant security challenges. However, traditional verification techniques face limitations in scalability and automation. Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) offer promising opportunities for automating hardware security verification. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of emerging research that applies LLMs to secure hardware design analysis. Through objective evaluation, we find that current LLM-driven approaches are often developed under overly simplified scenarios and demonstrate unstable performance across diverse hardware designs. To address these issues, we outline three key directions for future research: developing standardized security-oriented benchmarks, advancing domain-specific semantic reasoning capabilities, and facilitating tighter integration with verification tools. This study provides essential insights for building scalable and fully automated LLM-driven hardware security verification.

title: A Comparison of Large Language Models in a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) System for Machine Repair and Maintenance Prompts
authors: Shane Tikasingh, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: We constructed a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) system for industrial machine manuals to quantify the performance of various open-source Large Language Models (LLMs). Using technical manuals from a flour mill, textual data was extracted using MinerU. The data was processed using Natural Language Processing (NLP), embedded with "Qwen3-Embedding-0.6B" and entered into a PostgreSQL database using LangChain’s pgVector API. Our RAG pipeline integrated a tag extractor, three query expansion techniques (Multiquery, Decomposition, Step back) and one scoring algorithm (BM25), a PostgreSQL Database, a Reranker (mxbai-rerank-xsmall-v1), a Prompt template, and an LLM. We evaluated the BERTScore performance of five open-source LLMs (Gemma3:1B, Gemma3:4B, Llama3.1:8B, Llama3.2:1B, Llama3.2:3B) in this RAG pipeline. One key finding is that model performance is task-dependent: Llama3.1:8B excelled in precision, while Gemma3:4B excelled in recall. Smaller models can also outperform larger ones in specific cases—for example, Llama3.2:3B was more effective at identifying unanswerable questions, a crucial safety feature, and offered greater consistency, though with some trade-off in overall performance. This study provides a framework for selecting cost-effective, task-appropriate open-source LLMs in industrial applications and highlights the practical value of smaller parameter models, especially for compute-constrained businesses.

title: Advances in Unsupervised Relation Extraction for Big Data Analytics
authors: Ashwini Chandrakumaran
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Relation extraction is a fundamental task in Big Data Analytics, enabling the automatic discovery of meaningful relationships between entities in large-scale unstructured data. Traditional supervised approaches require extensive labeled data, which is often impractical given the exponential growth of information. This paper reviews recent and influential methods in Unsupervised Relation Extraction (URE), which leverage datadriven techniques to extract relations without labeled supervision. The study begins with an overview of relation extraction and its significance in Big Data Analytics, followed by a review of four major unsupervised approaches that have contributed to the field. The paper highlights key methodologies, challenges such as scalability, noise reduction, and domain adaptability, and insights gained from these approaches. Finally, we discuss the implications of URE for Big Data processing, knowledge graph construction, and automated information retrieval, offering perspectives on future research directions in large-scale relation extraction.

title: Countering Covert Timing Channels with Active Warden Delay Normalization Technique
authors: Vrushali U. Uttarwar, Dhananjay M. Dakhane
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Covert channels in computer networks, especially covert timing channels, pose a significant security risk by facilitating clandestine, unauthorized data transmission that circumvents conventional detection methods. This study introduces a comprehensive framework for assessing and mitigating covert channels through smart active warden mechanism that dynamically interferes with covert timing channels through delay normalization, protocol modifications, and real-time analysis.
