abstract: Deep Model Predictive Control (Deep MPC) is an evolving field that integrates model predictive control and deep learning. This manuscript is focused on a particular approach, which employs deep neural network in the loop with MPC. This class of approaches distributes control authority between a neural network and an MPC controller, in such a way that the neural network learns the model uncertainties while the MPC handles constraints. The approach is appealing because training data collected while the system is in operation can be used to fine-tune the neural network, and MPC prevents unsafe behavior during those learning transients. This manuscript explains implementation challenges of Deep MPC, algorithmic way to distribute control authority and argues that a poor choice in distributing control authority may lead to poor performance. A reason of poor performance is explained through a numerical experiment on a four-wheeled skid-steer dynamics.

title: Efficient UAV Trajectory Following through Data-Driven Modeling
authors: Abhishek Atrey, Ashish Gupta, P. M. Pathak, Bhanu Kumar Mishra
abstract: Nowadays, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are extensively applied in diverse fields, including surveillance, delivery, agriculture, mapping, and aerial photography. This study focuses on employing a data-driven control strategy for trajectory tracking in a quadrotor-type UAV, encompassing various trajectories such as circular and Lissajous types. The mathematical model of a quadrotor with an X-configuration is established using the Newton-Euler method. Simulations are conducted in MATLAB/Simulink to elucidate the quadrotor dynamics with data-driven control. The simulation results (obtained through analytical modelling) were refined through data-driven modelling, treating the quadcopter system as a black-box model to enhance trajectory-tracking accuracy. The application of data-driven modelling enhances trajectory tracking accuracy, showcasing the effectiveness of this technique.

title: Reducing computational complexity in convex control via partial feedback linearization for single-input single-output systems
authors: Danna Ruiz, David Vázquez, Miguel Bernal
abstract: This paper presents a novel methodology to reduce computational burden of convex control techniques in single-input single-output systems, which rapidly grows as the number of nonlinearities increase. The proposal is based on partial feedback linearization to transform the nonlinear system into another one via a properly chosen local diffeomorphism. The transformed system has fewer nonlinearities than the original and a stabilizing control law can be then calculated as a feed-forward term cancelling some nonlinearities plus a feedback nonlinear one mimicking parallel distributed compensation. Simulation examples put our proposal at test and provide comparisons on numerical complexity which help the reader to assess the contribution.

title: Eco-Friendly Biopolymers Shaping Sustainable Food Packaging
authors: T Saranya, P Shanmuga Priya, B Mohan, K Dhanees Surya Jenifer, J Relin Francis Raj, R Santhana Krishnan, S Mahalakshmi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Seaweeds have emerged as valuable resources in biotechnological applications, driven by their rich diversity of bioactive compounds. While their consumption dates back to ancient civilizations, recent advances in research have shed light on the mechanisms and vast potential of these compounds, facilitating their incorporation into food, cosmetic, pharmaceutical, and nutraceutical industries. Notably, macroalgae-derived polysaccharides, such as alginates and carrageenans, offer remarkable health benefits and are instrumental in developing biopolymeric films and biodegradable packaging materials. This innovation is particularly significant in addressing the growing environmental crisis caused by the widespread dispersion of plastics and microplastics in marine ecosystems, which adversely affect aquatic life and biodiversity. Seaweed-derived biopolymers represent a sustainable alternative to conventional plastics, enabling the replacement of harmful plasticizers with eco-friendly, biodegradable materials. Such advancements contribute to environmental preservation and support the global transition toward sustainable practices. This review explores the potential of seaweeds in bioplastic production, particularly for food and pharmaceutical packaging, and underscores their role in mitigating plastic pollution. By integrating seaweed biopolymers into various industries, we can achieve a balance between technological progress and environmental stewardship, paving the way for a cleaner and more sustainable future.

title: Multi-Stage Coupled Filter Implementation in Full-Duplex Wireless Power and Data Transfer System
authors: Hongwei Ye, Xin Jing, Xuan Wang, Zhihui Wang, Shuhan Zhou, Zhankun Feng
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: This paper proposes a simultaneous wireless power and data transfer system based on multi-level coupled filtering network. Using a multi-level coupled filtering network to form the receiving end for data on both sides can greatly reduce interference between the same side data source and the power transmission channel. Considering the impact of the power channel on the data channel, the first stage coupling filtering network at the data receiving end has a notch effect on the carrier frequency of the power channel, effectively ensuring the transmission of data. The second level coupled filtering network has a notch effect on the carrier frequency of the same side data source, reducing interference from the same side data source. By analyzing the transfer function of the data transmission channel, the expressions for SNR and gain are derived. Based on this, a method for designing a coupled filtering network is proposed. In addition, the interference between power and data transmission channels was analyzed, and methods for suppressing crosstalk were provided. The design of a full duplex system with a power of 57W, forward data transmission rate of 200kbps, and backward data transmission rate of 170kbps has been implemented, and the effectiveness of the proposed method has been verified through simulation.

title: Achieving Excellence Through Knowledge Management in the Public Sector
authors: Marah Hethnawi, Hafssa Yerrou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This study examines the substantial impact of knowledge management on organizational excellence in public service organizations in Palestine. To address an existing research gap in this sector in developing countries, the study applied a quantitative approach to a sample of 220 employees at senior management levels. The data were collected by questionnaire and analyzed using SPSS with Spearman correlation. The results demonstrated a strong positive correlation between all dimensions of knowledge management and organizational excellence. This paper makes a new contribution by providing practical tactics for decision makers to effectively implement knowledge management, achieve excellence, and deliver high-quality services in the public sector, emphasizing the role of technology as a critical enabler.

title: Short Text Topic Recognition Based on Contrastive Learning and Large Language Models
authors: Mingkun Yuan, Junxiu An
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Short text topic recognition, as an important research field in natural language processing, has problems such as insufficient semantic expression of texts and ambiguity in the topic clusters that edge texts belong to. Based on this, this paper proposes a short text topic recognition model (CCLTE) based on contrastive learning and LLMs. Firstly, the semantic vectors of the original text and the keywords extracted by LLMs are concatenated; then, the edge texts with rich semantic value are screened out from the MLP clustering results, and positive and negative sample pairs are generated by combining LLMs, and unsupervised contrastive learning is introduced to optimize the sentence pre-training model; finally, LLMs are used to discriminate anomalies of edge samples, and TF-IDF is used to extract cluster topic features. In experiments on 4 text datasets, the model's average performance in terms of topic coherence (TC) and topic diversity (TD) is 9.62 % and 4.59 % higher than that of the suboptimal model, respectively. This indicates that CCLTE significantly improves the accuracy and robustness of short text topic recognition through the mechanism of multi-stage assistance from LLMs and contrastive learning.

title: A Varying-Parameter Neural Dynamics for Lyapunov Equation with its Kinematic Robot Application
authors: Ying Kong, Yuanshao Sun, Junjie Hao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: To calculate the time-varying Lyapunov equation (TVLE), a varying-parameter neural dynamics (termed as VPND) is presented and analyzed. We specifically address the Stability of VPND, robustness against various disturbances and super-exponential convergent performance. The presented neural formula employs a super-exponential convergent speed and the strong tolerance for undesired noises. Comparisons for solving time-varying Lyapunov equation are carried out and substantiates the effectiveness of the proposed VPND model. Simulative examples on manipulators are conducted for the validity of the proposed method.

title: The AEP for Hidden Markov Tree Models
authors: Zhiyan Shi, Fan Xie, Bao Wang, Weiguo Yang
abstract: The asymptotic equipartition property (AEP) plays an important role in establishing lossless source coding theorems and asymptotic coding theorems through the concepts of typical sets and typical sequences in information theory. In this paper, we shall study the strong law of large numbers and the AEP for hidden Markov tree models. First, we give a strict definition of hidden Markov tree models, and study their key properties and equivalent characterizations. In fact, hidden Markov tree models are closely related to the tree-indexed Markov chains, therefore, we also introduce the definition of tree-indexed Markov chains and their equivalent properties. We also establish a strong law of large numbers for hidden Markov tree models indexed by a Cayley tree. As corollaries, we obtain some strong laws of large numbers for the parameters and the AEP for these models.

title: Smart LPG Monitoring and Safety System Using IoT for Real-Time Refill and Leak Detection
authors: Yazhini S, Suthiksha V N, Tarunika S P, Sriram V, Yavanapriya R, Subiksha K P
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The rise of smart home systems has underscored the need for intelligent safety and resource monitoring solutions. This work focuses on real-time LPG cylinder management through an IoT-enabled embedded system. Traditional LPG monitoring relies on manual checks, often resulting in unexpected depletion and unsafe conditions during leaks. These shortcomings highlight the need for automation in both tracking and safety response. Conventional systems either lack automation or do not integrate both weight monitoring and gas leak detection. They often depend on user intervention or fail to take immediate safety actions. To address these limitations, a PIC16F877A-based system is proposed, combining a load cell and MQ6 gas sensor with a GSM module. The system automates refill alerts, leak detection, and initiates safety actions such as shut-off and ventilation. Simulation and hardware testing validated real-time leak detection within 2 seconds and refill alerts when gas dropped below 30 %. Realtime LCD display output such as “G: 28.45” and “L: -2” confirmed accurate monitoring. The system was implemented using Proteus for simulation and assembled on a PCB for realtime hardware evaluation. The GSM module and solenoid valve were tested under live conditions. Experimental results show that refill alerts were sent within 2.5 seconds and leak alerts within 3.1 seconds. The power supply delivered stable voltages: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5. 0 2 V}$</tex> (microcontroller) and 12.10 V (GSM module). In conclusion, the proposed system improves safety, eliminates manual tracking, and enables timely refill scheduling. It is highly suitable for domestic use and scalable for commercial LPG management.

title: HQSI: Hybrid Quantum Swarm Intelligence – A Case Study of Online Certificate Status Protocol Request Flow Prediction
authors: Abel C. H. Chen
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: As quantum computing technology continues to advance, various sectors, including industry, government, academia, and research, have increasingly focused on its future applications. With the integration of artificial intelligence techniques, multiple Quantum Neural Network (QNN) models have been proposed, including quantum convolutional neural networks, quantum long short-term memory networks, and quantum generative adversarial networks. Furthermore, optimization methods such as constrained optimization by linear approximation and simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation have been explored. Therefore, this study proposes Hybrid Quantum Swarm Intelligence (HQSI), which constructs a QNN model as a forward propagation neural network. After measuring quantum states and obtaining prediction results, a classical computer-based swarm intelligence algorithm is employed for weight optimization. The training process iterates between quantum and classical computing environments. During the experimental phase, the proposed HQSI method is evaluated using an online certificate status protocol request traffic prediction task. Comparative analysis against state-of-the-art quantum optimization algorithms demonstrates that the proposed HQSI approach achieves more than a 50% reduction in error.

title: Real-Time Fraud Detection in Online Transactions Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Nikita Motwani, Rancel Rana, Sailee Jadhav, Yash Karia, Suresh B. Pathare
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Online financial fraud is a rapidly growing threat to security and trust in the digital landscape. This study performs a comparison of four well known machine learning classification algorithms—Logistic Regression, Naive Bayes, K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), and Support Vector Machine (SVM)—to assess their ability to detect fraudulent online transactions with high accuracy. We used a synthetic dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> transactions, to investigated the most crucial variables for fraud detection, including transaction amount, device type, location, risk score, and history of fraud. Following data preprocessing, our analysis found that SVM was the most effective model, achieving a detection accuracy of 97.82 %. We identified Failed Transaction Count and Risk Score as the primary indicators of fraudulent activity. Transactions with high-risk scores and many failed attempts were strong signs of fraud. Fraud also tended to come from certain types of merchants and places. This study shows how powerful machine learning can be, especially SVM, for finding fraud in real time. This can make financial systems much safer. Future research will entail the evaluation of more resilient deep learning techniques and the adaptation to emerging fraud trends.

title: Design and Analysis of Active Suspension Systems for Automotive Vehicles Using PID and Root Locus Controller
authors: R. Dhanasekar, K. Kumaresan, T. Rajavenkatesan, Sudhir Kumar V, S. P. Gowtham, Vaishnavi M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The active suspension system serves as the link between the vehicle's chassis and the rest of its structure, playing a key role in both ride comfort and handling. This study presents a method for designing a digital control unit for an active suspension setup using a quarter-car model, which simplifies the problem into a one-dimensional system made up of several springs and dampers representing one wheel out of four. The system uses PID and root locus control techniques to actively manage suspension behaviour. Although the method is straightforward and relatively new, the focus of this work is on the engineering aspects, including the design, development, and implementation of the experimental setup and control system. A nonlinear damping surface is introduced to help the vertical velocity of the vehicle converge quickly, effectively modifying how the system absorbs vibrations. The influence of the selected sliding surface on the system's behavior is also explored. The validation process has been completed successfully, and the findings demonstrate that the active suspension improves ride comfort significantly–reducing the vibration of the sprung mass by 20.8%. Additionally, the Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) method was applied to this quarter-car active suspension model. Details of the system design, analysis, and experimental results are also discussed. By incorporating PID and root locus control strategies, the active suspension enhances vehicle stability, safety, and driver control by minimizing the wheel movement caused by road irregularities.

title: Kronecker Powers, Orthogonal Vectors, and the Asymptotic Spectrum
authors: Josh Alman, Baitian Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We study circuits for computing linear transforms defined by Kronecker power matrices. The best-known (unbounded-depth) circuits, including the widely-applied fast Walsh-Hadamard transform and Yates’ algorithm, can be derived from the best-known depth- 2 circuits using known constructions, so we focus particularly on the depth- 2 case. Recent work [Jukna and Sergeev’13; Alman, STOC’21; Alman, Guan and Padaki, SODA’23; Sergeev’22] has improved on decades-old constructions in this area using a new rebalancing approach, but it was unclear how to apply this approach optimally, and the previous versions had complicated technical requirements.We find that Strassen’s theory of asymptotic spectra can be applied to capture the design of these circuits. This theory was designed to generalize the known techniques behind matrix multiplication algorithms as well as a variety of other algorithms with recursive structure, and it brings a number of new tools to use for designing depth- 2 circuits. In particular, in hindsight, we find that the techniques of recent work on rebalancing were proving special cases of the duality theorem which is central to Strassen’s theory. We carefully outline a collection of obstructions to designing small depth- 2 circuits using a rebalancing approach, and apply Strassen’s theory to show that our obstructions are complete.Using this connection, combined with other algorithmic techniques (including matrix rigidity upper bounds, constant-weight binary codes, and a “hole-fixing lemma” from recent matrix multiplication algorithms), we give new improved circuit constructions as well as other applications, including:•The $N \times N$ disjointness matrix has a depth-2 linear circuit of size $O\left(N^{1.2495}\right)$ over any field. This is the first construction which surpasses exponent 1.25, and thus yields smaller circuits for many families of matrices using reductions to disjointness, including all Kronecker products of $2 \times 2$ matrices, without using matrix rigidity upper bounds.•Barriers to further improvements, including that the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis implies an $N^{1+\Omega(1)}$ size lower bound for depth-2 linear circuits computing the WalshHadamard transform (and the disjointness matrix with a technical caveat), and that proving such a $N^{1+\Omega(1)}$ depth2 size lower bound would imply breakthrough threshold circuit lower bounds.•The Orthogonal Vectors (OV) problem in moderate dimension d can be solved in deterministic time $\tilde{O}\left(n \cdot 1.155^{d}\right)$, derandomizing an algorithm of Nederlof and Wegrzycki [STOC’21], and the counting problem can be solved in time $\tilde{O}\left(n \cdot 1.26^{d}\right)$, improving an algorithm of Williams [FOCS’24] which runs in time $\tilde{O}\left(n \cdot 1.35^{d}\right)$. We design these new algorithms by noticing that prior algorithms for OV can be viewed as corresponding to depth- 2 circuits for the disjointness matrix, then using our framework for further improvements.

title:
The Power of Recursive Embeddings for ℓ
                    <sub>p</sub>
                    Metrics
authors: Robert Krauthgamer, Nir Petruschka, Shay Sapir
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Metric embedding is a powerful tool used extensively in mathematics and computer science. We devise a new method of using metric embeddings recursively, which turns out to be particularly effective in $\ell_{p}$ spaces, $p \lt 2$, yielding state-of-theart results for Lipschitz decomposition, for Nearest Neighbor Search, and for embedding into $\ell_{2}$. In a nutshell, our method composes metric embeddings by viewing them as reductions between problems, and thereby obtains a new reduction that is substantially more effective than the known reduction that employs a single embedding. We in fact apply this method recursively, oftentimes using double recursion, which further amplifies the gap from a single embedding. Index Terms-Metric Embedding, Lipschitz Decomposition, Nearest Neighbor Search, $\ell_{p}$ norm

title: RE-completeness of entangled constraint satisfaction problems
authors: Eric Culf, Kieran Mastel
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs) are a natural class of decision problems where one must decide whether there is an assignment to variables that satisfies a given formula. Schaefer’s dichotomy theorem, and its extension to all alphabets due to Bulatov and Zhuk, shows that CSP languages are either efficiently decidable, or NP-complete. It is possible to extend CSP languages to quantum assignments using the formalism of nonlocal games. Due to the equality of complexity classes MIP* = RE, general succinctly-presented entangled CSPs are RE-complete. In this work, we show that a wide range of NP-complete CSPs become RE-complete in this setting, including all boolean CSPs, such as 3SAT, as well as 3-colouring. This also implies that these CSP languages remain undecidable even when not succinctly presented.To show this, we work in the weighted algebra framework introduced by Mastel and Slofstra, where synchronous strategies for a nonlocal game are represented by tracial states on an algebra. Along the way, we improve the subdivision technique in order to be able to separate constraints in the CSP while preserving constant soundness, construct commutativity gadgets for all boolean CSPs, and show a variety of relations between the different ways of presenting CSPs as games.

title: A Polynomial Space Lower Bound for Diameter Estimation in Dynamic Streams
authors: Sanjeev Khanna, Ashwin Padaki, Krish Singal, Erik Waingarten
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We study the space complexity of estimating the diameter of a subset of points in an arbitrary metric space in the dynamic (turnstile) streaming model. The input is given as a stream of updates to a frequency vector $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}^{n}$, where the support of x defines a multiset of points in a fixed metric space $\mathcal{M}=([n], \mathrm{d})$. The goal is to estimate the diameter of this multiset, defined as max $\left\{\mathrm{d}(i, j): x_{i}, x_{j} \gt \right. 0\}$, to a specified approximation factor while using as little space as possible. In insertion-only streams, a simple $O(\log n)$-space algorithm achieves a $\mathbf{2}$-approximation. In sharp contrast to this, we show that in the dynamic streaming model, any algorithm achieving a constant-factor approximation to diameter requires polynomial space. Specifically, we prove that a c-approximation to the diameter requires $n^{\Omega(1 / c)}$ space. Our lower bound relies on two conceptual contributions: (1) a new connection between dynamic streaming algorithms and linear sketches for scale-invariant functions, a class that includes diameter estimation, and (2) a connection between linear sketches for diameter and the minrank of graphs, a notion previously studied in index coding. We complement our lower bound with a nearly matching upper bound, which gives a c-approximation to the diameter in general metrics using $n^{O(1 / c)}$ space.

title:
Root Ridge Leverage Score Sampling for ℓ
                    <sub>p</sub>
                    Subspace Approximation
authors: David P. Woodruff, Taisuke Yasuda
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: The ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> subspace approximation problem is an NP-hard low rank approximation problem that generalizes the median hyperplane problem (p = 1), principal component analysis (p = 2), and the center hyperplane problem (p = ∞). A popular approach to cope with the NP-hardness of this problem is to compute a strong coreset, which is a small weighted subset of the input points which simultaneously approximates the cost of every k-dimensional subspace, typically to (1 + ε) relative error for a small constant ε.We obtain an algorithm for constructing a strong coreset for ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> subspace approximation of size $\tilde O\left( {k{\varepsilon ^{ - 4/p}}} \right)$ for p < 2 and $\tilde O\left( {{k^{p/2}}{\varepsilon ^{ - p}}} \right)$ for p > 2. This offers the following improvements over prior work:•We construct the first strong coresets with nearly optimal dependence on k for all p≠ 2. In prior work, [1] constructed coresets of modified points with a similar dependence on k, while [2] constructed true coresets with polynomially worse dependence on k.•We recover or improve the best known ε dependence for all p. In particular, for p > 2, the [1] coreset of modified points had a dependence of ${\varepsilon ^{ - {p^2}/2}}$ and the [2] coreset had a dependence of ε<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3p</sup>.Our algorithm is based on sampling by root ridge leverage scores, which admits fast algorithms, especially for sparse or structured matrices. Our analysis completely avoids the use of the representative subspace theorem [1], which is a critical component of all prior dimension-independent coresets for ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> subspace approximation.Our techniques also lead to the first nearly optimal online strong coresets for ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> subspace approximation with similar bounds as the offline setting, resolving a problem of [3]. All prior approaches lose poly(k) factors in this setting, even when allowed to modify the original points.

title: The Quasi-Polynomial Low-Degree Conjecture is False
authors: Rares-Darius Buhai, Jun-Ting Hsieh, Aayush Jain, Pravesh K. Kothari
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: There is a growing body of work on proving hardness results for average-case estimation problems by bounding the low-degree advantage (LDA) — a quantitative estimate of the closeness of low-degree moments — between a null distribution and a related planted distribution. Such hardness results are now ubiquitous not only for foundational average-case problems but also central questions in statistics and cryptography. This line of work is supported by the low-degree conjecture of Hopkins [1], which postulates that a vanishing degree-D LDA implies the absence of any noise-tolerant distinguishing algorithm with runtime ${n^{\tilde {\mathcal{O}}(D)}}$ whenever 1) the null distribution is product on ${\{ 0,1\} ^{\binom{n}{k}}}$, and 2) the planted distribution is permutation invariant, that is, invariant under any relabeling [n] → [n].In this paper, we disprove this conjecture. Specifically, we show that for any fixed ε > 0 and k ⩾ 2, there is a permutation-invariant planted distribution on ${\{ 0,1\} ^{\binom{n}{k}}}$ that has a vanishing degree-n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1−O(ε)</sup> LDA with respect to the uniform distribution on ${\{ 0,1\} ^{\binom{n}{k}}}$, yet the corresponding ε-noisy distinguishing problem can be solved in ${n^{O\left( {{{\log }^{1/(k - 1)}}(n)} \right)}}$ time. Our construction relies on algorithms for list-decoding for noisy polynomial interpolation in the high-error regime.We also give another construction of a pair of planted and (non-product) null distributions on ℝ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">n×n</sup> with a vanishing n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Ω(1)</sup>-degree LDA while the largest eigenvalue serves as an efficient noise-tolerant distinguisher.Our results suggest that while a vanishing LDA may still be interpreted as evidence of hardness, developing a theory of average-case complexity based on such heuristics requires a more careful approach.

title: Faculty Retention in Private Universities of Pune: a Factor Analysis
authors: Sandesh M. Bansode, Vijay Kulkarni
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Faculty turnover is a very pivotal question mark concerning the performance, sustenance, and academic quality of higher education establishments. This paper examines and reports on principal variables of faculty retention in private universities in Pune with special reference to job satisfaction, organisation culture and career growth. Although the growth in the field of education in India has been experiencing a booming trend, particularly, in areas such as Pune, the problem of faculty turnover is not going to go away. The research examines the institutional reports, accreditation feedback, HR analytics, and past literature whereby patterns that influence faculty stability can be revealed through a secondary data-driven approach. The University discovers that job satisfaction, including its elements of liberty, recognition, balance of workloads, and support by peers, is a prominent factor in influencing the results of retention. Indirectly in a similar way, the faculty commitment is influenced by the organizational culture which manifests itself in the leadership models, shared values, and decision-making procedures. Retention intentions are also reinforced by career growth in the form of mentorship, promotion as well as research opportunities. The study is based on the work of One-Factor Theory by Herzberg and Organizational Support Theory to support the conceptualisation. The results are expected to inform the work of educational policymakers and university administrators who are to work out the appropriate measures to achieve alignment between institutional practices and faculty expectations to increase the long-term retention. The paper provides a small contribution to a small body of literature on the pioneering region and highlight the requirement of contextsensitive retention policy in the higher education sector in the state of Pune, which is in the sphere of the private higher educational institutions.

title: Flux Characteristics Analysis of Novel Tubular Permanent Magnet Linear Launcher
authors: Xing Wang, Hao Chen, Hossein Torkaman, Xiaodong Li, Ryszard Palka, Jason Gu, Quoc Vuong Dang, Vu Thanh Nguyen, Abror Abidovich Pulatov, Murat Fikhratovich Shamiyev
abstract: This article analyzes the flux characteristics of a novel tubular permanent magnet linear launcher (TPMLL) with short stroke and high-frequency motion characteristics, suitable for application in the electromagnetic launcher. In this article, the proposed TPMLL consists of the following parts: the outer stator, outer air gap, mover made of permanent magnets (PMs), inner air gap, and the inner stator. A magnetic equivalent circuit (MEC) method is established to analyze the electromagnetic characteristics and provide the basis for the structural design. To solve the MEC model, the Newton–Raphson method is adopted. By comparing the results of the finite element method (FEM) with the MEC model, it is found that the accuracy of MEC method has good accuracy in estimating the flux linkage of the proposed motor, which is very suitable to be used in the initial stage of the structural design.

title: A Multivocal Literature Review on the Effectiveness of Security Threat Modeling
authors: Anh-Duy Tran, Stef Verreydt, Koen Yskout, Wouter Joosen
abstract:
The growing need for integrating security through out the software development lifecycle leads to the adoption of various security activities. Threat modeling is widely recognized as a process that helps assess security issues, especially architectural flaws, due to insecure design, thereby supporting the security-by-design mindset. While many research and industry sources advocate for threat modeling, others highlight issues such as the lack of motivation, its time-consuming nature, and practical difficulties, leading to questions about its overall effectiveness.

In this study, we conduct a comprehensive multivocal literature review to systematically examine the empirical evidence for the effectiveness of threat modeling. In short, by analyzing 109 sources from both white and gray literature, we did not encounter any direct, causal evidence (e.g., a controlled experiment) for the effectiveness of threat modeling as a technique to improve the security of a software application. This absence of causal evidence should not be interpreted as evidence that threat modeling is ineffective, though. The existing literature does describe several benefits and challenges related to threat modeling, as well as suggestions for improving the effectiveness of threat modeling activities. Studies on threat modeling often concentrate on benefits such as improved performance, effectiveness, efficiency, and usability of specific tools and methods. Recurring challenges, on the other hand, include a perceived lack of benefits, tool limitations, usability issues, and difficulties integrating threat modeling into the secure software development lifecycle. Suggestions for improvements include providing clear checklists or guidance, defining a clear scope, and involving different stakeholders during threat modeling activities.

Based on this review of the literature, researchers are invited to conduct rigorous empirical studies to address the underexplored aspects of threat modeling, thereby strengthening its evidence base and increasing its impact in the real world.

title: Efficient 3D Inversion for Transient Electromagnetic Method Based on Rational Krylov Subspace
authors: Yan Dong, Jingyu Gao, Handong Tan, Changhong Lin, Weilong Li, Chenyu Wang, Jie Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Conventional three-dimensional (3D) inversion algorithms for the transient electromagnetic method (TEM) require time-domain discretization in both forward and adjoint modeling. These algorithms start from the initial time and compute the electric field iteratively at each new time step, which involve repeatedly solving large-scale systems of linear equations and thus cause a substantial computational cost. In contrast, the Krylov subspace-based model order reduction technique computes the 3D time-domain electromagnetic response with just a one-time reduction process, allowing for the electric field at any time to be obtained by solving only a small-scale matrix exponential problem, significantly improving the efficiency of forward modeling. However, this approach has not yet been widely utilized in 3D TEM inversion. In this study, the rational Krylov subspace-based model order reduction technique is applied to both forward and adjoint modeling. The data misfit residuals at each observation time channel are treated as virtual sources for the adjoint problem, enabling the use of the rational Krylov subspace method to solve the corresponding adjoint field. The gradient is evaluated using results from both the forward and adjoint modeling, and the model is updated via the L-BFGS method. Throughout the gradient calculation, only two matrix factorizations and a limited number of backward substitutions for right-hand sides are required in total for all necessary forward and adjoint modeling, which substantially reduces the computation burden. The proposed algorithm is validated using synthetic data. Results show that the presented 3D TEM inversion algorithm using the rational Krylov subspace technique achieves satisfactory inversion accuracy while significantly improving computational efficiency compared to inversion methods that employ conventional time-stepping approaches. Therefore, this work can provide valuable insights for further application of rational Krylov subspace methods in TEM data inversion.

title: Retraction Notice: Ambiguity in Cloud Security with Malware-Injection Attack
authors: Iva Ranjan, Ram Bhushan Agnihotri

title: Controller for Incremental Input-to-State Practical Stabilization of Partially Unknown Systems with Invariance Guarantees
authors: P Sangeerth, David Smith Sundarsingh, Bhabani Shankar Dey, Pushpak Jagtap
abstract: Incremental stability is a property of dynamical systems that ensures the convergence of trajectories with respect to each other rather than a fixed equilibrium point or a fixed trajectory. In this paper, we introduce a related stability notion called incremental input-to-state practical stability (δ-ISpS), ensuring safety guarantees. We also present a feedback linearization based control design scheme that renders a partially unknown system incrementally input-to-state practically stable and safe with formal guarantees. To deal with the unknown dynamics, we utilize Gaussian process regression to approximate the model. Finally, we implement the controller synthesized by the proposed scheme on a manipulator example.

title: Estimating Urban Electricity Consumption Using the Correlation Between Nighttime Light (NTL) Satellite Imagery and Actual Consumption Data Across Different Tariffs
authors: Fatemeh Ahmadi, MahmodReza Sahebi, Abbas Kiani, Alireza Fereiduninan
abstract: Electricity consumption is a fundamental energy metric and an important indicator of urban and economic development. Remote sensing satellites allow continuous observation of the Earth's surface. Nighttime light (NTL) imagery captures artificial illumination emitted from the Earth's surface due to human activities. In this study, the Pearson correlation coefficient between actual electricity consumption across different tariffs and the total pixel values of NTL imagery at the provincial level over five years was computed, revealing an average correlation of 0.946. Subsequently, based on the established linear relationship, a first-order regression model was employed to estimate provincial electricity consumption for various tariff types. Relative to the truth data, the estimation for the total electricity consumption tariff exhibited the highest accuracy, achieving a coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.912, RMSE of 0.11 and a SMAPE of 61.15%. The findings indicate that, NTL data reliably indicate urban electricity consumption due to their strong correlation with actual usage.

title: Optimizing Construction Site Resources Under Uncertainty Through Stochastic Simulation and Advanced Scheduling Techniques
authors: Chen Liu, Haoqian Du, Yixiao Ren, Aquil Mirza Mohammed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Resource management in construction sites, particularly regarding parking and auxiliary facilities, faces increasing complexity due to unpredictable demands and operational constraints. Despite existing scheduling techniques, their effectiveness remains limited in dynamic environments, highlighting a critical research gap. This study aims to evaluate and optimize resource allocation through advanced stochastic simulation models and scheduling algorithms, including First-Come-First-Serve (FCFS), Priority-based (PRIO), Optimized (OPTI), and Integer Linear Programming (ILP), to enhance utilization and reduce delays. Using a comprehensive simulation framework, combined with real-world-like data generated via large language models and stochastic modeling, we tested these algorithms across various scenarios. Quantitative results reveal that, in peak demand situations, the ILP algorithm outperforms others by achieving up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 4. 9 \%}$</tex> parking utilization and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 1. 9 \%}$</tex> equipment utilization, representing a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 - 2 5 \%}$</tex> improvement over FCFS and PRIO. Conversely, OPTI demonstrated superior equipment utilization-up to 89 %-but with a trade-off of higher rejection rates, averaging <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5-7 \%$</tex>, compared to under 2 % for ILP. When tested on more randomized datasets, ILP consistently provided the highest parking utilization (up to 70 %), while OPTI optimized equipment use. The findings underscore that while ILP and OPTI significantly outperform traditional scheduling methods-enhancing utilization by approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 - 2 5 \%}$</tex>-they also increase rejection rates, aligning with the NO FREE LUNCH theorem. Notably, ILP prioritizes parking utilization, whereas OPTI balances between parking and equipment efficiency. These insights offer robust, quantifiable strategies for construction site resource management, facilitating improved operational efficiency, minimized delays, and better resource utilization.

title: Adaptive Observer-Based State and Parameter Estimation for Two-Level Quantum Systems Using Dynamic Regressor Extension and Mixing
authors: Eram Taslima, Shyam Kamal, R. K. Saket
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive observer-based framework for the simultaneous state and parameter estimation of a closed two-level quantum system governed by the Liouville–von Neumann equation. The system, driven by an external laser field with unknown atom-field coupling strength, is reformulated in the Bloch sphere representation, wherein the nonlinear dynamics of the spin variables are described. To estimate the unmeasured internal states and the unknown coupling parameter, we propose a cascaded strategy combining a nonlinear adaptive observer with the Dynamic Regressor Extension and Mixing (DREM) technique. The observer reconstructs the full Bloch vector from partial measurement (population difference), and the resulting regressors enable a scalar DREM formulation for the unknown parameter. Unlike traditional gradient-based identification, the DREM-based update ensures improved noise robustness and accelerated convergence even for scalar parameters. Numerical simulations confirm the accuracy and robustness of the proposed estimation strategy, demonstrating effective reconstruction of both the quantum state and the Hamiltonian parameter under realistic noisy measurements.

title: Development of a Marathi Paraphrasing System Using POS Tagging and Synonym-Based Techniques
authors: Sheetal R. Dehare, Aarti P. Raut, C. Namrata Mahender
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Paraphrasing, the process of re-expressing text using different vocabulary and structures, plays a crucial role in various NLP tasks such as Summarization, Translation, and Question Answering. Especially in morphologically rich languages like Marathi, accurate paraphrasing requires a deep understanding of grammatical structures, supported by tools such as Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging. Although Paraphrasing research is extensively done for languages like English, French etc., Marathi remains underexplored due to its complex Morphology and limited linguistic resources. Efforts have mostly relied on rule-based approaches and synonym dictionaries, with recent tools like stanza improving POS tagging and morphological analysis. In NLP, paraphrasing involves three key tasks: generation, identification, and extraction, each enhancing system flexibility and human-like understanding. Techniques such as Transformation Paraphrasing and Synonym Replacement are crucial, where sentences are rewritten either by altering structure or substituting words without altering semantics. The proposed methodology for Marathi Paraphrasing involves systematic steps-extracting sentences from textbooks, POS tagging, identifying keywords, generating a dynamic synonym dictionary, performing semantic validation, and creating multiple paraphrased variants. A manually curated dataset is built, validated through semantic checks, ensuring grammatical correctness and preservation of meaning. Special attention is given to sentence transformation and synonym substitution, with semantic validation ensuring that paraphrasing maintains the intended context without distortion. This comprehensive approach not only enriches linguistic datasets for Marathi but also significantly supports broader NLP tasks for low-resource languages.

title: Transmission Side PI Control Based on Wireless Power and Data Simultaneous Transmission Technology
authors: Dai Xin, Feng Zhakun, Li Junfeng, Gao Wenhao, Chen Zhujun, Yin Yangkang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: In order to better handle the communication problems of wireless power transmission systems, a method of using OFDM technology for communication between the transmitting and receiving sides of the system is proposed, which solves the communication delay between the transmitting and receiving sides of traditional methods and can achieve better real-time control. And a method for identifying model structure and estimating model parameters based on experimental data was proposed. More precisely, estimating unknown model parameters using sampled input-output data. On this basis, using OFDM technology, a passive proportional integral control was designed to improve the system’s resistance to rapidly changing coupling coefficients. Finally, the experimental results demonstrate the performance and robustness of this method for wireless power system.

title: Survey of Underwater Pipelines by an Autonomous Unmanned Vehicle Using Stereo Camera-Based Recognition of Characteristic Technological Elements
authors: Valeriy Bobkov, Antonina Shupikova, Alexander Inzartsev, Alexander Pavin
abstract: The report addresses the problem of underwater pipeline (UP) inspection using an autonomous unmanned underwater vehicle (AUV). A technology is proposed for automatic UP inspection without navigational support from a surface vessel. In such cases, the support vessel may either:•be entirely absent; or•be present but, if lacking access to satellite navigation, determine its position relative to the AUV.Under these conditions, autonomous AUV navigation is carried out through onboard processing of optical and hydroacoustic images.The proposed technology relies on a method developed by the authors for recognizing characteristic technological elements (CTEs), which are regularly positioned along the communication line. In the case of UPs, anode protection devices are proposed as the CTEs. Since the coordinates of the CTEs are well known, their regular detection enables correction of the AUV's onboard navigation data. The report presents a CTE recognition method based on optical images, which includes:•an algorithm for tracking the UP by calculating its centerline;•an algorithm for direct detection of CTEs and evaluation of their condition (intact or destroyed) using a 3D point cloud derived from its geometric shape.Testing on both model and actual data demonstrated the promising potential of the method and the applicability of the proposed technology.

title: Joint Space Piecewise Path Smoothing Method for a 6-DOF Parallel Robot
authors: Ruiheng Dong, Haitao Liu, Yunpeng Liu, Hongye Wu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper presents a joint space piecewise path smoothing method for a 6-DOF (degrees of freedom) parallel robot to eliminate geometric errors in the traditional interpolation path smoothing method. The approach first converts input discrete workspace points to joint space via inverse kinematics, so that it avoids parameter synchronization, then divides the points into substages (subpaths and transition paths) prone to generating large geometric errors. Each substage uses B-spline interpolation with boundary constraints, which enables more constraints to reduces geometric errors, and all substages are consolidated into an integral B-spline curve in sequence. Simulation results show that the method effectively generates a smooth path via discrete points without parameter synchronization and reduces geometric errors, verifying its feasibility in mitigating path deviation and generating a smooth path.

title: Optimization-Oriented Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Large-Scale Document Understanding
authors: Yuepeng Zhang, Jiayi Zeng, Jiayi Wang, Yang Gao, Wenqing Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Signal Processing (ICGSP)
abstract: Large language models have made significant strides in natural language processing but still struggle with factual accuracy and domain-specific knowledge retrieval. To address these limitations, Retrieval-Augmented Generation frameworks integrate information retrieval mechanisms with generative models to enhance response relevance and precision. In this paper, we propose an optimization-oriented RAG system for large-scale document understanding, which combines FAISSbased retrieval with multi-model generation architecture to improve retrieval accuracy, response consistency, and crossdomain adaptability. Our approach features advanced metadatarich embedding pipelines, adaptive text tiling, and multi-model integration for response optimization. We used two large-scale datasets to evaluate our system: an ArXiv-based scientific corpus and a domain-specific EV dataset. Experimental results show that our implementation is superior to the traditional RAG system in terms of retrieval efficiency, response quality, and domain adaptability. By introducing dynamic model scheduling and weighted answer aggregation, our system provides a scalable, high-performance solution for knowledge-intensive applications, including academic research and technical document analysis.

title: Intelligent Data Modelling and Predictive Statistical Evaluation of Postpartum Nutrition and Herbal Product Preferences: Evidence From a Pan-India Multi-Regional Survey
authors: Mahak Bhandari, Mohammed Shabab, Kavita Madipalli, Prasanna Bhalerao, Nawneet Kumar Kurrey
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: The study analyzes postpartum nutrition in various Indian settings and examines the use of herbal products, which represents a gap in nutritional science and health management. Researchers use intelligent data modeling and large data analytics to study the diets of postnatal women across various regions. A multi-regional survey provides robust statistical data for evaluation, while predictive statistical algorithms pinpoint nutritional trends and preferences. The community that was under research is highly inclined towards the use of some herbal products, and the result shows how traditional medicine is culturally relevant. Researchers are conducting an assessment of how socio-cultural situations influence dietary selection in the postpartum period. There is a need to have culturally sensitive and personalized nutritional therapies that consider advanced statistical models to estimate regional and socioeconomic differences. The socioeconomic background and access to healthcare affect food preferences after childbirth, where lower economic groups prefer more herbal supplements because of the lack of mainstream healthcare. The survey data depicts the demographic factor in postpartum dietary habits and disparities in health education and resource availability throughout India. A relationship can be observed between nutrition education and culturally appropriate diets, as portrayed by the journal cover of dietary management for chronic renal disease. As this abstract recommends, policymakers and health practitioners ought to incorporate indigenous knowledge systems in healthcare systems to meet the specific postpartum nutritional needs of women. The outcomes are expected to enhance both the mother's and child's health in India because of the diverse demographic needs and preferences. The present study is valuable to the literature on nutrition, health diversity competencies, and modern and traditional diets. The multiregional survey findings can be extended to future research on the nutritional requirements of postpartum women in different situations in society using herbal products.

title: Beyond Closing Prices: Improving Stock Price Prediction Models Using External Variables
authors: Daruri Kaustubh, Gigil James, Sanil Mishra, Amit Praseed
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Stock price prediction has garnered considerable attention in the past few years, largely due to the advancements in machine learning algorithms. However, most of the existing research use historical values of the closing price (CP) and trading volume (V) to predict future stock prices. There has been research indicating the influence of external variables such as oil and gas prices, and exchange rates on the stock market. However, research in direction has been scarce. In this work, we attempt to use external variables such as oil price, gas price and exchange rates in addition to historical values of closing price and volume traded, for predicting future stock prices. The research is carried out in an Indian context, by considering two popular Indian stocks. Experiments conducted suggest the usefulness of external variables for predicting future stock prices if the variables used have a moderate correlation with the stock prices. The inclusion of multiple external factors seems to improve system performance only if the variables themselves are not highly correlated with each other.

title: Battery Cycle Life Prediction Using Policy-Based Feature Sets and Supervised Machine Learning
authors: Wejdan Al-Shehri, Arbaz Ahmed, Omar Kittaneh, Mohammed Abdulmajid
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Accurate prediction of lithium-ion battery cycle life is vital for enhancing performance, reducing testing time, and accelerating deployment in energy storage systems. This study introduces a data-driven framework for battery lifetime forecasting using supervised machine learning techniques. A benchmark dataset containing 124 commercial lithium iron phosphate (LFP)/graphite cells—each cycled under varied charge–discharge protocols—was analyzed. To simulate practical diagnostic scenarios, six policy-specific early-cycle feature sets (F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>–F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>) were utilized, where each policy includes a different number and combination of charging and performance parameters reflecting incremental diagnostic information. Seven supervised regression models were evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation with the Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) as the primary performance metric. Among all models, Random Forest demonstrated the most stable and consistent accuracy across all six policy scenarios. Although K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) achieved a comparable average MAPE (0.2243), Random Forest achieved the lowest average Testing MAPE (0.2201) and maintained higher stability and generalization capability. These results demonstrate that early-cycle data, structured through policy-based feature configurations, can reliably predict battery cycle life, providing a scalable, efficient, and cost-effective alternative to traditional long-term degradation testing. Unlike previous work such as the MIT early-stage forecasting study, this framework extends the analysis through policy-based feature grouping and multi-model comparison to assess generalization performance.

title: Research on sodium-ion battery parameter identification methods based on third-order RC models
authors: Yong Yi, Zhiwei Li, Yuxin Wei, Ji Qi, Fanghui Yin
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: With the rapid development of the energy storage market, battery technology innovation is urgently needed. Sodium-ion batteries, which offer abundant sodium resources and excellent safety, have emerged as a highly promising alternative solution. Given the unique characteristics of sodium-ion batteries, such as the absence of a distinct voltage plateau, this paper constructs a third-order RC equivalent circuit model to describe their nonlinear characteristics. Three algorithms—the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm, genetic algorithm, and particle swarm optimization algorithm—were employed for parameter identification. The results show that the L-M algorithm achieves an average absolute error as low as 2.21828 mV and a root mean square error of 3.78116 mV, with significantly higher accuracy than the other two algorithms, providing strong support for precise estimation of sodium-ion batteries.

title: Attitude-Preserving Momentum Management for Reaction Wheels Using Generalized Torquer Control
authors: Ashok Kumar Kakula, Aditya Rallapalli, Suraj Kumar, M S Siva
abstract: Momentum management is a critical function in spacecraft attitude control systems that utilize reaction wheels, particularly to prevent wheel saturation caused by the accumulation of angular momentum over time. Momentum management refers to the control strategy used to maintain reaction wheel speeds within specified operational limits. Conventional momentum management methods using magnetic torquers often introduce undesirable attitude disturbances, which are typically corrected through feedback control using the reaction wheels themselves. Although this feedback may direct the momentum change as intended, it can still lead to significant attitude errors—particularly detrimental for high-precision pointing missions. Moreover, traditional desaturation strategies do not guarantee proper wheel speed regulation in systems with redundant reaction wheel configurations. This paper presents a generalized framework for reaction wheel momentum management that minimizes attitude disturbance during desaturation and ensures adherence to wheel speed limits even in redundant configurations. The proposed method first computes the total desaturation torque required for momentum unloading. This torque is then decomposed into two orthogonal components: a null-space torque, which redistributes momentum among reaction wheels without affecting the spacecraft’s attitude, and a range-space torque, which reduces the spacecraft’s net angular momentum. The range-space torque implemented using magnetic torquers is also feedforward to attitude control system along with residual term. This approach enables efficient momentum unloading, maintains wheel speeds within desired bounds, and significantly reduces attitude disturbance—making it suitable for high-precision agile spacecraft operations.

title: Find Us a Safe Path: Risk-Aware Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Unknown Environment
authors: John Rebeiro, Archit Sharma, Dharmendra Sharma, Peeyush Thakur, Narendra Kumar Dhar
abstract: Safe navigation in unknown and dynamic environments remains a key challenge for autonomous multi-robot systems. Traditional methods often depend on global maps or fixed heuristics, limiting scalability and adaptability in complex, unstructured settings. In this work, we propose a risk-aware multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) framework for mapless navigation through static and dynamic obstacles. Each robot learns an independent policy using local LiDAR, goal, and velocity data, with centralized training and decentralized execution. To enhance safety, we introduce a sequence-based risk critic that predicts continuous risk for each action from recent state-action histories. Instead of binary collision labels, we generate soft risk labels using a two-threshold scheme on future LiDAR data, allowing agents to anticipate and avoid imminent danger. Integrating this risk critic into the reward function fosters nuanced, proactive avoidance. Experiments in ROS2-Gazebo with moving obstacles and unseen layouts show improved success and lower collision rates versus MADDPG. The lightweight networks support real-time onboard inference and sim-to-real deployment.

title: Amplifying Rocket RCS With Retroreflective Structure
authors: Daria Tsukanova, Leon Hülsmann, Tobias Welling, Stephan Hauptmeier, Patrick Kwiatkowski, Jan Barowski, Ilona Rolfes, Nils Pohl, Tobias T. Braun
abstract: This article presents the development and validation of a retroreflective structure designed to improve the radar detection of amateur rockets. The work was carried out as part of the Student Design Competition (SDC) at the International Microwave Symposium (IMS) 2025 in San Francisco. The goal was to increase the radar visibility of rockets with cylindrical fuselages, as these are difficult to detect at high angles of incidence due to their low monostatic radar cross section (RCS). The proposed solution employs passive, air-filled slotted waveguide (SWG) antennas realized through additive manufacturing and metallic coating. The structure meets the stringent requirements for weight, size, and mechanical stability. Experimental validation shows that the developed structure significantly improves radar detection compared to a simple cylindrical body.

title: Efficiency-Oriented Stepwise Optimization of Variable Flux Memory Machine Considering Torque Requirement and Operation Envelope Expansion
authors: Wei Liu, Shuheng Qiu, Jinhua Chen, Hui Yang, Chi Zhang
abstract: Existing variable flux memory machines (VFMMs) typically suffer from the unavailability of operation envelope expansion and insufficient torque at the high magnetization state (MS), which severely hinders their potential for overall high-efficient operation through MS regulation. In this article, a novel efficiency-oriented stepwise (EOS) optimization strategy for VFMM is proposed. This strategy can innovatively take the coil flux linkage directly as an optimization objective, which can flexibly regulate the operation envelopes and PM torques at different MSs. A 27-slot/4-pole VFMM with the magnetic circuit complementary (MCC) concept is taken as a design example. Firstly, the operation principle, multiple operation conditions, and key requirements of the VFMM are theoretically investigated. Then, the MCC-VFMM and the EOS optimization strategy are introduced and implemented respectively. Furthermore, the key electromagnetic characteristics of the initial and optimized VFMMs are comprehensively compared. Finally, an optimized prototype is fabricated and experimented to confirm the feasibility of the proposed optimization approach.

title: TCDformer: A Temporal-Channel Decoupled Transformer Framework for Multivariate Time Series Classification
authors: Anan Dai, Ronghua Zhang, Song Ye, Zishu Hu, Jiale Chen, Yuxiang Liu, Tongyan Liu
abstract: Multivariate time series classification (MTSC) is an important research direction in data mining, providing fundamental support for data analysis and intelligent decision-making in complex dynamic systems. However, current methods often follow the temporal-channel mixing approach, where temporal and channel information are jointly processed in the feature space. This inevitably leads to feature confusion and information loss. Furthermore, the existence of distribution shift degrades the generalization capability of the model. To this end, we propose a Transformer-based framework for MTSC, named TCDformer, which improves classification effectiveness by decoupling the modeling of temporal and channel dependencies. TCDformer consists of two core modules: the Channel Independent Transformer Module (CITM) and the Patch Independent Transformer Module (PITM). CITM first captures the pure temporal patterns within each channel, while PITM further explores the inter-channel interactions within fine-grained temporal segments. Additionally, reversible instance normalization (RevIN) is introduced to mitigate the distribution shift in the feature extraction layers, thereby achieving robust performance. Experimental results on 25 UEA datasets show that TCDformer outperforms current competitive MTSC methods.

title: A Protocol-Agnostic Backscatter-Based Security Layer for Ultra-Low-Power SWIPT IoT Networks
authors: Taki E. Djidjekh, Alexandru Takacs, Gaël Loubet, Lamoussa Sanogo, Daniela Dragomirescu
abstract: This paper presents a lightweight, protocol-agnostic security enhancement for Simultaneous Wireless Information and Power Transfer (SWIPT) in Internet of Things (IoT) applications. Building on a backscatter-based identification mechanism, the proposed approach introduces a secure, energy-efficient layer that operates independently of communication protocols and with minimal hardware modification. A rectifier-driven backscattering scheme embedded in battery-free sensing nodes enables authentication without activating conventional RF transceivers, thereby reducing power consumption while ensuring secure device identification. To assess robustness, replay attacks are emulated on standard LoRaWAN Activation By Personalization (ABP) encryption, highlighting vulnerabilities and demonstrating the relevance of the proposed solution. The approach is experimentally validated in a real Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) using LoRaWAN-compatible, battery-free sensing nodes equipped with compact, low-profile antennas, confirming both practicality and scalability for space-constrained IoT deployments. Results show that the method achieves secure identification, reliable energy harvesting, and data transmission with negligible impact on node autonomy. The proposed approach offers a practical, energy-efficient, and scalable security framework for SWIPT-enabled IoT systems, strengthening device authentication without altering existing communication protocols or compromising power autonomy.

title: CANet: Cross Alignment Network for Human Gait Recognition
authors: Abdul Khalik Sheri, Mohammad Iman Junaid, Sandeep Madarapu, Samit Ari
abstract: Gait recognition has emerged as a crucial biometric technique because it enables unobtrusive and remote identification. However, silhouette-based methods are often affected by variations in clothing and carrying conditions. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multi-modal approach that integrates Gait Energy Images (GEI) and Skeletal Gait Energy Images (SkeGEI) to enhance recognition performance. GEIs capture appearance-based holistic motion patterns, while SkeGEIs, generated from normalized skeletal representations centred on the neck joint, provide robust structural features. Skeletal coordinates are extracted using HRNet for the CASIA-B dataset and AlphaPose for the OU-MVLP dataset, which are then used to generate SkeGEIs. Our composite fusion model effectively combines GEI and SkeGEI features through Cross-Alignment blocks (CAB), attention mechanisms, and Progressive Fusion Blocks (PFB). Extensive evaluations on the CASIA-B and OU-MVLP datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves superior performance compared to state-ofthe- art methods across diverse conditions. However, the model struggles with crossdataset generalization, particularly in varied clothing conditions. Additionally, an ablation study highlights the effectiveness of each component, validating the superiority of our integrated model.

title: Adaptive Multi-Resolution Dynamic Mode Decomposition for Non-Stationary Signal Analysis
authors: Alavala Siva Sankar Reddy, Ram Bilas Pachori
abstract: Non-stationary signals with rapidly evolving and overlapping spectral components present challenges for obtaining accurate time-frequency distribution (TFD). Conventional dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) extracts mode frequencies and damping information but struggles to represent the TFD of highly non-stationary signals. Multi-resolution DMD (MR-DMD) improves this but depends on a fixed embedding dimension, causing mode mixing and reduced resolution. This paper presents an adaptive multiresolution DMD (AMR-DMD) technique that automatically determines the embedding dimension at each decomposition level using a time-frequency resolution criterion obtained from the Heisenberg uncertainty principle for real-valued signals. The method is further extended to complex-valued signals by separating positive and negative frequency components for complete spectral characterization. Hilbert spectral analysis (HSA) is applied to the modes obtained from AMR-DMD to generate the TFD. Experimental results on real synthetic and complex signals show that the proposed AMR-DMD-based HSA technique provides improved TFDs, achieving sharper localization, lower reconstruction error, and higher quality reconstruction factor compared with empirical mode decomposition-based HSA, variational mode decomposition-based HSA, DMD-based HSA, and MR-DMD-based HSA methods.

title: A Behavior Tree and Dynamic Motion Primitive-Based Framework for Learning and Executing Robotic Tasks from Demonstration
authors: Tao Ma, Burkhard Corves, Gentiane Venture
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Learning from Demonstrations(LfD) enables robots to acquire complex skills by observing human behavior, significantly reducing the need for explicit programming. However, applying LfD in industrial settings remains challenging due to limited demonstrations, variability in task executions, and the need to generalize across diverse scenarios. To address these issues, this paper presents a learning based hierarchical task and motion planning framework that integrates Behavior Trees (BT) for high-level task sequencing and Dynamic Motion Primitives (DMP) for low-level motion generation. Demonstration trajectories are segmented and actions are generated using an agentcentric, state-augmented segmentation strategy. Subsequently, relevant features are automatically extracted to define the pre-and post-conditions for each action for the construction of a modular BT. For motion execution, DMP are enhanced with a recovery mechanism for adaptive, obstacle-aware reproduction. A backchaining mechanism is also introduced for BT extension. Validation was performed through simulation and real-world experiments on multiple tasks. Comparative results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing LfD and planning baselines in task success rate, efficiency, and motion smoothness, highlighting its potential for flexible and scalable automation.

title: Optimizing Cloud Service Efficiency with Infrastructure-Aware Scheduling
authors: Chengzhi Piao, Eunsam Kim, Choonhwa Lee
abstract: With the rapid development of cloud-native computing technologies, containers have become an integral part of cloud infrastructure. At the same time, Kubernetes has positioned itself as a solid foundation for cloud-native orchestration platforms. However, the exponential growth of the container adoption raises a concern over energy usage. Existing Kubernetes scheduling approaches are not sophisticated enough to factor energy efficiency and infrastructure differences into the scheduling decisions. To address these shortages, we propose a novel scheduling system for Kubernetes clusters that considers infrastructure specifics and further task requirements. The system uses a benchmarking suite to model node performance, selects appropriate scheduling algorithms based on the number of tasks, and further optimizes cluster power consumption through re-scheduling. Our evaluation results show that the proposed approach achieves a power consumption reduction of18.46% compared to the Kubernetes scheduler.
