title: Accelerating the Approval of Automated Driving Vehicles through standardized XiL test environments
authors: Maikol Funk Drechsler, Christoph Sell, Yuri Poledna, Werner Huber
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: The development of Automated Driving Systems demands extensive testing to ensure passenger safety. This testing follows a stepwise approach, progressing from purely virtual environments to open real-world traffic. This work proposes an X-in-the-Loop architecture that enables a seamless transition between different testing modalities. The architecture relies on open standards and open-source algorithms, enhancing accessibility for developers. A proof of concept is implemented for a subset of the architecture, covering vehicle dynamics, data exchange between systems, and feedback of the vehicle motion into the simulation. System credibility within the Hardware-in-the-Loop setup is assessed against Vehicle-in-the-Loop tests. The results confirm the applicability of the proposed architecture. Moderate deviations in vehicle dynamics behaviour are observed, attributed to model simplifications. Nonetheless, the control algorithm parameters tuned using the simulation model perform effectively on the real vehicle. Future work will focus on integrating sensor models and perception systems into the test chain. This will support validation of the architecture in a fully closed-loop testing environment.

title: Improved Sliding Mode Control for Fast Steering Mirror Based on Hysteresis Compensation and Sliding Mode Observer
authors: Jing Zhang, Shixiong Li, Guilin Zhang, Gang Jing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: The fast steering mirror (FSM) is extensively utilized in beam steering and precise tracking. However, the accuracy of the FSM is influenced by the piezo actuators. Firstly, the Bouc-Wen (B-W) model is established to describe the FSM. The hysteresis compensation is proposed to reduce the influence of hysteresis nonlinearity. Then, an improved sliding mode controller (SOSMC-STA) is proposed. The super-twisting algorithm (STA) which can eliminate the chattering is used in the controller to enhance the robustness, and the sliding mode observer is applied to estimate the unmeasurable state of the FSM. Finally, the experiment was conducted through both Matlab and dSPACE physical platform. The results show that the controller can satisfy the high precision tracking requirement with certain stability.

title: Coal-fired Power Plant Dual-Arm Automatic Uncoupling Robot System
authors: Mingyang Ai, Fuwen Luo, Wenbo Ni, Xuemei Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: To address the need for automated uncoupling prior to car dumper operations in coal transportation systems, this paper designed a novel dual-arm automatic uncoupling robot system, which includes a synchronization-arm and an uncoupling-arm. The system comprises a mechanical structure, a control system, and a vision module. Kinematic and dynamic models were derived, and its dynamic simulation model was established. By using gravity-compensated PD control strategy, the joint angle errors were controlled within 0.3°. A dual-arm uncoupling robot test platform was built in the laboratory. The test results showed that the designed robot system could stably and reliably complete the detection, recognition, and uncoupling operation with a load of 50 kg when the coal wagon is running at a speed of 1.5 m/s, and the entire uncoupling process takes about 6 seconds.

title: Research on a Neural Network-Based Weighing System for Standard Gas High-Pressure Cylinders
authors: Lihang Chen, Xingxia Hu, Bo Hu, Wenbo Yang, Yinbei Wang, Yuxi Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: The Accurate weighing of standard gas high-pressure cylinders is critical for precise filling, yet remains challenging due to nonlinear errors caused by dynamic temperature, pressure fluctuations, and valve hysteresis. This study proposes a neural network framework integrating Bayesian Optimization and Transfer Learning for single and binary gas systems. Experimental analysis revealed coupled relationships among operational parameters. The developed BO-BP-LSTM-Attention model demonstrated superior accuracy over traditional methods, achieving 97.59% prediction accuracy for single-component gases. Through transfer learning, the model maintained 98.67% accuracy for binary gases while reducing data requirements. A LabVIEW-based acquisition system ensured synchronized data collection and traceability, providing an adaptive solution for multi-component gas filling.

title: A Robust Adaptive Integrated Sliding Mode Compensation Method for Pneumatic Control Valve Stiction
authors: Dong Yang, Kuo Gao, Chunhong Li, Shouqi Fu, Huai Wang, Haoyu Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: In tobacco manufacturing processes, pneumatic control valve stiction often causes distortion in steam flow regulation, which increases the defect rate in hollow filter rod forming and significantly raises production costs. To address the limited generalization and poor robustness of existing stiction compensation methods, this study proposes a robust adaptive integrated sliding mode controller (RAISMC) based on the mechanistic model of valve stiction. The proposed scheme adaptively estimates unknown valve parameters to achieve effective compensation for diverse stiction characteristics of pneumatic valves. The stability of the controller is rigorously proven using Lyapunov theory. Furthermore, to mitigate the adverse effects of noise and measurement errors, an improved Levant differentiator is introduced, which effectively suppresses chattering and enhances robustness. Three groups of simulation experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in compensating valve stiction. The results provide a feasible solution for ensuring efficient operation of hollow filter rod forming equipment in the tobacco industry.

title: Optimization and Benchmarking of Monolithically Stackable Gain Cell Memory for Last-Level Cache
authors: Faaiq Waqar, Jungyoun Kwak, Junmo Lee, Omkar Phadke, Minji Shon, Mohammadhosein Gholamrezaei, Kevin Skadron, Shimeng Yu
abstract: The Last Level Cache (LLC) is the processor’s critical bridge between on-chip and off-chip memory levels - optimized for high density, high bandwidth, and low operation energy. To date, high-density (HD) SRAM has been the conventional device of choice; however, with the slowing of transistor scaling, as reflected in the industry’s almost identical HD SRAM cell size from 5 nm to 3 nm, alternative solutions such as 3D stacking with advanced packaging (i.e., hybrid bonding) are pursued (as demonstrated in AMD’s V-cache). Escalating data demands necessitate ultra-large on-chip caches to decrease costly off-chip memory movement, pushing the exploration of device technology towards monolithic 3D (M3D) integration, where transistors can be stacked in the back-end-of-line (BEOL) at the interconnect level. M3D integration requires fabrication techniques compatible with a low thermal budget (<400°C). Among promising BEOL device candidates are amorphous oxide semiconductor (AOS) transistors, particularly desirable for their ultra-low leakage (<fA/μm), enabling persistent data retention (>seconds) when used in a gain-cell configuration. This paper examines device, circuit, and system-level tradeoffs made when optimizing BEOL-compatible AOS-based 2-transistor gain cells (2T-GC) for LLC. A cache early-exploration tool, NS-Cache, is developed to model caches in advanced 7 & 3 nm nodes and is integrated with the Gem5 simulator to systematically benchmark the impact of the newfound density/performance when compared to HD-SRAM, MRAM, and 1T1C eDRAM alternatives for LLC.

title: S2S-Net: Addressing the Domain Gap of Heterogeneous Sensor Systems in LiDAR-Based Collective Perception
authors: Sven Teufel, Jörg Gamerdinger, Oliver Bringmann
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Collective Perception (CP) has emerged as a promis-ing approach to overcome the limitations of individual perception in the context of autonomous driving. Various approaches have been proposed to realize collective perception; however, the Sensor2Sensor domain gap that arises from the utilization of different sensor systems in Connected and Automated Vehicles (CAVs) remains mostly unaddressed. This is primarily due to the paucity of datasets containing heterogeneous sensor setups among the CAVs. The recently released SCOPE datasets address this issue by providing data from three different LiDAR sensors for each CAV. This study is the first to address the Sensor2Sensor domain gap in vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) collective perception. First, we present our sensor-domain robust architecture S2S-Net. Then an in-depth analysis of the Sensor2Sensor domain adaptation capabilities of state-of-the-art CP methods and S2S-Net is conducted on the SCOPE dataset. This study shows that, all evaluated state-of-the-art mehtods for collective perception highly suffer from the Sensor2Sensor domain gap, while S2S-Net demonstrates the capability to maintain very high performance in unseen sensor domains and outperforms the evaluated state-of-the-art methods by up to 44 percentage points.

title: Virtual Testing Environments for LiDARs: A Study of Scene Composition Effects
authors: Syed Mostaquim Ali, Vidyasagar Rajendran, Ghazal Farhani, Taufiq Rahman, Mohamed H. Zaki, Benoit Anctil, Dominique Charlebois
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Real-world testing, whether through naturalistic or test-track driving, cannot generate the test coverage required to prove the safety of autonomous vehicles with acceptable statistical significance. Virtual Testing Environments (VTEs) offer a complementary solution by enabling the creation of challenging safety-critical test scenarios that are difficult to replicate in real-world conditions. To ensure that a VTE is a sufficient representation of the real-world, our previous work proposed the development of a VTE using a digital twin of an actual roadway environment. This VTE can generate synthetic LiDAR scans, which can then be compared to real-world scans used to create the digital twin. We employed chamfer distance and density-aware chamfer distance as the metrics for this comparison. In this study, we implemented this approach on a variety of roadway scenes to investigate how different scene compositions affect the comparison metrics. Our findings reveal that factors such as road surface smoothness, vegetation presence, and the LiDAR’s point of view (elevation) significantly influence the comparison results.

title: Design and Evaluation of a Bionic Interlocking Adhesive Gripper for Versatile Object Grasping
authors: Liuwei Wang, Chenlu Xue, Yi Song, Zhouyi Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Robotic grasping of diverse objects, particularly flat or smooth surfaces, remains challenging for conventional grippers. To address this issue, a bionic interlocking adhesive gripper inspired by the counter-adducting toe mechanism of geckos is proposed. The gripper integrates an angle-spreading joint, an adhesion/detachment joint, and bionic adhesive toes to achieve inward interlocking for enhanced adhesion and outward extension for low-impact detachment. Experimental validation shows that the interlocking behavior effectively doubles the normal adhesion force on planar surfaces compared to non-interlocking conditions. It also enables stable grasping of multiple objects with varied curvature, stiffness, and materials. The results demonstrate that multilevel cooperative design and interlocking biomimetic mechanisms can significantly improve the versatility and controllability of adhesion-based grippers for complex and resource-efficient robotic applications. Beyond performance enhancements, the energy-efficient and reusable nature of gecko-inspired dry adhesion supports broader aims of industry innovation and sustainable industrial technologies.

title: Toward Interpretable Imputation: Through Discovering Spatiotemporal Patterns of Urban Metro Flow Data_supp1-3662701.docx
authors: Yining Dong
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) has enabled the development of intelligent transportation systems (ITS). However, missing data remains a common issue that hinders the effectiveness of ITS. Although many imputation methods have been proposed to handle missing values, they generally aim to improve the accuracy of final imputation results and often neglect the interpretability of the imputation process. This may cause limited trustworthiness and practical applicability in real-world metro management, where understanding the underlying metro data patterns is essential. To address this gap, this paper conducts an in-depth analysis and mining of the unique spatiotemporal structures inherent in metro flow data, aiming at both accurate and interpretable imputation. Specifically, an orthogonal-autoregression matrix factorization (OAMF) algorithm is proposed to discover two low-dimensional, complete spatial and temporal patterns from high-dimensional, incomplete data. By minimizing reconstruction error associated with these two patterns, OAMF ensures the accuracy of final imputation results. Furthermore, through simultaneous distinctive spatial representations modeling and predictive temporal modeling, OAMF encourages the two patterns with clear physical meaning that captures orthogonal spatial distributions and evolving metro flow trends over time, enabling the interpretability of the imputation process. Additionally, the above explicit temporal modeling further extends OAMF’s ability to predict futures. The proposed OAMF is validated using two real-world datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that OAMF not only extracts interpretable spatiotemporal patterns but also achieves superior accuracy in both imputation and prediction across various missing rates compared to existing methods.

title: Diff3D-Net: Self-Supervised Monocular Depth Estimation via Explicit Multi-Level Differentiable Geometric Constraints
authors: Jiaqi Dong, Guoliang Chen, Marco Piras, Yuewei Bo, Minghong Hu, Zitao Lin, Teng Wang, Zhenghua Zhang, Hu Liu
abstract: Self-supervised monocular depth estimation leverages photometric consistency across views as supervisory signals, yet inherently suffers from compromised geometric fidelity at object boundaries, surface smoothness, and cross-view consistency due to 3D structural information loss during 2D projection. This paper introduces Diff3D-Net, a novel framework integrating multi-level 3D geometric constraints to overcome these limitations. Key innovations include: a fixed-parameter RPM-Net point cloud registration module generating geometrically grounded supervision; a pose consistency constraint that directly optimizes the pose network using RPM-Net-refined transformations to suppress error accumulation; a dual-path photometric constraint adaptively fusing reconstructions from original and optimized poses to enhance low-texture robustness; and a multi-view 3D structural consistency constraint enforcing global point alignment via minimum residual selection. Evaluations on KITTI and DDAD show Diff3D-Net's state-of-the-art performance, achieving 0.094/4.220 Abs. Rel/RMSE on KITTI. The model also exhibits strong cross-domain generalization in zero-shot settings, outperforming competitors on Cityscapes, NYU Depth V2 and DrivingStereo datasets without fine-tuning, highlighting its IoT application potential. Despite higher training costs, its inference achieves an optimal speed-accuracy trade-off, with a lightweight variant reaching 51.73 FPS -sufficient to enable real-time applications such as UAV navigation on resource-limited IoT edge devices. Ablations confirm each constraint's contribution, and qualitative results demonstrate robustness in dynamic scenes and complex geometries.

title: SplitFed-CKD: SplitFed Learning with Contrastive Learning and Knowledge Distillation on non-IID Datasets
authors: Taisuke Noguchi, Hinata Tomimori, Takuya Azumi
abstract: High-quality Deep Learning (DL) enabled by large-scale training data has found applications across various industries. However, when local data contains sensitive privacy information, the amount of data to be aggregated is limited, hindering sufficient training. Federated Learning (FL) and Split Learning (SL) enable collaborative training while protecting the privacy information of local data, but each approach faces distinct difficulties, such as computational load and limited parallelism. SplitFed Learning (SFL), a hybrid of SL and FL, provides a promising method to overcome these issues. However, when dealing with non-Independent and Identically Distributed (non-IID) datasets, a common scenario in real-world applications, SFL performance suffers considerably as a result of client drift and biased model updates. To address this problem, this paper proposes SplitFed-CKD, which integrates contrastive learning and knowledge distillation into SFL through the use of an auxiliary classifier that takes the outputs of client models as input. Specifically, SplitFed-CKD classifies the output of the global model into reliable positive and unreliable negative samples according to dynamic thresholds. Contrastive learning is then performed on the feature vectors of the auxiliary classifier using prototypes that represent averaged samples. This enables each client-side model to effectively learn global knowledge and mitigate biased training. Furthermore, knowledge distillation is performed by using the training model as a teacher and the client and auxiliary classifiers as students. Finally, comparisons with recent state-of-the-art approaches, together with five-run statistical significance tests, confirm that SplitFed-CKD achieves consistently higher accuracy with statistically significant gains in large-class non-IID settings where class diversity is high.

title: Single-electrode, Bidirectional Control of Heart Rate via Vagus Nerve Modulation in Rat Model
authors: Shane A. Bender, David B. Green, Varun S. Thakkar, Hope L. Zimmerman, Mohamed Elazab, Kevin L. Kilgore, Tina L. Vrabec
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Electrical stimulation of somatic nerves has long been used as a treatment method for a wide range of diseases by increasing activity on a target nerve. Electrical nerve block is an emerging therapy that can provide the same targeted treatment by decreasing activity on the nerve. Here, we demonstrate that both of these techniques can be applied synergistically via a single electrode to achieve precise control of an autonomic system. Two electrodes were placed on the right-side rat vagus nerve. The vagus proximal to the electrodes was crushed, and the left side was cut to isolate the system. The proximal electrode was used to give a perturbing stimulus ramp (0 Hz → 30 Hz → 0 Hz) over 10 minutes to roughly mimic the vagal activity seen in an episode of vasovagal syncope. The distal electrode was used to apply either stimulation or kilohertz-frequency electrical nerve block (KHFAC) to the vagus to keep the heart rate at a specified setpoint. The stimulation parameters were decided by a closed-loop fuzzy logic controller. Three different gains for the controller were tried. While each gain showed success in controlling the heart rate, lower gain was sometimes not responsive enough for effective control, and high gain was seen to induce oscillations in the heart rate; a medium gain was seen to be effective without either of these issues. This demonstrates that a single electrode can deliver bimodal neuromodulation of a single nerve, providing a powerful treatment tool against autonomic dysregulation.

title: Physics-Informed Simulation-to-Hardware Alignement for DC-Link Capacitor Condition Monitoring
authors: Youssof Fassi, Shuai Zhao, Vincent Heiries, Jérôme Boutet, Sébastien Boisseau, Huai Wang
abstract: Reliable condition monitoring of DC-link capacitors is essential for the safety and longevity of traction inverters, yet long-term experimental degradation data are scarce. This work presents a physics-informed, simulation-to-hardware alignment framework for non-invasive capacitor health assessment using low-frequency (100 Hz) measurements from standard shutdown events. A high-fidelity electrothermal inverter model generates synthetic discharge profiles across a broad range of operating conditions and degradation levels. To bridge the synthetic–experimental gap, we introduce a degradation-aware latent space structuring mechanism combining domain alignment and class ordering, optimized via an adaptive multi-task loss balancing strategy. Experiments on a three-phase traction inverter demonstrate robust degradation tracking with 98.9% classification accuracy, full recall for the most degraded state, and low computational cost suitable for embedded deployment. The method enables interpretable and deployment-ready capacitor monitoring without additional sensors or control-layer modifications.

title: Design of an Automated Disassembly and Inspection Process for Stacked Paper-Film Dual-Layer Packaging Box
authors: Shi-Fei Jiang, Zhao-Guo Zhang, Zhi Li
abstract: Stacked packaging is a widely used method for products, with appearance inspections typically conducted manually. However, this manual approach often suffers from low accuracy, inefficiency, and limited automation, posing challenges to efficiency and consistency in modern manufacturing processes. To achieve efficient, precise, and automated inspection of products in stacked packaging, this study proposes the RFBS model for developing optimized unpacking and inspection methods. First, the requirements, including functional, behavioral, and structural aspects, were defined within the RFBS model. Second, the requirement layer was translated into functional and behavioral layers, which were subsequently transformed into the structural layer. Meanwhile, a fully automated disassembly and inspection process has been developed, consisting of the following steps: outer box imaging inspection, outer box disassembly, inner box imaging inspection, inner box disassembly. Finally, a prototype was developed based on the RFBS method to achieve fully automated disassembly and inspection of the packaging system. Experimental results show that this automated process can automatically disassemble and inspect the stacked packaging with a reliability of 97% and a non-destructive rate of 99.8%, which provides a practical and efficient solution for the quality control of industrial production.

title: DSS-Mamba: Deformable Spatial-Spectral State Space Model for Hyperspectral Land Cover Classification
authors: Dehua Huo, Weida Zhan, Yueyi Han, Jinxin Guo, Depeng Zhu, Yu Chen, YiChun Jiang, Deng Han
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: State space models (SSMs), particularly Mamba, have garnered significant attention from researchers owing to their efficient balance between computational efficiency and model performance, and they also provide a performance breakthrough for accurate land cover classification of hyperspectral images (HSIs). However, HSI data feature high spectral dimensionality and dense spatial information, so efficiently constructing Mamba sequences that align with the structural characteristics of HSI data remains a critical unresolved issue. To address this challenge, we propose an efficient deformable spatial-spectral Mamba network (DSS-Mamba), which aims to efficiently mine valuable spatial-spectral features from HSIs. To achieve this goal, we design a two-branch architecture consisting of a spatial deformable Mamba and a spectral bidirectional Mamba: the spatial deformable scanning Mamba (SDSM) integrates a spatial deformable state space model (SD-SSM) and adaptively focuses on salient feature regions through a dynamic scanning strategy, while the spectral bidirectional scanning Mamba (SBSM) incorporates a spectral bidirectional state space model (SB-SSM) and fully exploits spectral dimensional information via a bidirectional scanning mechanism. During feature processing, we propose a spatial-spectral complementary fusion (SSCF) module, which refines feature weights by means of a dual-threshold enhancement unit (DTEU) to realize efficient processing and dynamic fusion of spatial-spectral features. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DSS-Mamba effectively balances the fine-grained capture of spatial-spectral features and computational efficiency through the adaptive capture of spatial features by the deformable structure, the in-depth mining of spectral information via bidirectional scanning, and the complementary fusion of the spatial-spectral module. Consequently, it achieves superior classification accuracy in land cover classification.

title: Nearly Tight Regret Bounds for Profit Maximization in Bilateral Trade
authors: Simone Di Gregorio, Paul Dütting, Federico Fusco, Chris Schwiegelshohn
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: Bilateral trade models the task of intermediating between two strategic agents, a seller and a buyer, willing to trade a good for which they hold private valuations. We study this problem from the perspective of a broker, in a regret minimization framework. At each time step, a new seller and buyer arrive, and the broker has to propose a mechanism that is incentivecompatible and individually rational, with the goal of maximizing profit. We propose a learning algorithm that guarantees a nearly tight regret in the stochastic setting when seller and buyer valuations are drawn i.i.d. from a fixed and possibly correlated unknown distribution. We further show that it is impossible to achieve sublinear regret in the non-stationary scenario where valuations are generated upfront by an adversary. Our ambitious benchmark for these results is the best incentive-compatible and individually rational mechanism. This separates us from previous works on efficiency maximization in bilateral trade, where the benchmark is a single number: the best fixed price in hindsight. A particular challenge we face is that uniform convergence for all mechanisms’ profits is impossible. We overcome this difficulty via a careful chaining analysis that proves convergence for a provably near-optimal mechanism at (essentially) optimal rate. We further showcase the broader applicability of our techniques by providing nearly optimal results for the joint ads problem.

title: High-to-Low Dimensional PPA-completeness: Borsuk-Ulam, Tucker, Consensus Halving, and Ham Sandwich
authors: Ruiquan Gao, Alexandros Hollender, Aviad Rubinstein
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: The Borsuk-Ulam theorem states that every continuous odd function $f: {\mathcal{S}}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ must have a zero, i.e., an $x \in {\mathcal{S}}^{n}$ such that $f(x)=0$. While such a zero is guaranteed to exist, finding it is known to be computationally intractable: it is PPAcomplete already for n = 2. In this work, we show that the problem remains just as hard even if the function is mapping from a higher to a lower dimensional space. Namely, we prove that it is PPA-complete to find a zero of $f: {\mathcal{S}}^{k} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ for any constants $k \geq n \geq 2$. This result has very appealing consequences for other flagship PPA-complete problems such as Tucker, Consensus Halving, and Ham Sandwich. For example, in the Consensus Halving problem from fair division, we show that finding a partition that satisfies three agents with monotone valuations is PPA-complete, even if we allow any arbitrarily large constant number of cuts.

title: Rank Bounds and PIT for depth-4 circuits with top fan-in 3 and constant bottom fan-in via a non-linear Edelstein-Kelly theorem
authors: Abhibhav Garg, Rafael Oliveira, Akash Kumar Sengupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: We prove a non-linear Edelstein-Kelly theorem for polynomials of constant degree, fully settling a stronger form of Conjecture 30 in Gupta (2014), and generalizing the main result of Peleg and Shpilka (STOC 2021) from quadratic polynomials to polynomials of any constant degree. As a consequence of our result, we obtain constant rank bounds for depth-4 circuits with top fanin 3 and constant bottom fan-in which compute the zero polynomial. This settles a stronger form of Conjecture 1 in Gupta (2014) when $\mathrm{k}=3$, for any constant degree bound; additionally this also makes progress on Conjecture 28 in Beecken, Mittmann, and Saxena (Information & Computation, 2013). Our rank bounds, when combined with Theorem 2 in Beecken, Mittmann, and Saxena (Information & Computation, 2013) yield the first deterministic, polynomial time PIT algorithm for these circuits.

title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models for Employee Attrition Prediction with Explainable AI
authors: Sayali Sagar, Rajesh Dhumal, Vidya Kumbhar, T. P. Singh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Employee attrition is a major challenge for organizations worldwide, affecting operational efficiency, financial performance, and workforce stability. Identifying and predicting the factors driving attrition is essential for developing effective retention strategies. This study explores how advanced deep learning models, combined with Explainable AI techniques, can improve attrition predictions and reveal key underlying factors. Three deep learning models are evaluated based on their accuracy before applying Explainable AI to the most effective one for attrition prediction. The models include Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), and Radial Basis Function (RBF) networks. CNN, originally designed for image processing, also proves effective for tabular data, achieving an accuracy of 95.93 %. RNN, known for handling sequential and time-dependent data, achieves 94% accuracy. Meanwhile, RBF, which specializes in capturing nonlinear relationships, reaches an accuracy of 87.40 %. Among these models, CNN outperforms the others in accuracy, while RNN and RBF yield comparatively lower results. To enhance interpretability, Explainable AI (XAI) is employed to identify key factors influencing employee attrition. The study uses the LIME technique to explain individual predictions, making the model's decision-making process more transparent and actionable for HR professionals. By using Explainable AI, this study aims to provide HR professionals with data-driven insights to refine retention strategies, reduce attrition, and strengthen workforce stability. Future research could explore real-time datasets and broader industrial applications.

title: AI-Based Solutions for Improving Radiation Dose Distribution in Oncology
authors: Mario Antony, Monali Gulhane, Pooja Dhawane, Nitin Rakesh, Pratik Sarda, Nilesh P. Sable
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: One important part of radiation treatment in cancer is making sure that the radiation dose reaches the tumours as evenly as possible while hurting as few healthy tissues as possible. Even though traditional methods work, they don't always get the doses to the right places, which could limit the treatment. New developments in artificial intelligence (AI) hold promise for improving the accuracy of how radiation doses are distributed in cancer. AI-based methods, especially deep learning and machine learning, could completely change the way treatment plans are made by allowing automated and accurate dose prediction models, making it easier to target tumours accurately, and making the best use of radiation delivery. Computer programs that are driven by AI can look at complicated medical images like computed tomography (CT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to make very accurate dose distributions and find important structures that need to be protected. AI can also help with adaptive radiation therapy by constantly changing treatment plans as the tumour size or the patient's body changes during the treatment. This makes sure that the treatment is more personalized and optimized on the fly. By learning from big datasets to guess the best radiation tactics, machine learning models, especially convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and reinforcement learning, can make treatments even more effective. This essay looks at different AI techniques used to spread radiation doses in cancer. It also talks about how these techniques affect the accuracy of treatment and the problems that might come up when AI methods are used in real life. When AI is added to radiation treatment, it is expected to greatly improve patient results, lower side effects, and make personalized cancer care possible.

title: Modeling Fault Propagation for Model-Based Diagnosis as a MaxSAT Problem
authors: Huisi Zhou, Ning Kang, Wei Hu
publish: 2025 Asian Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium (AsianHOST)
abstract: Model-Based Diagnosis (MBD), a prominent technique for identifying the causes of system malfunctions, is an important research area in reliability engineering. Existing MBD methods generate a large number of candidate diagnoses for fault localization, which requires extensive computational cost. This work introduces a novel fault propagation model to replace the model used in conventional MBD approaches, and proposes a novel diagnosis method upon this model to improve diagnosis performance. First, we generate fault propagation constraints to capture the logical relationships as faults propagate between two connected components, which can be used to narrow down some subsets of candidate diagnoses in the subsequent diagnosis phase. Second, we formally model fault propagation through Weighted Conjunctive Normal Form (WCNF), encoding it as a Maximum Satisfiability (MaxSAT) problem. Building on this model, we use RC2-an efficient MaxSAT solver-to compute only a subset of candidate diagnoses, thereby significantly reducing the computational cost of fault localization. Experimental evaluations using ISCAS-85 and ITC-99 benchmarks demonstrate that FPMBD achieves a reduction in the number of diagnoses typically ranging from 1 to 5 orders of magnitude, along with a reduction in diagnosis time ranging from 1 to 4 orders of magnitude in almost all of the test cases, compared to state-of-theart algorithms, including CMMO, HSD, One-SAT, and DiagDO.

title: Design of a Reinforcement Learning Control Approach for Inverted Pendulum System
authors: Van Du Phan, Thai Son Dang, Dinh Tu Duong, Hung Cuong Ta, Van Nam Dinh
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Inverted pendulum (IPE) system is a standard plant commonly used as a bench-mark for developing advanced control algorithms. In this paper, a reinforcement learning control approach is proposed for the IPE system in the angle tracking control problem. To achieve an optimal solution, an actor-critic reinforcement learning structure is developed by utilizing an adaptive neural network (NN)-based Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) framework to observe the unknown nonlinear functions and optimize the cost function. The stability of the IPE system is ensured by the Lyapunov theorem. Comprehensive comparisons in simulation studies are conducted to confirm the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed controller.

title: Knowledge Management in the Aviation Sector: A Systematic Literature Review and Bibliometric Analysis
authors: Youness Belkhoumani, Abdelati Hakmaoui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Over the last few decades, knowledge management (KM) has gained a considerable attention due to management processes changes and technology progress and due to a spreading awareness of the importance of knowledge as a competitive advantage and as a key asset towards business performance enhancement. This article seeks to explore the concept of Knowledge Management within the Aviation Sector (AS). 149 documents indexed Web of Science and Scopus published between 2000 and 2023 were obtained through a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) following PRISMA protocol. Bibliometric analyses were performed using R software, RStudio application and its interactive web interface called biblioshiny dedicated to quantitative science mapping analysis presented under visuals and tables. 16 relevant grey literature publications were collected and examined as well. The contribution of this study to the literature is the introduction of an overview of KM within AS with particular focusing on Air Navigation Services Provider (ANSP) organizations and with grey literature consideration. The findings of this paper have indicated the increasing interest over years of the KM processes implementation particularly within the airlines industry, however it should be highlighted that the literature on this topic in aviation public sector is still not well developed especially for ANSP organizations.

title: Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis of Marathi Language in Education Domain Using Machine Learning

But instruments and organizations are not very satisfied with the overall sentiment; they like fine-grained knowledge about student reviews. We focus on aspect-based sentiment analysis for college review to analysis student for the best college. Also colleges to identify their strength and weaknesses. We use SVM, Naïve Bayes, XG Boost, Gradient Boosting, and Random Forest for sentiment classification. Interestingly, in most cases the data showed that both XG Boost and Gradient Boosting hit over 96% accuracy-outperforming the others. Generally speaking, this points to the promise of using tailored domain-specific word banks to fine-tune results, especially in languages where resources are limited. The results demonstrate how supervised learning and lexicon-based methods for low-resource languages can be combined

title: Smart Rail Maintenance: AI-Driven Acoustic Wave Monitoring for Defect Detection and Wear Prognostics
authors: Manali Lamture, Tejaswini Koparde, Jetkumar Gaikwad, Akash Shikhare, Nilesh Pinjarkar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Crack and fracture detection, if delayed or overlooked, might entirely endanger the safety of the tracks. The latest technological AIs, IoT, and sensors bring efficiency to fault-detection systems. This study reviews modern technologies such as acoustic analysis, ultrasonic sensors, and DT technology. Acoustic technology assesses vibrations to perceive abnormalities, while ultrasonic sensors use sound to detect internal defects. Meanwhile, DT technology helps in creating a virtual model of the physical tracks so that it can be monitored for predictive maintenance in real time. In this world of AI, monitoring systems can detect faults faster and more accurately, although some challenges still exist with environmental conditions and real-time data processing.

title: Effectiveness of AI-Enhanced Nursing Assessment in Critical Care: A Randomized Controlled Trial
authors: Sonopant Joshi, Husain Nadaf, Mangesh Jabade, Jasneet Kaur, Sheela Upendra, Ranjit Kumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Background: Integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into critical care nursing holds the promise of enhancing clinical decision-making through real-time feedback and predictive notifications from physiological and behavioural signals. The clinical effectiveness and nurse-led uptake of AI in ICU environments are yet to be fully explored. This RCT will examine whether AI-enhanced nursing assessments improve early detection of patient deterioration, response times among nurses, and general patient outcomes in critical care. A parallelgroup, two-arm RCT was implemented at a tertiary ICU, recruiting 200 critically ill adults (100 in the control group and 100 in the AI-assisted intervention group). The intervention was the incorporation of an AI-powered decision support system that processed continuous physiological data to alert for clinical deterioration. Primary outcomes were time to detection, length of stay in the ICU, and 30-day mortality. Secondary measures included nurse response time, usability and acceptance of the system, measured with structured tools and qualitative interviews. The AI-supported group exhibited notable improvements on a number of important outcomes. The mean length of stay in the ICU was decreased by 1.8 days (p < 0.05), detection of deterioration time was shortened by 3.4 hours (p < 0.05), and 30-day mortality was reduced by 33% (p < 0.05). Intervention group nurses also registered quicker response times and had high system usability and acceptance ratings (mean System Usability Scale score of 86.5/100, perceived usefulness score of 4.4/5). Open-ended feedback noted that nurses perceived the AI system as an auxiliary tool that supplemented their clinical judgment instead of diminishing it. This research clearly demonstrates that AI-enabled nursing assessment tools can lead to meaningful improvements in clinical outcomes and response times, along with being easily adopted into current ICU nursing workflow. The positive sense of usability for nursing personnel and belief in the AI tool's ability to enhance clinical decision-making suggests that involving nurses when designing AI into health care systems has value. These contributions point to the possibility of optimization of critical care utilization of resources by adopting AI in big-way approaches to integrate AI in health care systems - especially considering the significant shortage of resources (including human ones) in care settings around the world. Further studies which are multi-center and longer-term are needed to confirm the findings of this study and the long-term influence of an AI integration to regulate health care systems.

title: Enhancing Stock Forecasting Accuracy Through LSTM-Based Recurrent Models
authors: Eduardo Miguel Bennaton, Mohamed Nazih Baroudi, Waqas Ali Khan, Rand Kouatly, Meerah Karunanithi, Ahmed Hassan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Stock market forecasting has long been regarded as one of the most challenging yet critical tasks in financial analytics, as it directly supports decision-making in investment strategies, risk mitigation, and economic planning. Accurate forecasting not only assists individual and institutional investors in optimizing their portfolios but also contributes to the stability and predictability of broader economic systems. Recent developments in deep learning, particularly in the fields of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-based Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), have created new opportunities for handling complex financial time-series data. These architectures enable the discovery of non-linear dependencies and hidden structures within large datasets that traditional machine learning approaches often fail to capture. However, despite these advances, a systematic comparative analysis of CNN and LSTM performance across multiple stock indices remains limited, thereby restricting model selection strategies within financial research and practice. In this study, we conduct an extensive evaluation of CNN and LSTM-RNN models by applying them to diverse stock indices, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI), NASDAQ, New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), Russell 2000, and S&P 500. The experiments reveal that LSTM-based models consistently outperform CNN architectures, achieving predictive accuracies of up to 90 %. The findings of this research highlight the strategic advantage of adopting LSTM-based frameworks for stock market prediction, offering investors, policymakers, and developers reliable tools to enhance predictive performance. Ultimately, the study provides a robust, data-driven comparison between CNN and LSTM approaches, delivering practical guidance for designing future forecasting systems and contributing to the advancement of financial decision-support technologies.

title: Research on Parameter Optimization of Grid-connected Inverters Based on Swarm Intelligence Algorithms and the Impact of Error Criteria
authors: Gaoshan Hou, Yingpei Wang, Jiaxiang Wang, Zhengang Lu, Xin Qi, Xiaoyu Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The tuning of control parameters for dual-loop converters has long been highly dependent on engineering experience. The traditional manual tuning method has inherent drawbacks such as low efficiency and insufficient robustness. This paper constructs an optimization framework combining genetic algorithm and particle swarm optimization, and realizes the automatic optimization of the parameters of the dual-loop PI controller through the establishment of a PSCAD-Python joint simulation platform. This research focuses on two core issues: (1) Regarding the algorithm, in response to the common problems such as premature convergence and insufficient computational efficiency in swarm intelligence algorithms, innovative methods such as the elite retention mechanism and cosine annealing inertia weight were adopted to enhance the convergence speed. Moreover, the advantages and disadvantages of these two algorithms were compared, along with their applicability in this project. (2) Regarding result evaluation, a grid-connected system is simulated to analyze the differential influence laws of four typical error integral criteria (ISE, IAE, ITSE, ITAE) on the harmonic performance and dynamic response performance.

title: The Use of Digital Platforms in the Administration of Income Tax for Medical Professionals in Peru
authors: Noe Valderrama-Marquina, Claudia Valeria Huaman Cabanillas, Leonardo Anderson Huerta Alvarez, Mag. Eva Judith Berlanga-Valdez, Mag. Consuelo Huerta-Calixto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: This study examines how medical professionals in Lima, Peru use SUNAT's digital platforms to comply with personal income tax obligations. Using a quantitative, descriptive, cross-sectional design, data were collected from 380 physicians selected through simple random sampling. Results reveal low tax knowledge, limited digital literacy, and weak tax motivation, which negatively affect the effective use of digital platforms and compliance with fourth- and fifth-category income regulations. Although digital tools are available, their adoption remains hindered by insufficient training, usability barriers, and low trust in public fiscal management. The study highlights the need for targeted taxpayer education, improved platform design, and stronger institutional transparency to enhance tax compliance and digital adoption among professionals.

title: Toward Inclusive and Ethical Adoption of Autonomous Vehicles in Smart Urban Environments
authors: Swarnamouli Majumdar, Deepika Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) are becoming central to the mobility infrastructure of smart cities, promising safer, cleaner, and more efficient transportation. Yet, their adoption also introduces significant ethical, social, and regulatory challenges that extend far beyond technical deployment. This paper presents a multi-dimensional framework grounded in Rawlsian justice theory and Value-Sensitive Design to evaluate and guide the ethical integration of AVs into urban ecosystems. Drawing on empirical evidence and simulation using the Cityscapes dataset, we identify key areas of concern including perception bias, spatial inequity in AV deployment, data privacy risks, and surveillance implications. Our findings reveal that AV systems, if unregulated, may exacerbate digital redlining and reinforce socio-economic disparities. We propose ethical risk modeling and decentralized governance mechanisms to mitigate these risks and promote transparency, inclusivity, and sustainability. By combining theoretical ethics with technical simulation and policy analysis, this study offers a comprehensive roadmap for cities aiming to align AV innovation with principles of justice, trust, and resilience.

title: Advancing Last Meal Delivery: Developing a Reliable and Efficient YOLO Algorithm for Autonomous Food Delivery Drones
authors: P. A. Vikhar, Abhishek Kalaskar, Kanhaiya Patil, Siddhant Shinde

The YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithm was used for real-time object detection so that drones in FOODCOPTER can navigate their way on precisely agile maneuvers around dynamic urban environments. The project has high standards of safety, and the focus is on the maximum energy efficiency of the drone design. FOODCOPTER does its best job in the construction of the delivery system through properly equipped drones and using an optimized flight path for minimal possible effects on the environment. This actually becomes really important as sustainability is part of the global effort toward greener urban infrastructures. With this, the application built will be mobile responsive. Which will assure the customer that he can order and track his delivery easily in real time. Effortless platform, allowing consumers to seamlessly enjoy fast and reliable food deliveries with less hassle in comparison to traditional approaches. Through the highest testing and iteration, FOODCOPTER will strive to break the barrier in efficiency and sustainability in city logistics regarding food. It will represent a new norm in a smarter system of final mile delivery in the industry. Foodcopter is an example of innovation technology use and responsibility towards the environment. It's going to be the ultimate game-changer for the future of urban logistics.

title: Power Supply for AUV Charging Docking Stations
authors: Valleriy Knyazhev, Vladimir Loshchenkov
abstract: Charging-docking stations allow autonomous underwater-unmanned vehicles (AUV) to operate autonomously for a long time without returning to the port or lifting to the carrier vessel. At these docking stations, the onboard batteries of the AUV are charged and they can store and transmit further information received from the AUV. For this, charging docking stations must have energy sources capable of supplying energy for an unlimited time, or with periodic, but rather rare refueling. The energy supply of charging docking stations via cable lines, from renewable energy sources is considered: wind, wave, solar energy, energy of currents and temperature gradients in the ocean, nuclear energy sources, hydrogen fuel cells. The energy reserves at the charging dock station when using a hydrogen fuel cell battery depend on the capacity of the reagent storage system. The parameters of the system with fuel cell batteries and high-pressure gas cylinders produced in Russia are estiated. The energy and power of the charging station required for charging the MT-2010 and MT-2013 devices developed at the IPMT FEB RAS are determined.

title: Singular perturbation approximation based Frequency-limited Gramian Framework for Continuous-time LTI Systems
authors: Deepak Kumar, Kumari Kanchan
abstract: This study presents a novel configuration of frequency-limited controllability and observability Gramians to establish a new singular perturbation approximation-based model reduction approach. The proposed approach minimizes errors within designated frequency ranges for given higher-order models. The proposed method produces stable, simpler models and offers improved approximations compared to current methodologies. Two numerical examples are used to evaluate the efficacy of the presented method.

title: Energy-Optimized and Delay-Ensured Task Offloading in High-Mobility Vehicle Edge Computing Networks
authors: Ziyue Zheng, Haitao Yuan, Jing Bi, Jia Zhang, MengChu Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Vehicles and connected devices has intensified demands for data processing in intelligent transportation systems. While vehicles possess limited onboard computational resources, Vehicular Edge Computing (VEC) networks leverage edge servers to reduce energy consumption and meet latency requirements for delay-sensitive tasks. However, high vehicle mobility poses a significant challenge to effective resource allocation. Most existing studies focus on offloading strategies while overlooking the impact of vehicle mobility. This work formulates a constrained single-objective optimization problem and proposes a hybrid metaheuristic algorithm-Genetic Simulated Annealing Particle Swarm Optimization (GSPSO)-to obtain near-optimal solutions. Experimental results show that GSPSO effectively minimizes energy consumption, achieving reductions of 47.84 % and 97.95 % compared to Genetic Algorithm and Simulated Annealing Particle Swarm Optimization, respectively.

title: UAV Trajectory Tracking and Control Using Adaptive Particle Swarm Optimized Backstepping Sliding Mode Control for Aerial Inspections
authors: Ejaz Ahmed, Hazrat Bilal, Xiaopin Zhong, Ming Wen, Yibin Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Efficient Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) trajectory tracking and control are essential for aerial inspection applications. The control of quadrotor UAVs is challenging because of their nonlinear behavior and modeling uncertainties. To minimize these complexities, we propose an Optimal Backstepping Sliding-Mode Control (OBSMC) framework for UAV trajectory tracking that combines the capabilities of backstepping with the disturbance rejection feature of sliding-mode control. Trajectory planning is carried out by generating spiral waypoints, ensuring that each horizontal segment covers an equal area and facilitates smooth control. The adaptive particle swarm optimizer is used to tune the parameters of sliding surfaces and control laws, thus improving convergence and maintaining robust performance against dynamic parameter variations. The robustness and performance of the proposed controller were evaluated through simulation studies on different trajectories. Comparative analysis with advanced control strategies confirms the effectiveness of the OBSMC approach in achieving precise UAV trajectory tracking.

title: Optimality of Output-sampled Model Predictive Path Integral Control (oMPPI) using Inverse Models
authors: Wade Marquette, Leon Yan, Santosh Devasia
abstract: Trajectory-sampling-based techniques, such as model predictive path integral control (MPPI), are well suited to solve complex optimization problems with numerous weighted cost terms and non-smooth constraints. However, it can be challenging to design the input-sampling distribution to fully capture and correct the effects of system dynamics to enable precision output tracking. This challenge can be resolved with the output-sampled MPPI (oMPPI) approach, which first augments the system with its inverse to generate inputs that account for the system dynamics and achieve accurate output tracking, and second applies the standard MPPI approach to the augmented system with the inverse. The main contribution of this work is to show that optimality of MPPI is preserved with the oMPPI formulation when sampling the system’s reference outputs — rather than sampling the inputs as in standard MPPI. This theoretical development validates experimental improvements shown in prior work on oMPPI.

title: 3D Denoising Diffusion Video Frame Interpolation (5DVFI)
authors: Chandon Hamel, Mike Busch
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Video Frame Interpolation (VFI), the task of synthesizing intermediate frames, is crucial for applications like slow-motion generation and frame rate enhancement. Denoising diffusion models have emerged as the state-of-the-art for this task. However, leading methods often rely on complex latent diffusion frameworks or resource-intensive cascaded pipelines that operate in pixel space. This creates a need for simpler, more direct architectures that are computationally efficient.This paper introduces 5DVFI, a novel VFI method that utilizes a single, non-cascaded 3D U-Net architecture operating entirely in pixel space. This design prioritizes architectural simplicity and direct spatio-temporal modeling to provide an accessible alternative. Trained and evaluated under significant resource constraints, including a low training resolution (192p), the model does not yet match the perceptual metrics of state-of-the-art systems. However, it demonstrates exceptional efficiency, with an approximately 8x smaller parameter count (56M) and significantly faster inference speed compared to leading latent diffusion models. As a proof-of-concept, it establishes that lightweight, direct pixel-space diffusion models are a viable and promising direction for developing efficient VFI solutions.
