title: Practical Data-Induced Learning Control for Robotic Manipulators with Guaranteed Performance
authors: Changxin Lu, Deyuan Meng, Jingyao Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: This paper introduces a Practical Data-Induced Learning Control (P-DiLC) framework for high-precision motion control of multi-joint robotic manipulators. The proposed controller autonomously learns from operational data to handle challenges such as unknown inertial parameters (e.g., variable payloads), complex disturbances like friction, and external contact forces. A dual-timescale architecture enables the controller to build a predictive feedforward model for repeatable dynamics, such as gravitational torques, while adaptively suppressing unpredictable events. By systematically integrating a command filter, the design rigorously solves the fundamental problem of applying non-differentiable, data-induced learning laws to MIMO robotic systems. A composite energy function analysis proves that all signals are bounded and the tracking error converges to a user-prescribed neighborhood.

title: Development of a 6-DoF Robotic Manipulator with Smart Actuators and Real-Time Inverse Kinematics
authors: Zuyan Chen, Zhendai Huang, Yu Gan, Fei Hu, Juha Röning, Shuai Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: Commercial 6-DoF robotic manipulators are often expensive and structurally closed, limiting their accessibility in education, research, and low-cost automation. Moreover, many low-cost alternatives suffer from limited precision, poor real-time performance, or lack of reproducibility. As a practical alternative, this paper presents the development of a modular 6-DoF robotic manipulator constructed using Xiaomi CyberGear actuators and 3D-printed structural components. A Jacobian-based geometric inverse kinematics algorithm enables real-time, closed-loop pose control across all joints via a distributed embedded architecture with CAN bus communications. The mechanical structure is manufactured through additive methods to reduce weight and cost while maintaining design flexibility. Both simulation and physical experiments demonstrate sub-centimeter root-meansquare tracking errors for circular and square trajectories in three orthogonal planes. The results validate the system's suitability for applications requiring high precision, responsiveness, and ease of customization.

title: Dynamic Pricing with Bi-LSTM Load Forecasting: A Path towards Grid Stability
authors: P. Mondal, S. Sengupta, A Sarkar, A. Roy, C. Sain, Furkan Ahmad, Ameni Boumaiza
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: Fluctuations in electricity demand between peak and off-peak periods create significant challenges for modern power grids, including reduced operational efficiency, decreased reliability, and an increased risk of power outages. Peak demand conditions strain the transmission and distribution systems, while off-peak underutilization leads to inefficient resource allocation. This study proposes a machine learning–based dynamic subsidy and penalty framework to minimize demand fluctuations and enhance grid stability. Historical electricity consumption data are analyzed to identify peak and off-peak periods, and machine learning techniques are applied to forecast future demand with improved accuracy. Based on these forecasts, a real-time tariff adjustment scheme is designed, wherein subsidies are introduced during off-peak hours to encourage higher consumption, and penalties are applied during peak hours to discourage excessive demand. Additionally, the proposed approach is expected to smoothen the load curve, reduce grid stress during peak periods, and improve utilization of infrastructure during the off-peak periods. By influencing consumer behavior through adaptive pricing, the framework ensures an effective demand-side management strategy that enhances system reliability, stability, and efficiency in smart grid environments compared with existing approaches.

title: A Flexible Energy Scheduling Strategy for Fast Charging Stations Considering V2G of EVs and PV Uncertainty
authors: Xiaohai Ge, Xin Zhang, Dehong Xu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: To meet the growing electric vehicle (EV) charging demand, fast charging stations based on novel DC architecture are being widely deployed. However, the increasing number and expanding scale of EV fast charging stations introduce significant uncertainties and fluctuations, which can cause substantial disturbances to the power grid. It is necessary to design energy scheduling strategies that optimize system operation, achieving both load fluctuation mitigation and optimal economic efficiency. This paper proposes an innovative flexible energy scheduling strategy tailored for EV fast charging stations, utilizing a power forecasting model to reduce the uncertainty of scheduling and incorporating vehicle-to-grid (V2G) capabilities of EVs to reduce overall costs. An Informer forecasting model is developed to realize multi-timescale unified forecasting encompassing photovoltaic (PV) generation and EV loads with lower computing costs. On the other hand, the proposed method incorporates a certain proportion of EVs and flexible loads as virtual energy storage in system scheduling, thereby further optimizing operating costs. Finally, verification results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high forecasting accuracy and significant cost reduction, thereby realizing optimized scheduling for EV fast-charging stations.

title: Fault Detection of Small Fixed-Wing UAVs Based on Temporal Self-Attention and Long Short-Term Memory Network
authors: Suzhen Fan, Hao Luo, Jilun Tian, Minglei Li, Hao Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: To tackle the safety challenges encountered by small fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) operating in complex environments, we propose a deep learning model that integrates a temporal self-attention mechanism with a long short-term memory (LSTM) network for high-precision fault detection. The proposed method exploits the self-attention mechanism to explicitly capture long-range dependencies within sequential sensor data, while the LSTM network extracts dynamic temporal features, thereby enhancing the discriminative capability of fault types. Experimental results on real flight datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves over 97% accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, significantly outperforming conventional machine learning methods such as support vector machines. Moreover, ablation studies validate the effectiveness of integrating LSTM and self-attention, showing that the model substantially enhances robustness and performance in fault detection, thereby providing reliable technical support for the safe operation of small fixed-wing UAVs.

title: A Distortion-Aware Convolutional Neural Network for Head Pose Estimation in Fisheye Image
authors: Ning Zhang, Haoran Huang, Dong Zhang, Dah-Jye Lee
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Head pose estimation (HPE) is essential for understanding human behavior, bolstering interactions between humans and computers, and enhancing surveillance systems for safety. Fisheye lens, with its extensive field of view, outperforms the conventional perspective lens in applications that demand a broad visual scope. However, this advantage comes with significant image distortion, which may lead to the loss of crucial facial feature data and alterations in the relative positions of these features. This paper introduces a distortion-aware approach that jointly learns coarse- and fine-level distortion representations to enhance head-orientation estimation accuracy in fisheye image. Specifically, we design a distortion-aware branch to perceive coarse-grained distortion features by learning the position of the head center in the fisheye image. At the same time, the fine-grained distortion features of the head region are modeled by the coordinated attention. The proposed approach was benchmarked on fisheye-distorted variants of three widely used head-pose corpora: BIWI, 300W-LP, and AFLW2000. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms current state-of-the-art approaches. Compared with the suboptimal method, our model achieves a 7.4% and 9.7% decrease in MAE on the AFLW2000-360 and BIWI-360 datasets, respectively.

title: A Fractional-N Frequency Synthesizer with High-Precision Phase Shifter Based on Delta-Sigma Modulation
authors: Ming Qu, Duo Wang, Bufang Zhang, Xuan Wei, Mingyu Song, Bin Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: This paper presents a fractional-N frequency synthesizer incorporating a high-precision phase shifter implemented with Delta-Sigma modulation (DSM). The phase shift is achieved by controlling the translation of the DSM output sequence, and the 12-bit phase-control word covers a full <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$360^{\circ}$</tex> phase adjustment range with a resolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$360^{\circ} / 2^{12}$</tex>. Fabricated in 180 nm SiGe BiCMOS technology, the chip occupies an area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.54 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Operating from a 3.3 V supply with a 50 MHz reference frequency, the synthesizer delivers an output frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.55-4.4 \text{GHz}$</tex>. At a carrier frequency of 4.4 GHz, it achieves an output phase noise of −125.78 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz offset, a spurious suppression of 71.077 dB, and a power consumption of 495 mW. The proposed architecture is suitable for digital phased-array beamforming, high-speed serial-to-parallel conversion, and related systems.

title: Koopman Predictive Control of Series-Parallel Line-Interactive UPS Under Parameter Uncertainties for Power Quality Improvement
authors: Shana Zhu, Qing Wang, Yi Lu, Guilin Wang, Qingrong Zheng, Jianli Zhao, Ziteng Liu, Zhuofan Tang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional equivalent-circuit-model-based control methods for series-parallel line-interactive UPS, which are constrained by system parameter uncertainties (e.g., LC filter parameters, line impedances), this paper proposes a Koopman operator-based predictive control method. The method separates the Standby and Backup modes based on the static switch status of the UPS and constructs corresponding augmented state-space models for each mode. Utilizing observable functions, the input-output data matrices are built. The finite-dimensional approximation of the Koopman operator is then solved via an optimization problem formulated using the extended dynamic mode decomposition principle. Subsequently, mode-dependent Koopman predictors are constructed for both operational modes. Based on these predictors, mode-specific Koopman predictive controllers are designed. The control law for each mode is generated in real-time by solving a quadratic programming problem. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in regulating the series-parallel converters of the UPS to mitigate various types of power quality issues.

title: The Secondary Development of an Operation Record Management System Based on 3GL
authors: Bin Zhang, Duo Wu, Zhaoyuan Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: The paper takes the SINUMERIK 840DsI/828D/ One Computer Numerical Control (CNC) system as the research object. Based on the SINUMERIK Integrate Create MyHMI/3GL (Qt API) development framework, a set of operation record management system is designed and implemented. The system extends the standard HMI functions through secondary development, and realizes real-time monitoring and recording of operational behaviors, with support for multi-dimensional classification storage by date, time, operation type, etc. At the same time, the system provides flexible multi-condition query functionality, and adopts visualization technology to analyze the operation data, facilitating managers to quickly grasp the equipment operating status. Practical applications indicate that the system can effectively enhance the traceability of machine tool operations, optimize production management processes, and provide a feasible solution for the intelligent upgrading of CNC systems.

title: Smart Railway Passenger Counting and Information Systems Powered by Real-Time Embedded AI and Computer Vision
authors: Sajanraj Thandassery, Yixiao Zhang, Baihua Li, Mohamad Saada, Haibin Cai, Qinggang Meng, Qun Zhu, Qingsong Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: The passenger information system in railway sector is essential for helping passengers with schedules, connectivity, and overall comfort. It delivers on-board passenger information for trams, trains, and buses as an innovative solution with real-time information. Our proposed method utilizes an edge computing based computer vision algorithm to accurately count passenger data on an embedded computing board, including the number of passengers entering and exiting, as well as the current load in each carriage. This information is then presented in a way that helps passengers choose the carriage or route that best maintains their comfort. The system’s design and development, from the sensor device to the API specification and its visual representation, are developed as part of a comprehensive product development process. The proposed method tested with an accuracy of 98% using data collected from a wide angle Time-of-Flight (TOF) camera-based counting system that utilized passenger detection and tracking.

title: Automotive Middleware Performance: Comparison of FastDDS, Zenoh and vSomeIP
authors: David Philipp Klüner, Lucas Hegerath, Amin Dieter Hatib, Stefan Kowalewski, Bassam Alrifaee, Alexandru Kampmann
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: In this paper, we analyze the performance of modern automotive communication middleware and their interactions with the operating system kernel under various operating conditions. Specifically, we examine FastDDS, a widely used open-source middleware, the newly developed Zenoh middleware, and vSomeIP, COVESAs open-source implementation of SOME/IP. Our objective is to identify the best performing middleware for specific operating conditions and understand their interaction with the kernel to achieve best performance. To ensure accessibility, we first provide a concise overview of middleware technologies and their fundamental principles. We first introduce our performance testing methodology designed to systematically assess middleware performance metrics such as scaling performance, end-to-end latency, and discovery times across multiple message types, network topologies, and configurations. Then, we present our methodology to examine the kernel latency contribution and the metrics we consider. Finally, we compare the resulting performance data and present our results in 12 findings.Our evaluation code is available at https://github.com/embedded-software-laboratory/MWTracer.

title: Collapsing Catalytic Classes
authors: Michal Koucký, Ian Mertz, Edward Pyne, Sasha Sami
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: A catalytic machine is a space-bounded Turing machine with additional access to a second, much larger work tape, with the caveat that this tape is full, and its contents must be preserved by the computation. Catalytic machines were defined by Buhrman et al. (STOC 2014), who, alongside many follow-up works, exhibited the power of catalytic space (CSPACE) and, in particular, catalytic logspace machines (CL) beyond that of traditional space-bounded machines. Several variants of CL have been proposed, including nondeterministic and co-non-deterministic catalytic computation by Buhrman et al. (STACS 2016) and randomized catalytic computation by Datta et al. (CSR 2020). These and other works proposed several questions, such as catalytic analogues of the theorems of Savitch and Immerman and Szelepcsényi. Catalytic computation was recently derandomized by Cook et al. (STOC 2025), but only in certain parameter regimes. We settle almost all questions regarding randomized and nondeterministic catalytic computation by giving an optimal reduction from catalytic space with additional resources to the corresponding non-catalytic space classes. With regards to non-determinism, our main result is that CL = CNL and with regards to randomness we show CL = CPrL where CPrL denotes randomized catalytic logspace where the accepting probability can be arbitrarily close to 1/2. We also have a number of near-optimal partial results for non-deterministic and randomized catalytic computation with less catalytic space. We show catalytic versions of Savitch’s theorem, Immerman-Szelepscényi, and the derandomization results of Nisan and Saks and Zhou, all of which are unconditional and hold for all parameter settings. Our results build on the compress-or-compute framework of Cook et al. (STOC 2025). Despite proving broader and stronger results, our framework is simpler and more modular.

title: Group Order is in QCMA
authors: François Le Gall, Harumichi Nishimura, Dhara Thakkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In this work, we show that verifying the order of a finite group given as a black-box is in the complexity class QCMA. This solves an open problem asked by Watrous in 2000 in his seminal paper on quantum proofs and directly implies that the Group Non-Membership problem is also in the class QCMA, which further proves a conjecture proposed by Aaronson and Kuperberg in 2006. Our techniques also give improved quantum upper bounds on the complexity of many other group-theoretical problems, such as group isomorphism in black-box groups.

title: Gap-preserving reductions and RE-completeness of independent set games
authors: Laura Mančinska, Pieter Spaas, Taro Spirig, Matthijs Vernooij
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In complexity theory, gap-preserving reductions play a crucial role in studying hardness of approximation and in analyzing the relative complexity of multiprover interactive proof systems. In the quantum setting, multiprover interactive proof systems with entangled provers correspond to gapped promise problems for nonlocal games, and the recent result MIP*=RE [1] shows that these are in general undecidable. However, the relative complexity of problems within MIP* is still not well-understood, as establishing gap-preserving reductions in the quantum setting presents new challenges. In this paper, we introduce a framework to study such reductions and use it to establish MIP*-completeness of the gapped promise problem for the natural class of independent set games. In such a game, the goal is to determine whether a given graph contains an independent set of a specified size. We construct families of independent set games with constant question size for which the gapped promise problem is undecidable. In contrast, the same problem is decidable in polynomial time in the classical setting. To carry out our reduction, we establish a new stability theorem, which could be of independent interest, allowing us to perturb families of aThis is a striking phenomenlmost PVMs to genuine PVMs.

title: NLP-Driven Plagiarism Detection: A Smarter Approach
authors: Aditya Narsale, Suyog Nannaware, Vishwajeet Patil, Rohan Sapkale, Ratna Patil
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: With the growing availability of digital content, the demand for efficient plagiarism detection has become exponentially high. The major challenge here is detecting semantic similarity and paraphrased text since traditional keywordmatching algorithms tend to fail in detecting conceptual rewording. This paper introduces an NLP-based plagiarism detection system that performs automated text extraction, comparison, and similarity analysis for scholarly and professional writings. The system supports uploading PDFs, extracting text data, and evaluating possible plagiarism using TF-IDF vectorization and cosine similarity. For better accuracy, it cross-checks extracted text with web sources via Google's Custom Search API. The method combines text preprocessing, feature extraction, and similarity measurement to provide a more accurate textual overlap evaluation. Based on a Flask-based framework, the system provides a user-friendly interface for effortless document analysis and result visualization. Addressing the shortcomings of conventional plagiarism detection techniques, this work sets the stage for further enhancements based on deep learning methodologies to enhance identification of subtle textual similarities. This work advances the development of automated plagiarism detection with a scalable and effective solution for content integrity validation. The contribution of this work is combining NLP similarity analysis with real-time web verification through the Google Custom Search API and the provision of a scalable Flask-based interface to detect plagiarism. The combination embodies current NLP methods and real-world deployment, thereby making the system both useful and usable by professionals and academics.

title: Fully Actuated System Approach-Based Prescribed Time Fault-Tolerant Control and Hierarchical Structure Avoidance Collision for Multiple Unmanned Helicopters
authors: Bo Meng, Ke Zhang, Bin Jiang, Li Guo
abstract: For 6-DOF unmanned helicopters subject to actuator faults, convergence-rate constraints, and collision-avoidance requirements, a prescribed-time fault-tolerant control strategy is proposed in this paper. Primarily, to prevent the faulty unmanned helicopter from affecting other normal individuals, an upperlayer virtual agent system prescribed-time control protocol is developed based on the fully actuated system approach. Simultaneously, the artificial potential field is incorporated into the control protocol to establish a hierarchical interaction mechanism, enabling collision avoidance during flight missions. Subsequently, the newly presented prescribed-time sliding mode controller can enable the position subsystem to track the reference signals within the designer-defined time. In addition, a prescribed-time filter is constructed to generate the derivative of the attitude angle. Building upon this filter, the event-triggered mechanism, and fully actuated system approach, a prescribed-time fault-tolerant control tactic for the attitude subsystem is established to reduce the signal transmission burden. Finally, the theoretical results of the proposed control strategy are validated through a simulation example and a comparative experiment.

title: Design and Application of Autonomous Perception Systems for Unmanned Excavators
authors: Gesen Di, Jianlin Zhang, Jiabao Geng, Song Yan, Wanpeng Song, Dong Xu, Kaiqiang Wang, Qing Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: This paper addresses the autonomous perception requirements of unmanned excavators in complex construction environments by proposing a high-precision dump truck localization method based on LiDAR point clouds. Analyzing the technical challenges in excavation-and-loading tasks, the study employs Hesai QT-64 LiDAR as the primary sensor and designs a three-stage algorithm comprising point cloud preprocessing, feature matching, and pose estimation. In the preprocessing stage, environmental interference is effectively eliminated through rule-based filtering, ground segmentation, and joint clustering. For feature matching, an improved Point Pair Feature (PPF) global descriptor is adopted, reducing matching time to 0.09 seconds via hash table optimization and JSON serialization, meeting the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 H z}$</tex> real-time requirement. The pose estimation module introduces a search-based optimized bounding box generation algorithm, leveraging triple criteria and geometric features to resolve ambiguities, achieving a localization accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 10 ~\text{cm}$</tex>. Experimental results demonstrate the system's robustness and real-time performance across various working conditions for both four-wheel and eight-wheel dump trucks, providing reliable technical support for autonomous excavator operations.

title: Accurate Modelling of Wind Characteristics Using Temporal Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: NagaSree Keerthi Pujari, Saumya Mundra, Kishalay Mitra
abstract: On the way to attain energy security and mitigate the climate change related issues, many countries are shifting towards cleaner energy sources. Wind energy, in this regard, has become a promising resource due to its easy availability, cleaner production, and affordability. In studies of wind farm design and control, Wind Frequency Map (WFM) plays a crucial role for its direct involvement in the power calculations. WFM is a joint probability mapping between wind direction and speed considering their time series behavior. Limited amount of wind data, when used for forecasting as well as representing the WFMs, suppresses the ability to represent long term variabilities in wind. This leads to inaccurate estimation of WFM, which in turn results in unrealistic calculation of wind power, leading to non-optimal design and control. Hence, in this paper, Temporal Convolutional Neural Networks (TCNNs) are explored for accurate forecasting of WFMs. As determination of hyper-parameters are performed heuristically as a general practice, the novelty in the proposed formulation lies in determining these parameters through an optimization formulation while performing the network training simultaneously. Effectiveness of this approach, while developing realistic wind forecasting models, has been demonstrated further by showing its ability in accurate power calculations.

title: Retraction Notice: Research on the high resolution remote sensing image classification algorithm based on improved neural network model
authors: Tong Li, Xuan Zheng, Tong Xiong
publish: 2016 International Conference on Communication and Electronics Systems (ICCES)
abstract: Mapping the spatiotemporal attributes of swampland which is wetland that is forested has essential criticalness to the investigation of swampland environment and numerous related widely varied vegetation. Manuscript discusses innovative strategy in view of incorporation of BP and GA, supposed IBPGA, is suggested for high determination plotting of swampland collection (HSA) from multispectral RSI. In correlation with GAHSA, IBGHSA enhanced the exactness of HSA, as well as quickened the joining velocity of the algorithm. title: Retraction Notice: Diagnosis Using Data Mining Algorithms for Malignant Breast Cancer Cell Detection
authors: S. Saranya, S. Sasikala
publish: 2020 4th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Breast malignant development in the most regular disease among women now a day. Among 2.1 million ladies affecting every year and also furthermore causes the maximum number of cancer death related cases among ladies. Early analysis procedures focus on providing opportune access to malignancy treatment and also decreasing hindrances to care effective diagnosis services. The proposed research work has been primarily focused to contribute to the early analysis of breast malignant growth. Here, a study has been performed on the breast malignant growth. The primary goal of the paper is to locate a subset of features to ensure the patients with malignant and the remaining patients, who face difficulty with bosom malignant has to be prognosticate to envelop those data. The study on various malignant classification approaches using decision tree (DT) and deep learning method are used to find the different time complexity, accuracy, sensitivity, and AUC value.

title: Frequency-Weighted Singular Perturbation Approximation based Reduced-Order Design of 2-D Separable Denominator Discrete filters
authors: Deepak Kumar
abstract: This paper presents a novel frequency-weighted singular perturbation approximation-based model reduction technique which is implemented for the design of reduced-order two-dimensional (2-D) separable denominator-type discrete-time infinite impulse response (IIR) filters. The proposed technique uses a singularly perturbed balanced realisation that can be applied with single- and double-sided weights. A numerical example of a (12,12) order low-pass 2-D Butterworth filter is examined to establish the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: An Improved Adaptive Observer-Based T–S Fuzzy Event-Triggered Control For Networked Control Systems
authors: K. Hemalatha, S. Revathy, N. Padmaja
abstract: In consistent with the need of resource-efficient, this paper proposes an improved adaptive event-triggered mechanism (ETM) for networked control systems (NCS) under a communication channel. The study develops a output-based adaptive event-triggered (AET) sensor transmission for a fuzzy network control model to reduce unnecessary data transmissions. This improved AET transmission technique minimizes the utilization of constrained network resources. Lyapunov theory is applied to formulate linear matrix inequality (LMI) based stabilization conditions that guarantee the system’s stability. The proposed control approach, as demonstrated in the simulations, significantly reduces network resource usage compared to the widely used ET approach.

title: Proposal and Validation of a Spinally–Cortically Control Model–based Central Pattern Generator and Muscle Synergy Model during Walking
authors: Ryota Misu, Tianyi Wang, Hayato Mikami, Keisuke Shima, Takayuki Mukaeda, Koji Shimatani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Clarifying the hierarchical roles of the spinal Central Pattern Generator (CPG) and cortex in human walking is critical for addressing gait–related issues. We propose a CPG– Muscle Synergy model that extracts muscle synergies from electromyography and classifies them into spinally driven and cortically driven modes based on activation timing. We use CPG synergy analysis to quantify their rhythmic characteristics and validate the classification with a temporal variability index, hypothesizing that spinal patterns are less variable than cortical ones. Our results confirmed significantly lower temporal variability in the spinally driven group. CPG analysis also revealed that spinal patterns had simpler structures with fewer activation peaks and distinct time–shift properties. These findings support a hierarchical control system where the spinal cord generates a stable, basal rhythm and the cortex provides complex, adaptive modulations. Our model provides a framework for evaluating these neural contributions, enabling a deeper understanding of gait pathologies and informing rehabilitation strategies.

title: Mathematical Model of Once Through Helical Coil Steam Generator for Control Oriented Studies
authors: Vishesh Shrivastava, A. K. Mishra, S. R. Shimjith, S. Sengupta, N. C. Gohel
abstract: This paper presents a nonlinear mathematical model of the once-through type Helical Coil Steam Generator (HCSG). This model is developed using the fundamental principles of mass and energy conservation, to support control system design by capturing the key dynamics of the Steam Generator (SG) accurately. The model is validated through open loop simulations and results are benchmarked against reference model. To facilitate controller design, the nonlinear model is linearized around an equilibrium point to obtain a corresponding linearized model. The properties of the linearized model are studied, and the transient response of linear model is compared with that of the original nonlinear model. Based on the linearized model a Proportional Integral (PI) controller is designed. Finally, the controller’s performance is evaluated through stability analysis and simulations conducted on the original nonlinear model.

title: Descriptor: Synthetic Person Information Dataset for Entity Resolution (SPIDER)
authors: PRAVEEN CHINNAPPA, YASH MATHUR, ROSE MARY AROKIYA DASS
abstract: In the era of AI and cloud computing, customer data has become an integral part of modern business systems. As these data grow in volume and complexity, maintaining data quality, particularly managing duplicate records, remains a persistent challenge. Entity Resolution (ER) algorithms play a vital role in eliminating duplicates. However, developing, testing, and benchmarking these algorithms require large volumes of labeled data containing known duplicate records, which are rarely available in public datasets. The Synthetic Person Information Dataset for Entity Resolution (SPIDER) addresses this issue by providing 50,000 labeled person records, including 10,000 duplicates induced through seven rule-based transformations that simulate real-world duplicate variations. The dataset is available in JSON and CSV formats to ensure compatibility with standard software tools and includes a Python script for data generation to support reproducibility and extensibility. SPIDER offers a unified, person-level benchmark dataset with explicit duplicate lineage, advancing the capabilities of existing ER data-generation resources such as FEBRL and Magellan, and providing a reproducible foundation dataset for ER testing and evaluation.

title: Improved Nonlinear Disturbance Observer-Based Command-Filtered Backstepping Control of Clamping Force for Electro-Mechanical Brakes
authors: Hanning Zhang, Xiangyang Xu, Kun Yao, Longhui Qiu, Shuhan Wang, Peng Dong
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: The electro-mechanical brake (EMB), as a Brakeby-Wire (BBW) system that generates clamping force through a torque motor and mechanical mechanism, features compact structure, fast response, and high control accuracy. This article designs an improved nonlinear disturbance observer-based command-filtered backstepping controller (INDOB-CFBSC) for EMB system, which tracks the clamping force using a clamping force estimator and effectively addresses the nonlinearity and uncertainty of the EMB system. Firstly, an EMB model including the torque motor, gearbox, flexibility-considered ball screw model, pressure-displacement relationship-considered clamping force model and friction is built. Particularly, a clamping force estimation method based on the extended least squares (ELS) is proposed, which transforms the clamping force tracking control into torque motor angular position tracking control. Then, a robust clamping force control strategy, INDOB-CDBSC, is proposed based on the command-filtered backstepping controller (CFBSC) and the improved nonlinear disturbance observer (INDOB). Finally, the test results under different operating conditions demonstrate that the INDOB-CDBSC strategy exhibits excellent tracking performance and robustness in the presence of nonlinearity and uncertainty in the EMB system.

title: Early Detection of Unsupported Compilations during Prototyping in a Template-based Just-in-Time Compiler
authors: Michael C. Goodyear, Scott Young, Marius Pirvu, Harpreet Kaur, Kenneth B. Kent
publish: Proceedings of the 36th International Workshop on Rapid System Prototyping
abstract: None

title: CCAT: Magnetic Sensitivity Measurements of Kinetic Inductance Detectors
authors: Benjamin J. Vaughan, Yuhan Wang, Cody J. Duell, Jason Austermann, James R. Burgoyne, Scott Chapman, Steve K. Choi, Abigail T. Crites, Eliza Gazda, Ben Keller, Michael D. Niemack, Darshan A. Patel, Anna Vaskuri, Eve M. Vavagiakis, Michael Vissers, Samantha Walker, Jordan Wheeler, Ruixuan Xie
abstract: The CCAT Observatory is a ground-based submillimeter to millimeter experiment located on Cerro Chajnantor in the Atacama Desert, at an altitude of 5,600 meters. CCAT features the 6-meter Fred Young Submillimeter Telescope (FYST), which will cover frequency bands from 210 GHz to 850 GHz using its first-generation science instrument, Prime-Cam. The detectors used in Prime-Cam are feedhorn-coupled, lumped-element superconducting microwave kinetic inductance detectors (KIDs). The telescope will perform wide-area surveys at speeds on the order of degrees per second. During telescope operation, the KIDs are exposed to changes in the magnetic field caused by the telescope's movement through Earth's magnetic field and internal sources within the telescope. We present and compare measurements of the magnetic sensitivity of three different CCAT KID designs at 100 mK. The measurements are conducted in a dilution refrigerator (DR) with a set of room temperature Helmholtz coils positioned around the DR. We discuss the implications of these results for CCAT field operations.

title: Design and Implementation of an Anthropomorphic Robotic Hand with Key Kinematic Properties of Human Hand
authors: Dai Chu, Jiaji Ma, Siyuan Chen, Jiarui Zhang, Zhiyi Huang, Jinhao Yang, Chang He, Wenbin Chen, Baiyang Sun, Caihua Xiong
abstract: Designing an anthropomorphic robotic hand with few actuators while replicating the dexterous motion capabilities of the human hand remains a challenging problem. In this work, a kinematic synergy analysis method is proposed to identify joints with high motion independence and to quantify the synergistic motion characteristics of joints with strong motion dependence. Based on these findings, design principles for intra finger and inter-finger coupling–compliance mechanisms are developed, enabling the mechanical embodiment of joint kinematic synergies within and between fingers. Furthermore, a design principle for anthropomorphic robotic hands that reduces actuator count while retaining diverse motion functions is formulated. This principle is embodied in a 12-actuator, 21-joint prototype named SX-Hand, featuring a flexible thumb and an articulated palm. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that SX Hand achieves the maximum score in the Kapandji test, performs all 33 grasp types defined in the comprehensive GRASP taxonomy, and executes dexterous in-hand manipulations. The proposed approach provides an effective conceptual and technical route for reproducing rich motion functions with reduced actuation, offering valuable guidance for the development of efficient anthropomorphic robotic hands and other bionic systems.

title: Multimodal Non-Contact Based Modeling of Enervation
authors: Salem Sharak, Kais Riani, Mohamed Abouelenien, Mihai Burzo, Rada Mihalcea, John Elson, Clay Maranville
abstract: The advancement of autonomous vehicle technology has heightened interest in modeling occupant states and behaviors. This paper models occupant circadian state using four modalities: physiological, thermal, linguistic, and acoustic modalities. Moreover, it advances research by developing a fully non-contact pipeline to derive physiological signals from thermal imagery. Linguistic and acoustic features derived from speech are incorporated with the extracted physiological and thermal features to enhance circadian rhythm models and detect enervation states. The proposed approach leverages a multimodal dataset of 36 subjects captured across multiple channels. Comparative analysis between non-contact and contactbased channels reveals that physiological signals from thermal imagery, combined with linguistic and acoustic data, achieve accuracy comparable to or exceeding those of contact-based methods. This non-contact approach achieves accurate identification of energized versus enervated states, reaching 78.6% accuracy. These findings offer a novel framework for integrating unobtrusive sensing technologies in future automotive designs, facilitating next-generation occupant monitoring.

title: Rydberg Atom-Based OAM-FDM Integration for High-Capacity Microwave Communications
authors: Zheyuan Wang, Chao Zhang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: Rydberg atoms enable ultrasensitive microwave detection through their exceptional polarizability, but their use as decoders in communications is limited by a scarcity of scalable frequency points, which arises from cross-modulation in multifrequency fields and narrow operational bandwidth of the sensor. This work introduces a digital communication framework that integrates orbital angular momentum (OAM) with frequency-division multiplexing (FDM). By mapping each FDM subcarrier to a distinct OAM, we construct a 2-D multiplexing space that combines the spectral dimension of FDM with the spatial-phase dimension of OAM. As a result, the theoretical channel capacity scales as the product of the capacities attainable in each individual dimension, thereby overcoming the inherent limit of conventional single-dimensional multiplexing. OAM features are mapped to Rydberg electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) spectra through quadrupole-gradient coupling, enabling simultaneous OAM identification and FDM demodulation using spectral templates, without separate detectors. Simulations show greater than 98% overall recognition accuracy under the transition <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$|61\text {D}_{5/2}\rangle \to |63\text {P}_{1/2}\rangle $</tex-math> </inline-formula>: at an SNR of under 10 dB, OAM mode 1 is identified with 99.6% accuracy (0.4% misclassification) and OAM mode 0 with 98.1% (1.9% misclassification). Meanwhile, QPSK phase recognition remains greater than 98.5%, with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\varphi _{k}=\pi /2$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\pi /2$</tex-math> </inline-formula> being 1.5–2% lower than for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\varphi _{k}=0$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi $</tex-math> </inline-formula>. This work supports high-performance multifrequency microwave technologies by enhancing capacity and simplifying the architecture.

title: Regularized Gradient Descent for Hyper-Parameter Tuning in the Kappa-Eta Algorithm
authors: Deepak Ramsubhag, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The recently introduced Kappa-Eta algorithm has demonstrated exceptional performance in regression, classification, and other machine learning tasks. In this algorithm, each feature is associated with its own hyperparameter, which has traditionally been optimized in isolation. We show that jointly optimizing all parameters over the feature space leads to better performance due to the existence of multiple local optima. Furthermore, while independent tuning is more susceptible to the influence of outliers, joint optimization reduces these effects. We also introduce regularization and compare three approaches: independent optimization, joint optimization, and joint optimization with regularization. This combined method not only mitigates overfitting and enhances robustness against noise but also reduces computation by significantly narrowing the search space.

title: Hybrid Distributed Model Predictive Control of Flywheel–Battery Energy Storage Systems for Virtual Inertia and Fast Frequency Response
authors: Willy Stephane Ngaha, David Dorrell, Gomes Chandima
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Inverter-based resources (IBRs) are an intermittent source of energy, and their increased integration into power systems significantly reduces the physical inertia provided by synchronous generators, which account for about 20 % of gas emissions. This solution to global warming has created a problem of inertia response for the power system. The adequate control of these IBRs to provide virtual inertia should consider their percentage contribution capacity and existing grid energy storage, which are mostly battery energy storage systems (BESS). However, conventional control methods often fail to account for these critical features. This omission exacerbates the challenge of maintaining frequency stability in low-inertia grids, particularly in developing countries where centralized control architectures may be costly or impractical. This paper proposes a Hybrid Distributed Model Predictive Control (HD-MPC) strategy to coordinate 15 units of 100 kW flywheel energy storage systems (FESS) and 500 kW BESS, respectively, for virtual inertia support and fast frequency response in a two-area load frequency control (2A-LFC) system. The distributed framework enables each local area to operate semi-independently, thereby reducing communication burdens and enhancing resilience against delays or failures. Simulation results on MATLAB/SIMULINK of a 30 MW 2A-LFC model demonstrate that, in the event of 1 MW disturbances, the proposed HD-MPC approach outperforms conventional centralized MPC and uncontrolled cases by improving frequency nadir, reducing tie-line oscillations, and ensuring efficient BESS utilization. The results and validation of the mathematical model coding using Python highlight the viability of hybrid FESS–BESS coordination to improve frequency stability in inverter-dominated power systems, offering a scalable and practical solution for developing countries transitioning to IBR-dominated grids.

title: Design and Application of a Low Voltage Distribution Area Power Quality Monitoring System Based on the Internet of Things
authors: Bangpeng Xie, Jiayu Wang, Hao Shen, Wenkai Zhao, Daliang Hu, Weihong Zhang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To address growing power-quality issues in 0.4 kV networks, this paper presents an IoT-based monitoring system featuring lightweight terminals that acquire multi-parameter data and perform local diagnostics. Data are uploaded via 4G/5G to a cloud platform for real-time monitoring, fault alerts, and quality assessment. Field tests demonstrate improved power-quality management and decision support for utilities.

title: Simulation design of meter level wireless power system based on relay mode
authors: Xin Jing, Hongwei Ye, Zhenli Wang, Lina Zhang, Xing Wu, Xin Li
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: To meet the reliable power supply requirements of high-voltage transmission line monitoring equipment in smart grids, this paper designs an insulator embedded multi relay wireless energy transmission system, which achieves meter level transmission through short-range relay of relay coils. The study first establishes a multi coil equivalent circuit and an n-coil transmission efficiency model, combines insulator characteristics with Comsol simulation to optimize the coil, and verifies its performance through Comsol and Matlab. Thirteen relay coil prototypes were used in the experiment, with a resonant frequency of 150kHz and a transmission efficiency of 40%. The output power exceeded 15W, meeting the power supply requirements for monitoring equipment. The feasibility of this scheme was verified, providing a new solution for intelligent power supply.

title: Quantum-Inspired Genetic Algorithms for Secure and Scalable Cloud-Based Decision Support Systems
authors: Mithun DSouza, Rahul Pradhan, Chamandeep Kaur, S.Suma Christal Mary, Jyothi Preshiya, Ponni Valavan M
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Cloud-based DSS are critical for data-intensive decision-making but tremendously challenged by issues of scalability, security, and the optimization of resources. In general, optimization approaches such as GA, PSO, and ACO treat the problems of allocation and security enhancement of cloud resources very inadequately. Hence, the present work addresses developing a QIGA-based optimization framework for the performance optimization of cloud DSS. At its core, it utilizes quantum-like principles, such as superposition and probabilistic search, for resource optimization with respect to stability, security, and rapid convergence. Therefore, this underpinning framework comprises resource optimization, anomalous detection, and quantum-independent encryption through QIGA, which enhances the data security along with computational efficiency. The experimental results depict the performance efficiency of QIGA since its execution time, CPU, memory utilization requirements, and energy consumption are less while the task completion rate is higher and the security vulnerabilities are reduced in comparison to traditional optimization techniques. QIGA-based anomaly detection improves accuracy at the expense of response time, while its quantum-inspired encryption provides the best cryptographic security. Therefore, these results verify that QIGA is an efficient secured methodology for scalable cloud-controlled DSS, hence being a potential candidate for decision-making optimization in highly dynamic cloud environments.

title: IoT-Based Intravenous Fluid Monitoring and Alerting System for Automated Healthcare Management
authors: Amruta More, Prachi Bhagat, Pranali Zagade, Abhijit Wagh, Suhani Kad
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: In medical care, accurate and timely monitoring of intravenous (IV) fluid levels is essential to prevent complications. Traditional methods require manual checking, which can lead to oversight and increased workload on healthcare professionals. This paper presents an IoT-based Intravenous Fluid Monitoring and Alerting System designed to address this issue. The system automatically tracks the fluid level in the saline bottle using a load cell sensor and displays the status on an LCD. Once the fluid level reaches low or critical levels, alerts are triggered through a buzzer, an LCD display, and notifications sent via the Blynk IoT app. This ensures timely intervention and reduces the risk of air entering the patient's bloodstream, thereby enhancing patient safety and operational efficiency.

title: Protecting Deep Learning Channel Estimation in Wireless Networks with Defensive Distillation Against Adversarial Attacks
authors: Sowjanya Yerramaneni, Niteesha Shrama, T Asha Latha, Ramesh Babu Pittala, Gudepu Sai Krishna, Ch. Karthik Bharadhwaj, Gandla Mahesh, Dunpalle Basi Reddy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Very fast integration of deep learning techniques to wireless communication systems have made great impacts especially on channel estimation to enhance performance in dynamic circumstances. However, these models are still very vulnerable to adversarial attacks where small changes can result in incorrect estimations ruining the precision of wireless networks. This paper offers an innovative way to reduce adversarial effects on deep learning-based channel estimation by the use of defensive distillation. Defensive distillation initially designed for increasing the robustness of neural networks, makes the models less prone to be affected by introducing a secondary model to be trained with softened outputs of primary model. Carrying out numerous simulations, we estimate the effectiveness of the proposed method in different attack scenarios, showing substantial improvements in accuracy and robustness as compared to standard models. Based on our results, we can conclude that the defensive distillation can be effectively implemented in the channel estimation schemes, strongly increasing the robustness against the adversarial interference facilitating a viable road to reliable and secure wireless connectivity.

title: Optimization of Wind-PV-Storage Integrated Power System Based on Small Signal Stability and Voltage Stability
authors: Jiaqing Wang, Qing Liu, Peiru Feng, Xu Gui, Shankun Han, Bo Li
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The declining inertia in the power system due to the wind-photovoltaic (PV)-storage integration poses significant threats to small-signal and voltage stability. In response, this paper presents a stability-constrained optimization method, and formulates the problem by developing system models and an objective function based on critical stability metrics. The solution simultaneously optimizes the control parameters of the wind-PV-storage units and the siting of the pumped storage using a multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm. Simulation results validate that the proposed method correctly and effectively mitigates stability risks, ensuring safer grid operation.

title: Detection of Drunken Individuals Near Railway Platforms Using Depth Camera
authors: Sandaroo Wijesundara, Chinthaka Premachandra
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control and Robotics (ICCR)
abstract: Accidents on railway platforms remain a major safety concern, with a large proportion involving intoxicated passengers. Conventional measures such as installing platform doors, software-based measures, railway companies employ staff to monitor platforms and utilize camera surveillance are costly, limited in coverage, prone to human error, and raise privacy concerns due to continuous human or camera-based monitoring. Considering above issues, this study presents a vision-based approach that utilizes depth camera data to detect drunken individuals through gait analysis while maintaining passenger privacy. The Intel® RealSense™ D435i depth camera was employed to capture three-dimensional point cloud data, which were processed using DBSCAN clustering to isolate human figures and voxel downsampling to reduce data density. The refined 3D representations were converted into two-dimensional gait images and classified using a fine-tuned MobileNetV2 network pretrained on ImageNet weights. The proposed model achieved 97% accuracy and averages of 0.97 for precision, recall, and F1-score. The results demonstrate that the system provides high detection accuracy, reliable generalization, and enhanced privacy protection, suggesting its potential as a practical tool for real time safety monitoring on railway platforms.

title: Research on the Cross-border 110 kV AC Interconnected Case: Voltage Control and Transient Overvoltage Optimization
authors: Hu Shuai, Fan Xiaoxiao, Mu Teng, Li Lifeng, Xu Guangrui, Ge Jing
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: In this paper, the cross-border power supply project between China and Mongolia is taken as the research object, aiming at the problems of voltage instability and power frequency overvoltage in Ejina-Zeke-Mongolia MCS long-chain transmission system, and combining the characteristics of new power system with the differences of transnational standards, the voltage operation and overvoltage problems of 110kV long-distance transmission channels in areas with weak grid and no conventional power supply support are analyzed. It provides a reference for the solution of obvious voltage drop and over-limit of power frequency overvoltage for cross-border power interconnection of weak current networks.

title: Day-Type Segmented Load Forecasting with Multi-Head Attention-LSTM for Vehicle-to-Grid Scheduling
authors: Tianyu Yan, Jiahao Zhong, Ziyun Shao, Linni Jian
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: Accurate short-term load forecasting is critical for effective Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) scheduling. This study proposes a day-type segmented forecasting approach, where two Multi-Head Attention Long Short-Term Memory (MHA-LSTM) models are independently trained on weekday and weekend data. This design is motivated by the clear differences in load patterns across day types, such as regular weekday peaks driven by commuting routines versus the more erratic weekend profiles. Modeling them jointly may obscure such trends and degrade scheduling outcomes. To further enhance trend recognition, a Load Relative Magnitude (LRM) feature is introduced, allowing the model to focus on deviations from daily averages. Results demonstrate that the segmented models consistently yield lower V2G-SVE scores, validating the benefit of day-type-specific modeling in improving practical V2G scheduling performance.

title: A Comparative Study of Self-Healing Strategies in Smart Concrete Using AHP and FAHP Techniques
authors: Aboli Ravikar, Rohan Sawant, Deepa A. Joshi, Radhika Menon, Pramod Patil, R. K. Jain
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Despite its tendency to fracture, concrete is frequently employed in the building industry. The stuff is fairly priced and accessible. As a consequence, self-healing materials have gained popularity over the past two decades, particularly those built from environmentally benign, sustainable concrete. Each research centre employs its own testing procedures to assess the efficacy of medicine, making it difficult to find the optimum approach. Self-healing concrete (SHC) distinguishes itself by its ability to mend itself and the reduced need for external assistance in recognising and repairing internal damage, including fractures. This technique not only improves durability but also reduces concrete degradation and reinforcing corrosion, resulting in cost savings. This research provides a comprehensive examination of SHCs while taking into consideration self-healing strategies and efficacy. The literature review reveals several application-based self-healing concrete systems. The most efficient method for determining the optimum self-healing strategy is to compare three distinct algorithms: the Multi-Criteria Decision Making Tool (MCDM), the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), and the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process. Compared to the AHP methodology, the FAHP method produces more accurate and reliable results. Out of the five factors used to determine the best strategy, the Ease of Availability score received the highest rating, while the Performance Time meter received the lowest. The microbe-based technique ranks second, while the compound-based approach is the most essential of the four. Avoid using natural self-healing at any cost. Furthermore, we emphasise the strengths and areas for development of SHC, along with potential future applications and research avenues for further examination.

title: A Web Application for Real-Time Beach Safety and Suitability Assessment
authors: Amruta More, Mansi Pathak, Mrunalini Pachpute, Kasim Lohar, Anurag Pawar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: Beach tourism is one of the most popular activities worldwide and plays a significant role in India's economy, contributing approximately 7% to the nation's GDP. This sector not only generates valuable foreign exchange but also supports millions of jobs in hospitality and travel. However, along with its benefits, beach tourism faces challenges–particularly regarding public safety due to marine hazards. This project introduces an innovative web application to enhance beach safety and boost Indian tourism by employing AI models for real-time hazard monitoring, predictive analytics, and automated notifications. The application provides users with comprehensive information about popular Indian beaches, including current environmental conditions such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, and tidal heights. Initially, users receive an SMS outlining the safety conditions of a selected beach, and if hazardous conditions arise, automated alerts are sent. Additionally, the platform suggests nearby beaches and allows users to rate their experiences, further informing future visitors.

title: Configurable Multi-Attribute Trustworthiness Assessment for End-to-End Trusted Networks
authors: Zhou Su, Qichao Xu, Zhendong Li, Yihao Qi, Lang Ma
abstract: Assessing the trustworthiness of network elements, including devices, communication links, and end-to-end paths, is critical for building secure and reliable networks. However, the heterogeneity of these components and the dynamic nature of their security states make trust assessment in large-scale networks highly challenging. This paper presents a configurable end-to-end network trustworthiness assessment scheme featuring a hierarchical, life-cycle-based architecture for evaluating trust from initial network deployment through long-term operation to retirement. In the proposed scheme, trustworthiness is assessed at three levels: device, link, and path. At the device level, a Dempster-Shafer evidence theory-based model integrates multi-dimensional trust attributes to quantify each device’s trustworthiness. At the link level, a dynamic multi-attribute model combines static and dynamic trust attributes and employs a clustering algorithm to calculate link trust scores. At the path level, a distributed fusion-based model uses fuzzy logic to evaluate end-to-end path trust by aggregating the trust levels of constituent devices and links. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme significantly improves both the accuracy and efficiency of trustworthiness assessment in large-scale networks.

title: Pyramid Token Pruning for High-Resolution Large Vision-Language Models via Region, Token, and Instruction-Guided Importance
authors: Yuxuan Liang, Xu Li, Xiaolei Chen, Haotian Chen, Yi Zhen, Zhe Liu, Rui Zhu, Bin Li, Xiangyang Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have recently demonstrated strong multimodal understanding, yet their fine-grained visual perception is often constrained by low input resolutions. A common remedy is to partition high-resolution images into multiple sub-images for separate encoding, but this approach drastically inflates the number of visual tokens and introduces prohibitive inference overhead. To overcome this challenge, we propose Pyramid Token Pruning (PTP), a training-free strategy that hierarchically integrates bottom-up visual saliency at both region and token levels with top-down instruction-guided relevance. Inspired by human visual cognition, PTP selectively preserves more tokens from salient regions while further emphasizing those most relevant to task instructions. Extensive experiments on 13 diverse benchmarks show that PTP substantially reduces computational cost, memory usage, and inference latency, with negligible performance degradation.

title: DREAM: A Benchmark Study for Deepfake photoREalism AssessMent
authors: Bo Peng, Zichuan Wang, Sheng Yu, Xiaochuan Jin, Wei Wang, Jing Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Deep learning based face-swap videos, widely known as deepfakes, have drawn wide attention due to their threat to information credibility. Recent works mainly focus on the problem of deepfake detection that aims to reliably tell deepfakes apart from real ones, in an objective way. On the other hand, the subjective perception of deepfakes, especially its computational modeling and imitation, is also a significant problem but lacks adequate study. In this paper, we focus on the photorealism assessment of deepfakes, which is defined as the automatic assessment of deepfake photorealism that approximates human perception of deepfakes. It is important for evaluating the quality and deceptiveness of deepfakes which can be used for predicting the influence of deepfakes on Internet, and it also has potentials in improving the deepfake generation process by serving as a critic. This paper promotes this new direction by presenting a comprehensive benchmark called DREAM, which stands for Deepfake photoREalism AssessMent. It is comprised of a deepfake video dataset of diverse quality, a large scale annotation that includes 140,000 photorealism scores and textual descriptions obtained from 3,500 human annotators, and a comprehensive evaluation and analysis of 18 representative photorealism assessment methods, including recent large vision language model based methods and a newly proposed description-aligned CLIP method. The benchmark and insights included in this study can lay the foundation for future research in this direction and other related areas. We make the dataset available to the research community at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/bomb2peng/DREAM-A-Benchmark-Study-for-Deepfake-photoREalism-AssessMent</uri>.

title: Improved Resonant ESO-Based Sampling Delay Error Suppression Method for PMSM Drives Using a Single DC-Link Current Sensor
authors: Pengcheng Zhu, Jiming Zou, Wentao Zhang, Yanchen Zhai, Jibin Zou, Sergio Vazquez, Leopoldo G. Franquelo, Yongxiang Xu
abstract: In single DC-link current sensor control for permanent magnet synchronous motor drives, a sampling delay error (SDE) inherently exists due to the discrepancy between the sampling instants of the reconstructed phase currents and the ideal phase currents, which degrades current accuracy. The method of suppressing the SDE by calculating the online current slopes not only requires intensive computation but also depends on the accuracy of system parameters and the durations of voltage vectors. This article analytically demonstrates that the SDE exhibits a periodic disturbance correlated with the stator electrical frequency. Accordingly, an SDE suppression method based on a resonant extended state observer (RESO) is proposed without the need to calculate the current slopes. To address the resonance phenomenon in the conventional quasi-RESO (QRESO) caused by the coupling between disturbance attenuation capability and observer bandwidth, an improved RESO is proposed by redesigning QRESO while considering the quality factor that characterizes the frequency selection capability. Experimental results verify the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: SFPN: Lightweight Single Image Super-Resolution based on Step-by-step Feature Purification Network
authors: Yaoman Huang, Fudi Yi, Tao Liu, Fenglong Li, Junyu Lin, Zhengda Li, Hengshuo Liu, Zhihao Wang, Dianlin Xie, Zhujie Huan, Xiaolin Huang, He Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Single Image Super-Resolution (SISR) has witnessed rapid advancements, but they still face many challenges especially in balancing performance and computational efficiency. To address these limitations, this study proposes a Step-by-step Feature Purification Network Based on Multi-Angle Attention Mechanism (SFPN). SFPN introduces a Dynamic Multi-Angle Perception (DMAP) module, which utilizes three parallel branches: Dynamic Self-Attention (DSA) for global feature enhancement, Spatial Feature Modulation (SFM) for high-frequency detail recovery, and Local Detail Feature (LDF) extraction for fine-grained spatial refinement. These branches are integrated by an Interactive Multi-Scale Convolution (IMSConv) unit to enhance spatial context and feature diversity. In addition, an Enhanced Iterative Multi-Distillation (EIMD) module is designed to progressively distill and refine informative features through lightweight attention and spatial enhancement. Extensive experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate that SFPN achieves state-of-the-art performance in both PSNR and SSIM.

title: Real-World Deployment of a Lane Change Prediction Architecture Based on Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Bayesian Inference
authors: M. Manzour, Catherine M. Elias, Omar M. Shehata, R. Izquierdo, M. A. Sotelo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Research on lane change prediction has gained a lot of momentum in the last couple of years. However, most research is confined to simulation or results obtained from datasets, leaving a gap between algorithmic advances and on-road deployment. This work closes that gap by demonstrating, on real hardware, a lane-change prediction system based on Knowledge Graph Embeddings (KGEs) and Bayesian inference. Moreover, the ego-vehicle employs a longitudinal braking action to ensure the safety of both itself and the surrounding vehicles. Our architecture consists of two modules: (i) a perception module that senses the environment, derives input numerical features, and converts them into linguistic categories; and communicates them to the prediction module; (ii) a pretrained prediction module that executes a KGE and Bayesian inference model to anticipate the target vehicle’s maneuver and transforms the prediction into longitudinal braking action. Real-world hardware experimental validation demonstrates that our prediction system anticipates the target vehicle’s lane change three to four seconds in advance, providing the ego vehicle sufficient time to react and allowing the target vehicle to make the lane change safely.

title: Probabilistic Safety Verification for an Autonomous Ground Vehicle: A Situation Coverage Grid Approach
authors: Nawshin Mannan Proma, Gricel Vázquez, Sepeedeh Shahbeigi, Arjun Badyal, Victoria Hodge
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: As industrial autonomous ground vehicles are increasingly deployed in safety-critical environments, ensuring their safe operation under diverse conditions is paramount. This paper presents a novel approach for their safety verification based on systematic situation extraction, probabilistic modelling and verification. We build upon the concept of a situation coverage grid, which exhaustively enumerates environmental configurations relevant to the vehicle’s operation. This grid is augmented with quantitative probabilistic data collected from situation-based system testing, capturing probabilistic transitions between situations. We then generate a probabilistic model that encodes the dynamics of both normal and unsafe system behaviour. Safety properties extracted from hazard analysis and formalised in temporal logic are verified through probabilistic model checking against this model. The results demonstrate that our approach effectively identifies high-risk situations, provides quantitative safety guarantees, and supports compliance with regulatory standards, thereby contributing to the robust deployment of autonomous systems.

title: Parameter Estimation Via Single-Photon Detection in A Quantum V-Type Three-Level System
authors: Zhenghao Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: We investigate parameter estimation in a Vconfiguration three-level atomic system continuously monitored via photon counting. By unraveling the system's dynamics into individual quantum trajectories, we demonstrate how time-resolved fluorescence records can be processed using maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) to extract key system parameters such as spontaneous decay rates and Rabi frequencies. We analyze the role of waiting-time distributions, likelihood reconstruction, and finite detector efficiencies, showing that trajectory-based MLE achieves the Cramér–Rao bound in the asymptotic limit. Our results highlight the potential of quantum-jump–resolved statistics to enable precision parameter estimation in open quantum systems.

title: An Improved FOCV High-Efficiency MPPT Multi-Mode Adaptive Switching DC-DC Converter for 10mV-600mV TEG Harvesting
authors: Jiangyu Chen, Weilin Xu, Xueming Wei, Baolin Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electron Devices and Applications (ICEDA)
abstract: This paper presents a multi-mode adaptive-switching DC-DC boost converter that uses an improved FOCV technique. The proposed method incorporates an adaptive MPP turn-off point detection circuit to generate the comparator's turn-off voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{S F}$</tex>, by alternately applying the sampled open-circuit voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{M P P T}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{S F}$</tex> to the comparator's inverting input, then comparing them with the input ripple voltage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{C I N}$</tex> in each cycle. Moreover, enabling adaptive switching between Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM) and Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM) under different input voltages to improve conversion efficiency. The boost converter is implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> standard CMOS process. It reaches peak <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\eta_{E-E}$</tex> of 93.17% at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{s}=200 \text{mV}$</tex> and maintains 92.4% efficiency at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{s}=600 \text{mV}$</tex>. The proposed design exhibits a significant enhancement in power conversion efficiency across a wide range of input voltages and load ranges.
