title: On optimal distinguishers for Planted Clique
authors: Ansh Nagda, Prasad Raghavendra
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: In a distinguishing problem, the input is a sample drawn from one of two distributions and the algorithm is tasked with identifying the source distribution. The performance of a distinguishing algorithm is measured by its advantage, i.e., its incremental probability of success over a random guess. A classic example of a distinguishing problem is the Planted Clique problem, where the input is a graph sampled from either $G(n, 1 / 2)$ - the standard Erdős-Rényi model, or $G(n, 1 / 2, k)$ the Erdős-Rényi model with a clique planted on a random subset of k vertices. The Planted Clique Hypothesis asserts that efficient algorithms cannot achieve advantage better than some absolute constant, say 1/4, whenever $k=n^{1 / 2-\Omega(1)}$. In this work, we aim to precisely understand the optimal distinguishing advantage achievable by efficient algorithms on Planted Clique. We show the following results under the Planted Clique hypothesis:•Optimality of low-degree polynomials: No efficient algorithm can beat the advantage the optimal low-degree polynomial. Concretely, this means that the advantage of any efficient algorithm is at most $(1+o(1)) \cdot k^{2} /(\sqrt{\pi} n)$, which is optimal in light of a simple edge-counting algorithm achieving this bound.•Harder planted distributions: There is an efficiently sampleable distribution ${\mathcal{P}}^{*}$ supported on graphs containing k cliques such that no efficient algorithm can distinguish ${\mathcal{P}}^{*}$ from $G(n, 1 / 2)$ with advantage $n^{-d}$ for an arbitrarily large constant d. In other words, there exist alternate planted distributions that are much harder than $G(n, 1 / 2, k)$.Along the way, we prove a constructive hard-core lemma for a broad class of distributions with respect to low-degree polynomials. This result is applicable much more widely beyond Planted Clique and might be of independent interest.

title: Near-Optimal Fault-Tolerant Strong Connectivity Preservers
authors: Gary Hoppenworth, Thatchaphol Saranurak, Benyu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 66th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS)
abstract: A k-fault-tolerant connectivity preserver of a directed n-vertex graph G is a subgraph H such that, for any edge set F ⊆ E(G) of size |F| ≤ k, the strongly connected components of G−F and H −F are the same. While some graphs require a preserver with Ω(2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup>n) edges [1], the best-known upper bound is $\tilde O\left( {k{2^k}{n^{2 - /k}}} \right)$ edges [2], leaving a significant gap of Ω(n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1−1/k</sup>). In contrast, there is no gap in undirected graphs; the optimal bound of Θ(kn) has been well-established since the 90s [3].We nearly close the gap for directed graphs; we prove that there exists a k-fault-tolerant connectivity preserver with O(k4<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup>nlogn) edges, and we can construct one with O(8<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup>nlog<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5/2</sup> n) edges in poly(2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup>n) time.Our results also improve the state-of-the-art for a closely related object; a k-connectivity preserver of G is a subgraph H where, for all i ≤ k, the strongly i-connected components of G and H agree. By a known reduction, we obtain a k-connectivity preserver with O(k4<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k</sup>nlogn) edges, improving the previous best bound of $\tilde O\left( {k{2^k}{n^{2 - 1/(k - 1)}}} \right)$ [2]. Therefore, for any constant k, our results are optimal to a logn factor for both problems.Lastly, we show that the exponential dependency on k is not inherent for k-connectivity preservers by presenting another construction with $O\left( {n{\text{ }}\sqrt {kn} } \right)$ edges.

title: Intelligent Traffic Surveillance: A Vision-Based System for Detecting Traffic Rule Violations
authors: Harsh Samant, Kush Doshi, Rishabh Shah, Shreevardhan Bhosale, Dashrath Kale
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Integration of Computational Intelligent System (ICICIS)
abstract: India's vast and growing urban population has increased the number of vehicles on the road. Traditional traffic monitoring is quite slow and inefficient as it relies heavily on manual oversight, which is more prone to delays and mistakes for ensuring compliance with traffic laws. This paper proposes an intelligent, vision-based traffic surveillance system designed to automatically detect and classify and report violations like red light jumping, speeding, helmet-less riding, lack of valid insurance, and non-compliance of pollution control. The system is utilizing a custom-trained state-of-the-art object detection algorithm, especially YOLOv12 (You Only Look Once). It integrates real-time object tracking with license plate extraction with vision-based models and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) while delivery of the challan is achieved via an API backend. Experimental testing and evaluations have an accuracy of 93.76 % overall across multiple test cases. The results showcase a potential to enhance traffic law enforcement and improve overall road safety.

title: Using Reverse Electrodialysis to Produce Hydrogen
authors: Valleriy Knyazhev, Vladimir Loshchenkov
abstract: Hydrogen production without carbon dioxide emissions is possible with water electrolysis using electricity generated by renewable energy sources. The proposed energy source is the energy of salinity gradients (EGS), which can be obtained by reversibly mixing solutions of different concentrations. The most developed membrane methods for converting the energy of salinity gradients are considered: pressure-retarded osmosis on osmotic semipermeable membranes and reverse electrodialysis with ion-selective membranes in an electrodialysis battery. Reverse electrodialysis directly converts EGS into electricity. However, it is possible to combine the processes of reverse electrodialysis and water electrolysis in one battery, since gases are released on them when inert electrodes are used. This takes up some of the electricity received. The gases that are released depend on the solutions that are fed to the electrode chambers. When the alkali solution circulates in the electrode chambers, the hydrogen ions will be reduced at the cathode and hydrogen gas will be released.

title: Development of a Calibration Method for Underwater Video Cameras Using a Multi-Link Manipulator
authors: Vladimir Filaretov, Michail Belousov, Igor Gornostaev
abstract: The article focuses on the development of a calibration method for monocular underwater video cameras installed on underwater vehicles using multi-link manipulators via the well-known ray tracing approach. This calibration takes into account the refraction of light on the refraction surfaces between media with different refractive coefficients (air-glass-water). The use of this method enables the accurate determination of the spatial straight line on which the observed object point is located in any region of the video camera frame, including areas at the edges of the frame where the greatest distortions due to distortion are observed. Through the use of video cameras calibrated with this method, it becomes possible to accurately perform the required manipulation and technological operations in an underwater environment using multi-link manipulators. The performance and effectiveness of the presented calibration method were confirmed through fullscale experiments.

title: Voltage Stability in Smart Grids Operation: Case of US – Canada Grid Interconnection Energy Management System
authors: Syed Muhammad Umer Abdi, Muhammad Hamza Qamar, Muhammad Ahsan Ali, Kamran Iqbal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy and the growing demand for cross-border electricity transfer through interconnection pose significant challenges to voltage stability in modern smart grids operation. Among the various Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS) devices in power system management, the Static Synchronous Compensator (STATCOM) has emerged as an effective solution for dynamic voltage regulation and reactive power control. This paper presents a review of STATCOM applications in smart grids operation, focusing on its role in maintaining voltage stability and enhancing power flow. To complement the review, a case study is developed on a 500 kV, 150 km British Columbia (Canada) and Washington (USA) grid interconnection line. A MATLAB/Simulink model is implemented to evaluate system behavior under normal operation and fault conditions, both with and without STATCOM. Simulation results demonstrate that STATCOM significantly improves voltage recovery, reduces oscillations, provides rapid reactive power support, and stabilizes the DC link voltage. These findings confirm the practical importance of STATCOM in smart grid operations, particularly in long-distance and high-voltage interconnections. Future directions are also highlighted, including advanced control strategies and renewable energy integration in Energy Management Systems of Smart Cities.

title: DPAD: Research of Observable System and Algorithm for Intelligent Anomaly Detection in Distributed Photovoltaic System
authors: He Zhewei, Ma Chao, Fang Lixiong, Song Zhixing, Zhang Jiahao, Xu Ruixiang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: With the rapid development of the new power system, distributed photovoltaic installations are increasing, but their inherent randomness and output fluctuations pose challenges for stable grid operation. Enhancing the observable capabilities of distributed photovoltaic, especially through intelligent anomaly detection, is essential for ensuring reliable operation. To address this challenge, we propose DPAD, a novel anomaly detection framework that integrates a variational autoencoder, a bidirectional long short-term memory network, and a multi-head self-attention mechanism. Within the VAE framework, BiLSTM serves as the encoder to model the hidden-layer probability distribution of input data. The sampled latent variables are then refined via multi-head attention, enabling BiLSTM to reconstruct the hidden representations for robust anomaly detection. Experimental results demonstrate that the precision, recall and F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> score of the model in this paper reach 98.98%, 87.82% and 89.85%, which significantly improves the fault detection efficiency and operation and maintenance intelligence compared with the existing methods.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Task Allocation Strategies for Resource-Constrained Multi-Agent Drone Swarms in Wildfire Response
authors: Huan Vo, Constantino Álvarez Casado, Abhishek Kumar, Satu Tamminen, Petri Ihantola, Miguel Bordallo López, Le Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: The coordination of autonomous drone swarms for wildfire response presents a key problem in dynamic task and resource management. This paper presents a comparative analysis of coordination strategies for a resource-constrained multi-agent drone swarm. The evaluation is conducted within an agent-based simulation that includes a probabilistic Cellular Automata (CA) fire model with multi-directional wind and heterogeneous fuel loads. The drone agents operate under constraints, including a limited water payload or battery charge that requires periodic resupply. We implement and assess three strategies: a decentralized heuristic, a context-aware auction mechanism where bids reflect local fire intensity and predictive risk, and a reinforcement learning (RL) agent based on Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). The RL agent integrates an attention mechanism to extract relevant environmental cues and is informed by short-term fire spread forecasts to support proactive decision-making. The simulation results provide a quantitative comparison of these strategies based on fire containment, task completion time, and resource use. Although the auction mechanism offers robust performance, the predictive RL agent learns more proactive containment behaviors. This analysis quantifies the trade-offs across coordination strategies and informs the design of intelligent, resource-aware systems for autonomous wildfire response. The code is available at: https://github.com/Arritmic/oulu-wildfire-drones.

title: AI-Based Assistance Systems in Smart Distribution Grids: Developing a Workforce Management System
authors: Sijmen Robert Boersma, Kajan Kandiah, Cansu Kahveci, Philip Song, Xuan-Anh Nguyen, Max-Ferdinand Stroh, Wolfgang Boos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: The increasing decentralization and digitalization of energy distribution systems pose significant challenges to the management of operational and maintenance processes. The integration of renewable energy sources and the resulting dynamic grid conditions necessitate more adaptive, efficient, and technologically advanced workforce management (WFM) solutions. This work presents a systematic approach to modeling WFM processes tailored to the needs of modern smart grids. Based on a detailed evaluation of modeling languages and a requirements analysis informed by industry workshops, Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN) was identified as the most suitable formalism. An iterative development process was established, combining user story specification, process modeling, validation, and requirement refinement. The resulting WFM processes integrate real-time reactivity and AI-based decision support mechanisms. These include intelligent task classification, personnel selection, and resource planning, enabling human operators to make faster, more consistent decisions in dynamic grid environments. The work lays the foundation for a digitalized, flexible WFM-System that addresses the future demands of sustainable and secure energy distribution.

title: Stress Concentration Evaluation of On-Load Tap Changer Operating Mechanism Based on Finite Element Analysis
authors: Chuanyu Gu, Yingjie Yan, Jiahui Yang
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The vacuum tube operating mechanism is a core component of the on-load tap changer (OLTC) for converter transformers. It has a complex mechanical structure, and frequent operations easily lead to plastic deformation and damage of the mechanical mechanism, thereby causing converter transformer failures. Studying the dynamic simulation of the mechanical characteristics of this mechanism can make up for the deficiency that traditional testing methods cannot intuitively show the stress distribution, and provide a theoretical basis for the design and improvement of the vacuum tube operating mechanism. In this paper, a transient dynamic simulation model of the vacuum tube operating mechanism based on implicit nonlinear dynamics was first established in ANSYS. The Von Mises yield criterion and isotropic hardening model were used to calculate the equivalent stress of the model. Then, the overall stress distribution of the operating mechanism was analyzed through finite element method, and finally the stress distribution of the convex turntable was analyzed specifically.

title: A Scalable Federated XGBoost Framework for Urban Air Quality Forecasting: A Case Study in Tehran
authors: Saghar Shafaati, S. Hossein Erfani
abstract: The following work introduces a new federated learning (FL) paradigm that takes advantage of the capabilities of Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) to achieve scalable and privacy-protected air quality forecasting for smart cities. The designed architecture, the Four-Stage Parallel Federated Iterative XGBoost, is specially tailored to facilitate distributed training from disparate data sources while ensuring data privacy—a central prerequisite in contemporary IoT-supported smart city systems. The suggested approach is empirically compared with actual real-world datasets collected from 22 geographically distributed IoT air quality monitoring stations across the metropolitan area of Tehran. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves a 24.77% reduction in MSE and a 13.26% improvement in RMSE compared to the Stage-1 Federated XGBoost baseline. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the framework in discovering localized air pollution patterns with scalability and privacy. The Four-Stage Parallel Federated Iterative XGBoost model is a potential solution for real-time city-wide environmental monitoring and forecasting and is highly relevant to policymakers and urban sustainability requirements.

title: A High-Efficiency Three-Port High-Gain DC–DC Boost Converter for Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Parisa Shirinabadi, Amirreza Samadi Bonab, Ebrahim Babaei, Mehran Sabahi
abstract: This paper presents a dual output DC-DC circuit designed for ultra high voltage gain and for uses of renewable energy systems. The voltage gain is independently controlled by the duty cycle for the switch and the turns ratio of the coupled inductor, allowing for good design adaptability. The advantages of the topology are its exceptionally high gain, minimized voltage stress on active components, continuous input current, common input-output ground, and synchronized switch control. Simulation on a 200W, 50kHz prototype confirms proper operation, upgrading the 20V input to dual 123V outputs.

title: Soft Normalized Advantage Functions for Reinforcement Learning in Optimal Control Problems
authors: Dilli Bhaskar, Athira Mullachery, Shaikshavali Chitraganti
abstract: Maximum-Entropy reinforcement learning (Max-Ent RL) methods designed for continuous action spaces generally employ actor-critic framework, which involves alternating between policy evaluation and policy improvement stages. The normalized advantage function (NAF) simplifies continuous control by modeling a quadratic action-value function, but its deterministic policy limits exploration capabilities. In this paper, a MaxEnt RL framework, termed as soft normalized advantage function (SNAF), is introduced. SNAF extends NAF by incorporating a stochastic policy, thereby enhancing exploration and mitigating the risk of converging to local optima without requiring additional sampling approximations. The performance of SNAF is evaluated on benchmark optimal control problems, which encompass pendulum stabilization, the Van der Pol oscillator, and a target control task, comparing its performance with soft actor-critic and the original NAF. Experimental results demonstrate that SNAF achieves improved sample efficiency, accelerated convergence, and enhanced robustness while maintaining computational simplicity. These findings underscore its potential for addressing high-dimensional continuous control tasks.

title: Reinforcement Learning Inspired Genetic Algorithm for Solving Global Optimisation Problems
authors: Andrew Brown, Li Zhang, Piyushkumar Banugariya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking, Sensing and Control (ICNSC)
abstract: As a popular swarm intelligence algorithm, genetic algorithm has selection, crossover and mutation operators, as well as several key parameters such as crossover and mutation rates, which are typically configured for specific problems. These genetic operating parameters can be optimised for different problems, generalizing the approach for a range of applications. In particular, the parameters can be adjusted during the processes as the algorithm approaches an optimal solution. In this research, we propose a variant of the genetic algorithm by using reinforcement learning to select and update a mutation parameter as the algorithm progresses. Specifically, we investigate the use of the Q-Learning algorithm to select the optimal configuration of the mutation factor in each iteration. The Bellman optimality mechanism is used to govern the selection of the optimal mutation configurations which in turns allows the model to switch between a wider global search and an intensive local search during the search process. A realworld railway platform allocation problem and a number of benchmark test functions are used to evaluate the proposed model with Q-Learning based optimal mutation rate selection. The results of the proposed model show improvement in 7 out of the 8 test functions over a set of 25 trials. It also shows great efficiency in solving railway platform allocation problems, in comparison with the original genetic algorithm with a fixed mutation factor.

title: Suitable Interval Detection in UK-DALE Dataset for NILM Model Training
authors: Ali Bajoulvand, Negar Heydari Morchekhorti, Zahra Dehghani Arani, Amir Khorsandi, Hamed Nafisi, Seyed Hossein Hosseinian, Gevork B. Gharehpetian
abstract: This paper presents a transparent and data-driven approach for identifying a reliable continuous interval within the UK-domestic appliance-level electricity (DALE) dataset to ensure trustworthy training of non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) models. Rather than relying on aggressive interpolation or synthetic reconstruction, the proposed method preserves the dataset’s natural temporal structure by assessing time continuity, channel consistency, and energy balance. All appliance and mains signals are aligned on a uniform 6-second grid, incomplete samples are removed, and channel activity is visually verified using presence scatter plots. Through iterative temporal-gap analysis, a continuous and minimally manipulated window is identified for House 1 of UK-DALE (September 1, 2013–March 1, 2014), comprising 32 active channels with minimal interruptions. The selected segment exhibits strong temporal stability and energy alignment within ±5%, providing a reproducible and trustworthy foundation for NILM model training. This framework enhances the reliability, fairness, and comparability of NILM research and can be extended to other datasets to promote standardized, data-consistent evaluation.

title: Robust Task-Space Bilateral Teleoperation of Soft Robots
authors: Lasitha Weerakoon, Nikhil Chopra
abstract: The compliance and agility of soft robots make them ideal for complex tasks in unstructured environments. This paper presents a robust task-space bilateral teleoperation framework for heterogeneous systems, featuring a non-redundant rigid leader and a redundant spatial soft follower, modeled using the piecewise constant curvature assumption. Using passivity-based robust control, we prove ultimate boundedness of system trajectories under parameter uncertainties and constant asymmetric time delays. Additionally, the follower’s null-space velocity is leveraged for collision avoidance. Simulation results on a spatial soft robot demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

title: Framework for Effective Vehicle-to-Grid Integration for Sri Lankan Power Grid
authors: Tharindi Raneesha, Nisali Sadara, Dinika Piyarathne, Nimantha Madhushan, Charithri Yapa, Nishan Dharmaweera, Randula Wijeratne, Udaya Madawala
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The integration of Electric Vehicles (EVs) into power systems presents a promising solution to the growing challenges of Renewable Energy (RE) variability, peak demand stress, and limited grid scale storage. This paper proposes a demand driven methodology to identify optimal periods for Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) charging and discharging, using historical load data without requiring detailed EV fleet characteristics. The approach involves constructing representative daily demand profiles, filtering outliers, and statistically identifying peak and valley periods using a thresholding technique based on mean and standard deviation. These time windows are then used to estimate the grid’s capacity to absorb or release power through V2G operations. A case study using Sri Lanka’s 2023 load data demonstrates that consistent nighttime and midday valleys are ideal for EV charging, while evening peaks offer significant discharging opportunities. The framework enables early stage feasibility assessments in data scarce regions and supports strategic planning for V2G integration.

title: Blockchain-Assisted Energy Trading Framework for Vehicle-to-Grid Integration
authors: Yasas Wimalasooriya, Ayumi Batuwatta, Sandali Kamburugamuwa, Charithri Yapa, Nishan Dharmaweera, Randula Wijeratne, Udaya Madawala
publish: 2025 15th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems (ICPES)
abstract: The rise of electric vehicles (EVs) creates a unique opportunity to improve grid stability by allowing bidirectional energy transfer via Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology. This research presents a smart V2G integration architecture for EVs that can provide real-time demand-side energy support. The solution combines a dual-interface mobile application with a blockchain-based energy tokenization method to allow for safe and transparent energy transactions between EV owners and system operators. Core frontend and backend algorithms control energy availability estimation, discharge approvals, and dynamic pricing, assuring maximum EV participation while maintaining vehicle usability. Real-time data synchronization between the mobile application and Ethereum-based smart contracts provides safe and role-specific transaction execution. Validation results indicate the framework’s ability to promote energy conservation through decentralized EV coordination.

title: Contact-Based Perching Control Strategy for Quadrotors to Enhance Endurance in Power Grid Inspection
authors: Zhaohui Wu, Lili Liu, Jiping Ai, Xiaoyu Zhang, Cheng Chen, Siwei He, Junchao Yan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Aerial robots, such as quadrotors, have demonstrated significant application value in fields like equipment inspection. However, limited flight endurance remains a critical constraint for these aircraft. This paper proposes a control strategy to enhance the operational endurance of power grid inspection drones by enabling them to perch on specific components of transmission towers using landing gear or support brackets. By lightly contacting these structural elements, the quadrotor can counteract part of its gravitational force, reducing hover energy consumption and extending mission time. Unlike conventional perching on flat surfaces or mounting on structures, this approach emphasizes maintaining attitude stability and operational capability during contact-based perching, where mechanical interaction with the environment is leveraged for energy efficiency. A method for estimating support forces and torques is developed, forming the basis of a feedforward compensation control strategy. Additionally, a disturbance observer(DOB) is designed to mitigate disturbances and enhance attitude stability. Simulations in the Simscape environment validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, demonstrating its potential to address endurance limitations in aerial robotic applications.

title: Multi-Actuated Control of Car-Semitrailer Systems via Nonlinear MPC
authors: Gabriele Rini, Francesco Bottiglione, Nicola Menga, Aldo Sorniotti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of torque vectoring (TV) and active suspension (AS) control on the towing vehicle for yaw rate tracking, and trailer sway reduction in car-semitrailer systems. Due to the nonlinear influence of antiroll moment distribution, nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) is employed. Several real-time NMPC algorithms are developed and compared, using either predicted hitch dynamics or estimated hitch joint forces, in a high-fidelity simulation environment with an optimization-based tuning routine. Results show that: (i) integrated AS and TV control outperforms other configurations and, (ii) NMPCs based on hitch joint force estimation are a viable alternative to those embedding hitch dynamics at the cost of reduced robustness.

title: Overcoming Autonomy Limitations: A Robust Teleoperation Solution for Intelligent Vehicles
authors: Javier Gómez, Jaime Godoy, Martín Palos, Abdulla Al-Kaff, Fernando García
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a robust and modular teleoperation system for Intelligent Vehicles (IVs), intended to serve as a fallback solution when autonomous vehicles (AVs) encounter operational limitations. Built using modern technologies such as WebRTC, LTE 4G and node-based architectures, the system enables real-time remote driving with low latency and high reliability. The proposed solution was deployed and validated on a real research vehicle, controlled from a remote teleoperation station. Both qualitative and quantitative evaluations were performed, including latency and usability analysis. The results demonstrate that the system is reliable, scalable and suitable for real-world teleoperation applications, offering a solid foundation for future research in AVs and remote driving systems.

title: SafeCrossLight: Pedestrian-Aware Traffic Light Control using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Lingyue Zeng, Shen Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Urban intersections often struggle to balance traffic efficiency with the safety of Vulnerable Road Users (VRUs) such as pedestrians. While traditional traffic light control (TLC) methods focus on optimizing vehicle flow, they often neglect pedestrian safety. Therefore, we propose SafeCrossLight, a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) - based approach that aims to address both efficiency and safety in a unified framework. By factoring pedestrians’ safety into the learning process, Safe-CrossLight enables a more responsible and adaptive decisionmaking process at intersections. Our method is evaluated through Simulation of Urban Mobility (SUMO) and compared with several state-of-the-art TLC approaches. Results show that SafeCrossLight significantly reduces unsafe pedestrian behaviors while maintaining strong efficiency in both vehicle and pedestrian flow, suggesting its high potential for real-world deployment in urban traffic systems.

title: Enhancing Passenger Comfort via Real-Time Motion Sickness Mitigation in a Vehicle Simulator
authors: Jon Ander Ruiz Colmenares, Estibaliz Asua, Óscar Mata-Carballeira, Óscar Montserrat, Jose María Echevarria
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper validates a real-time system for mitigating motion sickness using readily accessible vehicle CAN-bus data and an interpretable CatBoost model. This work makes two primary contributions from a study in a vehicle simulator. The first is a framework for generating and delivering interpretable driving recommendations. The model’s output is used to identify the specific root causes of discomfort and translate them into clear, actionable advice, with the most effective communication method established through a comprehensive Human-Machine Interface (HMI) study. The second contribution is a semi-autonomous, closed-loop control system that performs direct interventions to enhance comfort. Crucially, this system uses the very same recommendations as a transparency layer for its automated actions; when a correction is made by the vehicle, the interpretable reason for the intervention is simultaneously communicated to the driver. The system’s efficacy is demonstrated in a comparative study, wherein a substantial reduction in high and moderate motion sickness scenarios and a significant increase in comfortable driving time are observed. Through this research, a practical framework is validated in which automated interventions are rendered transparent, proving that enhanced comfort can be achieved in synergy with driver understanding.

title: Joint Spatial-Channel Attention Refinement in Lightweight Networks for Real-Time Robust Feature Matching
authors: Haoxin Tian, Hanyu Zhan, Haobo Tian, Qieqie Zhang, Lejun Chen, Jizhou Lai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: Feature matching is essential for many computer vision tasks, yet achieving high accuracy with low computational cost remains challenging. This paper proposes a shallow-deep decoupled attention architecture based on the XFeat framework. Spatial attention is applied in shallow, high-resolution layers to enhance geometric detail capture, while channel attention is applied in deep, high-channel layers to improve discriminative feature selection. A joint channel-spatial refinement module following multi-layer feature fusion suppresses redundancy and enhances feature discriminability. The approach introduces minimal parameters and computational overhead while significantly improving feature representation and matching robustness. Extensive experiments and ablation studies demonstrate superior performance across multiple benchmarks.

title: Formation Fault-Tolerant Control for Multi-UGVs Based on Velocity-Adaptive Potential Field
authors: Wendong Gai, Xiaochun Yu, Xichao Fu, Gang Jing, Jing Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: The multi-UGVs formation safety is important when the UGV happens the serious actuator failure and has to break away from the formation. The formation fault-tolerant control method based on velocity-adaptive potential field for multi-UGVs is proposed to achieve the formation control and collision avoidance in this situation. Firstly, the formation model based on the leader-follower is built. Then, the Hungarian algorithm is used to implement the optimal formation reconstruction, when the follower UGV happens the serious actuator failure. And the velocity-adaptive potential field is proposed to achieve the formation control and enhance the collision avoidance capability with the dynamic faulted UGV and other formation members. The simulation result shows the proposed method is able to achieve the formation reconstruction and collision avoidance, when the follower UGV happens the serious failure.

title: Real-Time Performance Analysis of V2V and V2I-2V Architectures for Smart Communities
authors: Khader Zaahid Umar, Swetha Gangineni, Raja Vara Prasad Yerra, Purav Shah, Ramona Trestian, Hrishikesh Venkataraman, Deepak Gangadharan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time, low-latency communication and energy- efficient framework for IoT-enabled micro-mobility systems, specifically targeting gated environments such as residential campuses, educational institutions and industrial zones. As a core application platform, an IoT-enabled Segway is deployed and integrated with the proposed framework, serving as a practical micro-mobility solution within gated communities. The proposed system enables both Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) communication using ESP-NOW, and Vehicle-to-Infrastructure-to-Vehicle (V2I2V) communication using Wi-Fi-based UDP, implemented using ESP32-S3 and NodeMCU microcontrollers integrated with IMU, ToF, Ultrasonic, and GPS sensors. To evaluate performance, end-to-end latency is measured across varying distances under both Line-of-Sight (LoS) and Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS) conditions. Along with the latency measurement, power profiling system is also implemented using the INA226 sensor, comparing the energy consumption of ESP-NOW and 4G-based communication. To extend this analysis, Simulation of Urban MObility (SUMO) simulation was performed. Results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in supporting reliable micro-mobility communication, offering a practical foundation for intelligent transport in localized smart environments. This work introduces a novel, energy-efficient, and infrastructure-independent V2X communication solution tailored for smart gated communities.

title: Machine Learning-Based Vehicle Dynamics Estimation from Wheel Rim Strain Sensors
authors: Chiara Gei, Willibald Krenn, Helios Sanchis Alepuz, Peter Priller, Albert Frank, Aleš Travnik, Julian Karoliny
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Modern vehicles rely more and more on sophisticated sensor systems for navigation and dynamics monitoring, however most approaches depend on centralized, expensive sensor suites. This paper presents a novel approach to vehicle state estimation using strain sensors mounted on wheel rims. We demonstrate that strain patterns captured at the wheel-road interface contain rich information about vehicle dynamics that can be extracted using machine learning (ML) techniques. We collected high-resolution telemetry data from strain sensors mounted on all four wheels of a test vehicle, synchronized with ground truth generated from GPS signal for supervised training. Using ML methods, we successfully predicted vehicle speed and turning direction directly from the strain sensor data. Our results show that wheel-mounted strain sensors can serve as an independent, redundant source of vehicle dynamics information, with potential applications in sensor fusion, fault detection, and low-cost navigation systems. This work is a first step for future research into vehicle driving scenarios identification and road condition monitoring using the same sensor configuration.

title: Stability-Aware and Computationally Efficient Energy Management in Microgrids Using Fuzzy Supervision
authors: Mohsen Nikanjam, Ali Sohrabi Bidar, Mohammad Kamran
abstract: The global energy transition has accelerated the adoption of renewable energy sources (RES) while creating new challenges for the stability, reliability, and cost-effectiveness of microgrids. To overcome these issues, this study proposes a hybrid two-layer Energy Management System (EMS). The deterministic layer ensures primary scheduling of resources while the fuzzy layer adaptively mitigates renewable and loads fluctuations to obtain stability of the microgrid. A 33-bus microgrid test case is used to evaluate the proposed approach under realistic operating conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that the fuzzy-supervisory EMS achieves significant improvements in frequency regulation, stability indices, and overall resiliency, while reducing operational costs compared to basecase. Moreover, the hybrid design offers computational efficiency which is suitable for real-time applications because it does not need several populations and iterations. The findings emphasize the potential of this framework for microgrid operations that are resilient, cost-efficient, and involve high utilization of renewable energies.

title: Convergence analysis of Federated Learning in a Stochastic Approximation Setting
authors: Srihari P V, Bharath Bhikkaji
abstract: This paper investigates Federated Learning (FL) within the framework of Stochastic Approximation (SA). FL is a decentralized approach to training machine learning models collaboratively across multiple clients, eliminating the need for centralized data storage. Each client updates a local model using its own data and periodically transmits the model parameters to a central server. The server aggregates these parameters and redistributes the aggregated model to the clients, who then continue training from the updated state. SA is an iterative optimization technique that employs noisy or approximate gradient estimates along with a diminishing step size to converge to a minimizer of a cost function. In the proposed approach, clients update their local model parameters using a stochastic approximation scheme. It is shown that the evolution of the aggregated model parameters closely follows the trajectory of an autonomous ordinary differential equation (ODE). Numerical experiments are conducted to evaluate the performance of the method, with comparisons made to baseline algorithms such as FedAvg and FedProx. The results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm exhibits enhanced robustness and yields more accurate parameter estimates.

title: Accurate is Not Necessarily the Best: Edge-Assisted Bitrate Re-adaptation for Video Streaming
authors: Wanxin Shi, Weijia Lang, Qing Li, Chao Wang, Gengbiao Shen, Lei Li, Yang Xu, Yong Jiang, Gabriel-Miro Muntean
abstract: The increasing volume of video traffic presents significant challenges to network transmission, while edge computing accelerates video delivery by leveraging caching and computation to optimize content forwarding. However, as edge computing is generally deployed by service providers in a transparent manner, clients cannot perceive edge states, e.g., cache availability, potentially resulting in suboptimal bitrate decisions. This issue persists even with intelligent bitrate selection approaches on the client side, as the inaccurate estimation of network delivery capacity due to edge cache transparency remains unresolved. Meanwhile, single-edge servers or nodes, with limited cache space and computational capacity for a small number of users, can be more effective by aggregating into clusters to better serve users and optimize resource utilization. Therefore, we propose an edge-assisted bitrate re-adaptation scheme (e-BitRead) for adaptive streaming, utilizing neighbor edges to accelerate video deliveries. e-BitRead introduces three key innovations: (i) it employs a bitrate re-adaptation mechanism that intelligently selects alternative bitrates from edge servers instead of strictly responding with the requested bitrate, (ii) it utilizes collaborative caching across multiple edge servers to expand available bitrate options through coordinated resource sharing, and (iii) it enhances the learning efficiency through joint optimization of network architecture and reward design, which leverages actor-critic structure to fit into multi-edge bitrate adaptation. In experiments with an intelligent client ABR, e-BitRead demonstrates its superiority by achieving a 1.43x higher hit ratio compared to the baseline, while improving QoE by 1.93x over the scheme without smart bitrate matching and delivering a 33% gain over the single-edge re-adaptation approach.

title: Set-Membership Estimation Based Distributed Cooperative Localization of Multiple UAVs
authors: Yu Ding, Xujie Qin, Yirui Cong, Xiangke Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: This paper investigates the distributed cooperative localization problem for mobile multi-UAV systems using set-membership estimation (SME). Unlike existing SME approaches relying on prior-known anchors or beacons, we consider a fully autonomous scenario where UAVs need to collaboratively derive guaranteed positional sets using only absolute measurements and relative range measurements from neighboring agents. To handle this problem, we first propose a law-of-total-range method to rigorously quantify the estimated sets from relative measurements, which fits the general form of relative measurements between pairwise UAVs. Based on this new method, a novel distributed SME framework is developed, where each UAV can obtain the guaranteed set containing its true state with only local measurements and communications. In addition, a distributed localization algorithm based on extended constrained zonotopes (ECZ) is designed with a proposed framework. Simulation results and field experiments verify that our proposed method efficiently improves the cooperative localization accuracy and outperforms the linearization-based extended SME method.

title:
Headsail: One-Year Tape-Out of a 25-mm
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Linux-Capable RISC-V MPSoC
authors: Matti Käyrä, Thomas Szymkowiak, Mohamed Soliman, Antti Rautakoura, Antti Nurmi, Kari Hepola, Henri Lunnikivi, Toni Jääskeläinen, Abdesattar Kalache, Petteri Toivanen, Roope Keskinen, Andreas Stergiopoulos, Väinö-Waltteri Granat, Arto Oinonen, Joonas Multanen, Pekka Jääskeläinen, Karri Palovuori, Timo D. Hämäläinen, Syed Mohsin Abbas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: The Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices feature a broad range of power, memory, and performance requirements. Ultralow-power, low-performance controllers are at one end of the spectrum, while high-performance, power-intensive systems-on-chip (SoCs) are at the other. Heterogeneous and specialized multiprocessor SoC (MPSoC) architectures have emerged as the most effective paradigm for delivering high performance and energy efficiency across a wide range of application workloads. This work introduces Headsail, an MPSoC application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) designed by SoC Hub at Tampere University, Finland. Headsail features a 512-KiB primary data buffer, 128 KiB of shared on-chip SRAM, seven CPU cores (including four CVA6 64-bit RISC-V processors), a low power-DDR2 (LP-DDR2) memory controller, two unique chip-to-chip (C2C) interfaces, and shared peripherals. Headsail has been successfully implemented using a TSMC 22-nm low-power CMOS technology. Testing results show that the samples can support a maximum operating frequency of 1 GHz and achieve a peak performance of 1100 giga operations per second (GOPS), with an implementation area of 25 mm2 and a power-consumption range of 64 mW–1.5 W.

title: Hybrid Granularity Distribution Estimation for Few-Shot Learning: Statistics Transfer from Categories and Instances
authors: Shuo Wang, Tianyu Qi, Xingyu Zhu, Yanbin Hao, Beier Zhu, Hanwang Zhang, Meng Wang
abstract: Distribution estimation is a pivotal strategy in few-shot learning (FSL) to mitigate data scarcity by sampling from estimated distributions, utilizing statistical properties (mean and variance) transferred from related base categories. However, category-level estimation alone often fails to generate representative samples due to significant dissimilarities between base and novel categories, leading to suboptimal performance. To address this limitation, we propose Hybrid Granularity Distribution Estimation (HGDE), which integrates both coarse-grained category-level statistics and fine-grained instance-level statistics. By leveraging instance statistics from the nearest base samples, HGDE enhances the characterization of novel categories, capturing subtle features that category-level estimation overlooks. These statistics are fused through linear interpolation to form a robust distribution for novel categories, ensuring both diversity and representativeness in generated samples. Additionally, HGDE employs refined estimation techniques, such as weighted summation for mean calculation and principal component retention for covariance, to further improve accuracy. Empirical evaluations on four FSL benchmarks, including Mini-ImageNet, Tiered-ImageNet, CUB and CIFAR-FS, demonstrate that HGDE offers effective distribution estimation capabilities and leads to notable accuracy gains, with improvements of more than 1.8% in 1-shot tasks on CUB. These results highlight HGDE’s ability to balance mean precision and variance diversity, making it a versatile and effective solution for FSL.

title: Efficient Multiscale Computation of Radar Cross Section for Large-Scale Chaff Clouds
authors: Zhenhua Song, Junhao Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Accurate and efficient Radar Cross Section (RCS) computation for chaff clouds is critical in electronic warfare. This task is challenging due to the massive scale of these clouds, complex element distributions, and intricate electromagnetic interactions, particularly mutual coupling and screening. This paper proposes the Multiscale Chaff Cloud RCS (MCC-RCS) method, a framework for computationally efficient RCS prediction of large-scale chaff clouds. It is specifically developed for clouds with arbitrary spatial but statistically uniform orientation distributions, while the underlying framework is extensible to other orientation models and bistatic scenarios. Its high computational speed and modest resource demands make it suitable for standard desktop computers, enabling rapid iterative computations such as echo simulation or chaff mixture optimization. The method employs a hierarchical multiscale strategy. At the microscale, it utilizes Einarsson’s formulation for the RCS of a single chaff dipole. The mesoscale implements a model combining mutual coupling with an intra-cell screening model. At the macroscale, an octree-based spatial decomposition provides efficient management and systematic accumulation of inter-cell screening. Numerical simulations demonstrate that MCC-RCS computes the monostatic RCS for clouds of up to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> elements within tens of seconds on a standard desktop with low memory usage, representing a significant speedup of several orders of magnitude compared against reported performance benchmarks for reference methods. The method shows good agreement with full-wave Method of Moments (MoM) for sparse distributions, and its accuracy for large-scale clouds is comparable to established Vector Radiative Transfer (VRT) methods, exhibiting physically consistent behavior. While high-fidelity solvers like Sparsification via Neglecting Far-field Coupling (S-NFC) offer superior accuracy, MCC-RCS provides a faster, less resource-intensive alternative, ideal for rapid large-scale assessments with a calibrated and acceptable trade-off between speed and accuracy.

title: Differential Braking-Assisted Emergency Steering Function for Semi-trailer Trucks
authors: Mertcan Sunuc, Berke Konca, Mert Sever, Melih Cakmakci
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Vehicular Electronics and Safety (ICVES)
abstract: Emergency steering maneuvers offer significant safety benefits by enabling the navigation of perilous traffic situations. Extensive research has been conducted to develop emergency maneuvering systems for passenger vehicles. However, performing evasive maneuvers with semi-trailer trucks presents unique challenges that limit their maneuvering capabilities, such as restrictions on the power steering system. This paper presents a unified control approach for automatic evasive maneuvering that integrates steering and differential braking. Differential braking, applied within conservative limits, is used to generate an additional yaw moment to complement the steering, thus enhancing the lateral dexterity of the vehicle. A jerk-optimal quintic polynomial path generation approach is adopted. For path tracking, a linear-quadratic controller (LQR) is employed. The proposed system is evaluated via simulations in MATLAB/Simulink. The simulation results show a significant improvement in evasive performance based on our assessment criteria, the Last Point to Brake (LPTB) and the Last Point to Steer (LPTS).

title: Maximum Mixture Correntropy Criterion-based Square-root Cubature Kalman Filter for High-accuracy Vehicle Sideslip Angle Estimation under Non-Gaussian Abnormal Noise
authors: Yanlin Jin, Yinong Li, Ling Zheng, Guangxuan Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Conference on Robotics, Automation and Intelligent Control (ICRAIC)
abstract: As a core parameter within vehicle stability control systems, the vehicle sideslip angle (VSA) significantly influences both maneuverability and operational safety. However, the prevailing assumption in current research is that measurement noise is Gaussian distributed. In reality, factors such as sensor degradation, measurement anomalies, and external disturbances often result in heavy-tailed, skewed, and time-varying non-Gaussian noise characteristics. Under such conditions, conventional filters tend to diverge, resulting in significant degradation of estimation accuracy. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes a square-root cubature Kalman filter enhanced with the maximum mixture correntropy criterion (MMCC-SCKF) to improve vehicle speed and VSA estimation under non-Gaussian noise conditions. The proposed method maps observation data into a high-dimensional feature space via kernel functions, emphasizing samples with small errors near the mean while assigning lower weights to outliers or samples with large errors far from the mean. This method reconstructs the measurement noise covariance matrix and efficiently mitigates the impact of non-Gaussian noise on system performance. The hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testing results under different road adhesion conditions demonstrate that the proposed algorithm maintains superior VSA estimation accuracy despite the presence of non-Gaussian noise. Specifically, compared to the SCKF algorithm, the proposed method reduces the RMSE of the VSA by 62.50% on high-adhesion roads and by 66.67% on low-adhesion roads. The outcomes demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves notable gains in estimation precision, robustness, and dependability.

title: Fields of Action of a Digital Engineering Transformation Framework
authors: Fabian Wyrwich, Malte Trienens, Aschot Hovemann, Roman Dumitrescu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: In the era of rapid technological advancement, Digital Engineering Transformation (DET) has become imperative for organizations seeking to maintain competitive advantage. This paper introduces a comprehensive framework that delineates the fields of actions in a Digital Engineering Transformation. Anchored in the strategic direction of the enterprise or product, the framework identifies four critical fields of action: product, processes & methods, IT-architecture, and organization. The activities on the product level focuses on the advancement and integration of digital development technologies which enhance the characteristics of the product directly. Processes and methods aim to optimize efficiency and innovation. The IT-architecture underpins scalability and flexibility, while the field of the organization emphasizes cultural and structural adaptation. Drawing on established theories and real-world case studies, this framework provides a structured approach to understand and implement a Digital Engineering Transformation. This paper aims to serve as a foundational reference for academics and practitioners navigating the complexities of Digital Engineering Transformation.

title: Data-Driven Weighting for Coastal Vulnerability Assessment in Small Island Developing States
authors: Deepak Ramsubhag, Letetia Addison, Deborah Villarroel-Lamb, Patrick Hosein
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Technology Management, Operations and Decisions (ICTMOD)
abstract: Coastal regions of Small Island Developing States (SIDS) face mounting risks from sea-level rise, storm surge, wave action and socio-economic pressure. Traditional vulnerability indices typically employ fixed, expert-defined weights for hazard and exposure layers, which may not adequately reflect local conditions, especially in SIDS where data scarcity and environmental variability are prevalent. This can lead to a misrepresentation of effectiveness of solutions for reducing vulnerability, particularly nature based ones that play a crucial role in these contexts. We propose a data-driven framework that leverages feature importance values derived from an XGBoost model to assign objective weights to geological and ecological features. The model was trained to predict significant wave height, and the resulting feature importance values illustrate a data-driven weighting approach that can enhance the design and refinement of coastal vulnerability indices. In addition, Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) values were also computed to gain deeper insights into the marginal contribution of each predictor and to validate the robustness of the feature importance results. This framework provides a way to capture the relative influence of key factors, improve the representation of nature-based solutions and support more informed adaptation planning in many countries especially SIDS.
